fields.headline: Wenger admits he wants Campbell
fields.standfirst: Arsenal move for Spurs captain but first things first with Bayern tonight
fields.trailText: Arsène Wenger added further spice to next month's FA Cup semi-final between Arsenal and Tottenham by admitting yesterday that he was interested in bringing Sol Campbell to Highbury in the summer.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger added further spice to next month's FA Cup semi-final between Arsenal and Tottenham by admitting yesterday that he was interested in bringing Sol Campbell to Highbury in the summer.

Campbell's contract at White Hart Lane expires at the end of the season, allowing him to leave on a free transfer under the Bosman ruling, and Wenger sees the 26-year-old as a figure around whom he could rebuild his defence.

"I personally believe Sol Campbell, if he was free, would interest the 20 clubs in the Premier League - I hope minus one in Tottenham," Wenger said. "Sol Campbell is a great player but he has said he will stay at Tottenham, so what can I do?"

Campbell has indicated he would be happy to stay at Spurs and is due to hold talks with the new owner. Wenger cannot approach him until the end of the season, though Campbell has been free to talk to foreign clubs since January 1, but he will hope to lure him with the offer of Champions League football.

"That's up to Sol Campbell to decide," Wenger said before flying to Munich for this evening's crucial Champions League game against Bayern, who are also keen to sign the England centre-back. "He said he would try to find an agreement with Tottenham and we have to respect that.

"At the moment I have other worries 24 hours ahead of a big game like this. I'm not on the phone to Sol Campbell today to see if he can get an agreement with Tottenham."

For the time being Wenger's thoughts are on Bayern. Arsenal must win to be sure of reaching the next round - a draw would suffice for Bayern - and failure to pick up three points will send them out if Lyon beat a Spartak Moscow side already eliminated.

Wenger said he would not ask for regular updates from Russia -"our tactics should not depend on their result" - but he was warned last night to pray for a favour from Spartak.

"I have no respect for Arsenal," said Bayern's Brazilian striker Elber. "They're not a great club. The only English team I respect is Manchester United. That is why we will score at least two goals."

Wenger's response was typically measured. "I cannot influence his words," he said, "but maybe the result will change his mind."

With Bayern undefeated at home in five Champions League games during which they have conceded only one goal, Arsenal face a tough task. Their topsy-turvy European campaign was encapsulated by a failure to hold a 2-0 lead against Bayern in December but Wenger sounds confident.

"It's a high-pressure game and I'm confident my players can cope with that," he said. "When it has mattered we have lost only one game in Europe since the beginning of the season, in Moscow. We have to try to take the game to them and try to score goals and win." Nwankwo Kanu is favourite over Sylvain Wiltord to partner Thierry Henry up front.

Although Bayern are top of the Bundesliga, the locals are not confident. They have been in poor form, beset by internal disputes after the 3-0 defeat at Lyon and are without their suspended captain Stefan Effenberg. Yet Wenger believes there is as much chance of Bayern turning out in lederhosen as there is of them showing signs of a crisis. "The Ger- mans are the Germans," he said.

Bayern Munich (possible, 4-2-1-3): Kahn; Kuffour, Andersson, Linke, Lizarazu; Fink, Jeremies; Scholl; Salihamidzic, Paulo Sergio, Elber.

Arsenal (possible, 4-4-2): Seaman; Dixon, Adams, Grimandi, Silvinho; Pires, Lauren, Vieira, Ljungberg; Kanu, Henry.

fields.headline: Elland Road to host England
fields.trailText: The announcement yesterday that Elland Road is to host its first England international in seven years, a friendly against Italy on March 27 next year, was well timed, coming as it did on the day the Italian champions arrived in West Yorkshire. However, the Lazio side who will face Leeds in tonight's final Champions League group game are likely to be missing many of their most famous names.
fields.body:
The announcement yesterday that Elland Road is to host its first England international in seven years, a friendly against Italy on March 27 next year, was well timed, coming as it did on the day the Italian champions arrived in West Yorkshire. However, the Lazio side who will face Leeds in tonight's final Champions League group game are likely to be missing many of their most famous names.

With little more than pride to play for, Dino Zoff's under-strength biancocelesti clearly had other things on their minds as they went through the motions of a light training session on the Leeds pitch, not least this weekend's Serie A skirmish with Juventus.

The list of Lazio absentees - Alessandro Nesta, Diego Simeone, Angelo Peruzzi, Dino Baggio, Juan Sebastian Veron and Simone Inzaghi among them - spoke volumes about how the Italians are approaching the match. "Yes, it will be a very depleted side," admitted Zoff. "But the group is finished, what have we to gain?"

Not that Leeds will mind too much. David O'Leary's side also have other concerns, not least Friday's quarter-final draw in Geneva. But amid the anticipation there is also a palpable air of misgiving. Galatasaray are also assured of their place in the final eight and if the Turkish side remain top of their group Leeds will have a one-in-four chance of meeting them.

Less than a year after two of their fans were killed in Istanbul, and with the trial yet to be concluded, it is a prospect they will not relish. "If we are drawn against Galatasaray it is something we will have to deal with," O'Leary said. "Knowing our luck we will probably get them, but until the draw is made I shouldn't say any more."

Nothing could detract, however, from the glow of satisfaction over Elland Road yesterday as it was chosen to host its first international since the days of Terry Venables.

"It is a great honour for Leeds," said the club secretary Ian Silvester. "This will give the people of Yorkshire the chance to see the national team playing on their own doorstep. We may well have two or three Leeds players involved and that would be an added bonus."

Leeds United (probable, 4-4-2): Robinson; Kelly, Ferdinand, Mills, Harte; Bakke, Batty, Dacourt, Kewell; Viduka, Smith.

Lazio (probable, 4-4-2): Marchegiani; Colonnese, Couto, Mihajlovic, Pesaresi; Lombardo, Stankovic, Berrettoni, Nedved; Lopez, Ravanelli.

webTitle: Foot and mouth becoming global problem

fields.headline: Foot and mouth becoming global problem
fields.standfirst:
 231 confirmed cases in Britain
 Outbreak in Argentina
 European meat bans
 Growing demands to delay UK elections

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.trailText:
 218 confirmed cases in Britain
 Outbreak in Argentina
 European meat bans
 Growing demands to delay UK elections

Special report: foot and mouth
fields.body:
The foot and mouth crisis which has assailed Britain was becoming a global problem today as an outbreak was confirmed in Argentina and the world increasingly shunned European meat.

The United States, Canada, Australia, New Zealand, Japan and South Korea have all moved to ban some agricultural imports from Europe, following the first continental confirmation of an outbreak in a rural corner of north-west France yesterday.

The European Union responded to the outbreak by ruling all exports of live animals from France will be banned, but many countries are taking more extreme precautionary measures against the disease.

Meanwhile, more suspected cases are being investigated in France as farmers slaughtered and burned affected livestock.

The outbreak in Argentina has put the country's £344m beef export sector at risk and sent shockwaves through the US farming community that the disease has reached the American continent.

In Britain, 26 new cases were confirmed today, bringing the national total to 231.

The scale of the crisis is already worse than the 1967 epidemic at the same stage, the chief veterinary officer, Jim Scudamore, said yesterday.

The government today repelled growing pressure from countryside leaders to delay elections as the foot and mouth crisis escalated.

Almost half the rural county councils affected by the disease have expressed their opposition to elections in May, because of the impact on campaigning, according to a survey.

The leaders of 10 of the 25 affected councils said the prime minister, Tony Blair, should delay the elections until June at the earliest, with only three saying he should press ahead, the Times newspaper found.

But the environment minister, Michael Meacher, who is heading the foot and mouth task force, said the government still intended to schedule local elections on May 3 unless the situation degenerated.

In Cornwall, the opening of the world's largest greenhouse, the £80m Eden project, will take place as planned this Saturday despite the present foot and mouth crisis gripping the countryside.

In the US, officials yesterday suspended all imports of livestock and fresh meat from the EU, and Canada slapped a similar ban on imports of livestock, farm products and even used farm equipment from the EU. A similar Canadian ban was already in place for Britain.

The ban is expected to have the biggest impact on imports of pork from the Netherlands and Denmark. Imports of beef from the EU were already banned because of mad cow disease.

However, EU officials expressed surprise that the US import ban extended to all 15 member countries. "Thirteen EU states are disease free. We have measures in place to keep it that way," said spokeswoman Maeve O'Beirne.

The EU estimated the US import restrictions would affect £344m worth of annual sales in meat and livestock.

webTitle: An oasis in a desert of failure and misery

fields.headline: An oasis in a desert of failure and misery
fields.standfirst: Your football questions answered every Wednesday. Email the.boss@guardian.co.uk and we'll do our best to help
fields.trailText: MY FAVOURITE YEAR
fields.body:
MY FAVOURITE YEAR

"In 1967, Nottingham Forest came very close to winning the league and Cup double, despite having no success in either competition a decade either side of this season. Is there another example of a club having a single, isolated season of brilliance in a lengthy period of relative mediocrity ?" asks Alan Sheridan

This one is just begging to be opened up to our readers, Alan. But we can think of a couple of recent - albeit obvious - examples to set the ball rolling.

In 1975-76, a QPR team containing the likes of Gerry Francis, Stan Bowles, John Hollins, Don Masson and Phil Parkes was pipped by a single point to the league championship by Liverpool, the Anfield side only denying the west London club by scoring with 13 minutes to go in their final match of the season against Wolves.

QPR, who had done nothing of note since winning the League Cup as a Third Division team in 1967, went on a downward spiral which culminated in their relegation three years later. OK, so they made the 1982 FA Cup final, but God those matches were tedious.

Or what about the 1985-86 West Ham United side, who slipped a free-scoring Frank McAvennie into their previously mid-table team while no-one was looking - TV blackout, y'see - and missed out on the league title by four points, mainly thanks to the effects of a hectic fixture pile-up on their young and threadbare squad?

We also nominate the Chelsea side of 1954-55, whose league title came amidst a total dearth of success and a superabundance of uselessness. They couldn't even build on their championship win when a young and hungry Jimmy Greaves forced his way into the team, for goodness' sake.

But surely there are more examples of one-season wonders. So please send them in. Please.

HAVE BOOTS, WILL TRAVEL

"Can someone tell me who has played for the most professional clubs during a season or career?" asked Derek Tomkin.

"As memory serves me, a player called Frank Large racked up about 13 clubs in the late 60s and early 70s including Northampton Town, Chesterfield, Fulham, and Leicester City," offers Gerard Sugrue. "I think that he had a couple of spells with some of the clubs in the list. Sorry, I can't be more specific but it's a start."

Well, we reckon that between June 1959 and May 1974, Frank played for Halifax Town, QPR, Northampton Town, Swindon Town, Carlisle United, Oldham Athletic, Northampton Town, Leicester City, Fulham, Northampton Town and Chesterfield; a total of nine clubs (eleven if you count his three stints at the County Ground separately).

Which is some total. However, Frank can't hold a candle to John 'Budgie' Burridge, as Peer Lawther explains:

"In a career spanning 26 years he was transferred or loaned 28 times to 26 different clubs (3 non-league, 4 Scottish and the rest English league clubs). He has amassed a total (and a mileage) that no sane person could ever hope to better.

"They are (deep breath): Workington, Blackpool, Aston Villa, Crystal Palace, QPR, Wolves, Derby, Sheffield United, Southampton, Hibernian, Newcastle United (twice), Lincoln, Aberdeen, Dumbarton, Falkirk, Manchester City, Notts County, Witton Albion, Darlington, Grimsby, Gateshead, Northampton, Queen of the South, Scarborough and finally Blyth Spartans (twice).

"However, watch out for young Stuart Elliott, who has just transferred from Darlington to Plymouth. He's only 23 but has been at 12 clubs already (and played senior games for 10 of them). He'll certainly be pushing John Burridge in a few years time."

For the record, Argyle defender Elliott has previously played for Newcastle United, Hull City, Swindon Town, Gillingham, Hartlepool United, Wrexham, Bournemouth, Stockport County and Darlington. We're keeping our eyes on what this bloke's up to, don't you worry.

BIKES AND TRAINS (BUT NO BOATS OR PLANES)

"I'm interested in English soccer between the wars and I was wondering if you could tell me how the teams travelled in those times. Was it all by train or also by bus? Did the stars like Hughie Gallacher and Dixie Dean made enough money to buy their own motor car?" asks Frédéric Charvigny.

As far as we know, Frédéric, players like Dean and Gallacher travelled to and from matches on public transport. Certainly, in the days before the maximum wage, they weren't paid the sort of sums which allowed them to purchase top-of-the-range vehicles, so unless players came from a seriously well-to-do background, it was onto the bus or train for them.

Indeed, Dean's eventual replacement at Goodison, the England international Tommy Lawton, often told stories of how Evertonians (and fellow tram passengers) would wish him well on the way to matches - while telling him he'd "never be as good as Dixie". ("Well, that's charming," was Lawton's response.)

Coincidentally, motor vehicles and trains played a big part in the lives of the two players you mention. Dean broke his skull and jaw coming off a motorbike in 1926, injuries which were thought at the time to have ended the 19-year-old's career almost before it had begun. He was unconscious for 36 hours and had to have a metal plate inserted into his head, but soon enough, he was up and about, scoring 60 goals in the 1927-28 season.

Gallacher's case was altogether more tragic. The Scottish forward, whose goals led Newcastle to the title in 1926-27, was sold to Chelsea against his will in 1930, and some say he was never the same again. He eventually returned to Tyneside to play for Gateshead, but booze and personal problems took a hold. And in 1957, having been accused of mistreating his son, Gallacher visited the tracks near his house and threw himself in front of the York to Edinburgh express train.

PHIL NEVILLE? PAH!

"Does anyone know who has the highest ratio of international caps to league appearances? Surely Phil 'overachiever' Neville is a prime candidate?" asked Chris Field

"This is not a full answer," writes Stephen Pepper, "but I believe Liverpool winger Steve Heighway represented the Republic of Ireland as a full international before he had made any league appearances at all.

"That made his ratio, for a while, infinite!"

CAN YOU HELP?

"Which sport originated the term hat-trick?" asks Harry Gottlieb.

"Who were the first Australians to play in the top flight in Britain?" asks Robert Lawton.

"Why don't more teams play in either black, green, maroon or purple? What is the history behind most teams playing in either blue, red or white?" asks Paul Kilgour

Your football questions are answered every Wednesday. Email the.boss@theguardian.com and we'll do our best to help.

"That made his ratio, for a while, infinite!" CAN YOU HELP? "Which sport originated the term hat-trick?" asks Harry Gottlieb. webTitle: Local elections remain uncertain, despite Blair's assurances

fields.headline: Local elections remain uncertain, despite Blair's assurances
fields.trailText: Ministers have refused to rule out delaying this year's county council elections if the foot and mouth crisis continues to worsen, despite assurances from the prime minister that there are no plans to change the May 3 date.
fields.body:
Ministers have refused to rule out delaying this year's county council elections if the foot and mouth crisis continues to worsen, despite assurances from the prime minister that there are no plans to change the May 3 date.

Speculation that the government would be forced to postpone the local polls has been building since the end of February, when agriculture minister Nick Brown told canvassers they should stay away from farms.

Some councillors argue that the movement restrictions intended to halt the spread of the disease will make it difficult to effectively campaign and could stop rural voters reaching polling stations.

The prime minister's official spokesman today said the elections were fixed for May, and there were no plans to delay or postpone them.

But environment minister Michael Meacher, head of the government's foot and mouth taskforce, admitted it might be forced to reconsider: "It depends on the future course of the outbreak as to whether we are peaking at this stage or whether it is going to get worse. At the moment, the intention is to continue with the local elections on May 3," he said.

Tony Blair's resistance to any delay comes despite pressure from county council leaders.

Devon's Brian Greenslade has already asked the government if his county can hold its election by all-postal ballot: "If [foot and mouth] is going to rage on the way it has been raging on over this weekend, and now this week, there must be a question over whether the election should go ahead at all."

Senior Labour figures are arguing that postal voting means no one need lose their vote. Local government association chairman Sir Jeremy Beecham and Northumberland leader Michael Davey are among those who believe this makes any delay unnecessary.

The party's local government unit is also urging councillors to make the most of postal voting, and has advised Labour opposition groups to pass resolutions calling on their authority to provide registration forms to all residents.

Nationally, the Conservatives say they hope the May elections will go ahead, but that the government should keep the option of delay open and continue monitoring the spread of foot and mouth.

webTitle: In brief: Hollywood stars nominated for gay awards

fields.headline: Hollywood stars nominated for gay awards
fields.standfirst: Plus: Spielberg extends Close Encounters on DVD; Eminem's autobiographical film debut; Bowie's ex-wife plans kiss-and-tell film
fields.trailText: Plus: Spielberg extends Close Encounters on DVD; Eminem's autobiographical film debut; Bowie's ex-wife plans kiss-and-tell film
fields.body:
 Johnny Depp and Robert Downey Jr are among a host of stars nominated for the first Gay and Lesbian Outfest Screen Idol Awards to be held in California. The organisers of the event have nominated Depp and co-star Javier Bardem for their roles in Before Night Falls, a film about gay poet and novelist, Reinaldo Arenas, Robert Downey Jr for his role as Terry Crabtree in Wonder Boys and Stuart Wells for Billy Elliot. Actresses Ellen DeGeneres, Chloe Sevigny and Vanessa Redgrave were nominated for If These Walls Could Talk 2, Julianna Margulies for What's Cooking and Maria Schrader for Aimee & Jaguar. Winners will be selected by a national vote online which will run from today until 15 April and the results will be declared on 20 April.

 Just three years after releasing a third cut of the classic Close Encounters of the Third Kind, director Steven Spielberg is planning a collector's edition DVD. Spielberg has already recut and released the legendary 1977 film in 1980 and in 1998 but the new DVD edition will apparently feature eleven deleted scenes plus a 100-minute documentary in which Spielberg discusses offering the film's lead role to Steve McQueen.

 Controversial rap-star Eminem's mother and his estranged wife Kim are to be the subjects of his film debut he admitted today. The Slim Shady star has revealed that the film he recently signed up for will be based on his life."It's definitely gonna reflect my life, although the whole story won't be exactly like my life," he told reporters. Brian Grazer, who is producing the project, believes that the singer shows the same acting potential as former pop star Mark Wahlberg. "I think Em has a very fluid quality in the same way Mark does, and he's extremely charismatic."

 Angie Barnett, who divorced David Bowie in 1980, is planning to make a kiss-and-tell film about their turbulent 10-year relationship. Courtney Love is rumoured to be playing Angie in the film with a Hollywood newcomer likely to take the role of Bowie. The singer and actor, who is now married to supermodel Iman, is reported to be opposed to the project which will feature scenes of bisexuality and sexual and drug excess.

webTitle: Comment: We can use the Human Rights Act against these politicians

fields.headline: One law for the rich, quite another for the rest of us
fields.standfirst: We can use the Human Rights Act against these politicians
fields.trailText: March 14: We can use the Human Rights Act against these politicians, writes Jonathan Freedland.
fields.body:
Apparently all is well. The custodians of our civic good health have conducted a thorough examination and found nothing untoward. We are in the clear.

Sir Anthony Hammond was first to give the good news. He methodically prodded and poked into the cash-for-passports affair, before declaring happily that he had found nothing "improper". Peter Mandelson, Keith Vaz and their numerous officials were guilty of no wrong- doing; their relationships with the Hinduja brothers were perfectly sound.

On Monday the House of Commons sleazebusting committee of MPs issued another set of exonerations, this time not quite as complete. Their probe into the earlier affairs of Mr Vaz cleared him of nine charges, finding him guilty on only one: failing to declare that a man he had nominated for inclusion in the honours' list just so happened to be a contributor to his own constituency fund. Still, that was not too serious, certainly not worthy of any punishment. The committee decided no action was necessary.

And there has been an equally cheery verdict on the weekend reports that Downing Street intervened in a controversial planning application by the billionaire arms broker, Wafic Said. Sure, an official memo spoke of "pressure from the prime minister's office not to delay the decision" on Said's plan to build a business school on the site of a much-loved old railway station in Oxford. But that means nothing. Number 10 insists it was merely concerned with the timing of the decision, not the decision itself. Once again, everybody behaved perfectly properly.

So given this rash of good news - confirming our public officials' complete probity and propriety - why do we feel so bad? Why is this sequence of denials, rebuttals and exonerations not good enough? If the rules say nothing wrong happened, why doesn't it feel quite right?

The answer is common sense. Forget what the reports and inquiries say; these cases are all versions of the same, all-too-familiar story: someone, somewhere got special treatment because they have money.

Hammond confirms it. Even as he insists there was no wrongdoing, he provides chapter and verse on the extraordinary efforts made in pursuit of the Hindujas' applications for British citizenship. Their forms weren't processed by some overworked staffer in the passport office - they were championed by the head of the immigration and nationality directorate himself. The rules were bent, too, so that SP Hinduja got his passport in a quarter of the normal time, even though he clearly did not meet the usual residency requirements. Watching over it all were a choir of guardian angels, from Margaret Thatcher and Edward Heath to Peter Mandelson and Jack Straw, all doing their bit to make sure the Hindujas' request was dealt with "helpfully".

Hammond accepts all this as perfectly proper, but we don't have to. We know what it amounts to: special treatment for the wealthy. Just as we knew it when Tony Blair exempted Formula One from the ban on tobacco advertising after Bernie Ecclestone gave £1m to the Labour party. We knew it when the Tories bagged a peerage for Michael Ashcroft soon after he gave the party so much money he became their treasurer. The officials may tell us everything is "proper"; but all that proves is their definition of "proper" is wrong - and we ought to get a new one.

But how? How can we stop money talking? The default response is to demand that politicians stay well clear of millionaires, by freeing them of the need to raise cash in the first place. Then Blair and William Hague wouldn't have to grovel to the likes of Ecclestone and Ashcroft. The state could fund political parties and all would be well.

Wrong. Even if state funding did not contain risks of its own - like squeezing out new movements by denying them funds - it would not solve the problem. After all, the Hindujas were not offering money to the Labour party, but to the dome. State funding would not have kept Mandelson, Blair and Straw away from them.

Accepting the presence of money in politics, but regulating it, seems the next best step. But that's what the MPs who just cleared Vaz are meant to do - and just look how ineffective they are. They had to give up on eight additional charges against the minister because he refused to cooperate with their inquiries. They were powerless to resist.

No, we need a new, more radical solution to the problem. And we may find it in, of all places, the law.

For what is the real offence in the Hinduja case, or episodes like it? Surely it's the clear evidence that there's one rule for the rich and another for everyone else. It is a violation of our deep belief that everyone should be equal under the law. That can be more than a sentimental hope. In the United States, the 14th amendment's insistence on "equal protection of the laws" has formed the basis for countless civil rights actions demanding fairness and an end to discrimination. It was that clause which underpinned 1954's legendary Brown v Board of Education decision, ending the racial segregation of America's schools. It has been invoked regularly ever since, with Americans petitioning their courts to outlaw preferential treatment for one group of individuals over another.

That option is now open to us. Under a happy coincidence, we have a 14th amendment of our own: article 14 of the European Convention on Human Rights, now absorbed into British law as the Human Rights Act. That article bars discrimination on grounds of sex, race, colour and "any other status." That "other status" could be wealth.

Put simply, there is nothing to stop two, hypothetical Patel brothers petitioning the courts to demand why the passport request they made for their third brother was not treated as swiftly as Prakash Hinduja's. A Wafic Smith could complain that the decision on his planning project was not announced as swiftly as Wafic Said's. Bernie Bloggs could claim discrimination denied him the policy exemption that so pleased Bernie Ecclestone.

Such scenarios need not be fanciful. Leading human rights lawyer Keir Starmer says: "The whole point of the Human Rights Act is to give protection against discrimination - and discrimination against those with less money could come within the prohibitions set out in article 14." As long as you amassed the evidence and could prove that, say, the Patels and the Hindujas were genuinely comparable in every other respect bar riches, Starmer reckons you could make a serious challenge under the act. At the very least, it would force the discriminating authority to explain why they favoured one set of individuals over another.

The experts always told us this new law would make a big difference. In the US the bill of rights has long been used to advance civil rights, from abortion to women's status at work, that were too hot for the politicians to handle. Now it can be our turn. For those of us who are sick of the fast track and special favours granted to the rich, politicians are now too much the problem to be the solution. It may be time to go to court.

webTitle: Doomed beasts of Toryism await the cull

fields.headline: Doomed beasts of Toryism await the cull
fields.trailText: Toryism is in crisis. Every day brings more grim news from round the country. The unspoken fear is that the entire Tory party may have to be eradicated just to end this dreadful crisis.
fields.body:
I love New Labour jargon. The point is that nobody who uses it actually listens to it. So yesterday during health questions Yvette Cooper, a junior minister, solemnly announced: "We are rolling out free fruit in primary schools."

Minutes later, Patrick Nicholls, the Tory MP for Teignbridge, rose superbly from his seat. He was clad in an aggressive chalk stripe suit (the stripe goes all the way through him, or so one of his colleagues assures me.) He wanted to talk about the threat to the British holiday trade caused by the foot and mouth crisis. Sadly, something went wrong.

"In view," he said, "of the massive damage caused to the Toryism industry -"

So that's the problem. That's what's going on! Toryism is in crisis. Every day brings more grim news from round the country. Party membership now lower than at any time since the first world war. William Hague's poll ratings worse than Nero's! There is near panic on the continent, where rightwing leaders are terri fied that the infection will spread across the Channel.

Tory agents are in tears. For decades many of them have built up superb grazing herds of party members. Admittedly these were hardly breeding herds - the average age is about 67 - but they were fine, pure-bred, bull-headed animals, bright-eyed, glossy-skinned, and festooned with blue best of show rosettes.

Now, amid the hopes and dreams which lie shattered in the mud, they are marked for the abattoir and the incinerator. Do these huge but docile beasts realise the fate that is in store? Or will they rattle down country lanes to the polls, perhaps only dimly perceiving what waits for them at the very end?

Possibly the army will be called out. Marksmen will halt the spread of the illness by killing Tories one by one in the fields. They'll have to aim high, since those tweed suits are thought to be bullet-proof.

Some have miraculously survived. Sir Edward Heath, Old Teddy, stomped slowly into the Chamber as if across a sodden meadow. He had a bewildered look, perhaps asking "where am I? What is this place? Shouldn't someone put me out of my misery?" He flumped down on the green bench, like an old bull in his favourite field, and then fell fast asleep.

A few young Tory rams tried to justify their continued existence. John Redwood wanted to know why Keith Vaz had been declared innocent, when the report into his conduct merely records that he had refused to provide information about his conduct. This is like a man on a criminal charge being acquitted simply because he refuses to say where he was at the time. But special rules seem to apply to politicians.

My Tory chum received an urgent message on his bleeper saying that Michael Portillo was about to speak on the Budget, and would MPs be good enough to go to the chamber and listen?

There was but a sprinkling of Tories there to hear their possible next leader. These included some of the party's noisiest barrack room lawyers - Michael Fabricant and John Bercow for two - who were once advised by a party elder, "remember to throw the grenade, and not the pin".

But there were few others. As Mr Portillo rose, just 13 backbenchers out of the 165 Tory MPs were there to listen to him.

After a quarter of an hour, the figure had rocketed to 17 backbenchers. It was a good, scornful speech, and caused Gordon Brown to look extremely grumpy.

But almost nobody was there. Had the cull begun? The unspoken fear is that the entire Tory party may have to be eradicated just to end this dreadful crisis.

webTitle: Blair may be forced to delay May election

fields.headline: Blair may be forced to delay May election
fields.standfirst:
Ministers fear rural backlash if polling goes ahead while countryside in chaos

Special report: election countdown

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
Labour face election injuction
fields.trailText: Ministers were yesterday seriously starting to consider delaying the election set for May 3 in the wake of the spread and persistence of foot and mouth disease.
fields.body:
Ministers were yesterday seriously starting to consider delaying the election set for May 3 in the wake of the spread and persistence of foot and mouth disease.

Cabinet members and party strategists were anxiously looking in their diaries for possible booby traps and disasters that might await them if they put off the election until the autumn.

No prime minister likes to get knocked off a preferred election date, let alone be at the mercy of a disease that no one seems to be able to control. But the danger for Tony Blair is that if he presses ahead with the election, as well as the 34 county council polls, it would be viewed as another sign that Labour does not care for the countryside. Even worse, it could deteriorate into a slanging match about whether or not the election is being conducted freely and fairly in rural constituencies.

Labour's local goverment chief, Sir Jeremy Beecham, protested: "This is a non issue. Anyone can apply for a postal vote and post is being delivered to outer reaches of farms. The Tories do not have any door to door canvassers. They do it by phone" But some ministers, including those in agriculture, fear that Labour could be hit by cries of "fix". Rural seats are, after all, still overwhelmingly Conservative.

Unless the prime minister can hold a postponed election in June, he will probably have to delay it until October, or even later.

The Conservatives, given their current poll standing, are desperate for a delay, but cannot say so publicly. "Things can only get better for them," one minister said yesterday.

There are some unwelcome events between now and the autumn that might make the electorate look at Labour in a more jaundiced light. The single biggest factor is the world economy.

At present, the British economy could not be in a better position. Inflation is consistently undershooting its 2.5% target. Interest rates are likely to fall further. Unemployment is set to dip below 1m today for the first time in 25 years.

Mr Blair will mark the moment with an employment green paper promising £120m in measures to target the jobless who are not claiming the job seekers' allowance. He will hold out the prospect of a return to full employment. However, there are storm clouds gathering, with US shares falling fast in the wake of corporate profit warnings, especially high technology stocks. In Japan, the Nikkei 225 stock index fell by 3.6% yesterday to its lowest level since April 1985. The EU's economy has also been slowing in the past five months.

The already-tricky timetable for handling the euro-referendum would also be complicated by an election delay.

Not all the factors work against postponment. The home secretary, Jack Straw, will be under less pressure as police numbers continue to rise slowly, judging by the figures for the numbers of police in training. He might also be able to claim the government is getting closer to meeting its target of halving the amount of time it takes for young offenders to be sentenced.

At health, Alan Milburn, the heath secretary, might welcome delay. NHS waiting lists go up over winter and drop through the summer and early autumn. If the election is held in October, Labour would be able to say it has more than met its target to cut 100,000 from the inherited waiting list.

John Prescott's marathon tussle with London's mayor, Ken Livingstone, and Bob Kiley over control of the scheme for modernising the London Underground is also awkwardly timed for a spring poll. With commuters iincreasingly frustrated by erratic trains and tubes, more time might mean progress.

Downing Street and Millbank publicly remain determined to push ahead with the May 3 timetable - despite growing concern among rural MPs in all parties. If so, parliament would have to clear up its business by April 5 to comply with election law.

There are two jokers in the pack. The government has missed the deadline for delaying the county council elections in the 34 county councils in England. Mr Straw would need to make pass primary legislation to delay the council elections, probably with all-party support. In theory the legislation need not be passed until days before the council elections, but in reality - to ensure pointless canvassing did not go ahead - it would have to be passed earlier.

The second joker is the census, due to take place on April 29 and requiring an army of government enumerators to knock on the nation's front door. The office of national statistics said yeserday it was "monitoring the situation and preparing continegency plans for areas where there are restrictions on movement".

fields.headline: Crisis now worse than in 1967
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
 Total number of outbreaks reaches 205
 France identifies first case
 US bans all animal imports from EU
fields.trailText: The scale of the foot and mouth outbreak is already far worse than the 1967 epidemic at the same stage, covering much larger areas of the country and condemning many more animals to be slaughtered, Jim Scudamore, the government's chief veterinary surgeon, said yesterday.
fields.body:
The scale of the foot and mouth outbreak is already far worse than the 1967 epidemic at the same stage, covering much larger areas of the country and condemning many more animals to be slaughtered, Jim Scudamore, the government's chief veterinary surgeon, said yesterday.

Twenty-two new cases were confirmed yesterday, bringing the total to 205. France confirmed its first outbreak and EU vets banned all livestock exports from the country for a fortnight.

The dramatic increase in the scale of the problem in the last few days has upset all hopes of an early end to the crisis and the government is now seriously considering delaying the general election beyond May.

The disease has been randomly spread over the country by sheep dealers, Mr Scudamore said. Many movements were untraceable and there were unknown numbers of animals incubating the disease.

In 1967, there was only one centre of the disease, on the Welsh border with Shropshire. Now there are three large areas where the outbreaks are both intensifying and spreading across neighbouring farms.

Although the number of farms where foot and mouth has been confirmed is fewer than at the same stage of the 1967 epidemic, the scale of modern farms means much bigger numbers of animals are in contact with the disease. Farms are six times as big as the average holding in 1967 and many have more than 1,000 animals, compared with an average of 100 then.

The large-scale slaughter being carried out daily to try to contain the disease is causing logistical problems in the disposal of carcasses: instead of burying small herds or flocks on farms as happened in 1967, dead animals are having to be burned or rendered, both far more difficult to organise.

In the first three weeks of the present outbreak, 170,000 animals had been earmarked for slaughter on 333 premises, compared with 430,000 animals on 2,300 farms in the six months of the 1967 outbreak, Mr Scudamore said.

Yesterday, for example, at William Davidson's farm at Poldean Wamphrey, Moffat, in Dumfries, 483 cattle and 1,612 sheep were condemned in one new outbreak.

The average number of animals to be slaughtered per confirmed case has risen from fewer than 200 in 1967 to more than 600 this time.

The sheer size of the flocks being condemned seems to have initially masked the seriousness of the outbreak. A few sick sheep in 1,000 would not be noticed. A second or third wave of infection is breaking out before enough animals became ill for the farmer to notice.

Mr Brown, the agriculture minister, said: "We did what we could right at the beginning. We put movement restrictions on as quickly as possible but it had already got out into the national flock and is still incubating.

"It is a very serious situation; we do not know where it will emerge and we do not know how much of it there is. We are not able to make any judgments at all about when it will peak."

Mr Scudamore added: "Once we reach a peak we can begin to estimate how long it will take to go down, how long the tail will be. It could be a very long tail."

Jim Walker, president of the Scottish National Farmers' Union said after meeting Tony Blair yesterday: "It is time for pre-emptive action to take possible carriers out of the system. While such steps will bring further heartache to farmers, there is little doubt that we are dealing with a disease that is crippling our industry."

Yesterday a task force was set up under Michael Meacher, the environment minister, to try to help beleaguered rural industries heavily dependent on the tourist trade, which is collapsing in affected areas. The government is discussing compensation, including not paying business rates, to stave off a wave of bankruptcies. Rural tourism supports 380,000 jobs in England alone.

Emergency measures will be announced in the next 48 hours to try to rescue half a million sheep forced to give birth to lambs away from the shelter of home farms and stranded in open fields because of movement restrictions.Mr Brown is reluctant to destroy healthy flocks but nervous about allowing movements which could spread infection. The army might be used as escorts.

The idea of using army snipers to kill farm animals has been discussed by ministers but will only be used as a last resort. While troops are trained to use guns, they know nothing of humane slaughter of animals.

Among yesterday's new cases, the three areas which were of most concern were a large area of the north including Northumberland, Cumbria and Dumfries and Galloway, the central border area of Wales, where Powys was becoming an increasing problem, and Devon where the disease had centred on the sheep dealer Willy Cleave's 13 farms and spread. It is these areas where there are large concentrations of sheep.

"Potentially, in these three areas we have a very serious problem indeed," Mr Scudamore said.

fields.headline: Arts industry worth £100bn
fields.trailText: The government said yesterday Britain's artistic industries were contributing more than ever to the economy, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The Cool Britannia tag may have been quietly dropped, but the government yesterday said that Britain's artistic industries were contributing more than ever to the economy.

Britain's creative sector, including music, design and advertising, generates more than £100bn a year and employs more than 1m people, according to an audit published by the secretary of state for culture, Chris Smith. The fastest growing areas are computers, film and television, where revenue and employment is flourishing. Overall, the industries account for 5% of gross domestic product.

But there were warnings that the artistic industries needed strong government support, because of their volatile nature. The British film industry has particular problems: the distribution system is dominated by US conglomerates, and more British films than ever are lying unreleased.

The figures were revealed in a government audit providing a comprehensive picture of the sector. It is the second time such a document has been compiled; in 1998, the industries were found to have generated £57.5bn.

Mr Smith said that the creative industries had to be supported by government as their contributions to the economy increased. "Creativity is not a luxury add-on, but an essential ingredient for economic success," he told an industry audience in London yesterday.

The industries now generate £112.5bn of revenue, while exports are worth £10.3bn. They employ 1.3m people and account for more than 5% of GDP. The biggest sector is software and computing services, which is worth £2.75bn.

Mr Smith said: "The work of our creative industries is all around us, in the shoes and clothes we wear, the buildings we live and work in, the computer software we use for business and pleasure, the music we listen to, the books and TV programmes we enjoy."

He said the figures provided further evidence that creative industries had moved from the "fringes to the centre stage".

The broadcaster Jon Snow, who introduced the launch at Channel 4's headquarters in London, said the importance of the creative industries made it essential to retain the Department of culture. There had been speculation - denied by Mr Smith - that the department would be split up after the election.

Dick Powell, the designer involved in the creation of the Bioform bra, said the industry had benefited from a favourable economic climate, but was vulnerable to volatility. Digital design was "crashing and burning" at the moment, he said.

Mr Smith also announced an initiative - the creative industries' higher education forum - to address the demand for high quality training in the artistic sectors.

Software and computers

 Revenue £36.4bn

 Employs 555,000

 Exports £2.8bn

Britain is biggest IT market in Europe after Germany, but lack of certain skills will remain a barrier to growth. Some 90% of businesses use internet.

Design

 Revenue £26.7bn

 Employs 76,000

 Exports £1bn

UK seen as a world leader in all design disciplines. Consultancies, such as Dick Powell's, generate the export earnings. But there are concerns about quality of recent graduates.

Publishing

 Revenue £18.5bn

 Employs 141,000

 Exports £1.7bn

Book sales increased by 10% in1999, and 80% of adults read a magazine. But copyright is problematic, with concern at speed of mergers and lack of certain skills.

TV and radio

 Revenue £12.1bn

 Employs 102,000

 Exports £440m

Britain's TV industry is dynamic, with satellite and cable audiences increasing. Broadcasters are using internet but sector is in rapid change.

Music

 Revenue £4.6bn

 Employs 122,000

 Exports £1.3bn

UK was the world's third biggest recorded music market in 1999, but the internet poses problems for copyright, and internet piracy is spreading.

fields.headline: My sit-in against the dictators
fields.standfirst:
Ann Widdecombe is facing possible Commons censure after trying to disrupt committee sessions on a guillotined bill

Special report: Tories in opposition

Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: Ann Widdecombe is facing possible Commons censure after trying to disrupt committee sessions on a guillotined bill.
fields.body:
I first suspected the totalitarian instincts of this government during the visit of Jiang Zemin, the Chinese president. Peaceful demonstrators protesting about the treatment of Tibet had their banners and flags snatched by the police, a practice completely alien to the British concept of free speech.

There was of course an earlier indication of this government's contempt of parliament itself when the prime minister decided to come and answer questions in the House only once a week instead of the time honoured twice, without even so much as consulting the Speaker.

Ministers announced new policy to the press rather than parliament, the prime minister avoided the House of Commons as much as possible and he has spoken in less than one third of the number of debates than any post-war prime minister before him.

The most recent example of ministerial arrogance towards parliament was when Nick Brown said "I do not welcome an urgent debate. It will divert ministerial resources ..." In other words parliament must not debate national emergencies such as foot and mouth.

Most shockingly of all, we are governed by whole tranches of law which have never so much as been debated, let alone on which there has been a vote. All governments occasionally use the guillotine, by which bills are timetabled to finish at a certain time, but only this government has used them as a matter of course, regardless of how well the bill is progressing, regardless of whether it is even opposed in principle and only this government has rou tinely cut short the committee stage of bills, which is, of course, where all the serious examination takes place. There were more guillotines in the first three years of this government than in the last six of ours - even before they decided to make the practice routine. Between 1979 and 1997 the guillotine was used on average less than three times a year. Labour has trebled that rate.

Thus provisions affecting freedom of information, the conduct of referendums, electoral law, policing in Northern Ireland, members of the Dail sitting at Westminster - and even the protection of areas of out-standing natural beauty - are now the law of the land without ever having been discussed by MPs. Most recently 522 out of 666 amendments were not debated when a guillotine fell.

Then along came the criminal justice and police bill, including provisions to retain the DNA of unconvicted people, to widen the ability of the police to inspect individuals' tax records and to impose fixed penalty fines for criminal behaviour. We did not oppose the bill but we did want to alter parts of it to, for example, make sure that a fine on the spot did not remove a victim's right to compensation and to protect civil liberties.

Despite our helpful attitude a government guillotine meant we arrived at the last day of committee with 56 clauses, six schedules, 42 opposition amendments and 10 government ones still to be debated and only a few hours left. Worse, the government had promised us 16 sessions but then quite arbitrarily and without consulting parliament cut that to 14 sessions. A bill of this size would normally take about 20 sessions.

There had been no filibustering. At one point David Lock, a Labour minister, accused us of stringing out proceedings on clause seven. The chairman himself stamped on that, by saying that in his view there had been no untoward or over-lengthy debate and that the committee was dealing with intricate issues. His Labour co-chairman agreed.

Now Labour has decided to drop clause seven altogether as it was too "confusing". Suppose we had never debated it? Suppose we had only done so briefly? Suppose we had failed to produce the arguments, which so wearied Mr Lock and his colleagues? The result would have been confusing legislation. Scrutiny is our solemn duty.

There is a great deal of law to which we have not been allowed to apply that duty. So we decided quite simply that the committee would not finish at seven o'clock on Thursday with so much undiscussed and therefore we used the only technique available to make sure it did not finish. At ten to seven I and three whips entered the committee room and quietly sat in the seats reserved for committee members. Parliamentary procedure and precedent specifies that this puts the committee out of order and does not allow it to proceed. That should have meant the committee would have to meet again on another day and we had hoped it might then have been granted a few more hours of debate.

We should have known better. The government instead tabled a motion "deeming" the committee to have completed its passage. I mock you not. That is what they are doing - without so much as a blush.

Yet was it not Jack Straw who said in opposition, when he was doing the job I am doing now, "careful scrutiny is one of the best guarantors of good legislation"?

This government is profoundly undemocratic and contemptuously dictatorial.

 Ann Widdecombe is shadow home secretary.

Ministers announced new policy to the press rather than parliament, the prime minister avoided the House of Commons as much as possible and he has spoken in less than one third of the number of debates than any post-war prime minister before him. The most recent example of ministerial arrogance towards parliament was when Nick Brown said "I do not welcome an urgent debate. It will divert ministerial resources ..." In other words parliament must not debate national emergencies such as foot and mouth. Most shockingly of all, we are governed by whole tranches of law which have never so much as been debated, let alone on which there has been a vote. All governments occasionally use the guillotine, by which bills are timetabled to finish at a certain time, but only this government has used them as a matter of course, regardless of how well the bill is progressing, regardless of whether it is even opposed in principle and only this government has rou tinely cut short the committee stage of bills, which is, of course, where all the serious examination takes place. There were more guillotines in the first three years of this government than in the last six of ours - even before they decided to make the practice routine. Between 1979 and 1997 the guillotine was used on average less than three times a year. Labour has trebled that rate. Thus provisions affecting freedom of information, the conduct of referendums, electoral law, policing in Northern Ireland, members of the Dail sitting at Westminster - and even the protection of areas of out-standing natural beauty - are now the law of the land without ever having been discussed by MPs. Most recently 522 out of 666 amendments were not debated when a guillotine fell. Then along came the criminal justice and police bill, including provisions to retain the DNA of unconvicted people, to widen the ability of the police to inspect individuals' tax records and to impose fixed penalty fines for criminal behaviour. We did not oppose the bill but we did want to alter parts of it to, for example, make sure that a fine on the spot did not remove a victim's right to compensation and to protect civil liberties. Despite our helpful attitude a government guillotine meant we arrived at the last day of committee with 56 clauses, six schedules, 42 opposition amendments and 10 government ones still to be debated and only a few hours left. Worse, the government had promised us 16 sessions but then quite arbitrarily and without consulting parliament cut that to 14 sessions. A bill of this size would normally take about 20 sessions. There had been no filibustering. At one point David Lock, a Labour minister, accused us of stringing out proceedings on clause seven. The chairman himself stamped on that, by saying that in his view there had been no untoward or over-lengthy debate and that the committee was dealing with intricate issues. His Labour co-chairman agreed. Now Labour has decided to drop clause seven altogether as it was too "confusing". Suppose we had never debated it? Suppose we had only done so briefly? Suppose we had failed to produce the arguments, which so wearied Mr Lock and his colleagues? The result would have been confusing legislation. Scrutiny is our solemn duty. There is a great deal of law to which we have not been allowed to apply that duty. So we decided quite simply that the committee would not finish at seven o'clock on Thursday with so much undiscussed and therefore we used the only technique available to make sure it did not finish. At ten to seven I and three whips entered the committee room and quietly sat in the seats reserved for committee members. Parliamentary procedure and precedent specifies that this puts the committee out of order and does not allow it to proceed. That should have meant the committee would have to meet again on another day and we had hoped it might then have been granted a few more hours of debate. We should have known better. The government instead tabled a motion "deeming" the committee to have completed its passage. I mock you not. That is what they are doing - without so much as a blush. Yet was it not Jack Straw who said in opposition, when he was doing the job I am doing now, "careful scrutiny is one of the best guarantors of good legislation"? This government is profoundly undemocratic and contemptuously dictatorial.  Ann Widdecombe is shadow home secretary. comment@theguardian.com

webTitle: Leader: Economic apprehensions in US and Japan

fields.headline: Economies under threat
fields.standfirst:
Apprehensions grow in the US and Japan

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The world's two most powerful economies face stagnation if not deepening recession. If these two dominant nations, the United States and Japan, fail to find remedies, they risk bringing others down with them.
fields.body:
Suddenly, the economic portents begin to look menacing. The world's two most powerful economies face stagnation if not deepening recession. If these two dominant nations, the United States and Japan, fail to find remedies, they risk bringing others down with them. In part, what is now happening reflects a spectacular collapse, here as elsewhere, of overblown expectations for the hi-tech revolution. Only a year ago, the City was gleefully awaiting the stock market debut of Lastminute.com, the latest internet venture that was going to make millions overnight. The inexorable rise in share prices, it was confidently asserted, was not the result of a classic speculative bubble but the inevitable consequence of the rewriting of the laws of economics. But that argument was also trotted out in 17th-century Holland, when the craze was for speculation in tulips; in 1720, when Isaac Newton lost his shirt investing in the South Sea Company; and in 1929, when radio stocks were the dot.coms of their day.

Britain - so far - has got off relatively lightly. In America, where speculation reached epidemic proportions in late 1999 and early 2000, trillions of dollars have been wiped off the value of share portfolios by the 60% decline in the Nasdaq index, which includes most of the high-technology stocks. The US public used the notional gains from rising share prices to fund a consumption boom that has allowed the country to carry on growing for 10 years without a break. Now there is a risk - far greater than is commonly acknowledged - that falling share prices and a wave of redundancies will push the economy into recession.

Should this happen, the global economy would be in serious trouble. Japan, the world's second biggest economy, is in a state of almost permanent recession, but for the past few years its weakness has been disguised by America's strong performance. In 1997 and 1998, when financial crisis swept through south-east Asia, the US acted as the world's consumer of last resort, buying all the goods that were being produced and helping countries such as South Korea out of their plight. This time as countries like these are caught up (see other Leader) in the turbulence, there may be no one to come to the rescue.

At least America's policy makers have plenty of scope to ease policy. Interest rates can be cut and Bill Clinton's budget surplus can be spent. Even so, there will inevitably be a price to pay for America's period of unsustainable growth, just as there was in the UK after the Lawson boom of the late 1980s. Moreover, given America's pivotal role in the world economy and the transmission mechanism provided by closer global integration, the effects of the US downturn will be felt way beyond its own shores. Unregulated flows of speculative capital will inevitably lead to regular financial crises, which have seen both developed and developing countries humbled in the past decade. America's current problems might occasion a rethink about the wisdom of that. It is certainly needed.

fields.headline: Straw bans terror groups
fields.trailText: MPs on all sides last night attacked Jack Straw's move to proscribe 21 organisations under the new Terrorism Act designed to prevent British-based exiles using or threatening violence to overthrow foreign regimes.
fields.body:
MPs on all sides last night attacked Jack Straw's move to proscribe 21 organisations under the new Terrorism Act designed to prevent British-based exiles using or threatening violence to overthrow foreign regimes.

In a late night Commons debate to enact the necessary order the home secretary explained the need to ban bodies as different as the Tamil Tigers in Sri Lanka, the Workers Party of Kurdistan and No vember 17 in Greece - which killed a British brigadier, Stephen Saunders, in Athens last year.

With the qualified support of his Tory shadow, Ann Widdecombe, Mr Straw said he was acting on intelligence advice to "ensure that the UK did not become or continue to be a base for international terrorists or their supporters".

Also due to be proscribed in the vote early today were the Hezbollah external security organisation, Palestinian Islamic Jihad, Abu Nidal's group, Osama bin Laden's Afghan-based group Al-ga'ida, and the Iranian mojahedin.

Labour MPs joined forces with Liberal Democrats and Conservatives to protest that it was a "travesty" to be required to cast a single vote on 21 bodies after 90 minutes of debate. Mr Straw was "judge, jury and executioner", said Labour leftwinger Jeremy Corbyn.

Douglas Hogg, the former Tory minister, said: "We haven't a clue as to the strength of the evidence on which the home secretary relies."

webTitle: Mandelson ally's home swept for bugs

fields.headline: Mandelson ally's home swept for bugs
fields.standfirst: Police act after novelist who defended MP reports break-in
fields.trailText: The police have made an anti-bugging sweep of the Berkshire home of Robert Harris, the political novelist and friend of Peter Mandelson, following an unexplained break-in after his campaign to defend the fallen Northern Ireland secretary.
fields.body:
The police have made an anti-bugging sweep of the Berkshire home of Robert Harris, the political novelist and friend of Peter Mandelson, following an unexplained break-in after his campaign to defend the fallen Northern Ireland secretary.

Mr Harris confirmed last night that thieves stole the hard drive from his computer, but ignored more valuable items. "I was inclined to think it was a coincidence, but Newbury CID thought otherwise," he said.

As a result a technical expert was called in to check the former vicarage near Newbury for listening devices. Mr Harris's wife, Gill, was given a security alarm to wear when he was away. A separate alarm was installed in the property where Mr Mandelson, an old friend and godfather to one of the Harrises' children, occasionally stays for weekends.

Last night Mr Harris said the raid could not have been in pursuit of his latest novel - as yet unwritten. "I have no idea what to make of it," he said.

It was most likely to have been motivated by someone searching for material to sell to a newspaper. He was phoned yesterday by a journalist who knew of the break-in.

The novelist also revealed that his home telephones had been malfunctioning. After calls from Mr Mandelson during the Hinduja passport affair it had been difficult to get a line out.

Mr Harris, a former Westminster journalist turned best-selling writer, spoke out on Mr Mandelson's behalf when the Northern Ireland secretary was forced to resign over the Hinduja affair in January.

The Hammond report last week which cleared Mr Mandelson of wrongdoing vindicated his judgment, Mr Harris believes.

In the wake of Sir Anthony's report, critics protested that the former Home Office QC had written a "whitewash" which blamed no one.

A more subtle reading left Sir Anthony implying many failings in the system, not least the willingness of several ministers - including Jack Straw, the home secretary - to lend their names to passport inquiries on behalf of the wealthy Hinduja brothers, who were giving £1m to the Millennium Dome.

Tory ex-ministers complained that advice from the security services had made them wary of the Hindujas, not least because of the ongoing inquiry into bribery allegations over the sale of Swedish Bofers guns to the Indian army in the 1980s. Yet Mr Mandelson and Tony Blair both got close to the Hindujas and considered them a risk worth taking.

Mr Mandelson's friends believe Sir Anthony's report failed to address the extent to which Downing Street encouraged Mr Mandelson, the dome minister in 1997, to court the Hindujas for a project in need of sponsors.

Mr Straw was active in making sure Mr Blair knew that Mr Mandelson had spoken directly to the immigration minister, Mike O'Brien, about the Hinduja case in June 1997. Mr Mandelson denied that he spoke to Mr O'Brien. At Commons question time this week Mr O'Brien faced down Tory taunts over Mr Straw's subsequent claim that Mr Mandelson had told "an untruth" about the phone call.

Mr O'Brien told MPs: "It is of course the case that telling an untruth may be honestly done or dishonestly done. People have to consider these matters for themselves."

webTitle: MPs demand more powers for watchdog urges Bell

fields.headline: MPs demand more powers for watchdog urges Bell
fields.trailText: Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, should be given tougher powers to compel witnesses to give evidence, Martin Bell said yesterday.
fields.body:
Elizabeth Filkin, the parliamentary standards commissioner, should be given tougher powers to compel witnesses to give evidence in the wake of the Keith Vaz investigation, Martin Bell, the independent MP on the Commons watchdog committee, said yesterday.

He also called on Tony Blair to instruct all ministers to answer questions from the watchdog after it emerged that Mr Vaz had refused to deal with Mrs Filkin so she could not complete her inquiries into eight allegations against the Foreign Office minister.

The aftermath of the Vaz inquiry - despite official support from Mr Blair's spokesman and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook - is pointing to the minister being dropped from the government after the election.

Even though he was cleared on nine points, his attitude towards the commissioner was being seen as "arrogant" by many MPs.

The situation is also leading to renewed support for Mrs Filkin from MPs who had been previously been silent on the matter and had privately dubbed her "Mrs Longnose " because of her detailed inquiries into their business interests.

The growing support for Mrs Filkin follows anger among members of the standards and privileges committee about the way she was treated by MPs and by lawyers called in to advise MPs and witnesses. Correspondence from one solicitor, Mark Stephens, of the law firm, Finers Stephens Innocent, to be published next week, is unanimously described by the committee as "unacceptable".

The firm was acting for one witness, Jaffer Kapasi, a deputy lord lieutenant of Leicestershire, refused to deal with her because she used to sit on the audit commission, which once looked at Leicester city council, and accused her of a conflict of interest.

Mr Bell said yesterday: "The refusal of Mr Kapasi to answer any questions and of Mr Vaz to answer any further questions means that the commissioner must be given greater powers. We have backed the commisisoner to the full in the report."

Other MPs yesterday took an even stronger line, by attacking the committee. MPs have noticed the four cases where the committee have refused to uphold the commissioner's findings all involve government ministers - John Prescott, Peter Mandelson, John Reid, and now Keith Vaz.

Austin Mitchell, Labour MP for Great Grimsby, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "These are protective devices in a sense. There is a Whitehall whitewash industry, but the inquiries really are protective in the sense of prophylactic. They want to kill the sperm of suspicion and protect the chaps."

Reports like those produced by the standards committee's investigation of Mr Vaz were important for the detail they dug up rather than their conclusions, Mr Mitchell said.

"It is the detail that is interesting because people can see what actually happened in time terms, and I think that is the nearest to proof you are going to get. We are not going to get the privileges committee of the House of Commons finding against one of its own."

The system encouraged those under scrutiny not to co-operate with inquires, as Mr Vaz has been accused of doing, Mr Mitchell added. "They should cooperate, but if it serves their interests they are not necessarily going to."

MPs like those on the standards committee were as likely to find against a fellow MP as a jury of whites would have been to find a white suspect guilty during the separatist days of the American South, he said.

webTitle: LibDem campaign HQ gets a refit

fields.headline: Campaign HQ gets a refit as Kennedy team sets its sights higher
fields.standfirst:
In the last of a series examining the readiness of the three main parties for the election, we look inside the Liberal Democrats' war room
Special report: election countdown
fields.trailText: In the last of a series examining the readiness of the three main parties for the election, we look inside the Liberal Democrats' war room.
fields.body:
Adorning the wall of the election war room at the Liberal Democrats' newly-smartened Cowley Street headquarters will be a fantasy map of Britain. The poster, highlighting the political colour of each constituency, will show the nation as the most optimistic Lib Dems believe it can one day be - a riot of yellow, with splashes of red across the north, Scotland and Wales and just a few blobs of blue to the south-east.

The map reflects the findings of a recent Mori poll in which voters were asked how they would cast their general election vote if they believed the Lib Dems could win in their constituency - a presumption which would, in theory, give Charles Kennedy's party a whopping 216 seats, with Labour on 358 and the Tories mustering just 54.

It should warm the hearts of the keen young volunteers at Cowley Street in the gloomier days of the election campaign, but is, of course, no more than the product of fantasy politics.

Under the first past the post voting system - which Labour apparently has no real plans to change - the Mori poll's big "if" will slip from voters' minds on election day, and the fantastical golden map might as well say "here be dragons" in the corner.

Propaganda

Lib Dem strategists are not fooled by their own propaganda, however. Officially, as it claims at every election, the party is fighting to win every seat in England, Scotland and Wales, in an effort to build on its record total of 47 seats (including last year's surprise byelection victory in Romsey). In 1997, strategists believe, they set their sights too low, ending up narrowly missing some former Tory strongholds. So, where former leader Paddy Ashdown spent a great deal of the 1997 campaign yomping round the target seats of the south-west, Mr Kennedy will hop by plane, bus and helicopter through every region with - organisers hope - at least a fraction of his predecessor's energy.

Calculation

Alongside the rhetoric of "every seat a target seat", the Lib Dems are privately playing their usual game of campaigning by numbers, albeit this time with more precise calculation and information than ever before.

With a campaign budget of only £3m against their rivals' £15m, it makes financial and electoral sense to focus on holding existing seats and snatching a further 20 which shifted towards the marginal category at the last election.

"This will be a more targeted campaign than ever," according to one insider. "We'll throw everything at 60 or 70 seats - effort, advice, speakers, tours, research."

Chris Rennard, the Lib Dems' newly-enobled campaign director and chief psephologist, denies any targets cut-off point, but cheerfully admits that "quite a lot of seats will be told to fight like a byelection", with particularly energetic flurries of posters, leaflets and the party's usual efforts to portray each contest as a two horse race in an attempt to win tactical votes against the incumbent.

Labour voters disappointed at the slow pace of change and Conservatives fearful of their party's rightward drift will both be in Lib Dem sights.

In all but a handful of their best-hope seats, the Lib Dems will be chasing a Tory, just as 40 of their 47 seats have the Conservatives in pursuit. Campaigners will pound the pavements repeating the mantra "remember Romsey" - the traditionally true-blue Hampshire seat where the Conservatives were ousted by a stay-at-home Tory vote and an intensive Lib Dem campaign overseen by Lord Rennard.

The formula could work again if the Tories collapse, although - with the Lib Dems currently polling 15% against 17% in the 1997 election - many believe they will do well to maintain their existing number of seats.

Whatever their poll ratings, the Lib Dems boast they are ahead of both rivals in terms of campaign preparations. Party workers have just moved back into their Cowley Street HQ after a comprehensive refurbishment intended to make the wood-panelled, Edwardian building more like Labour's open-plan 21st century command centre down the road at Millbank.

The demolition of a few internal walls has created less a war room than a series of large bunkers with freshly painted cornicing, but the party's media, research and policy operations are now at least all gathered in one building at the shiny new Ikea-style pine desks and souped-up computers they will use during the campaign.

Lord Rennard, together with his fellow peer and co-campaign leader, Tim Razzall, will sit at adjoining desks in the first floor war room - a floor above the press office - overseeing operations.

Lord Rennard, an experienced political enthusiast so immersed in election statistics and strategy he claims to "get paid for my hobby", will run the so-called ground war (the constituency battles) and air war (the party's national positioning, leader's tour, advertising and policy launches), assisted by deputy Kate Fox, election planning manager and partner of the party's health spokesman, Nick Harvey. Lord Razzall, a well-to-do lawyer and fixer-about-town referred to by one insider as "our Charlie Falconer", will share strategic responsibility, and chair daily 8am press conferences, the earliest of the three main parties, in the old Transport House on nearby Smith Square.

Experienced former Ashdown aides Neil Sherlock and Ian Wright will be brought back to work on leader's speeches and attack and rebuttal lines of the day.

Mr Kennedy, accompanied by his youthful spin doctor, Daisy Sampson, principal aide Anna Werrin, tour fixer-in-chief Niall Johnston and sometimes his partner, Sarah Gurling, will head each morning for City airport to the waiting plane - where even the air hostesses will be dressed in cheery Lib Dem yellow - before joining his battlebus at the day's campaign destination.

The tour schedule, organisers say smugly, is already planned, while the party's manifesto is also completed bar a few post-budget tweaks. Its author, chief policy wonk Richard Grayson, reputedly handed his university essays in similarly early, though several frustrated party figures whisper they would have preferred a later document with more fresh ideas.

Slogan

The party will campaign under the slogan "A real chance for real change", though its posters, designed surprisingly by the hip agency Bank, will appear on the side of campaign vans rather than on costly billboards.

Party election broadcasts, meanwhile, will be made with input from the production company Tiger Aspect, whose programme Streetmate sees passers-by being hauled off the street to go on blind dates. Rumours that the same approach will be used to drag apathetic voters to the polling booths are hotly denied.
