So, where former leader Paddy Ashdown spent a great deal of the 1997 campaign yomping round the target seats of the south-west, Mr Kennedy will hop by plane, bus and helicopter through every region with - organisers hope - at least a fraction of his predecessor's energy. Calculation Alongside the rhetoric of "every seat a target seat", the Lib Dems are privately playing their usual game of campaigning by numbers, albeit this time with more precise calculation and information than ever before. With a campaign budget of only £3m against their rivals' £15m, it makes financial and electoral sense to focus on holding existing seats and snatching a further 20 which shifted towards the marginal category at the last election. "This will be a more targeted campaign than ever," according to one insider. "We'll throw everything at 60 or 70 seats - effort, advice, speakers, tours, research." Chris Rennard, the Lib Dems' newly-enobled campaign director and chief psephologist, denies any targets cut-off point, but cheerfully admits that "quite a lot of seats will be told to fight like a byelection", with particularly energetic flurries of posters, leaflets and the party's usual efforts to portray each contest as a two horse race in an attempt to win tactical votes against the incumbent. Labour voters disappointed at the slow pace of change and Conservatives fearful of their party's rightward drift will both be in Lib Dem sights. In all but a handful of their best-hope seats, the Lib Dems will be chasing a Tory, just as 40 of their 47 seats have the Conservatives in pursuit. Campaigners will pound the pavements repeating the mantra "remember Romsey" - the traditionally true-blue Hampshire seat where the Conservatives were ousted by a stay-at-home Tory vote and an intensive Lib Dem campaign overseen by Lord Rennard. The formula could work again if the Tories collapse, although - with the Lib Dems currently polling 15% against 17% in the 1997 election - many believe they will do well to maintain their existing number of seats. Whatever their poll ratings, the Lib Dems boast they are ahead of both rivals in terms of campaign preparations. Party workers have just moved back into their Cowley Street HQ after a comprehensive refurbishment intended to make the wood-panelled, Edwardian building more like Labour's open-plan 21st century command centre down the road at Millbank. The demolition of a few internal walls has created less a war room than a series of large bunkers with freshly painted cornicing, but the party's media, research and policy operations are now at least all gathered in one building at the shiny new Ikea-style pine desks and souped-up computers they will use during the campaign. Lord Rennard, together with his fellow peer and co-campaign leader, Tim Razzall, will sit at adjoining desks in the first floor war room - a floor above the press office - overseeing operations. Lord Rennard, an experienced political enthusiast so immersed in election statistics and strategy he claims to "get paid for my hobby", will run the so-called ground war (the constituency battles) and air war (the party's national positioning, leader's tour, advertising and policy launches), assisted by deputy Kate Fox, election planning manager and partner of the party's health spokesman, Nick Harvey. Lord Razzall, a well-to-do lawyer and fixer-about-town referred to by one insider as "our Charlie Falconer", will share strategic responsibility, and chair daily 8am press conferences, the earliest of the three main parties, in the old Transport House on nearby Smith Square. Experienced former Ashdown aides Neil Sherlock and Ian Wright will be brought back to work on leader's speeches and attack and rebuttal lines of the day. Mr Kennedy, accompanied by his youthful spin doctor, Daisy Sampson, principal aide Anna Werrin, tour fixer-in-chief Niall Johnston and sometimes his partner, Sarah Gurling, will head each morning for City airport to the waiting plane - where even the air hostesses will be dressed in cheery Lib Dem yellow - before joining his battlebus at the day's campaign destination. The tour schedule, organisers say smugly, is already planned, while the party's manifesto is also completed bar a few post-budget tweaks. Its author, chief policy wonk Richard Grayson, reputedly handed his university essays in similarly early, though several frustrated party figures whisper they would have preferred a later document with more fresh ideas. Slogan The party will campaign under the slogan "A real chance for real change", though its posters, designed surprisingly by the hip agency Bank, will appear on the side of campaign vans rather than on costly billboards. Party election broadcasts, meanwhile, will be made with input from the production company Tiger Aspect, whose programme Streetmate sees passers-by being hauled off the street to go on blind dates. Rumours that the same approach will be used to drag apathetic voters to the polling booths are hotly denied.

fields.headline: Anger over arms answers
fields.trailText: MPs last night delivered a stinging criticism of the government's handling of arms exports, accusing ministers of "factually inaccurate" replies to questions about sale of military aircraft parts to Zimbabwe.
fields.body:
MPs last night delivered a stinging criticism of the government's handling of arms exports, accusing ministers of "factually inaccurate" replies to questions about sale of military aircraft parts to Zimbabwe.

A report by four Commons select committees also said the supply of gun spares to Morocco should not have been allowed and that officials should have told ministers that British arms could have been used by Israeli forces occupying south Lebanon.

The report renewed demands for prior parliamentary scrutiny of export licence aplications by British companies.

The Foreign Office gave MPs incorrect information about how many export licences were awarded to Zimbabwe over the sale of spares for Hawk aircraft, said the Commons trade and industry, defence, foreign affairs, and international development committees.

Zimbabwe forces are involved in the civil war in the Democratic Republic of Congo.

The MPs also said the government owed a "debt of honour" to enact the recommendations in Sir Richard Scott's 1996 report on the arms-to-Iraq affair, which called for proper parliamentary scrutiny of arms exports.

The MPs said it would be "deeply regrettable" if the government had not at least produced a draft bill by the time of the general election.

webTitle: NHS staff wooed by golden hellos

fields.headline: NHS staff wooed by golden hellos
fields.trailText: Doctors' and nurses' leaders yesterday welcomed government plans to spend £168m over the next three years on a package of golden hellos and loyalty bonuses to attract more staff to the health service.
fields.body:
Doctors' and nurses' leaders yesterday welcomed government plans to spend £168m over the next three years on a package of golden hellos and loyalty bonuses to attract more staff to the health service.

Alan Milburn, the health secretary, said that GPs reaching the age of 60 who agree to continue working for the NHS until they are 65 will get a £10,000 "golden goodbye". The money will be invested in an interest-yielding bond pending retirement and those doctors forced to quit through ill health will be compensated with a pro rata payment.

Newly qualified doctors will get a £5,000 "sign on" fee if they go into NHS general practice. Those choosing to work in "under-doctored" areas in poorer parts of the country, will get £10,000 instead.

Nurses coming back to the NHS will get a £1,000 grant to help with their costs while they complete a 12-week refresher course. Trainee nurses will get a 10.4% increase in bursaries - a sum that adds £500 a year to the income of the average student on a diploma course. An extra £15m has also been earmarked for more NHS nurseries to help doctors, nurses and other staff with families.

Mr Milburn said: "Doctors and nurses do a great job for the NHS and we need more of them. These measures are an important recognition of the work family doctors do and the need to make their careers more rewarding."

The £56m annual recruitment and retention initiative is funded from the chancellor's £850m health budget. The inducements are intended to help reach targets in the NHS plan for an extra 20,000 nurses and 2,000 more GPs for the NHS in England by 2004.

Mike Pringle, chairman of the Royal College of General Practitioners, welcomed recognition by the government that there was a serious workforce crisis with GPs. "We are pleased they are working on recruitment and retention. We hope these initiatives will be successful. However, the scale of the workforce crisis is such that this can only be viewed as a beginning."

Christine Hancock, general secretary of the Royal College of Nursing, said: "For many nurses, the only thing preventing them returning to nursing has been the lack of financial support while they are on essential 'return to practice' courses. Providing £1,000 for [them] will go a long way towards addressing the problem."

But the shadow health secretary, Liam Fox, said: "Recruiting and retaining doctors and nurses is proving so difficult because NHS staff morale is plummeting. Blame for that lies squarely at Alan Milburn's door. He should get off doctors' backs and allow them to spend more time seeing patients and less filling in forms."

The government had told the nurses' pay review body that there was no need for a pay increase on the grounds of recruitment problems. Three months later it said the opposite. "Even by Labour's standards, today's announcement is an astonishing attempt at deception," Dr Fox said.

fields.headline: Labour could face election injunction
fields.standfirst:
Special report: election countdown
Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The government was last night facing the threat of a legal action under the Human Rights Act to stop Tony Blair pressing ahead with a May 3 general election.
fields.body:
The government was last night facing the threat of a legal action under the Human Rights Act to stop Tony Blair pressing ahead with a May 3 general election.

Downing Street remains adamant that it has "no plans" to postpone either the local or general elections, but contingency arrangements are now on the desk of the home secretary, Jack Straw.

Ministers have only days to decide on emergency legislation to delay the annual local elections, either to June or October, possibly by extending councils' legal powers for up to a year.

The UK Independence party (UKIP), which has strong support in some rural areas, has become the first political body openly to tell Mr Blair to abandon the spring election he is determined to stage if he can.

The party has been examining the act to see if it can win an injunction.

Legal experts doubt that the high court would get involved, but Article 3 of the European convention on human rights, on which the act is based, enshrines "free and fair elections at reasonable intervals in conditions which will ensure free expression of opinion". People restricted to their farms might claim to be unable to vote.

webTitle: Rail speed limits to stay until Christmas

fields.headline: Rail speed limits to stay until Christmas
fields.standfirst: Special report: transport in Britain
fields.trailText: Parts of the rail network will not be restored to normal working before Christmas, causing new problems for the prime minister about the timing of the election, it was revealed last night.
fields.body:
Parts of the rail network will not be restored to normal working before Christmas, causing new problems for the prime minister about the timing of the election, it was revealed last night.

Downing Street has been working on guidance from Railtrack that the network would be back to normal by Easter. But the prime minister has been warned that new rail cracks have been discovered and a return to normality is months away.

Tony Blair is understood to be furious about Railtrack's broken promise on restoring the network to its pre-Hatfield accident levels. Downing Street realises that the effect will be to make the state of the industry more of an issue during the election campaign.

Railtrack said last night that more than 90% of the network would be back to normal by Easter, although some parts would still be under repair over the Easter holiday.

The company admitted that more than 100 new sites involving rail cracks had been discovered in addition to those identified in Railtrack's recovery programme after the Hatfield crash in October.

Railtrack said 263 speed restrictions were currently in operation, of which 34 were 20mph, 150 were 40 mph and 79 were 60 mph.

The company said rail cracks known as "gauge corner cracking", the cause of the Hatfield crash, was a well known problem on other rail systems. Railtrack has been severely criticised by an independent inquiry for not taking swift action to remedy the problem.

Railtrack said the network would not be back to normal "until some time later in the year", but official industry sources said last night some of the network would have to wait until the end of the year before trains were running to pre-Hatfield schedules. The rail regulator, Tom Winsor, is to meet Railtrack and other industry leaders later this month to force the company to improve its performance. He has the authority to impose sanctions on Railtrack, but will probably opt for greater supervision.

Sir Alastair Morton, chairman of the Strategic Rail Authority, confirmed yesterday that the network would not be operating normally by Easter. But he hoped that 9 out of 10 trains would be running on time soon afterwards.

He said that the job of maintaining and enhancing the network was too big a job for Railtrack. Private sector money was needed to reverse "the decades of under investment in an ageing network".

Sir Alastair said it was time for the industry to put behind it "the traumatic stress" of the past 18 months. Privatisation had been a "pretty flawed structure which didn't deliver what was needed". Railtrack had presided over "a frequently erratic, often unmeasured infrastructure".

Sir Alastair was speaking at the launch of the SRA's strategic agenda for the next 10 years, which contains no firm proposals for the future of the railway. The plan has already been delayed for a year.

Steve Marshall, Railtrack's chief executive, said his company could not develop the rail network on its own. It recognised the need to work with other parties, a remark widely interpreted as meaning that the company might be split up.

Don Foster, Liberal Democrat transport spokesman, said that the SRA's strategy did not begin "to deliver a safe, reliable and affordable railway".

RMT, the biggest rail union, said the agenda was a recipe for further fragmentation. Public opinion was in favour of a publicly owned railway.

webTitle: Labour imposes tough new rules on jobless

fields.headline: Labour imposes tough new rules on jobless
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: The government will exploit a fall in unemployment to below 1m today by announcing tough new measures for Britain's jobless claimants that will signal a decisive shift towards a US-style workfare system in a second Labour term.
fields.body:
The government will exploit a fall in unemployment to below 1m today by announcing tough new measures for Britain's jobless claimants that will signal a decisive shift towards a US-style workfare system in a second Labour term.

Under plans to be unveiled by the prime minister and three of his senior cabinet ministers, Labour will seek to underpin its support in middle England by denying benefits to adult workers and their partners who refuse to take one of the four options offered by the New Deal.

Claimants will be forced to take a subsidised job, training, voluntary work or a place on an environmental taskforce, or lose their entitlement to jobseeker's allowance.

Up until now the sanctions have only been applied to 18-to 25-year-olds, but the government believes it can sell its hardline message as a result of the first fall in unemployment below 1m for 25 years, com bined with more than 1m unfilled job vacancies.

"The tough approach adopted so far has helped to get 270,000 people into work and as we move into the second stage of the New Deal we need an even tougher regime," said a senior Whitehall source.

The source said that from now on the government would adopt an "employment first" principle, with the unemployed being required to attend an interview with the employment service before signing on for benefit rather than the other way round. "This will enable them to think about job opportunities and the steps they are ready to take to find one before they get benefits," said the source.

Single parents will also be faced with a more stringent regime. From April 2002 all lone parents will be called in for interview by the employment service, not just those with children over five. However, they will not be forced to take part in the New Deal unless they choose to. The over-50s and the disabled will also remain outside the scope of the New Deal, unlike in America where virtually every segment of the labour force is subject to sanctions unless they take part in New Deal-type schemes.

Mr Blair will be accompanied by Gordon Brown, the chancellor, David Blunkett, the education and employment secretary, and Alistair Darling, the social security secretary, when he announces the proposals at the Industrial Society.

The prime minister's mes sage will be that Britain's labour market must involve a balance of rights and responsibilities, with the unemployed obliged to do everything they can to find work at a time when the economy is buoyant.

In return the government will promise to make sure the jobless claimants are equipped for work by giving them enhanced training. Instead of being assessed for their basic skills needs at the end of the New Deal programme, lasting six months, participants will be screened after 13 weeks.

Today's announcement is being seen by the government as the price to be paid by the unemployed for the measures outlined in last week's Budget offering financial help to Britain's low paid workers. These included an increase in the working families tax credit, the introduction of a new children's tax credit and extra help for parents with very young children.

It also follows the government's decision to increase the national minimum wage by almost 11% to £4.10 from October, a move expected to boost the pay of up to 1.5m workers.

Mr Brown will use today's unemployment figures to argue that there is no reason why any jobless claimant should not find work. After standing at almost 3m in 1992, the February total fell below 1m for the first time since the recession of the mid-70s. Although job vacancies are currently running at around 375,000, ministers believe that unadvertised vacancies mean the true figure is around 1m.

webTitle: Universities get closer to creative industries

fields.headline: Universities get closer to creative industries
fields.trailText: A new high-level advisory committee for universities and the creative industries was unveiled by the Culture Secretary Chris Smith yesterday.
fields.body:
A new high-level advisory committee for universities and the creative industries was unveiled by the Culture Secretary Chris Smith yesterday.

The Creative Industries Higher Education Forum will aim to strengthen links between academics and the music, film and advertising business sectors. It is likely to focus in particular on how universities provide skilled graduates for the creative industries, as well as research and expertise.

Creative industries minister, Janet Anderson said: "The future success of the creative industries in this country relies on harnessing the enthusiasm and skills of young people.

"Schemes such as these are a welcome attempt to involve people in the creative industries. The link between universities and the business sector is especially important and I wish them all the success possible."

Mr Smith has said that creative industries have moved from the "fringes to the centre stage". Universities UK, which represents university heads, has welcomed the link-up with the booming industries.

Robin Jackson, Universities UK policy adviser on business and industry links said: "We welcome this forum as this will formalise and improve a relationship which already exists between universities and the creative sector. It will try to establish a strategic and advisory channel which runs parallel to that which currently exists between science-technology industries and their surrounding disciplines."

He said that whilst details of the forum are not yet available, he felt sure that skills would be on the agenda. "Government and industry are bound to be interested in ensuring students graduate with the skills which will continue to boost the effectiveness of the creative sector. This is entirely appropriate. At the same time, universities will be seeking to highlight the broader relevance for the creative industries of the knowledge base in these disciplines."

Professor David Eastwood, chief executive for the Arts and Humanities Research Board responded with similar enthusiasm: "Arts and humanities research has a positive contribution to make in the creative sector. As to the emphasis on skilling students to ease their passage into these industries, we ourselves have postgraduate schemes for vocational awards in this area. We are in full support of the initiative."

The Creative Industries Higher Education Forum will aim to strengthen links between academics and the music, film and advertising business sectors. It is likely to focus in particular on how universities provide skilled graduates for the creative industries, as well as research and expertise. Creative industries minister, Janet Anderson said: "The future success of the creative industries in this country relies on harnessing the enthusiasm and skills of young people. "Schemes such as these are a welcome attempt to involve people in the creative industries. The link between universities and the business sector is especially important and I wish them all the success possible." Mr Smith has said that creative industries have moved from the "fringes to the centre stage". Universities UK, which represents university heads, has welcomed the link-up with the booming industries. Robin Jackson, Universities UK policy adviser on business and industry links said: "We welcome this forum as this will formalise and improve a relationship which already exists between universities and the creative sector. It will try to establish a strategic and advisory channel which runs parallel to that which currently exists between science-technology industries and their surrounding disciplines." He said that whilst details of the forum are not yet available, he felt sure that skills would be on the agenda. "Government and industry are bound to be interested in ensuring students graduate with the skills which will continue to boost the effectiveness of the creative sector. This is entirely appropriate. At the same time, universities will be seeking to highlight the broader relevance for the creative industries of the knowledge base in these disciplines." Professor David Eastwood, chief executive for the Arts and Humanities Research Board responded with similar enthusiasm: "Arts and humanities research has a positive contribution to make in the creative sector. As to the emphasis on skilling students to ease their passage into these industries, we ourselves have postgraduate schemes for vocational awards in this area. We are in full support of the initiative."

webTitle: New school year to reform university entry 'getting closer'

fields.headline: New school year to reform university entry 'getting closer'
fields.trailText: A shake-up of the school year that would allow universities to select their students only when their A-level grades are known is getting closer, MPs were told today.
fields.body:
A shake-up of the school year that would allow universities to select their students only when their A-level grades are known is getting closer, MPs were told today.

Tony Higgins, chief executive of the Universities and Colleges Admissions Service, which administers the applications system, told MPs on the Commons education select committee that '"a head of steam" was getting behind the new system, which he himself had first recommended back in 1993.

MPs were taking evidence from Mr Higgins to follow up their controversial report on widening access in higher education, published in February.

The report made a number of radical recommendations, including shaking up the school year to allow universities to select pupils only once A-level grades are known.

The committee debated the means of increasing the number and fairness of applications from ïfirst generationÍ applicants, who have no family history in higher education.

Among the favoured solutions is the introduction of a tariff system which, it is hoped, might be a more faithful measure of applicant potential than the present UCAS form. The introduction of the so-called post-qualifications assessment (PQA) was among the other high-profile alternatives debated.

"Everybody would like to see the PQA if it could be managed", Mr Higgins told the committee. On the tariff system he was more circumspect, pointing out that selection by universities should not in any way become a matter of "measuring people by numbers".

Mr Higgins also praised current means of assessing the social origin of applicants, including collating information on parental occupation and postcodes, as the best weapons in the fight against social inequality in applications.

On the threat that PQA might pose to the traditional Oxbridge policy of interviewing all applicants, Mr Higgins insisted that in the event of deadline changes all universities would simply "have to abide by the rules".

But when Dr Evan Harris MP, whose constituency includes Oxford University, expressed concern that tariffs might in fact limit current attempts at flexibility, he suggested that individual institutions could "choose not to accept the tariff" if they so wished.

fields.headline: Publisher drops Irving trial book
fields.standfirst: Top historian's work rejected amid libel fears finds new home
fields.trailText: The UK publisher Heinemann has pulled out at the last minute from publishing a leading British historian's study of the Holocaust denial libel case, it was disclosed yesterday.
fields.body:
The UK publisher Heinemann has pulled out at the last minute from publishing a leading British historian's study of the Holocaust denial libel case, it was disclosed yesterday.

The book, Telling Lies About Hitler: The Holocaust, History and the Irving Libel Trial, was put on sale by another publisher in the US two weeks ago. The British edition - due out last week - continues to be advertised on the website of Random House, Heinemann's parent company, as "a major contribution to our understanding of the Holocaust".

But it was never sent to a printer and is still in typescript. Heinemann has told the author, Richard Evans, professor of modern history at Cambridge University, that it has abandoned the project.

The decision apparently sprang from fears that publication might provoke further libel action from David Irving, despite his humiliating defeat last July in a libel action which cost the publisher contesting it, Penguin Books, more than £2m in legal costs, which are still unpaid.

Heinemann's climbdown enabled Irving to rejoice on his website yesterday: "Book has been pulped by British publisher William Heinemann Ltd because it libels Mr Irving".

But the book is now likely to be taken over by another British publisher, Granta, which said last night after reading the typescript that it was "very enthusiastic and keen to publish".

Gail Lynch, Granta's associate publisher, said: "We do not see any terrible legal nightmares ahead".

Professor Evans, who has published 16 previous books, most of them on German history, was academic team leader for Penguin's defence in the 32-day high court case which resulted from Irving's libel action against the American author and scholar Deborah Lipstadt. He took two years preparing for the court a 740-page report on the historiography of the Holocaust.

At the end of the action, Mr Justice Charles Gray ruled that a book by Professor Lipstadt was justified in branding Mr Irving a Holocaust denier.

The judge found that Mr Irv ing was "an active Holocaust denier; that he is anti-semitic and racist; and that he associates with rightwing extremists who promote neo-Nazism.

"The content of his speeches and interviews often displays a distinctly pro-Nazi and anti-Jewish bias. He makes surprising and often unfounded assertions about the Nazi regime which tend to exonerate the Nazis for the appalling atrocities which they inflicted on the Jews.

"In my view, the defendants have established that Irving has a political agenda. It is one which, it is legitimate to infer, disposes him, where he deems it necessary, to manipulate the historical record in order to make it conform with his political beliefs."

The ruling left Irving facing bankruptcy with a total of £2.5m in defence costs.

Soon after the ruling, Heinemann commissioned Prof Evans's book. The deal was negotiated by Ravi Merchandani, the company's publishing director, previously a leading editor at Penguin. Random House's website advertisement for the book stresses the authority of Prof Evans's report for the court case.

It says his book "unpacks the issues raised by the trial, from the career of Mr Irving and the exposure of his methods, to the wider question of the preservation of the cultural memory of the Holocaust - and the social and cultural functions of the historian in society".

A review on the US website Amazon.com of the American version, published by Basic Books, calls the work "a cogent and deeply informed study in the nature of historical interpretation".

Yesterday Professor Evans and his literary agent, Peter Robinson, said in a joint statement: "Random House UK has taken the position that the work is not safe to publish at present. We disagree with that. But, since it was clearly not possible to proceed further with Random House, we have sought - and found - another publisher, Granta. They want to take the book on".

It is understood that Heinemann's legal advisers concluded that, though the book might present some legal problems, it was feasible to publish. Senior Heinemann staff were attending a conference yesterday. None returned phone calls from the Guardian inviting comment.

fields.headline: Getting butch with teachers
fields.trailText: There used to be a Kosovan Albanian girl called Alma living on our street ... then one day, she was gone, sent to Nottingham under the government's scheme for messing refugees about as much as possible.
fields.body:
There used to be a Kosovan Albanian girl called Alma living on our street. She was older than my daughter but I encouraged a friendship, because any newcomer, especially one who is troubled, needs friends. You might think my response was inadequate and that I should have deployed ground troops in some way, but I used to take her to the pictures with us sometimes, to get her out of the B&B.

She settled well into the school, gained confidence, learned good English and was all set to transfer to secondary school. Then one day, she was gone, sent to Nottingham under the government's scheme for messing refugees about as much as possible. And the government accuses teachers of disrupting children's education. Perhaps Alma has now been deported. Perhaps she now breathes freely the uranium dust of liberal humanitarianism.

In any event, it is understandable that David Blunkett is upset by the very limited industrial action being taken by teachers. He is still reeling from the humiliation of being savaged by Chris Woodhead. Most of us would consider that a badge of honour but, if you are foolish enough to have given someone like him a second chance, you must feel a sap, and frankly you deserve to. And to attempt to sound dignified and saddened at being traduced by the ingrate just makes the humiliation complete.

So perhaps that's why he has come over all butch with the teaching unions. He tells the Daily Mail: "Far from being intimidated, we are getting increasingly iron-souled about this and we are looking at ways we can deal with the unions in a way they could be surprised about." Well, I have long-considered Blunkett and his colleagues to be a bunch of complete iron-souls, but who is supposed to be impressed by this preposterous bluster? Not Mail readers, surely. Unless teachers are shot and burnt or sent to the colonies, Blunkett cannot possibly fulfil the promise of so enticing a wink to the Mail, the unthinking man's piece of paper with words on.

What is he threatening? A gunboat on the Thames? Dragoons in Doncaster cutting teachers down with sabres? Green goddesses delivering Bob the Builder videos to schools to keep teacherless infants entertained? If he really wanted to surprise teachers, he would treat them decently, stop privatising education and fulfil his promise to end selection.

Teachers are taking industrial action. They are not striking, which is unfortunate, because if they did that they would win and it would all be sorted in a week. There is no reward for being diplomatic with the government. If you are going to take it on, you must beat it, otherwise it absorbs your energy and grows in strength, to paraphrase Nietzsche or Star Trek.

And this government has demonstrated its cowardice boldly. It is caving in to the Countryside Alliance at a time when the Metropolitan police must be having to explain to would-be marchers that a giant foot-bath in Hyde Park isn't feasible. What a coup for the government that the rural lobby's leaders are trapped in their London mansions, unable to drive out to Dorset and march back in again. And what a time to give in to them.

No the government isn't tough at all, just vindictive. It tried to break the teachers by using performance management and unequal pay to divide them, but it has driven them closer together. It is privatising the running of schools and education authorities, bringing oil companies into education action zones and threatening to tear up contracts. It is opening city academies, whereby private agencies run schools and a token splash of private money is the excuse.

For Blunkett to rail about "children's life chances" being threatened is like farmers weeping for their pigs - which they are having to slaughter, instead of training them for the Olympics as they'd planned. The thing that is most disrupting children's education is the fact that Blunkett is driving teachers out of the profession, not the fact that teachers are protesting about it. Kids are already sent home because of staff shortages. The unions are saying their members will continue to do their jobs but just refuse to cover the cracks to make Blunkett look less bad.

But Blunkett claims to "represent" children, who must presumably have the vote in his constituency. He appears to feel no responsibility to his shop-floor employees, most of them parents themselves. Of course industrial action is disruptive, and the more worthwhile and difficult the job, the more disruptive it is. The army can't be sent in to cover teacher absences; although that might push the Sats results up, which, after all, is what Blunkett really cares about.

webTitle: Teachers in more cities join protest

fields.headline: Teachers in more cities join protest
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education
Special report: teaching
fields.trailText: Industrial action by teachers over staff shortages is being extended to five more cities, unions announced yesterday, as employers threatened to dock the pay of those who take part by up to £250 a day.
fields.body:
Industrial action by teachers over staff shortages is being extended to five more cities, unions announced yesterday, as employers threatened to dock the pay of those who take part by up to £250 a day.

Schools in Leicester, Nottingham, Middlesbrough, Portsmouth and Southampton face the threat of disruption after members of the two main teacher unions balloted to join the protest begun this week in London and Doncaster.

The National Union of Teachers and National Association of Schoolmasters Union of Women Teachers said increased turnouts in the ballot showed opinion was hardening in favour of the action.

Their members will refuse to cover for long term absences and staff vacancies. Hundreds of schools could be forced on to shortened timetables and send children home. No schools have been disrupted since the action started, although some may be by the end of the week.

Graham Lane, chairman of the National Employers Organisation for School Teachers, said teachers who disobeyed headteachers' instructions to cover lessons should have their pay docked by £20 an hour. If the action resulted in children being sent home they could be fined a day's pay and extra costs for disruption.

"This is normal procedure when people take industrial action," Mr Lane said.

Thousands of children could be affected. "This is the most damaging piece of action they could do. A strike would be easier to deal with than this."

Nigel de Gruchy, NASUWT general secretary, acknowledged that teachers would be breaching contract but said employers were provoking unions by threatening financial penalties.

He expected even better turnouts in further ballots of NUT and NASUWT members. Results from Kent, Manchester and Reading are expected within days.

Turnout in results announced yesterday was higher than in London and Doncaster, when it was 30% and 38% respectively, though in no case was it higher than 50%. In all but one ballot at least 90% of those voting supported the action.

Doug McAvoy, NUT general secretary, said: "The support for the action and the turnout continues to rise as members see what they need to do to show parents the extent of the staffing crisis in our schools. There are still 19 more ballot results to come and more areas queuing up to be considered for balloting."

The teacher supply agency TimePlan, meanwhile, attacked its rival Teaching Personnel for putting retired university and college lecturers in schools, saying they had not been trained to teach children.

But Graham Hellier, chairman of Teaching Personnel, said if headteachers reported that lecturers were not up to scratch they would not be used again.

fields.headline: Q&A: Supporting People
fields.trailText: The scheme will see councils take over the funding, planning and commissioning of all housing-related support services from housing benefit and the Housing Corporation.David Batty explains.
fields.body:
What is it?
Under Supporting People councils will take over the funding, planning and commissioning of all housing-related support services from housing benefit and the Housing Corporation. This includes support for the elderly, people with mental health problems or learning difficulties, physical disabilities and chronic illnesses, rough sleepers, ex-offenders, drug and alcohol users, victims of domestic violence and young care leavers.

Why change the system?
Housing-related support has traditionally been funded from a variety of sources, chiefly housing benefit, as well as the Housing Corporation, the Department of Health and the Home Office. But housing benefit was never meant to fund care services and has come under increasing scrutiny. A 1997 court ruling stated it could only pay for such support in limited situations. This threatened the viability of hundreds of supported housing projects. The government then introduced a transition scheme, but from 2003 a single Supporting People grant will replace the various existing funding streams.

What is the aim of the scheme?
The main aim of Supporting People is to provide service users with help tailored to their individual needs rather than slotting them into existing services. It will end the link between support and housing tenure. The current system is biased towards supported housing, hostels and council accommodation. This might mean older people who need basic support having to go into a home to get help. But under the new arrangements, they will have access to visiting support services to enable them to remain in their own homes. People leaving institutions (such as prison) or who have been homeless will also get help to set up home. Local authorities will identify users' needs and commission appropriate services through local Supporting People strategies.

How will this be achieved?
Local authorities will review and commission all housing-related support services on a regular cycle - every two or three years - starting between 2003 and 2006. It is anticipated that Supporting People funds will eventually be allocated under a national formula based on indicators of local need. A cross-authority fund will meet the needs of groups such as transient rough sleepers and women escaping domestic violence, who have previously missed out on support. Existing users of sheltered housing and short-term users of schemes such as women's refuges will be exempt from charges but new clients will have to pay for long-term services.

Who is involved in the scheme?
Supporting People strategies will be developed by a partnership of housing and social services departments, encompassing district and county authorities, together with health, probation services, users, and providers. Local authorities' plans must link in with wider strategies in health, social services, housing and neighbourhood renewal and community safety. These include health improvement plans, joint investment plans and the national service framework for older people. The aim is to establish joint commissioning and funding of services with the NHS, leading to joined-up care packages that provide everyday support alongside specialist care.

What preparations must councils make?
The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions has set an action plan for local authorities with targets to achieve by April 2003. The government has set aside £138m over three years to cover administration costs, with the first money available from April 1.

By March 2002, councils must have mapped all local support services. This includes those provided by the council itself, registered social landlords, voluntary sector agencies, NHS trusts, private sector organisations and landlords and the probation service. This mapping exercise must identify local users' needs and gaps in current services. Authorities will also need to discuss potential changes with service providers.

By August 2002, they should have drawn up a shadow Supporting People strategy with their partners. A list of all existing providers should be ready by November 2002 and the value of the grant to be paid to each from April 2003. The first Supporting People strategies will be produced in 2003.

What are the potential problems?
Many in local authorities, housing associations and social care broadly welcome the aims of Supporting People but fear the pot of money available will be too small leading to cuts in services. Changes to the funding system have already begun with the introduction of transitional housing benefit. Providers now have to state what proportion of rent pays for housing costs and what proportion pays for support costs. The funds councils receive for Supporting People will partly be based on these local support costs.

But Fahmeeda Gill, policy officer of the National Housing Federation, warns that providers are underestimating their support costs to maximise the amount of housing benefit they continue to receive after 2003. "This means the government will underestimate the total cost of support, leading to a shortfall in funding."

Ms Gill also warned that the competitive nature of the scheme could squeeze smaller voluntary services. "We're moving from a system based on rights - housing benefit - to one based on grants, where you bid for funds. But smaller providers lack the resources to prepare bids." She wants greater awareness of the changes as well. "It's one thing to tell existing tenants but another to tell the wider population who could benefit from Supporting People. We fear private tenants are not being informed, which will lead to ethnic minorities in particular missing out on support."

Chris Hampson, head of policy and strategy at London housing association Look Ahead, warned it would be difficult to identify unmet needs, such as people sleeping on friends' floors. But he said local audits would raise far greater needs than there would ever be cash for, leading to rationalisation.

It will end the link between support and housing tenure. The current system is biased towards supported housing, hostels and council accommodation. This might mean older people who need basic support having to go into a home to get help. But under the new arrangements, they will have access to visiting support services to enable them to remain in their own homes. People leaving institutions (such as prison) or who have been homeless will also get help to set up home. Local authorities will identify users' needs and commission appropriate services through local Supporting People strategies. How will this be achieved? Local authorities will review and commission all housing-related support services on a regular cycle - every two or three years - starting between 2003 and 2006. It is anticipated that Supporting People funds will eventually be allocated under a national formula based on indicators of local need. A cross-authority fund will meet the needs of groups such as transient rough sleepers and women escaping domestic violence, who have previously missed out on support. Existing users of sheltered housing and short-term users of schemes such as women's refuges will be exempt from charges but new clients will have to pay for long-term services. Who is involved in the scheme? Supporting People strategies will be developed by a partnership of housing and social services departments, encompassing district and county authorities, together with health, probation services, users, and providers. Local authorities' plans must link in with wider strategies in health, social services, housing and neighbourhood renewal and community safety. These include health improvement plans, joint investment plans and the national service framework for older people. The aim is to establish joint commissioning and funding of services with the NHS, leading to joined-up care packages that provide everyday support alongside specialist care. What preparations must councils make? The Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions has set an action plan for local authorities with targets to achieve by April 2003. The government has set aside £138m over three years to cover administration costs, with the first money available from April 1. By March 2002, councils must have mapped all local support services. This includes those provided by the council itself, registered social landlords, voluntary sector agencies, NHS trusts, private sector organisations and landlords and the probation service. This mapping exercise must identify local users' needs and gaps in current services. Authorities will also need to discuss potential changes with service providers. By August 2002, they should have drawn up a shadow Supporting People strategy with their partners. A list of all existing providers should be ready by November 2002 and the value of the grant to be paid to each from April 2003. The first Supporting People strategies will be produced in 2003. What are the potential problems? Many in local authorities, housing associations and social care broadly welcome the aims of Supporting People but fear the pot of money available will be too small leading to cuts in services. Changes to the funding system have already begun with the introduction of transitional housing benefit. Providers now have to state what proportion of rent pays for housing costs and what proportion pays for support costs. The funds councils receive for Supporting People will partly be based on these local support costs. But Fahmeeda Gill, policy officer of the National Housing Federation, warns that providers are underestimating their support costs to maximise the amount of housing benefit they continue to receive after 2003. "This means the government will underestimate the total cost of support, leading to a shortfall in funding." Ms Gill also warned that the competitive nature of the scheme could squeeze smaller voluntary services. "We're moving from a system based on rights - housing benefit - to one based on grants, where you bid for funds. But smaller providers lack the resources to prepare bids." She wants greater awareness of the changes as well. "It's one thing to tell existing tenants but another to tell the wider population who could benefit from Supporting People. We fear private tenants are not being informed, which will lead to ethnic minorities in particular missing out on support." Chris Hampson, head of policy and strategy at London housing association Look Ahead, warned it would be difficult to identify unmet needs, such as people sleeping on friends' floors. But he said local audits would raise far greater needs than there would ever be cash for, leading to rationalisation.

fields.headline: Royal palaces plan marketing push
fields.trailText: 8.30am: St James's Palace is gearing up to tempt visitors into the Queen's official residences, reports Julia Day.
fields.body:
St James's Palace is going into marketing overdrive this year in a bid to tempt visitors into the Queen's official residences.

The first advertising campaign for Windsor Castle to target the public rather than the tourist trade will launch later this year.

Creative and media advertising agencies are being sought to handle the account. Advertising has previously been carried out in-house.

The move is part of an aggressive push to promote the residences as visitor attractions in an increasingly competitive tourism market.

Royal Collection Enterprise is the body responsible for promoting public admissions to Buckingham Palace, Windsor Castle and the Palace of Holyroodhouse, Edinburgh.

The organisation is in the process of staffing up its marketing and PR department.

RCE is looking for a business development manager to implement new marketing and promotional strategies targeting the tourism trade, groups and individuals. The role also includes the introduction of commercial ventures.

The newly created positions of press and PR officer and PR assistant have also to be filled.

Frances Dunkels, RCE director of PR and marketing, joined from the British Museum last June.

She was brought in to build a marketing and PR strategy in the run-up to the 2002 golden jubilee.

"We are in an increasingly competitive market," said Ms Dunkels.

"We have to look at how to deliver to our different audiences most effectively, including tailoring promotions to particular markets."

A marketing strategy for the jubilee, to include consumer advertising, is being discussed.

fields.standfirst: Rub of the Greens editor Steve Nicholson on the life and times of his fanzine
fields.trailText: RotG was launched by Tony Scowcroft (RIP) in March 1990 when Argyle were struggling in the dizzy heights of the old Second Division. fields.body:
RotG was launched by Tony Scowcroft (RIP) in March 1990 when Argyle were struggling in the dizzy heights of the old Second Division. The name came up in a pub conversation between Tony and his brother Nigel, during which they were trying to think of a suitable name for their fanzine, the only precondition being that it had to include the word 'green' (it's that important to us). This was because - according to Tony - "all Argyle fans are obsessed with the colour, which is unique to Argyle in the league."

David Kemp - an all time playing hero - was the manager at the time, and Argyle were in dire financial straits. Chairman Dan McCauley arrived on his white charger to "save" the club from further progress - in his own inimitable style - and the hate-hate relationship between the club's newest and longest surviving fanzine and the chairman was born.

The editorship changed hands in April 1996 when yours truly took the reins after Tony became too ill to continue. The status quo was largely retained, and the fanzine continued its forthright views on football in general and Argyle in particular. We try to see the funny side of situations as well as the serious. When you've been an Argyle fan as long as I have, you develop a morbid sense of humour - it's the only way we stay sane.

It is no great secret that the RotG take on our beloved chairman is that he is the worst thing ever to happen to the club - and there are no shortage of negatives to choose from! That doesn't stop us including the odd pro-McCauley article from time to time though. Indeed, McCauley actually wrote something himself a few years ago, and still 'enjoys' his copy.

We have had an interesting relationship with the club over the years. For a period in the early nineties RotG was actually sold in the club shop - but it didn't last long. At one stage we were even banned from selling it outside the ground, but that didn't last long either.

It was probably the only issue that Tony and I disagreed on, as I didn't think that a fanzine should be considered to be accepted by the establishment, and tame enough to be sold in the club shop - Tony though, looked at the extra sales it would generate.

Over the years we have seen off opposition from at least six other Argyle fanzines: Evergreen, Green Piece, Central Heating, Way Out West, Guzzler and Hoof!, to become the one and only Argyle fanzine currently available.

I think our greatest achievement has been the continuing allocation of funds from RotG sales to Youth Development at the club - something we are particularly proud of when we see ex-youth players in the first team (Wotton, Adams, Beswetherick etc).

The low points for a fanzine editor are often the high points for a club, particularly in our case. Sales are much better if the team is doing badly, and more people write articles because they have something to moan about! Therefore the Wembley play-off triumph - and the fall-out after it - was, in my opinion, RotG's lowest point to date. I personally think that being promoted in glory at Wembley having finished fourth is absurd anyway. And in typical McCauley fashion, he lied about the profit he made on the triumph, leaving a bad taste in the mouth of all at RotG.

Although our fanzine has become a bit of a one-man band in the last couple of years, I am indebted to a small group of contributors - particularly David Keogh - and my regular salespeople - Big Nick, Sarah, Dave and Bob without whom it would not happen.

Our web site, www.rubofthegreens.com is expertly run by David Pay.

fields.headline: Yahoo! hit by fresh blow as sales chief quits
fields.trailText:
5.30pm: Yahoo! was dealt a further blow today when the man in charge of building advertising revenues announced his departure, writes Amy Vickers.

Mar 8: Yahoo! deepens dot.com gloom
Mar 8: Future of Yahoo! in doubt
fields.body:
Yahoo! was dealt a further blow today when the man in charge of building advertising revenues at the troubled internet company threw in the towel.

Anil Singh, chief sales and marketing officer and senior vice-president of business operations, has become the latest high-ranking director to resign, following recent resignations from Tim Koogle and Fabiola Arredondo.

Mr Singh, 41, who was Yahoo!'s first ever sales executive in 1995, now plans to retire by May to spend more time with his family.

Since Yahoo!'s flotation, Mr Singh, who earns $280,000 a year, has cashed in some $74m-worth of options, according to the company's declared holdings.

"Under his leadership, the company built a top sales organisation from the ground up and pioneered the concept of online advertising when it was still a new idea for marketers," said Jeff Mallett, Yahoo!'s president and chief operating officer, in a statement.

But times have changed, and the online advertising market is in turmoil. Yahoo! once commanded a 16% share of the global market; this has now dropped to around 11%.

Morale at the company is said to be at an all-time low with more departures expected in the coming months.

Additionally, given Yahoo!'s profit warning last week and need to bring costs under control, speculation has started up again that the internet company is about to lay off 15% of its workforce.

Related stories
Mar 8: Yahoo! deepens dot.com gloom
Mar 8: Future of Yahoo! in doubt

webTitle: A cultural icon for our times

fields.headline: A cultural icon for our times
fields.standfirst:
Richard Mullender, a fan who recently met with the Board of Directors to discuss
several supporter's initiatives, on how Argyle offers an intensity not to be found in any multiplex
fields.trailText: Richard Mullender, a fan who recently met with the Board of Directors to discuss several supporter's initiatives, on how Argyle offers an intensity not to be found in any multiplex
fields.body:
At a party given recently by the Prince of Wales, Sir Christopher Bland (the Chairman of the BBC) made a speech in which he listed a number of cultural icons. On his list were The Archers, the novels of Anthony Trollope and Patrick O'Brian, and the early vinyl recording of Jazz saxophonist Charlie ('Bird') Parker. Also included on Sir Christopher's list was an item that, no doubt, took most, if not all, of those listening to his words by surprise: viz, "the away games of Plymouth Argyle". Moreover, bemusement was surely the reaction of most of those who have subsequently read Sir Christopher's words (which were reported in the Diary section of The Times on March 6 2000, p 20). This last item on Sir Christopher's list should, however, come as less of a surprise to Plymouth Argyle's travelling supporters.

When Argyle's supporters travel around the country, they typically do so with a particular self-understanding. They view themselves as the representatives of a distinctive part of the country - a fact that is made plain in a repertoire of songs that are celebrations of their distinct south-western identity. Moreover, these songs are sung with a degree of intensity that is matched by the supporters of only a minority of clubs in the professional game. One such club is Newcastle United. When Newcastle's supporters sing "Toon, Toon, Black and White Army" or "The Blaydon Races", they are doing so in order to celebrate a distinct (city-wide) form of North Eastern life.

So what inspires such intensity in the supporter's of Newcastle and Argyle? The beginnings of an answer can be found in the assumption that a particular city (Newcastle) or a particular region (the south-west) is intrinsically valuable and, hence, worthy of celebration. But, in order to answer the above question satisfactorily, more is surely needed. And it can, perhaps, be found, in the (more or less conscious) perception that ours is a society and an age in which distinct regional (and other) identities are being rapidly eroded. We live, after all, at a time when, among other things, the homogenising forces of global capital exert an unprecedented level of influence. Consider, for example, the films that are served up for our entertainment in multiplex cinema chains that circle the planet. In both Plymouth and Newcastle, this fare simultaneously inducts us into a global mega-culture and lures us away from that which makes our region or city distinctive and, as such, a site of (active) cultural production rather than (passive) cultural reproduction.

If the above is broadly correct, then the intense support Argyle enjoy away from home might be seen as a defence of a particular and valued culture. And if this is indeed the case, then it is a state of affairs that has great practical significance for both the club and people in the south-west. The club could become a regional beacon - an institution that gives expression to and serves to secure a valued regional identity. This is, of course, not the most obvious task for a football club (centrally concerned with success on the pitch) to undertake. But it is one that could encourage growth in the ranks of Argyle's Green Army. For what is on offer is intensity of a sort not to be found in any multiplex. And it is intensity of a sort that makes Sir Christopher Bland's inclusion of Argyle's away matches on his list more fitting than many hearing his words may have appreciated.

fields.headline: Axe falls heavily at Express
fields.trailText: 5.30pm: The Express will announce tomorrow that up to 130 jobs will be axed, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The Express will announce tomorrow that up to 130 jobs will be axed.

It means an agonising weekend ahead for journalists - letters from editorial director Paul Ashford are not being posted out until tomorrow.

Figures have not been confirmed, but a crunch meeting with the journalists' union has been scheduled for tomorrow morning.

In a meeting at the Express's Ludgate House canteen, journalists were told by NUJ's Jeremy Dear that he and general secretary John Foster have been called in to be told of the paper's redundancy plans.

Up to now, executives at the company have privately confirmed that between 50 and 100 redundancies would be made.

But during the meeting, Mr Dear said he believed the final figure could be as high as 170. However, well-informed sources say the figure is likely to be closer to 130.

The NUJ said letters had already gone out to staff by second class post detailing the redundancy plans.

It is believed that new Express owner Richard Desmond also wants to cut holiday allowance by two weeks a year.

This would affect all remaining journalists who are normally on six weeks' paid leave.

In what insiders say was a packed, emotional meeting in the Express Newspapers canteen, a unanimous motion was passed by 200 staff to resist cuts "with all means at its disposal".

The motion states: "Despite promises to spend 'whatever it takes' to 'restore the papers to their rightful position', reports indicate that plans are being drawn up to axe more than 100 jobs in the editorial departments.

"This chapel believes that such a redundancy programme would harm the quality of the paper and result in worse terms and conditions for other staff."

Mr Dear warned staff that Express Newspapers management was pressuring journalists to accept new contracts from the parent company Northern & Shell, which would see them moving from six to four weeks paid holiday a year.

Under current employment law, employers must agree to a 90-day consultation period for plans involving any number of redundancies over 100.

The Express made over 60 marketing, sales and administrative staff redundant after Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell bought the paper late last year.

Mr Desmond's last round of redundancies met with widespread condemnation, not least from former Express editor Rosie Boycott, who chided him for "heavy-handed" management techniques.

webTitle: The biggest big heads in the Third Division

fields.headline: The biggest big heads in the Third Division
fields.standfirst: Are Argyle big heads? Possibly, but with good reason, argues Argyle reporter Paul Roberts
fields.trailText: Are Argyle big heads? Possibly, but with good reason, argues Argyle reporter Paul Roberts.
fields.body:
It's not every day that average Third Division football clubs are labelled arrogant. But in Plymouth Argyle's case, we are apparently "the biggest big heads in the lower divisions". And that from Barnet's official mascot - Mr Bumble!

It's a strange accusation to fire at a club huffing and puffing its way through a third consecutive season in the basement league. So just what has got Mr Bumble so flustered?

The Pilgrims have always considered themselves to be Devon's big cheeses, for a wealth of reasons. They are the only club in the county to have made the First Division (albeit in its former guise as the Second Division) and have spent the vast majority of their existence in the division below that (where we occasionally bumped into Devon's other clubs, Exeter and Torquay).

They possess a ground big enough to squeeze in nearly 20,000 supporters, and have attracted crowds of almost double that on several occasions some years back; on top of that, they took 32,000 fans to the 1996 Third Division play-off final.

Primarily of course, it's the size of the place that really adds colour to the canvas. Twice the size of Exeter, and big enough to make Torquay look like a one-pub village, Plymouth is easily big enough to support a top-flight club.

If you listen carefully, you can almost hear the Exeter and Torquay fans seething with resentment. They cannot abide our bouts of nostalgia, when we recall - starry-eyed - beating the great Leeds 6-3 at Home Park in a league encounter, or mighty Newcastle by two goals to nil. You can add Leicester, Manchester City, Middlesbrough, Ipswich, Sunderland, Bradford and Charlton to the list of current Premiership teams to have succumbed to defeat at Home Park within the last ten seasons.

It's that name-dropping that so incenses our dear neighbours, who revel in the fact that we are slumming it with them in a division we never thought we would have to endure.

But here we are, twelfth in that very place, with the glum prospect of a trip to Scunthorpe this coming Saturday.

So, fellow Devonians, the next time you fire a shot across our tattered bows, just consider our painful demise for a moment. Imagine the indignity of substituting a diet of caviar and fois gras, for a lifetime supply of stale Happy Shopper custard creams.

People used to sit up and take notice of Plymouth Argyle; now we're slowly being digested by the mediocrity of the worst professional division in England. People see us as no more significant than Rochdale or Mansfield, and it's hard to take.

The rivalry between the Devon clubs has always existed on a superficial level. They don't hate us anymore than we hate Abu Dhabi United, and we don't honestly see them as a serious threat to our standing as the only club in Devon with a realistic chance at the big-time.

It's not just the Pilgrims who suffer from delusions of grandeur either. Cardiff City and Brighton both feel they are the Third Division's big fish, it's just that they have teams currently justifying the tag.

webTitle: Getting Britain Giving: the issue explained

fields.headline: Getting Britain Giving: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Backed by £1m of government funding, the Getting Britain Giving campaign was launched last November by the Treasury. In partnership with the Charities Aid Foundation and the National Council of Voluntary Organisations, it aims to increase the total amount of money available to charities by encouraging people to donate more through new tax efficient methods.
fields.body:
Backed by £1m of government funding, the Getting Britain Giving campaign was launched last November by the Treasury. In partnership with the Charities Aid Foundation and the National Council of Voluntary Organisations, it aims to increase the total amount of money available to charities by encouraging people to donate more through new tax efficient methods.

The big idea is to develop an "overarching brand for charitable giving" and reverse a five-year decline in donations to good causes. The campaign will be looking at ways to attract non-typical new donors and encourage existing supporters to make their donations work harder. The objective is to double the amount donated to charity through payroll giving from £29m in 1998-99 to £60m by 2003.

Recognising that it is pointless to introduce innovative tax-breaks for charities if nobody has heard of them, the government funded a publicity drive, including advertising and mailshots, to 24,000 small and medium-sized companies. It wants many more of them to offer payroll giving schemes so that employees can make their donations more tax-efficient.

Payroll giving works by taking an employeeÍs donation from their gross salary, so charities benefit from the income tax that would otherwise go to the Inland Revenue. Last April, the Treasury decided to supplement payroll donations to the tune of 10% until April 2003. It also scrapped the upper limit on what people can give through their payroll. There is no longer a minimum donation eligible for Giftaid so charities can claim tax back on any amount, and shares can be donated with tax relief on their full market value.

So far, though, many charities have not taken advantage of these benefits. One major charity has converted only 15% of its database of 500,000 donors, and a reason cited for the general lack of action is the high logistical and financial cost of modifying donor databases.

Employers too, particularly smaller ones, say it is difficult to administer payroll giving, and the Treasury has launched a website and a helpline for people to find out more. The target is to make the scheme available to one in three employees, rather than one in five in 1998-99.

But can an "overarching brand", no matter how worthy, really get people reaching enthusiastically for their wallets? The Future Foundation think tank suggests that people respond to causes that touch or inspire them, and that what donors want is to help something or someone specific. Its criticisms of the Getting Britain Giving campaign focus on whether a drive to create a generic giving campaign will be a sufficient incentive to get people to give more.

The Charities Aid Foundation will however shortly launch a report stating that there is already a noticeable increase in charitable giving through payrolls since the government's new incentives took effect last April. CAF points out that payroll-giving has been a highly effective fundraiser for some local charities that have made direct, personal contact with employees and companies in their area.

fields.headline: Charity campaigning: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Charities and voluntary organisations have traditionally been at the forefront of social change in Britain. They have done so by conducting carefully orchestrated campaigns to change the views of politicians and other important decision-makers.
fields.body:
Charities and voluntary organisations have traditionally been at the forefront of social change in Britain. They have done so by conducting carefully orchestrated campaigns to change the views of politicians and other important decision-makers.

Today charities need those campaigning skills more than ever. Charities must now use a range of different lobby and advocacy techniques to ensure their voice is heard at the highest level.

Whether charities try to secure change at national or international level or whether they focus their effort on local issues (such as stopping a local road being built or campaigning to improve nursery care provision) any successful campaign must know what it wants to achieve, and who it needs to lobby to gets it.

In the past there have been two models of campaigning. Firstly "the inside track", whereby charities have tried to use their influence, reputation and contacts to convince civil servants and politicians of the merits of their cause. The second approach has been more adversarial or confrontational: using the media to expose issues in public and thereby pressurise politicians by using the weight of public opinion.

Yet today campaigners need to be more sophisticated. They operate in a more competitive environment. Politicians and decision-makers and constantly lobbied. If a charity's voice is going to be heard it needs to develop far reaching alliances and secure the endorsement of other public interest groups.

It also needs to understand that the Labour Government is less ideological. Ministers are open to persuasion. But New Labour likes to avoid confrontation. It will not make policy decisions which are out of step with public feelings. Indeed, clever politicians today pride themselves on their ability to predict how the public will react.

Campaigners have always needed to illustrate public support for their cause. Today they need to go further. They must show that there is deep rooted and widespread concern for their issues. Grassroots support and local support networks are therefore crucial.

The internet allows campaigns to harness the support and enthusiasm of "normal" people. It has also empowered these supporters by giving them access to information and the ability to lobby decision makers from their own homes.

The internet also allows campaigns to be organised across national boundaries. This has becoming increasingly important because of what many people are now calling "globalisation". Those corporations which operate across the world, seem to have a growing influence on how people live their lives. National politicians seem powerless to halt their influence. Campaigners are therefore linking up via the internet to give themselves a voice on the international stage.

Companies themselves now feel under attack. They are keen to win over the public who has become more cynical about the activities of "big business". They are keen to talk about "social responsibility". Campaigners and activists are now focussing their attention to see if this new buzzword is just PR puff or whether there is any substance behind it.

fields.trailText: • 2001 has been designated the International Year of Volunteering.
fields.body:
 2001 has been designated the International Year of Volunteering.

 The government plans to galvanise volunteers with a £300m budget to encourage more people to volunteer.

 Conservative leader William Hague also plans to revolutionise the voluntary sector and would send 5,000 young people a year abroad were he to be elected.

 Some of the more recent volunteering initiatives in the UK have aimed to attract people in their 50s who may have taken early retirement. Both major political parties are said to be keen to harness the various faith groups in Britain to encourage more volunteering

 It is now perfectly possible to forge a career out of volunteering for various charities.

fields.headline: Fraudsters target tired travellers
fields.standfirst: Seven suspected Iranian terrorists have been arrested by the FBI. They are alleged to have bought an impressive arsenal of weapons by rattling charity collection tins at LA airport, reports Duncan Campbell
fields.trailText: Seven suspected Iranian terrorists have been arrested by the FBI. They are alleged to have bought an impressive arsenal of weapons by rattling charity collection tins at LA airport, reports Duncan Campbell.
fields.body:
Britons arriving at Los Angeles airport are often tickled to hear the public address system telling them earnestly: "You are not required to give money to solicitors."

This is reassuring news to anyone who has had an argument with their lawyer over why they have been billed £185 because the lawyer's secretary made a phone call on their behalf, or because they ended up paying a solicitor a larger sum in fees than they were awarded in a damages action.

But the solicitors you are not required to give money to are those who sidle up in the terminals, usually wearing name-badges, and try to solicit money from passengers. Typically the money is for "homeless children" or "sick children" - certainly always for a seemingly worthy cause. But there has always seemed to be something rather off-putting about the idea of tackling people when they are feeling most flustered and disorientated, either because they are late for a flight or have just arrived on a non-stop from Tokyo.

So there has been no little interest in the arrest by the FBI of seven people alleged to be members of an Iranian terrorist group in LA and said to be supporters of the MEK group that was involved in the take-over of the US embassy in Tehran and the killing of US military and civilian personnel overseas.

An FBI spokesman said that the seven had been targeting visitors arriving at LAX by asking them for money for starving children. The FBI alleges that the money raised was used for the purchase of weapons, including mortars and rockets.

But what was most interesting about the news of the arrests was that those accused were said to be earning up to $5,000 (£3,300) to $10,000 a day through their soliciting.

A few months ago, I spent a day interviewing people who "panhandled" - that kinder, gentler word for begging - in the dot.com area of San Francisco. I learned two very interesting things: first, that the young panhandlers, though they slept under bridges or in parks, kept in touch with each other and their mums by e-mail through free use of public library computers; second, that, even working long hours amidst some of the richest young people in the world and with the least responsibilities, the panhandlers were making barely $6 an hour.

Clearly if they had just put on a suit, got a picture of a small child and approached people staggering red-eyed off the overnight flight from Sydney or Kuala Lumpur they could have increased their earnings 20-fold and started their own dot.com company. (One enterprising chap in San Francisco did have a "sparechange.com" cardboard sign beside him.)

In the meantime, anyone coming to LA who feels guilty about not giving money at the airport should know that there are plenty of deserving souls on Venice Beach or Broadway. They will be only too happy to make good use of your spare dollars and can guarantee that the money is used for nothing more terrifying than an increase in their local liquor store's profits.
