webTitle: Leaders pledge to end use of race card

fields.headline: Leaders pledge to end use of race card
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Election countdown
Special report: Race in Britain
fields.trailText: The leaders of the three main political parties will today sign a pledge vowing not to "use the race card" during the general election campaign.
fields.body:
The leaders of the three main political parties will today sign a pledge vowing not to "use the race card" during the general election campaign.

The historic promise will see the prime minister, Conservative leader William Hague and Liberal Democrat chief Charles Kennedy agree to discipline any activist or candidate who acts in a way "likely to stir up racial prejudice."

The three party chiefs will also be joined by representatives of Plaid Cymru and the SNP.

The scheme - organised by the commission for racial equality - is designed to take race out of the election campaign, expected to be called in the next fortnight for a May 3 polling day.

The move comes despite high-profile criticism of the Tory leader William Hague for a speech in Harrogate promising to "give you your country back."

And he claimed Britain under a Labour second term would become a "foreign land."

The speech - to Conservative party activists - was criticised by even rightwing allies in the press like The Sun and The Times.

Former liberal democrat leader Paddy Ashdown compared it to Enoch Powell's "rivers of blood" speech, and retiring conservative MP Michael Heseltine admitted it made him think twice about voting conservative.

Plaid Cymru has also been criticised recently for an outspoken attack on English people living in Wales.

The leaders will sign the pledge card at a ceremony in the House of Commons after prime minister's questions this afternoon.

fields.headline: Galatasaray fans in Paris violence
fields.trailText: Violence flared at the Parc des Princes last night, with several supporters injured and play suspended for 25 minutes in the Group B match between Paris St-Germain and Galatasaray.
fields.body:
Violence flared at the Parc des Princes last night, with several supporters injured and play suspended for 25 minutes in the Group B match between Paris St-Germain and Galatasaray.

The referee Vitor Manuel Pereira took the players off the pitch on 59 minutes after fighting in the stands. Officials considered calling off the game with PSG leading 2-0 but decided to resume as tempers cooled. There was no further scoring.

The violence began in the Turkish section, seats being ripped out and thrown. Some supporters climbed out of the stands and wandered towards the pitch, clearly bleeding, and two Galatasaray followers ran on to the pitch. Five fans were taken to hospital.

Uefa is expected to comment today, with Galatasaray fans again in trouble after serious clashes with Arsenal and Leeds supporters last season.

There was trouble at the San Siro, too, after Milan were eliminated in drawing 1-1 with Deportivo la Coruna, who took over top spot from Galatasaray.

Riot police fought off dozens of Milan fans who tried to reach the VIP area. Astonishingly, Italy has no club in the last eight of either European competition.

webTitle: A Polish Holocaust tale is finally told

fields.headline: A Holocaust tale is finally told
fields.standfirst: Sixty years after the massacre of a Polish town's Jewish population, the country is confronting uncomfortable truths about its past, writes Kate Connolly
fields.trailText: Sixty years after the massacre of a Polish town's Jewish population, the country is finally confronting uncomfortable truths about its past, writes Kate Connolly.
fields.body:
Viktor Kohav has vivid memories of July 10 1941. He was then 16, and remembers lying in a field of rye "high enough to hide a horse", as harvest time had not arrived.

As he lay still, fearing that even his shallow breaths would give him away, he heard a "whoosh" in the distance as the rabbi's prayer of death was carried on the wind.

"It sounded like the waves pulling on the shore," he still recalls. Then there were the screams, the smoke that he saw darken the sky, followed by the smell of burning flesh.

Viktor had been warned by the school friend of a cousin the day before that the inhabitants of Jedwabne in eastern Poland were planning a massacre of the local Jewish population.

He and his cousins had run into the forest to hide, but Viktor had then fled through the fields to tell his parents, who were visiting another village, not to return to Jedwabne. On the way he was caught by local boys and driven with sticks to the town square, where men, women and children were beaten, before the survivors were marched to a barn.

En route Viktor escaped, outrunning the locals who chased after him. He recalls no Germans being among his persecutors.

As night fell he left the town, never to return. Sixty years on, he says he is still waiting for an apology or "some sort of recognition" for the Polish massacre of 1,600 Jews, among whose victims were his two younger sisters, his mother and father, and grandfather.

A film of the massacre was allegedly made and shown as wartime propaganda material in Warsaw cinemas. Now thanks to a Polish professor of history, the New York-based Jan Gross, Viktor's story along with those of other survivors and those who were murdered, has been set down in a candid book called Neighbours.

The historical account, which gathers statements from eyewitnesses, and turns to the court copy of a 1949 communist-era trial of several townsfolk involved in the massacre, has caused a storm in Poland.

This is not least, many say, because it has forced Poles to confront a few uncomfortable truths about their past. It also seriously damages the image of them as heroes of the war.

The massacre of Jedwabne took place just two weeks after German forces replaced the Soviets, who in September 1939 had invaded eastern Poland.

Some locals claim it was a revenge attack for the Jews' alleged collaboration with the Soviets, who terrorised the Polish population. "They sent us to Siberia," said a local woman last week.

Now in Jedwabne, where there is hardly a trace that the massacre took place bar a communist-era plaque which puts the blame on the Gestapo, reactions are mixed, but mainly dismissive of the claims.

"This wasn't a crime committed by the Polish people," local Catholic priest Edward Orlowski told me. "It was the Germans who killed Jedwabne's Jews, and of course some Poles took part, but that doesn't mean you can put the whole Polish population on trial."

Others however, such as the town's mayor, Krzysztof Godlewski, show a strong willingness to face up to the past.

"We are not the same town anymore," he said. "Asking the town to make peace with its past is tantamount to desecrating its deepest beliefs, of patriotism and Catholicism, and this is difficult."

Mr Godlewski is pushing for the memorial plaque to be corrected, to blame Polish citizens rather than German troops, and for proper care of a victims' mass grave, which lies neglected, in a farmer's field on the edge of the town.

The Polish president, Aleksander Kwasniewski, has also been quick to offer apologies, particularly with the 60th anniversary approaching in a few months.

"In my opinion it is our duty to bring to light not only what happened, but who is responsible for it," he said.

The Warsaw-based Institute of National Remembrance is currently working on an investigation into the events of July 10 1941. Its results are due to be made public in the near future.

Speaking from Warsaw university, where he is currently on a research project, Prof Gross says he hopes his book will help, not hinder, Poland's attempts to come to terms with its past.

"Poland is only in its 12th year without communist rule, so to talk about things like this so openly is still very taboo. Under communism the reality was constructed and most people never realised what had really happened," he says. Now the country needs to start building up a "truthful history," he says.

Viktor, who is now 75 and lives in Tel Aviv, talked non-stop for an hour and a half when I called him at his home. Hardly anyone had been interested in his story until recently when Prof Gross's book was published, he said.

Now, finally, he feels he can find some sense of peace. His grandson downloads stories on the internet from the Polish newspapers which detail the heated discussion the resurrection of the Jedwabne massacre story has sparked in his old homeland, he says.

He still speaks Polish, but the country feels so distant and he says he will never go back. Then he whispers the Polish birth name he renounced so long ago - Viktor Nielrawicki - spelling it out precisely on the crackly line.

fields.headline: Blair announces new 'minister for veterans'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: New Labour in power
Special report: Life in parliament
fields.trailText: A special "minister for veterans" to look after Britain's war heroes is to be created, the prime minister announced this afternoon.
fields.body:
A special "minister for veterans" to look after Britain's war heroes is to be created, the prime minister announced this afternoon.

The new post will look after the affairs of former service personnel from all wars and across all departments of government, Mr Blair told the Commons at prime minister's questions.

The minister, who will work out of the Ministry for Defence, is the current under-secretary of state for Defence, Dr Lewis Moonie.

It is expected the new minister will tackle issues ranging from widow's pensions to the ongoing saga of gulf war syndrome.

A spokesman for the MOD said: "It is time veterans were properly recognised for the great sacrifice they have made. The nation owes it to them to give them what they need - that is exactly what the new minister will do."

The prime minister did not reveal exactly when the new minister will take up his responsibilities, but it is expected to be after the election.

No mention was made of the election during the 30-minute grilling of Tony Blair this afternoon.

Instead, in one of the last sessions before a general election is expected to be called, all three party leaders debated the foot and mouth epidemic.

Tory leader William Hague said the country was "in the grip of a national crisis" and called for the exemption from rates of tourism businesses worst hit by the outbreak.

Mr Blair said ministers would look at "all the measures necessary to help them" and promised a statement on the government's response to the mounting crisis tomorrow.

The government is examining ways of stepping up the slaughter of animals in areas most affected by foot and mouth disease, the prime minister told the Commons. Mr Blair added : "We are using already some final year veterinary students and retirees are important as well. Mr Brown will outline some of the extra measures as to how we also bring in vets from outside.

"We are already using the vets that the army have kindly provided and we do look and see how the armed forces can help with the logistics and the disposal of the animals themselves.

"But I have to say some of the more lurid stories about troops roaming the countryside, shooting animals or wildlife, are simply not the case and wouldn't be helpful. We've already been in contact with, and there are meetings taking place today, with the Ministry of Defence to see how the army can assist in the process that is being carried out.

"It is self evident that if we intensify the process of slaughter we have also got to increase the resources available to carry it out."

webTitle: Consumer: How much can you pay for ... a dressing gown.

fields.headline: How much can you pay for ... a dressing gown
fields.trailText: Enough of Chelsea ladies with nothing to occupy them but lunch and a little light shopping. There are some who don't even get out of bed. The levee where Parisian society courted Duchess Fou-Fou in her boudoir has crossed both the channel and the centuries.
fields.body:
Enough of Chelsea ladies with nothing to occupy them but lunch and a little light shopping. There are some who don't even get out of bed. The levee where Parisian society courted Duchess Fou-Fou in her boudoir has crossed both the channel and the centuries.

But what's a doyenne of SW1 to wear while receiving? Agent Provocateur? Too racy. Fluffy sheep pyjamas? Too Ally McBeal. Thomas Goode dressing gown at £423 a pop? Now we're talking.

Made exclusively for the store by Daniele De Blanzy, the garment has shimmied over from gay Paris itself. Lined in 100% silk and satin, it slithers over the Chanel-scented skin like a dream. The outside fabric comes in ruby and emerald, while the Baroque detail, hand-woven in golden thread on to collars and cuffs is too Dangerous Liaisons for its own good. Worn with a light spray of Aqua di Palma and whomsoever you're greeting - lover, masseur, coiffeur, dog's pedicurist - you can't go wrong. Getting out of bed is so passé after all.

 Thomas Goode, 19 South Audley Street, London, W1. Tel: 020 7499 2823

webTitle: Comment: trying to stub out the smoking habit

fields.headline: Trying to stub out the habit
fields.standfirst: The news that the NHS is to hand out free nicotine patches to people who want to kick the weed is welcomed by serial quitter Amanda Kendal
fields.trailText: The news that the NHS is to hand out free nicotine patches to people who want to kick the weed is welcomed by serial quitter Amanda Kendal.
fields.body:
On national no smoking day, it seems rather shameful to confess that I'm a serial giver-upper and that, as the fag I've just stubbed out proves, I'm currently in a state of relapse.

But having once read that nicotine is harder to quit than heroin, I'm quite ready to believe it.

A couple of years ago, I managed it for 11 months, having started the year with a course of patches. All had been going swimmingly until, like a fool, I thought I was strong enough to accept an offered cigarette over a glass of wine in a bar. How wrong can you be?

Most recently, a domestic spat sent me scurrying to the drawer where the battered remnants of a pack lay in the dark like some security blanket, waiting to be picked up and embraced once more.

It's not that I don't want to pack it in. And one day, I know I'll finally kick the dreaded weed.

Today's news that the NHS is going to offer more help to people who want to quit is welcome.

The decision to provide nicotine patches for the £6 cost of a prescription (free for those who are exempt from prescription charges) is an acknowledgement that smokers who want to give up need constructive support, not simply a stern warning about the health ramifications of their habit.

I hate being in hock to the damned things. I may draw deeply on the sacred first cigarette of the day, but the hacking cough in the middle of the night is a constant reminder that these things aren't doing me any good.

Giving up isn't straightforward. I know. It's all too easy to reach for the packet if something's going slightly awry with your day, or to convince yourself that one more won't make any difference.

It costs a fortune, but no matter how much respective chancellors have increased the price over the years, with each hike I initially say I'm going to jack it in - and then continue to fund my addiction.

There's no social kudos to be gained from smoking. I started at such a late age - 26 - that it wasn't even a case of trying to look good in front of my peers.

I shall smoke throughout today. Designating it as some special day makes no difference. But I'll wake up tomorrow - or some day - in the right frame of mind to throw away all the ashtrays, lighters and other accoutrements, and finally prove that I can really kick the habit.

fields.headline: Regional government: the basics
fields.trailText: • Labour committed itself to elected regional government for those areas of England that wanted it in the 1997 general election manifesto, but set no timetable. The new parliaments would be introduced only where people voted for them in referendums.
fields.body:
 Labour committed itself to elected regional government for those areas of England that wanted it in the 1997 general election manifesto, but set no timetable. The new parliaments would be introduced only where people voted for them in referendums.

 The government has since made little progress on the issue. But ministers have created several new regional bodies, including the Greater London Authority, the eight regional development agencies and unelected regional assemblies to scrutinise the agencies.

 Deputy prime minister John Prescott is the main cabinet-level supporter of regional government. He apparently promised a green paper on the issue at Labour's spring conference, and many commentators believe the move is now inevitable.

 Supporters argue that regional government would boost democracy, give voters more control of the regional economy and give regional politicians more clout when bargaining for funds at the national and European levels, as well as when dealing with investors.

 The 1997 Labour manifesto said regional government would have powers over transport, planning, economic development, land use planning and bids for European funding. However, some campaigners want to go even further.

webTitle: Scared silly: Controversial author Frank Furedi argues that irrational fear about children's safety is turning us into control freaks.

fields.headline: Scared silly
fields.standfirst: In his book Paranoid Parenting, controversial author Frank Furedi argues that irrational fear about children's safety is turning us into control freaks. Kids need their own space and parents need to chill, he tells  Joanna Moorhead
fields.trailText: In his book Paranoid Parenting, controversial author Frank Furedi argues that irrational fear about children's safety is turning us into control freaks. Kids need their own space and parents need to chill, he tells Joanna Moorhead.
fields.body:
Frank Furedi is not a relaxed parent. He can be laid-back about some things: his five-year-old son, Jacob, is encouraged to play in the woods near their family home, and Furedi hopes he will soon be able to cycle to school. But when it comes to illness, Furedi frets. He worries about his son's health. He can even quote you Jacob's temperature when he was last poorly. In short, he is paranoid - in common with all parents, he maintains.

"We all have our vulnerabilities, our areas of concern, our fears," says Furedi. "We all have something that can be played on and opened up, and which then becomes the basis of fear in our parenting."

So, Furedi is on a mission: he wants to make us aware of our paranoia so we can all cool it and be a bit more rational where looking after our kids is concerned. Thus the message of his new book, Paranoid Parenting, is: stop listening to the "experts"; tear up the handbook; and follow your instincts - where your child is concerned, you know best.

Of course, there is a certain paradox to all this, since Furedi himself is a type of expert - a sociologist at the University of Kent - and before you follow his advice never to read another parenting book, he would love you to buy this one. His ideas were formed, he says, after he became a father at the relatively advanced age of 48, and discovered that parenting had changed rather a lot in the decades between his own boyhood and that of his son.

In particular, what he noticed was that children were no longer left to their own devices. He describes it as a "colonisation" of the world of children by adults. As a consequence, he says, adults not only inhabit but control the lives of children to an alarming and unhealthy extent.

For Furedi, whose 1997 book The Culture of Fear examined the way risk is perceived in society, the most obvious manifestation of this control centres on fears about children's safety. The real risks, he argues, are magnified by irrational fears; and so kids' freedom and creativity are being limited. While Jacob is encouraged to play outside the Furedis' home in Faversham, Kent, many children are kept indoors - out of harm's way. But the harm, Furedi would have us believe, is largely imagined: yes, we read a lot about child abduction, murder and paedophilia, but the risks to our own children from these evils are minuscule. Our fears are fed by study after alarm-bell-ringing study alerting us to this or that childhood danger. Furedi disputes the idea that most of these studies originate in universities like his own. In fact, he says, many are market research reports masquerading as more serious analyses. The media are the villains of the piece, and here there is a whiff of Furedi's past as a member of the Revolutionary Communist Party, whose magazine Living Marxism had an unerring instinct for controversy and an abiding contempt for the "bourgeois press". But the result, he says, is a generation of parents who believe that their children are at real risk, and who are overreacting in their efforts to protect them.

"When I ask people why they limit their children's activities in a particular way," says Furedi, "they always say, 'I couldn't live with myself if anything happened.' In other words, they're talking about themselves, not about their children."

All this worry, he believes, is casting a shadow over family life. Take cot death, for example. Furedi says that when he and his wife, Ann, were expecting Jacob, the risks of cot death were often mentioned. "Every mother I know admits to having worried at some point that their child is at risk," he notes. "It's emblematic of the campaign that we've created."

The effect of this climate of fear on parents is exacerbated by the fact that more and more is expected from them, argues Furedi: "Take education: today's parents are expected to be amateur teachers, involved in every part of their children's schoolwork. It's certainly not enough to leave it to the school. I think that degrades education, because it means politicians can ignore the problems of schools.

"What I'm saying is that we've established this culture in which parents have a direct sense of responsibility for everything that happens to their children. What this means is that we've lost our autonomy."

Furedi thinks that because we now feel we have to take responsibility for every part of our children's lives, we take every threat to their safety too seriously. "It's not worth altering your behaviour and being on red alert for what are relatively small risks," he maintains. "We've got to accept that life contains risks and it's far better to be aware of them than to let them enslave our lives."

The counter-argument to all this is that today's parents are more knowledgeable about certain areas of parenting and more involved in their children's lives than parents in the 50s and 60s. But Furedi is having none of this. First, he says, it is naive to argue that the information we are being fed about, say, health risks in pregnancy is widening our choice or improving our parenting; in fact they often lead to enforced conformity. "Take the US, where in some areas pregnant women can be arrested for drinking in public," he says. "What begins as advice ends up as coercion."

Furedi concedes that there may be a positive aspect to parents being more involved in the lives of their children, but adds that: "The danger is, it becomes compulsive. What starts as involvement becomes this infinite process, and you lose the ability to draw a line between what your children should be doing on their own and what adults should be doing."

Furedi describes his own childhood - he grew up in Hungary in the 50s - as a happy one, despite a lack of material wealth and a father who had to work a 60-hour week. Interestingly, he admits that his mother, who had survived imprisonment in a concentration camp, was overprotective. His own desire to be hands-off about Jacob's upbringing, and to persuade the rest of us to take the same approach, is at least partly a reaction to that. "Our own parents probably did a reasonable job given the constraints they were under, and I don't think it's helpful to criticise them."

Furedi denies that he is harking back to a golden age when parents left their kids to get on with growing up and did not meddle so much (although it is difficult to dismiss entirely the thought that, somewhere inside, he does believe that today's kids are worse off than previous generations). What he says is that there is no model from the past for good practice in parenting: every generation has to deal with the difficulties around it and do the best it can. But the bottom line is: if we stopped trying so hard, we would make a better job of bringing up our kids - and if we ignored most of the advice we are bombarded with, we would do a better job still.

 Paranoid Parenting by Frank Furedi is published by Penguin Press. Readers can order a copy for £9.99 including first-class UK p&p. Freephone 0800 3166 102 or send your order with a UK cheque, payable to The Guardian, to 32-34 Park Royal Road, London, NW10 7LN.

Thus the message of his new book, Paranoid Parenting, is: stop listening to the "experts"; tear up the handbook; and follow your instincts - where your child is concerned, you know best. Of course, there is a certain paradox to all this, since Furedi himself is a type of expert - a sociologist at the University of Kent - and before you follow his advice never to read another parenting book, he would love you to buy this one. His ideas were formed, he says, after he became a father at the relatively advanced age of 48, and discovered that parenting had changed rather a lot in the decades between his own boyhood and that of his son. In particular, what he noticed was that children were no longer left to their own devices. He describes it as a "colonisation" of the world of children by adults. As a consequence, he says, adults not only inhabit but control the lives of children to an alarming and unhealthy extent. For Furedi, whose 1997 book The Culture of Fear examined the way risk is perceived in society, the most obvious manifestation of this control centres on fears about children's safety. The real risks, he argues, are magnified by irrational fears; and so kids' freedom and creativity are being limited. While Jacob is encouraged to play outside the Furedis' home in Faversham, Kent, many children are kept indoors - out of harm's way. But the harm, Furedi would have us believe, is largely imagined: yes, we read a lot about child abduction, murder and paedophilia, but the risks to our own children from these evils are minuscule. Our fears are fed by study after alarm-bell-ringing study alerting us to this or that childhood danger. Furedi disputes the idea that most of these studies originate in universities like his own. In fact, he says, many are market research reports masquerading as more serious analyses. The media are the villains of the piece, and here there is a whiff of Furedi's past as a member of the Revolutionary Communist Party, whose magazine Living Marxism had an unerring instinct for controversy and an abiding contempt for the "bourgeois press". But the result, he says, is a generation of parents who believe that their children are at real risk, and who are overreacting in their efforts to protect them. "When I ask people why they limit their children's activities in a particular way," says Furedi, "they always say, 'I couldn't live with myself if anything happened.' In other words, they're talking about themselves, not about their children." All this worry, he believes, is casting a shadow over family life. Take cot death, for example. Furedi says that when he and his wife, Ann, were expecting Jacob, the risks of cot death were often mentioned. "Every mother I know admits to having worried at some point that their child is at risk," he notes. "It's emblematic of the campaign that we've created." The effect of this climate of fear on parents is exacerbated by the fact that more and more is expected from them, argues Furedi: "Take education: today's parents are expected to be amateur teachers, involved in every part of their children's schoolwork. It's certainly not enough to leave it to the school. I think that degrades education, because it means politicians can ignore the problems of schools. "What I'm saying is that we've established this culture in which parents have a direct sense of responsibility for everything that happens to their children. What this means is that we've lost our autonomy." Furedi thinks that because we now feel we have to take responsibility for every part of our children's lives, we take every threat to their safety too seriously. "It's not worth altering your behaviour and being on red alert for what are relatively small risks," he maintains. "We've got to accept that life contains risks and it's far better to be aware of them than to let them enslave our lives." The counter-argument to all this is that today's parents are more knowledgeable about certain areas of parenting and more involved in their children's lives than parents in the 50s and 60s. But Furedi is having none of this. First, he says, it is naive to argue that the information we are being fed about, say, health risks in pregnancy is widening our choice or improving our parenting; in fact they often lead to enforced conformity. "Take the US, where in some areas pregnant women can be arrested for drinking in public," he says. "What begins as advice ends up as coercion." Furedi concedes that there may be a positive aspect to parents being more involved in the lives of their children, but adds that: "The danger is, it becomes compulsive. What starts as involvement becomes this infinite process, and you lose the ability to draw a line between what your children should be doing on their own and what adults should be doing." Furedi describes his own childhood - he grew up in Hungary in the 50s - as a happy one, despite a lack of material wealth and a father who had to work a 60-hour week. Interestingly, he admits that his mother, who had survived imprisonment in a concentration camp, was overprotective. His own desire to be hands-off about Jacob's upbringing, and to persuade the rest of us to take the same approach, is at least partly a reaction to that. "Our own parents probably did a reasonable job given the constraints they were under, and I don't think it's helpful to criticise them." Furedi denies that he is harking back to a golden age when parents left their kids to get on with growing up and did not meddle so much (although it is difficult to dismiss entirely the thought that, somewhere inside, he does believe that today's kids are worse off than previous generations). What he says is that there is no model from the past for good practice in parenting: every generation has to deal with the difficulties around it and do the best it can. But the bottom line is: if we stopped trying so hard, we would make a better job of bringing up our kids - and if we ignored most of the advice we are bombarded with, we would do a better job still.  Paranoid Parenting by Frank Furedi is published by Penguin Press. Readers can order a copy for £9.99 including first-class UK p&p. Freephone 0800 3166 102 or send your order with a UK cheque, payable to The Guardian, to 32-34 Park Royal Road, London, NW10 7LN.

webTitle: Home rules? A report out today suggests working mothers harm their kids' education.

fields.headline: Home rules?
fields.standfirst: A report out today suggests working mothers harm their kids' education.  Kate Figes takes it with a pinch of salt
fields.trailText: A report out today suggests working mothers harm their kids' education. Kate Figes takes it with a pinch of salt.
fields.body:
The perpetual onslaught against working mothers rears its ugly head again today with the publication of a study from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation which implies that under-fives with full-time working mothers are less likely to grow up into successful A-level students than those whose mothers work part-time or stay at home. The research has found that those who didn't work increased the chances of their children getting one A-level by 12%, while those who worked part time increased their children's chances by 6%.

All research needs to be treated with scepticism. This was a study of 1,236 people born in the 1970s, when times were very different. Working mothers were rarer; high-quality daycare was almost nonexistent; and our knowledge of the psychological development of under-fives was scant. There were no early music classes, no dance or drama workshops, and few nursery schools with Montessori equipment encouraging the basic learning skills that we take for granted today.

A great deal happens in children's lives between the ages of five and 18 that can affect their attitudes to education; without knowing their individual life stories, it is hard to tell surely whether they would have dropped out or failed A-levels anyway. It is obvious, but no less striking, that the children of educated working mothers stood a better chance of getting A-levels than those lower down the social scale.

John Ermisch, co-author of the report with Marco Francesconi at the University of Essex, agrees that other factors inevitably influence educational outcomes: "There are a lot of other things that you can't control, but I was a bit surprised by the size of the difference. My preconception was that what parents did with their time when they were not working would muddy the waters so much that the difference would be less."

For every research paper that suggests working motherhood damages children, others indicate more positive effects on the social and cognitive development of children. At the Institute of Child Health, Ian Roberts con ducted a systematic review of childcare research and found that, on balance, it was good for children, provided they were in high-quality care. A trained nursery worker, able to stimulate and excite a child with a wide variety of educational toys for part of the day, is likely to be of far greater benefit than a bored or preoccupied full-time mother who plonks the baby in front of the television for hours at a time. Other research indicates that stay-at-home mothers are more likely to be depressed and feel isolated. Depressed mothers interact far less with their babies, which is in itself a developmental downer.

When this research is put into the wider context of what is happening within education, whether or not mothers are working must surely be secondary to what is happening within our schools. Educational standards are higher than ever for those children who manage to stay the course, and unprecedented numbers of young people now go on to some form of higher education. But, at the other end of the scale, rising numbers of disaffected children fail to see the point of getting an education at all when both of their parents are unemployed (presumably with their mother at home) and they live on run-down estates where the schools struggle to buy books and keep their charges in the classroom.

From pre-conception onwards, parents are bombarded with research that centres on the welfare of their children and the way that parents can unwittingly damage them. At best, parents feel confused about the implications. Most, however, feel a great deal worse. They feel they are to blame for every minor mistake, for eating the wrong foods or living with too much stress while pregnant, guilty about opting for a caesarean rather than a natural birth, guilty about preferring reading the newspaper to engaging in vigorous interactive play with their toddler, and guilty about going back to work when most have little choice but to do so.

Yet other research has shown that, despite our guilt (or perhaps because of it), parents today are spending more "quality time" with their children than ever before. Jonathan Gershuny - by coincidence, a sociologist also based at the University of Essex - found that even full-time employed women in 1995 devoted more time to childcare than non-employed mothers did in 1961. Meanwhile, as Ermisch is willing to concede, we still do not have a systematic overview of what constitutes good childcare: "Society can do a great deal to make it easier for mothers to stay at home more when their children are small, but I'm less clear about what the individual can do. Psychologists don't have the answers either on the best types of childcare; the jury is still out on that."

Clearly, we could do with more research.

webTitle: The panel: New research shows poorer children are more likely to be victims of road accidents. How can we make roads safer?

fields.headline: The panel
fields.standfirst: New research shows poorer children are more likely to be victims of road accidents. How can we make roads safer?
fields.trailText: New research shows poorer children are more likely to be victims of road accidents. How can we make roads safer?
fields.body:
Andrew Howard, Head of road safety at the AA

Campaigners lobbying for safer roads in villages and market towns talk about "an accident waiting to happen", but in more deprived inner cities these accidents happen all the time. It's not just about 10mph speed limits, home zones and places where the motorist is always wrong; it's also about road design. Pedestrians often have to cross between parked cars because older houses were not designed with cars in mind; nor were long, straight roads, which allow motorists to pick up speed quickly. We need to direct resources to where they are needed most, not just to those who lobby most.
Verdict: Target resources

Tony Bosworth, Friends of the Earth Transport Campaign

Speed limits need to be reduced to 20mph. We would like to see the introduction of home zones: networks of residential streets where pedestrians have priority even on the roads. The government should also invest more money in safe routes to school. A lot of children have to cross busy roads to get to school and local authority planners need to work with children and schools to find the safest routes for walking and cycling to school. Many parents won't let their children walk to school because of busy roads, but in some areas up to 20% of peak-time traffic is because of the school run.
Verdict: Home zones

Mike McDonnell, Road safety manager for RoSPA

If you live in a poorer area you are four times as likely to be a victim of a road accident than if you live in a more affluent area. Often in poorer areas, there are fewer safe places to play so many children play in the street. And because car ownership is lower, there are fewer cars on the road, which means they can drive at faster speeds and do more damage when they hit children. The road needs to be shared between different road users; everyone has a right to use the road space safely. Standards of driving need to improve and care should be taken when driving to keep speeds down.
Verdict: Slow down

Paul Osborne, Spokesman for Safe Routes to School

It is very important that road safety should be given a much higher priority in schools, along with cycle training. We have been asked to distribute money from the lottery-backed new opportunities fund to improve road safety awareness in schools, and we are focusing on the most deprived areas. There needs to be a lot more emphasis on getting children involved. Road safety can be improved by a walking school bus, where parents take turns to walk a group of about 10 children to school, picking children up along the way, so parents do not have to drive their children to school.
Verdict: Walking buses

Sally Barrett, Psychologist and parent

Sometimes I drive my children to school and sometimes we walk. Although parents know it is polluting and antisocial to drive, I think it will continue until there are more initiatives from the government and others to reduce the number of cars on the road. I think one of the keys to road safety for children is to allow them to decide when it is safe to cross the road supervised by a parent for a few years before they do it by themselves, in the hope that after years of practice they will be sensible. It's an ongoing process of raising their awareness about road safety.
Verdict: Parental training

Martin Barnes, Director of the Child Poverty Action Group

Poverty is the most serious problem affecting the welfare of children today. Poverty is not just about having a low income but also the quality of life and the home and community environment. The link between poverty and child health and well-being is strong. Injury (as opposed to illness) is the main cause of death among children, and those from lower-income families are particularly vulnerable. If they live far from playgrounds, there is more danger that they will be involved in a pedestrian accident. An estimated 1,400 lives could be saved every year if child poverty were eradicated.
Verdict: End child poverty

webTitle: Yawn chorus: A survey says babies wreck relationships by depriving us of sleep.  Joanna Briscoe recalls six months of hell.

fields.headline: Yawn chorus
fields.standfirst: A survey says babies wreck relationships by depriving us of sleep.  Joanna Briscoe recalls six months of hell
fields.trailText: A survey says babies wreck relationships by depriving us of sleep. Joanna Briscoe recalls six months of hell.
fields.body:
Hurrah! Here comes another costly and statistic-bristling survey to tell us what we all know already. Its conclusion? "Babies wreck relationships and working life." In one giddy hurdle, the horror leaps from the anecdotal to the official.

So, according to Mother & Baby magazine's Sleep Survey 2001, 81% of mothers say lack of sleep puts immense strain on their relationship, while 88% of those who have to return to work say they feel "fed up, exhausted, and pulled in too many directions". More than half of the 2,000 mothers questioned claimed that tiredness leaves them in a "state of despair and desperation". During the first four months, mothers get an average of less than four hours' sleep.

Yes! Others have suffered too. I'm so glad. Because, let's face it, the world is full of smug liars whose little Ellas and Milos "sleep through" from nine weeks of age. Rubbish! When questioned aggressively, nay hysterically by me, the truth starts leaking out. It seems that "sleeping through", that stock favourite in the specialist field of mother-and-baby lingo - along with "falling pregnant" and "on solids" - can mean three hours. That 2.30am "drink" - of boiled water? Of rosehip tea? - is, in fact, milk. Ah, right. So young Morpheus sleeps through with a feed or two before waking at 5am. Otherwise known as not sleeping through at all.

You'd think the liars would want to bond over eyelash tics, sobbing fits and exhaustion-induced nausea, for example - like one's more human and evolved friends. But no. The prodigy competition is kickstarted in the womb, you understand.

Nevertheless, I felt I had given birth to a hyperactive insomniac. After a pregnancy spent eating organic broccoli, I landed myself a tartrazine kid. Nowadays, the lad is a genius in the art of slumber, but for the first six-and-a-half months it was not so. My own set of figurelets, my own two-person survey, is etched with horrible accuracy upon my memory. For the first three weeks he usually stayed awake all night. He then bawled, grizzled and whimpered between most two-hourly feeds. Upon learning to doze with a lactose hit, he still woke with the same promptitude. All day. All night. And then suddenly - no gentle gradation in his little sleep graph - he slept all night.

So indeed, Mother & Baby, sleep deprivation does rather tend to wreck one's life. "It's used as a form of torture, you know," people would inform me brightly as I sat there in a grey and slack-jawed haze. Yes, yes, as if we didn't all bloody know that.

My partner and I were actually united in shock. But we felt as though we walked side by side without touching through a strange fog-filled land. A land of separate beds, breast pumps, expressed bottle shifts, cot-death fixation, £40-worth of sleep manuals, rare sex and a physical obstacle between us at all times.

Early on, the insomnia carries a strange kick. Two months in, I was on a feverish high: buzzy, chocolate-addicted and oestrogen-flushed. Then the crash comes. At four months, we dropped our baby. The paediatrician in A&E pointed a strict finger at me and said: "He's all right; you're not."

We read Dr Richard Ferber with the piteous optimism of the zealot; we tried sleep training, formula bottles, white noise and dark curtains. Later, it's so easy to forget. I recall it only by the physical symptoms: black spots in front of the eyes, faint hallucinations, the fear of actual vomiting, the whole body a vibrating, empty chamber of panic. Your head is composed of shifting sand. Your mind is grainy, buzzing, separated from the world by a layer of scum. It functions only for the obsessive calculation of available sleep.

Older parents helpfully explain that one must let babies cry all night in their knitted bootees. Yet abject expertise in cot-death prevention forbids one from carting the cot next door. Work becomes torment. Sleep becomes sex, food, love, soap operas all rolled into one - the only need.

What we failed to understand was: a) there's little you can do to make the buggers sleep before they're ready; and b) it gets better.

I'm happy to establish that our hyperactive insomniac was, in fact, a fairly normal hyperactive insomniac. But, to all those triumphant bastards who made us feel like weeping freaks, I'd just like to say that he now sleeps 11 hours a night. Ha ha ha.

webTitle: Over 'ere son, on me arm. Jim White charts the rise and rise of the new footballing dad.

fields.headline: Over 'ere son, on me arm
fields.standfirst: British men have named David Beckham the perfect role model for first-time fathers.  Jim White charts the rise and rise of the new footballing dad
fields.trailText: British men have named David Beckham the perfect role model for first-time fathers. Jim White charts the rise and rise of the new footballing dad.
fields.body:
"Posh blasts Becks over Brooklyn." Never mind foot and mouth, train crashes or the impending election - this was the Sunday Mirror's front-page banner headline a couple of weekends ago. It came above a fanciful tale - sourced from that great standby of desperate newsdesks, "a close friend" - of an alleged transatlantic mobile-phone row between Britain's unofficial royal couple over childcare. While his wife was in America on a promotional tour, David Beckham had apparently spent a day off playing paintball with his chums, leaving the boy Brooklyn in the care of his mother-in-law. Posh was, so the story claimed, furious, and angrily reminded him of his parental priorities. The close friend concluded that tension would be high on her return as the couple prepared for the biggest social event of their calendar year: their boy's birthday party.

Phew! We're lucky that this in-depth piece of investigative reporting didn't gain wider currency. Otherwise it might well have affected the survey of men, conducted this week by Norwich Union Healthcare, which found that Beckham is their ideal role model as a first-time father. Becks triumphed in the poll, which also reckoned Liam Gallagher to be the worst kind of dad. This has been a bad week for the Oasis singer and polls: GQ magazine's April edition pronounced Gallagher the worst-dressed man in Britain, which was a rather dramatic fall from grace since he was voted the best-dressed man last year.

Any poll involving celebrity is generally about as scientifically well-founded as Nick Brown's assertion that the foot and mouth crisis is under control. Most respondents simply mention the first star that enters their head. Thus Beckham and Gallagher would be certain to feature in any survey, from "Which celebrity is most likely to be a closet homosexual?" to "If a plane of celebrities crashed on a desert island, who would be the first to suggest cannibalism?"

Even so, the news that Beckham is regarded as a good dad has some resonance with the truth. Despite his alleged paintballing lapse, every image we have of him and his son together is positive. His is a very tactile approach to the boy: photographs reveal him forever hugging and kissing his son, film footage shows him breaking into a broad smile and lifting the boy on to his shoulders whenever Brooklyn waddles into view. What's more, he has the lad's name tattooed across the small of his back - a space that is going to get very crowded if he has as many children as he has threatened. And while media manipulation may well be involved here, you could not fake the easy familiarity that he exhibits towards his child. He looks every inch a natural dad.

Besides, it is worth remembering that this is a man who has put his child before his work, to the point of getting himself a bollocking from the boss. Back in December 1999, Beckham failed to turn up for training at Manchester United because, he said, his son was ill. His manager, Sir Alex Ferguson - not a man, you suspect, who would have stayed at home when young Darren was running a temperature - was apoplectic. Beckham, he said, had to refocus his priorities: work was what counted; everything else had to fall in behind it. Footballers, after all, are not exactly bereft of free time in which to bond with their offspring. Many newspaper columnists - not all of them women - sided with Beckham. They applauded his behaviour and welcomed the way it opened up a debate about why it is always the female half of a working couple who is obliged to take time off when their child is ill. It was an argument that many stuck to even when the press printed photographs of Victoria Beckham out clothes-shopping in London on the very day the boy was snuffly.

The battle of Brooklyn's snotty nose was weighed down by much baggage, not least Ferguson's Presbyterian disdain for the flimflam of his player's celebrity lifestyle. It was as much about wasting time and energy on OK! photo shoots as it was about nappy-changing. The row nevertheless highlighted a generational gap in football over the issue of children. Ferguson is the first to admit that he did not watch his own three sons grow up. He left the day-to-day parenting duties to his wife, Cathy. That's what men of his generation and background did: they devoted themselves to their career, and filed everything else under "women's work". Rarely, if ever, did the children intrude on their ambitions.

But for the next generation in football, kids have become a badge of pride, to be celebrated and shown off. At last year's FA Cup final, Chelsea's Dennis Wise became the first captain in history to lift the trophy in one hand while holding his baby in the other. He had carried his infant son, Henry, up the steps to Wembley's royal box, wanting the lad to be there with him at the big moment. In his Chelsea shirt with the word Daddy embroidered across the shoulders, the boy Wise looked sweet, if a little bemused. No doubt he will look back on his first final like many a participant and claim it passed him all by. Logged deep in his memory bank, it will appear to be no more than routine: had bottle, filled nappy, dad lifted FA Cup.

Yet many commentators thought Wise's gesture an affront to the dignity of the FA Cup. You couldn't help feeling, listening to the grouches complaining, that what they were most worried about was the unholy intrusion of womanly things - you know, babies - into a male preserve. For the rest of us, it showed a somewhat unexpected side of a man generally renowned for his thuggishness. If anything, Wise went up in the country's collective estimation.

And last weekend, another psychological victory was won for the new footballing dad. The Wycombe Wanderers player Steve Brown celebrated the goal that took his lowly club to the semifinal of the FA Cup by removing his shirt. He was promptly sent off. But what made the referee's action not so much petty as heartless was that Brown had taken off his shirt to reveal, scrawled on his vest, a message to his critically ill 15-month-old-son, Maxwell. "Wyked", the Sun's front page called the incident. All day on Monday, Brown conducted back-to-back media interviews about it. And how did he choose to celebrate his new-found celebrity? With the toddler happily gurgling on his knee.

Beckham is going to have to pull off some coup to retain his position as number-one role-model dad with that sort of competition. Taking the boy Brooklyn with him next time he goes paintballing might just do the trick.

fields.headline: Training the voluntary sector
fields.standfirst: Project 2001 enables volunteers to acheive formal recognition for the skills they gain through their work, writes Adam Woolf
fields.trailText: Project 2001 enables volunteers to acheive formal recognition for the skills they gain through their work, writes Adam Woolf.
fields.body:
Most people know Jon Snow. He presents the news each night on Channel 4. Yet few people know that before he embarked on his career as a television newscaster he ran a day centre for young homeless people.

Mr Snow revealed this at the recent Learning and Skills in the Voluntary Sector: Priorities for Action conference, hosted by the Voluntary Sector National Training Organisation and the Royal Society of Arts (RSA).

Mr Snow explained what happened when he left his post. "Although I'd been there for three years, I left with no qualifications and no recognition of my skills. All I had was my CV saying I'd done the job".

Although the voluntary sector has grown tremendously since the early 1970s, almost 30 years later many staff - both paid and volunteers - still experience similar problems when it comes to the issues of training, support and securing recognition and qualifications for their skills.

Today, it is a multi-million pound industry. There are around 166,000 charities employing 512,000 paid staff. The sector accounts for almost 2% of UK gross domestic product and around 2.2% of its workforce. Yet 75% of voluntary organisations have no paid staff. Three million people regularly volunteer.

In 1996 the RSA wanted to address this problem. It established a pilot project which - two years later - became Project 2001. The project aims to enable volunteers to achieve formal recognition for the skills they gain through their work. The conference was presented with Project 2001's final report.

The project worked with small community based organisations in London, Yorkshire and the Humber. It looked to support individuals by helping them gain qualifications, and enabling the organisation itself to develop to its full potential. A hundred projects were selected in each region, and each was offered three days of free advice. They were also given a grant of up to £2,000. The services of a mentor were also put at their disposal.

Janet Fleming, Project 2001 director, explained that the main problem for most of these community groups was a lack of time to develop training. "People were too busy on their own workload and concentrating on service delivery."

Rather than simply offering training courses and accreditation schemes to these groups, Project 2001 advisers worked closely with them to identity the right courses and qualifications, as well as helping with funding.

Ms Fleming said: "There was hard evidence that this model of offering advice, coupled with grants, yields results."

More than 1,000 volunteers in over 200 organisations achieved qualifications. The organisations themselves also benefited. Sixty per cent now have motivated volunteers; 80% have increased the confidence of their volunteers and staff; and more than half (57%) have improved the quality of their services.

Ms Fleming called on the new Learning and Skills Council - which on April 1 takes over the responsibility of all training and learning for everyone over the age of 16 in England - to provide similar support and funding for voluntary organisations in the future.

She also called on funders to place more importance on training. "Funders like innovative projects. But these are not sustainable if they don't support the people who will deliver the projects. Details about training and accreditation need to become an integral part of all funding applications".

Delegates at the conference backed these findings. Alison Chambers, of the voluntary sector unit of the community council for Hereford and Worcester, was particularly keen on this model.

"We have offered management training in the past. People come, do the training and then disappear. We have never had the opportunity to follow up and see if the training is effective. This is a very practical model."

Karen Cole, human resources manager of the National Schizophrenia Fellowship, said, "It is encouraging to think that the voluntary sector is now beginning to demand rights to train staff and volunteers. In the past they have been left out in the cold".

fields.headline: Managers benefit from Project 2001
fields.standfirst: Mandy Asquith tells Adam Woolf how Project 2001 helped her get the management skills she needed to enhance her organisation
fields.trailText: Mandy Asquith tells Adam Woolf how Project 2001 helped her get the management skills she needed to enhance her organisation.
fields.body:
Just over 10 years ago Mandy Asquith was going through a tough time. She had recently been divorced and was bringing up children on her own. She felt unable to work full time because of her childcare commitments. Even so, she really wanted to do something that would get her out of the house and stop her from feeling isolated.

One day when she was visiting the doctor she noticed a poster up on the noticeboard in the surgery. It was from an organisation called Wakefield Riding for the Disabled. It needed volunteers to help out.

Ms Asquith had done a fair bit of horse riding in the past. As she had the necessary experience with horses she thought, "Why not?". She was initially asked to commit only one hour a week and and has not looked back since.

"The one hour soon become 37 or 38 hours a week. I was quickly roped in," she explained. "At first I was only paid £2O a week. Any more and I would have lost my benefit. But for the last five years I've been paid full time as a manager."

"The job's great. I really loved it. The only trouble was I did not have any training, and certainly none in management issues." Ms Asquith had two staff to manage and up to eight volunteers at any one time.

There was too much for her to do on a day-to-day basis. "Working with horses means that you can never predict exactly what is going to happen. Even so, the horse side of things was fine, and the riders were enjoying the riding. But I still got the sense that we were always managing a crisis. We were working one day to the next. We never really got anywhere because I did not have time to plan ahead."

Ms Asquith was impressed by the adviser from the Project 2001 team who came to see her.

"She was really great. It was obvious to her that if the organisation was ever going to move forward and grow, I needed to go on management training," she says. "She suggested I took an NVQ in management, which a Project 2001 grant would pay for."

Ms Asquith had to travel from Wakefield to York one afternoon a month to take the course which was run by the Advisory Council for Voluntary Organisations. She enjoyed it tremendously.

"It was so inspirational. Most of the people on the course were like me. They were women with kids. It was brilliant to know there were others dealing with the same problems and same issues. "

Now Ms Asquith has an NVQ4 in management. Both she and Wakefield Riders for the Disabled have benefited from this training.

"It is now much easier to spot problems early and deal with them before they become a big issue. It has also made me much more confident in my abilities. We have also been able to improve our communications with other local organisations. This has raised our profile locally."

Ms Asquith stressed that her training has not just benefited her personally, but has helped the whole organisation to develop. "I've learnt to plan and prioritise and concentrate on the key issues for the organisation. Things are now really happening. We have produced a handbook which shows how to train people who want to be riding instructors for disabled people. We have distributed this guide to 600 groups. It is now going to be used nationally."

Ms Asquith herself has volunteered to be a mentor for other management trainees from the voluntary sector.

"I learnt a lot from other people when I was on the course. Hopefully, I can now pass on my experience to help others."

fields.standfirst: He may still look as if he's barely into double figures but Dennis the Menace has hit his 50th birthday. Here's our guide to the best sites on the middle-aged terror
fields.trailText: He may still look as if he's barely into double figures but Dennis the Menace has hit his 50th birthday. Here's our guide to the best sites on the middle-aged terror.
fields.body:
1. Dennis the Menace is Britain's longest surviving comic villain and star of the Beano, and there is no sign that his notorious conduct is improving with age.

2. Dennis, who boasts a fan club of 1.5m members, is famous for his spiky hair and striped jersey, and is the unlovable horror who ultimately became the star of his own TV cartoon, with voices by Hugh Laurie and Billy Connolly.

3. Dennis first burst onto the pages of the Beano in mid-March 1951, amid - according to editor Euan Kerr - fears among social workers that his atrocious behaviour might have a bad influence on children.

4. Despite its age, the comic strip keeps up with modern events and featured Brooklyn Beckham as a football playing tot. And, for its 3,000th edition in January 2000, 4,000 readers chose Geri Halliwell to appear with the man they thought was most like Dennis - her beau of that week, DJ Chris Evans.

5. Dennis was an overnight success and was followed by Minnie the Minx and the Bash Street Kids. But it was not until 17 years later that Dennis's evil dog, Gnasher, described as a fierce, stray Abyssinian wire-haired tripehound, appeared on the scene.

7. Gnasher's claim to fame was that he had "teeth so tough they can bite clean through solid granite and even make a dent in a British Rail sandwich". There was pandemonium in 1986 when Gnasher went missing for six weeks. But he returned: with six pups.

9. On his arrival in 1951, Dennis was billed as "the world's wildest boy". And in 1976, the hugely successful Dennis the Menace Fan Club was launched. It included Gnasher's Fang Club.

10. It was in 1996 that Dennis became a TV celebrity as a walking, talking star on the BBC. He has also ventured into cyberspace, as the star of Beanoland on the Beano website, as well as figuring on masses of merchandise for his millions of fans, who hold online auctions.

webTitle: Human Rights Act: the issue explained

fields.headline: Human Rights Act: the issue explained
fields.trailText: The Human Rights Act 1998 gives anyone the right to challenge public authority if they believe their rights have been breached. But how are those working in health and social care and the voluntary sector likely to be affected? David Batty reports.
fields.body:
Challenges to deportation orders for asylum seekers, more family friendly conditions for prisoners and an end to postcode rationing of NHS drugs are just some of the potential consequences of the Human Rights Act 1998.

The act, which came into force on 2 October 2000, has been described as the biggest change to UK law since the 1688 bill of rights. Nobody understands its full impact, but it means everyone can now challenge public authority in the UK's courts if they believe a basic right has been breached. This is certain to affect health and social care and the voluntary sector.

The act incorporates the European convention on human rights into UK law. This enshrines several basic rights, including: the right to life; prohibition of torture; the right to a fair trial; the right to respect for private and family life; freedom of thought, conscience and religion; freedom of expression; freedom of assembly and association; the right to marry, and prohibition of discrimination.

Public authorities, such as the prison service, that deal with people in tense or sensitive situations may be particularly vulnerable to challenges under the act.

Prisoners located hundreds of miles from their homes, or denied conjugal visits or artificial insemination, or those in mother and baby units eventually separated from their children, might claim an infringement of their right to family life.

Action against the NHS is also expected. Under article two, the right to life, the state must not only refrain from taking life but has to safeguard it. Thus patients could challenge the postcode rationing of certain lifesaving drugs if a particular drug were available on the NHS in Oxford but not in Newcastle.

The act also looks likely to provoke litigation over the care of people with mental health problems. Families of patients could argue that detention in hospital without consent is a breach of article five - the right to liberty - and article six, the right to a fair trial.

Care proceedings and adoption cases are also likely to be affected by the right to family life. This could guarantee natural parents the right to see papers and records when decisions are to be made on their child's future.

Asylum seekers could also challenge the restrictions introduced by home secretary Jack Straw, under the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999. The restrictions in the act leave many asylum seekers with no entitlement to help with accommodation costs.

A HIV-infected man from Colombia, jailed for causing grievous bodily harm and possessing drugs, won the right to stay in Britain last October under article eight - the right to family life - pending the outcome of his former partner's application for asylum.

Charities that provide residential care, hospice care, health care and advice or child care could be affected by the act as they carry out a public function. The same applies to housing associations and family planning and pregnancy advice centres.

But the charity commission has said charities should see the act as an opportunity to bolster their campaigns. The Child Poverty Action Group, for example, hopes to use the law to challenge benefit decisions.
fields.bodyText: Challenges to deportation orders for asylum seekers, more family friendly conditions for prisoners and an end to postcode rationing of NHS drugs are just some of the potential consequences of the Human Rights Act 1998. The act, which came into force on 2 October 2000, has been described as the biggest change to UK law since the 1688 bill of rights. Nobody understands its full impact, but it means everyone can now challenge public authority in the UK's courts if they believe a basic right has been breached. This is certain to affect health and social care and the voluntary sector. The act incorporates the European convention on human rights into UK law. This enshrines several basic rights, including: the right to life; prohibition of torture; the right to a fair trial; the right to respect for private and family life; freedom of thought, conscience and religion; freedom of expression; freedom of assembly and association; the right to marry, and prohibition of discrimination. Public authorities, such as the prison service, that deal with people in tense or sensitive situations may be particularly vulnerable to challenges under the act. Prisoners located hundreds of miles from their homes, or denied conjugal visits or artificial insemination, or those in mother and baby units eventually separated from their children, might claim an infringement of their right to family life. Action against the NHS is also expected. Under article two, the right to life, the state must not only refrain from taking life but has to safeguard it. Thus patients could challenge the postcode rationing of certain lifesaving drugs if a particular drug were available on the NHS in Oxford but not in Newcastle. The act also looks likely to provoke litigation over the care of people with mental health problems. Families of patients could argue that detention in hospital without consent is a breach of article five - the right to liberty - and article six, the right to a fair trial. Care proceedings and adoption cases are also likely to be affected by the right to family life. This could guarantee natural parents the right to see papers and records when decisions are to be made on their child's future. Asylum seekers could also challenge the restrictions introduced by home secretary Jack Straw, under the Immigration and Asylum Act 1999. The restrictions in the act leave many asylum seekers with no entitlement to help with accommodation costs. A HIV-infected man from Colombia, jailed for causing grievous bodily harm and possessing drugs, won the right to stay in Britain last October under article eight - the right to family life - pending the outcome of his former partner's application for asylum. Charities that provide residential care, hospice care, health care and advice or child care could be affected by the act as they carry out a public function. The same applies to housing associations and family planning and pregnancy advice centres. But the charity commission has said charities should see the act as an opportunity to bolster their campaigns. The Child Poverty Action Group, for example, hopes to use the law to challenge benefit decisions.

webTitle: Different routes to a voluntary sector career

fields.headline: Different routes to a voluntary sector career
fields.standfirst: Adam Woolf talks to four people who have secured paid work in the voluntary sector
fields.trailText: Adam Woolf talks to four people who have secured paid work in the voluntary sector.
fields.body:
One of the major downsides of working for a charity is dealing with all the people who presume that your involvement is purely in a voluntary capacity. They think that charities don't have the money to employ people; working for "worthy causes" is therefore simply act of kindness, rather than a professional job.

Of course this is a myth. The voluntary sector employs more than 500,000 people in the UK and makes up 2.2% of Britain's workforce. That makes it a bigger employer than both the agricultural and motor industries.

The case studies below illustrate just some of the different ways of securing paid work and a rewarding career in the voluntary sector.

Switching from the private sector: Victor Darcy-Smith, Director of Corporate Services, National Centre for Volunteering
After securing a degree in economics, Mr Darcy-Smith trained as a Chartered Accountant. He worked for an accounting firm and then took various jobs in industry and commerce. He wanted a change because he felt a lack of fulfilment. Mr Darcy-Smith's first voluntary sector job was as Finance Manager at Centrepoint, more than 10 years ago. He had to take a pay cut, but he had no regrets as the work was more rewarding. After a stint as director of Mind in Camden, he joined the National Centre for Volunteering, where he is now director of Corporate Services.

The group offers a range of services to support organisations and volunteer managers in other charities. Mr Darcy-Smith is responsible for human resources, IT, communications and finance. "The job has been an extremely rewarding experience," he said. "It is a job with a broad base of responsibility, with a number of major departments under my management. This may not be the case in the private sector."

Volunteer first: Andrew van Doorn, policy and research officer, National Homeless Alliance
While studying for his degree Mr van Doorn volunteered at the Colchester emergency night shelter. This developed into a paid position as a project worker. Mr van Doorn held this post as well as working part time at the university as a research officer. He also coordinated volunteers for Nightline.

His next post was as survey and information assistant in the research team at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations. After research posts at the Unemployment Unit and Youth Aid, Mr van Doorn joined the National Homeless Alliance as policy and research officer.

The National Homeless Alliance is the umbrella organisation for those providing services to homeless people. Mr van Doorn undertakes policy-based research and writes briefings for member organisations and for government departments. He also visits local homeless agencies across the country, talking to staff about their experiences.

Mr van Doorn recommends working in the voluntary sector: "You need a commitment and passion for what you do. Often these organisations are under resourced and the work can be stressful. On the other hand, it's fun."

Training schemes: Suzanne Smith, project manager, Awetu
Ms Smith has had numerous jobs in the past, from barmaid and working at a fruit stall to a vet's practice. After doing a Manpower scheme called "Schemes for the deaf" she was a community visitor for St John's Urban Ministry. She then did clerical work for HTV television, after which she joined Fullemploy Wales.

She is now project manager at Awetu, the only black and ethnic minority mental health organisation in Wales.

Ms Smith enjoys her work. "I find my job vocational and rewarding. It is very satisfying when you know that your service has made a positive impact in someone else's life."

Academic Route: Lucy Peake, press and research manager, YMCA
Ms Peake took a degree in politics at Loughborough University She then taught undergraduates and MSC students at Southampton University where she was taking a PhD. She joined YMCA as research officer after she completed her doctorate. She then became parliamentary, press and research manager.

Ms Peake says "The most satisfying part of my job is that I can undertake research and public relations with a human face and a practical edge. This sector is very people focused."

There are over 160 YMCA's in England. Among the many services they run, they also provide housing and advice for the homeless and training for the unemployed.

fields.headline: Eco soundings
fields.trailText: environment news
fields.body:
Total sense

Exeter students are bitter that their barrister chancellor, Lord "Bob" Alexander of Weedon, is a non-executive director of Total Oil, which is building a pipeline through Burma and seen by many as propping up a grotesque military junta. M'lud is a principled man, understanding fair play (he's president of the MCC) and the poetry of compassion (he's chair of the RSC), but he doesn't seem to grasp the simple human rights principle at stake. Nevertheless, continual demos and occupations in Exeter are getting to him, it seems. The university tells Eco soundings that if the students come up with a "reasoned" letter he will then put it before the Total board. A suggestion for Lord Alexander: try putting a letter of resignation before the Total board (or the university one, for that matter) and then reasoning the principle with the students.

Yellow streaks

What really happened at Bangor University last week, when development secretary Clare Short had a sense of humour failure and experienced the trickle-down effect of a (fair trade) custard pie thrown at her while condemning irresponsible demonstrators? The students say her first reaction was one of horror and that she was naturally anxious that the images should not go much further. Students were surprised that the BBC and ITV, having got very excited, then rapidly backed off.

Space to let

Alexander and Short, the BBC and ITV might say students should "get real". They would all surely approve of the team of three "consultants" sent by those corporate artists known as space plc to change minds about the environment at the University of London tonight and tomorrow. You can book via lindsay@spaceplc.com

Vacant look

That fab job teaching English in the Amazon offered here last week is still open, mainly because we printed the wrong email address. Try: bschmal@hotmail.com

Hot on the issue

Even as Mr Blair is talking about the climate crisis, Nick Raynsford, a junior environment minister, is watering down the new rules on energy efficiency in newly-built houses. Why? Because tougher standards would be (Nick's words) "an undue burden on builders and their materials and component suppliers".

fields.headline: Hunt takes helm at BBC Six O'Clock News
fields.trailText:
2.30pm: The BBC has confirmed speculation that One O'Clock News editor Jay Hunt will take over as editor of the 6pm bulletin. By Jessica Hodgson.

Mar 6: Hunt set to move from One to Six
Dec 22: Popescu to edit Ten O'Clock News
fields.body:
The BBC has today confirmed speculation that Jay Hunt, editor of the One O'Clock News, will take over as editor of the Six O'Clock bulletin.

She will be replaced by Chris Rybczinski, who is currently weekend editor of BBC TV news.

Ms Hunt takes over from Mark Popescu, who will edit the Ten O'Clock News after the general election.

Mike MacFarlane, editor of BBC Radio Five Live, takes over Ms Rybczynski's post, while Kevin Bakhurst, currently assistant editor of the Ten O'Clock, becomes evenings editor on BBC News 24.

David Kermode and Marek Pruszewicz, currently assistant editors, will act for a period as strand editors on BBC News 24.

The moves end a period of uncertainty at BBC news following the appointment of new chief Richard Sambrook, who takes over in April.

He replaces Tony Hall, who is joining the Royal Opera House as chief executive.

"This is one of the strongest set of appointments we've ever made. The emphasis is on programme-making and creative talent across the board." said Roger Mosey, head of BBC TV news.

Ms Hunt's editorship of the One O'Clock News is being hailed as a triumph. Since she took over in 1999 the audience on the bulletin has grown from an average of 2.6m to over 3m, beating what the BBC claim is ITV's lunchtime bulletin average of 2.1m

She worked as assistant editor on Panorama and Newsnight before taking over as editor of the One O'Clock late in 1998.

Chris Rybczynski was a launch strand editor for BBC News 24 and has also worked as a news editor at ITN and GMTV.
