fields.headline: Fundraising: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Whether it is a small community-based group run by volunteers or a large international agency employing thousands, fundraising is the lifeblood of every charity.
fields.body:
Whether it is a small community-based group run by volunteers or a large international agency employing thousands, fundraising is the lifeblood of every charity.

A charity can have the best intentions but without funds it can do very little. Galvanising an army of volunteers and using donated goods can keep costs down, but ultimately all charities need to raise additional funds.

This can be a daunting task. Fundraising is like painting the Humber Bridge. Just as the organisers celebrate reaching one year's financial targets they have to start all over again working on the next year's appeal.

The bad news is that this annual fundraising cycle is going to get harder. While the needs of charity funding continues to increase, for the first time in 20 years overall charity income has dropped.

Research by the Charities Aid Foundation (CAF) shows that the income of the top 500 charities has decreased in real terms by 1.7% in 1999.

High profile media and advertising campaigns and celebrity endorsed events can prove successful fundraisers for attractive and innovative projects. But finding the funds to pay for more mundane costs such as office equipment and electricity bills, is more difficult.

Traditionally, central and local government grants and funding from other statutory bodies has helped meet these core costs. However, CAF research showed funding from these sources had fallen by £87m or 6.7% in real terms in 1999.

But it is not all bad news for charity fundraisers. Changes to the Gift Aid rules - which means charities can claim back tax already paid by donors - could yield between £200m and £400m for the voluntary sector in the future. There has also been an increase in the legacy income in recent years.

Other fundraising sectors may also become more lucrative in the future. Charity shops have traditionally been hugely lucrative for many charities - although in recent years sales have dropped and profits have plummeted. However, many charities now predict a return to profit for their shops after cutting staff costs and streamlining their activities.

The internet also offers hope. As some commercial internet enterprises have failed to live up to expectations, charity fundraisers are beginning to see a good return from this medium. In January CAF announced it had raised £1m through its All About Giving website.

The business community is a source of funding. Companies are only able to support a small percentage of causes that contact them. Most have a set budget for charity work. Rather than spreading funding widely, many companies now choose to develop longer-term relations with just a few charities.

fields.headline: Intercountry adoption: the issue explained
fields.trailText: The still unresolved case of the "internet twins" has made intercountry adoption a household issue, discussed in living rooms up and down the land.
fields.body:
The still unresolved case of the "internet twins" has made intercountry adoption a household issue, discussed in living rooms up and down the land.

Although unique in many ways - most adopted children aren't sold to the highest bidder, taken on a road trip across the US and paraded in front of the international media - the case helps to illustrate some of the emotional and legal difficulties raised when adopting children from a foreign land.

The Kilshaws paid £8,200 for the two little girls. This caused kneejerk disapproval among most people who agree that children shouldn't be bought. But did the money represent the "buying" of the children or the "reimbursement" of expenses? Is there a difference?

And what about this so-called agent or facilitator? There is a need for some form of intermediary in adoptions, but how do we know which are reputable and which are not? Who decides which agencies are reputable? How do they decide? Were any regulations broken?

The confusion surrounding this question shows how inadequate domestic and international law in this area is. No one seems to be sure whether the Kilshaws broke UK law, which requires a home study by a local authority or approved adoption agency before permission to adopt is granted, or international law.

More to the point, if a couple is not deemed suitable for adoption by UK authorities, should they be allowed to adopt if another country's authorities give them the green light? The case has promoted renewed enthusiasm for ratification of the Hague Convention on Intercountry Adoption - due to become UK law in January 2002 - but there are already doubts that the convention will do much to prevent a repeat of the internet twins fiasco.

Child rights activists say it is, quite simply, an issue of supply and demand. Couples desperate to be parents will go to desperate lengths to fulfil their need. And so long as they are willing to pay, some one, somewhere will come up with goods. Horror stories of young women in Central America being forced to give their new-born babies to child traffickers are unlikely to deter wannabe parents who may believe the child will be better off in the prosperous west.

And herein lies the crux of the problem. The International Convention on the Rights of the Child states that decisions should always be made in the "best interests of the child". It is clear that in the "internet twins" case few people are thinking of their best interests.

Child psychologists unanimously agree that having five sets of carers by the time they are eight months old is unacceptable. But others think the act of placing children in cultures and ethnic groups different from their own raises more problems than it solves. The children, they say, grow up with a confused identity.

More importantly, children up for adoption often spend long periods of time, months and often years, in institutions. Are prospective parents able to deal with the developmental and emotional problems associated with institutionalisation? And what happens if, once the child is at home in the UK, they feel unable to cope?

Intercountry adoption raises more questions than answers and, as the internet twins case so poignantly showed, answers are a long way from being found.

fields.headline: Greenlees said to be leaving TBWA
fields.trailText: 1.15pm: TBWA Worldwide chief executive Mike Greenlees is reported to be leaving the agency. By Claire Cozens
fields.body:
The British chief executive of TBWA Worldwide, Mike Greenlees, is reported to be leaving the agency.

Mr Greenlees, who founded the UK advertising agency GGT, has held the post since May 1998.

According to US reports, his five-year contract with the company still has two years to run.

He took on the role after TBWA owner Omnicom bought GGT for $235m in January 1998.

Mr Greenlees's remit was to build a cohesive agency network out of the diverse collection of agencies that make up TBWA Worldwide.

He was also charged with expanding the list of global client's on TBWA's roster.

Jean-Marie Dru, who reports to Greenlees as the head of TBWA's European operations, is said to be a frontrunner for the worldwide chief executive position.

fields.headline: ITV anticipates cash injection
fields.trailText:
1pm: ITV is hoping for a multimillion-pound cash windfall from its £100m satellite broadcasting deal, writes Dan Milmo.
10am: ITV to open negotiations with Sky
9.30am: ITV under pressure to join Sky
8am: ITV comes in from digital wilderness
fields.body:
ITV is hoping for a multimillion-pound cash windfall from its £100m satellite broadcasting deal.

ITV giants Granada and Carlton Communications will receive a rebate on their licence fee according to how many of their viewers use the digital service, which will be launched by the end of the year.

Under the terms of the latest regional licence agreements, ITV companies could therefore make a considerable saving on the £450m a year they pay out to the government in franchise fees.

A major drain on ITV revenues is the "percentage of qualifying revenue" or PQR.

This accounts for three-quarters of the £450m bill and is based on a percentage of the network's advertising income.

If millions of ITV viewers switch to watching the channel on digital satellite as a result of today's deal, the rebate on PQR totals could be significant.

"It is the first piece of good news for ITV earnings we have heard in the past few months," said Simon Baker, analyst at SG Securities.

One senior media analyst added ITV should not worry about paying a reported £20m a year to appear on Sky Digital.

"It will take them six months to make that money back if they join up with Sky," he said.

However, some analysts pointed out the cost of beaming ITV onto a satellite platform will not be cheap.

"There will be savings on PQR but there will also be substantial costs in running a satellite service.

"The financial advantage could be wiped out by the cost of distributing the channels," said Mathew Horsman, analyst at Investec Henderson Crosthwaite.

The remaining ITV licence renewals, which should be settled by next week, are: LWT, owned by Granada; Grampian and Scottish, both owned by SMG; Border, owned by Capital Radio; and Channel, owned by Channel Islands Communications.

Related stories

Mar 14: ITV under pressure to join Sky
Mar 14: ITV comes in from digital wilderness

fields.headline: No 9. Plymouth Argyle
fields.standfirst: Paul Roberts, from Plymouth fanzine Rub of the Greens, introduces us to the strange world of Argyle
fields.trailText: Paul Roberts, from Plymouth fanzine Rub of the Greens, introduces us to the strange world of Argyle.
fields.body:
What separates Plymouth from all the rest, then?

Our unusual name for starters. There are several theories as to where we picked it up from, but nobody is really all that bothered. Whatever its origins, we're all fond of it - and no bona fide supporter refers to the club as 'Plymouth', we're Argyle, simple as that.

Then there's the dubious distinction of being the only League club in the country to have chosen green as its colour, and stuck with it.

And then of course - and this is the one we hate most - we are the second biggest city in England never to have graced the top-flight with a football team. At least Hull can claim to being the biggest city never to have achieved premier status. We can't even come top of that particular table of shame!

The highs . . .

Errrrmmmm . . . not a lot to write home about, to be honest. Whilst more glamorous sides will accept nothing less than a place in Europe, or another trophy in the cabinet come the season's end, little old Argyle have traditionally settled for much less. Scraping the bottom of the Home Park achievement barrel, you'd struggle to come up with anything other than our one and only Wembley appearance, back in 1996. Our first-ever season in the League's basement division ended with a successful run in the play-offs, and 32,000 Greens made the trip to the decaying national stadium to see Ronnie Mauge leap like a salmon above the Darlington defence to send us back into the promised land. Well, the Second Division anyway.

The 1993/94 season was one of near constant highs. Peter Shilton - before he started borrowing money off of everyone from his assistant manager to the Home Park tea-lady - built a side that is widely recognised as one of the best ever to grace Home Park. Steve Castle, Paul Dalton, Dwight Marshall et al swept the Second Division aside in their charge towards the play-offs. Their 88 League goals bettered the tally of every other team in Britain, and their 8-1 victory at Hartlepool on the final day summed up one of the most memorable campaigns in the history of our football club.

And then Burnley came along.

. . . and the lows

So, Burnley. A club we had never been particularly bothered about. Until they dealt us two quite horrible blows within four years, that is.

That brilliant Shilton side of 1993/94 didn't have many off-days that season, but they chose to have one on the very day it mattered most - the second leg of the play-off semi-final. Burnley had finished 12 points below us, yet they were still in with a shout of denying us the promotion we so thoroughly deserved. (Well, we did!)

A 0-0 draw in Lancashire set things up nicely for a triumphant night at Home Park, after which promotion would be assured with a victory over Stockport at Wembley. Dwight Marshall fired us into an early lead, and most of the home crowd were already planning their trips to the capital.

The rest now becomes too painful to recount, but the gist of it is that Burnley scored three goals without reply before the night was out, and then went on to secure promotion at Wembley. Four years later - after two seasons back in the Second Division - we were unceremoniously dumped back into the basement by none other than bloody Burnley.

"Chim-chiminee, chim-chiminee, chim-chim, cheroo, we hate those . . ."

Last fixture

Argyle 3, Chesterfield 0. This was described as a "shock" result by almost everyone - they obviously aren't aware of our irresistible home form. Since Paul Sturrock took the helm last November, we haven't lost a league match at Home Park - drawing only two at that. It's away from Plymouth that we become a mediocre mid-table side.

Next fixture

Tuesday night brings Hull City to Home Park, and now that the Tigers have been saved from extinction, they might start losing again. [Note: the match ended 1-1.]

Argyle travel to fashionable Scunthorpe on Saturday, and have absolutely no chance in hell of coming away with the three points. (You won't catch me tempting fate.)

Sore point

Argyle don't travel well, and it's really starting to get on our nerves. The Pilgrims have now gone a hair-tearing sixteen months without a victory outside of Devon - only managing a brace of victories at local rivals Exeter and Torquay.

Paul Sturrock has even gone as far as to select two different sides for home and away matches in an attempt to pull that elusive victory out of the bag. It's just a shame that one of those sides can't be Brazil.

What's the chairman like?

When chairman Dan McCauley finally hangs up his ego in the Home Park boardroom, he will leave behind him enough drama to produce an entire TV mini-series. His eleven years at the helm has seen nine different managers, three relegations, one promotion, two goes at the play-offs, grandiose stadium plans aplenty, countless spats with the local press, and a disastrous performance on a Talksport phone-in that will live long in the memory.

His relationship with the supporters is tepid at best, and the self-made millionaire has a long way to go to win back the hearts of a significant section of the Home Park faithful. The Talksport performance at the beginning of this season only served to enhance his poor reputation in the eyes of some fans. McCauley treated several callers with astonishing contempt, and went as far as to accuse one of being a member of the National Front.

It seems McCauley learnt his lesson from that PR disaster, and has steered clear of the spotlight since that ill-advised flirt with fame, letting his manager do all the talking. He's much better at it.

Who are your rivals?

The south-west corner of England and the term "football hotbed" aren't often uttered in the same breath, except when proceeded by the words "it isn't one". Thus, encounters between Argyle and neighbours Exeter and Torquay are disappointingly low-key affairs. Exeter fans have never thrown bags of piss at us, and Torquay supporters have certainly never considered purchasing the airspace over Home Park to taunt us with airborne slurs - as Manchester City cunningly attempted recently to their beloved rivals across Manchester.

That said, we love beating them both and have made a habit of doing so in recent seasons. Argyle have always been the biggest club out of the three: bigger ground, better support and traditionally loftier league status. It's only in recent years that our Devon neighbours have been able to convincingly question our claim that we are the pride of the county - and two seasons ago we achieved the unthinkable - finishing below both the Gulls and the Grecians for the first time in our history.

For real passion and palpable hatred, we'd need to start playing Burnley again. Other than that, the Bristol clubs always ensure large turn-outs at Home Park, mainly due to the fact that we consider the size of both to be similar to our own. Torquay and Exeter are both small-town clubs in our eyes, and should be too small to worry about - no arrogance here!

Kit

Argyle fans take great pride in our sole status as bearers of the colour green in the English game - we don't have much else to be proud of - and many were shocked at the club's decision to play in a home strip of white this season. Alright, so the white of the shirt is punctuated by green pinstripes, but the fact remains that you wouldn't catch Manchester United or Liverpool wearing anything but red on their own patch, and could you imagine Celtic ever dropping their famous green? The latest news though, is that green will be making a comeback in next season's home strip - and the fans are to be given the chance to decide exactly what the players will run-out in next season.

Club mascot

Word has it that kind-hearted Argyle officials once dished out free match tickets to residents of the local mental hospital. That practice ceased some years ago, but one of those lucky few somehow managed to slip through the net, and continues to take advantage of the club's sense of community spirit.

Disguising himself as Yosemite Sam, the canny loon spends his Saturday afternoons rocking back and forth in the centre circle, and scaring young children with his hare-brained antics. Pilgrim Pete - as he calls himself - marked his sixth season as Plymouth Argyle's official mascot by bundling over Cheltenham's Robin-type thing, his first run-in with one of his peers and his only brush with controversy to date. He's harmless enough, but the way he prances around the place, you'd think someone had stuck a hot pasty in his pants - bless him.

Merchandise

It's a shame the world's poverty stricken countries couldn't find a use for Pilgrim Pete teapots - the Argyle club shop has got thousands of the bloody things, and no one seems to want them here.

Home Park heroes

Rapidly playing his way into the Plymouth Argyle hall of fame is Frenchman David Friio. Signed until the end of the season by Paul Sturrock, the former FC Valence midfielder is improving by the game, and Argyle fans everywhere will be urging the club to offer him a permanent contract when the curtain comes down on the current campaign. Friio is composure personified, and makes Des Lynam look like Norman Wisdom on speed.

When it comes to true heroes though, no Argyle player in recent years has come close to achieving the status of one Tommy Tynan, Plymouth's favourite scouser. 120 goals spread across six seasons during the 80s remains a painful reminder of just what we've been missing for the past decade, and the number nine shirt has yet to be filled in quite so spectacular a fashion.

Favourite sons still plying their trade in the game include Manchester City defender Andy 'Jock' Morrison, who would receive a red-carpet return if he decided to finish his career where it began more than a decade ago, Mark Patterson, a hugely popular right-back cruelly stolen from us by Gillingham, and Marc Edworthy, now at Coventry City.

Home Park villains

Argyle supporters can moan with the best of them, but no member of the current squad is a regular target for the boo-boys.

By far and away the least popular player ever to don the green shirt is the now retired centre-back Peter Swan. Peter Shilton signed the bastard for a club record £350,000 from Port Vale, during the close season after we missed out on promotion to the First Division. Swan was regarded as the final piece in the jigsaw, and expectations were sky high, especially when Swan scored an early goal in our first match of the new season at home to Brentford.

That perfect start proved to be a false dawn though, and a more accurate sign of things to come was evident in Brentford going on to score five goals without reply. That season ended in totally unexpected relegation, and Swan was bundled off to Burnley - a match made in heaven in the eyes of Argyle's supporters. As soon as he was safely away from Devon, Swan launched a scathing attack on the club, the city, its supporters and even fate itself.

Swan's dog died during that miserable season, a misfortune he tried to blame on his move south. Which makes him nuts, as well as crap.

Home Park is where the heart is

It's taken us the best part of a decade, but it looks like Argyle will finally be joining the band of lower division clubs touching up their grounds. After several false dawns - most of which involved potential deals with supermarkets - it seems Home Park will finally be opening its eyes to the modern era.

Work on an 18,500, all-seater revamp of the old stadium should start in the summer, and one of the biggest grounds in the lower divisions will also become one of the best within a couple of years.

Traditionalists will miss Home Park in its current guise, but the truth is the place is in dire need of a facelift. Crumbling paint-work and ancient turnstiles might be some people's idea of a good old-fashioned day out, but the makeover is long overdue.

The Argyle experience

Home Park is set amidst the tranquillity of Central Park, and the hustle and bustle found at other grounds on matchday is largely conspicuous by its absence when Argyle are at home.

The Britannia is the closest pub to the ground, and despite its newly acquired status as a Wetherspoons pub, retains the matchday atmosphere that has made it a popular haunt for both home and away supporters. The Golden Hind - the first pub you'll see coming off the A38 - serves top nosh at decent prices, and is only a 15-minute walk away from the ground. A jaunt to the city centre won't kill you, either, and you'll be rewarded with a veritable feast of pubs.

If you're lucky enough to play us at Easter time - Brighton fans - you'll be able to soak up all the fun of the fair. Literally. Every Easter, a whole procession of barf-inducing rides rocks up and dumps itself right outside the ground's main entrance. If you can put up with the host of spotty teenagers hanging out and trying to shag each other in the bumper cars, then it's an ideal way to waste a few pre-match minutes. (If I see any ugly Brighton fans alone in those bumper cars this Easter, I'll be sure to point you out to all and sundry as boisterously as I can.)

What does the future hold for the Greens?

Cautious optimism are very much the key words. Paul Sturrock has impressed all with his no-nonsense approach to management, and has the hopes of Argyle's long-suffering faithful firmly in his hands. If he can find an answer to our away day blues, we will be up there next season.

As for the long-term, much depends on Dan McCauley to ensure that any on the pitch success is matched by an ambitious response from the boardroom. We've seen the guy do some crazy things over the years, and if he really wants to earn the recognition he craves, he will be well-advised to deliver on any promises he makes from now on.

fields.bodyText: What separates Plymouth from all the rest, then? Our unusual name for starters. There are several theories as to where we picked it up from, but nobody is really all that bothered. Whatever its origins, we're all fond of it - and no bona fide supporter refers to the club as 'Plymouth', we're Argyle, simple as that. Then there's the dubious distinction of being the only League club in the country to have chosen green as its colour, and stuck with it. And then of course - and this is the one we hate most - we are the second biggest city in England never to have graced the top-flight with a football team. At least Hull can claim to being the biggest city never to have achieved premier status. We can't even come top of that particular table of shame! The highs . . . Errrrmmmm . . . not a lot to write home about, to be honest. Whilst more glamorous sides will accept nothing less than a place in Europe, or another trophy in the cabinet come the season's end, little old Argyle have traditionally settled for much less. Scraping the bottom of the Home Park achievement barrel, you'd struggle to come up with anything other than our one and only Wembley appearance, back in 1996. Our first-ever season in the League's basement division ended with a successful run in the play-offs, and 32,000 Greens made the trip to the decaying national stadium to see Ronnie Mauge leap like a salmon above the Darlington defence to send us back into the promised land. Well, the Second Division anyway. The 1993/94 season was one of near constant highs. Peter Shilton - before he started borrowing money off of everyone from his assistant manager to the Home Park tea-lady - built a side that is widely recognised as one of the best ever to grace Home Park. Steve Castle, Paul Dalton, Dwight Marshall et al swept the Second Division aside in their charge towards the play-offs. Their 88 League goals bettered the tally of every other team in Britain, and their 8-1 victory at Hartlepool on the final day summed up one of the most memorable campaigns in the history of our football club. And then Burnley came along. . . . and the lows So, Burnley. A club we had never been particularly bothered about. Until they dealt us two quite horrible blows within four years, that is. That brilliant Shilton side of 1993/94 didn't have many off-days that season, but they chose to have one on the very day it mattered most - the second leg of the play-off semi-final. Burnley had finished 12 points below us, yet they were still in with a shout of denying us the promotion we so thoroughly deserved. (Well, we did!) A 0-0 draw in Lancashire set things up nicely for a triumphant night at Home Park, after which promotion would be assured with a victory over Stockport at Wembley. Dwight Marshall fired us into an early lead, and most of the home crowd were already planning their trips to the capital. The rest now becomes too painful to recount, but the gist of it is that Burnley scored three goals without reply before the night was out, and then went on to secure promotion at Wembley. Four years later - after two seasons back in the Second Division - we were unceremoniously dumped back into the basement by none other than bloody Burnley. "Chim-chiminee, chim-chiminee, chim-chim, cheroo, we hate those . . ." Last fixture Argyle 3, Chesterfield 0. This was described as a "shock" result by almost everyone - they obviously aren't aware of our irresistible home form. Since Paul Sturrock took the helm last November, we haven't lost a league match at Home Park - drawing only two at that. It's away from Plymouth that we become a mediocre mid-table side. Next fixture Tuesday night brings Hull City to Home Park, and now that the Tigers have been saved from extinction, they might start losing again. [Note: the match ended 1-1.] Argyle travel to fashionable Scunthorpe on Saturday, and have absolutely no chance in hell of coming away with the three points. (You won't catch me tempting fate.) Sore point Argyle don't travel well, and it's really starting to get on our nerves. The Pilgrims have now gone a hair-tearing sixteen months without a victory outside of Devon - only managing a brace of victories at local rivals Exeter and Torquay. Paul Sturrock has even gone as far as to select two different sides for home and away matches in an attempt to pull that elusive victory out of the bag. It's just a shame that one of those sides can't be Brazil. What's the chairman like? When chairman Dan McCauley finally hangs up his ego in the Home Park boardroom, he will leave behind him enough drama to produce an entire TV mini-series. His eleven years at the helm has seen nine different managers, three relegations, one promotion, two goes at the play-offs, grandiose stadium plans aplenty, countless spats with the local press, and a disastrous performance on a Talksport phone-in that will live long in the memory. His relationship with the supporters is tepid at best, and the self-made millionaire has a long way to go to win back the hearts of a significant section of the Home Park faithful. The Talksport performance at the beginning of this season only served to enhance his poor reputation in the eyes of some fans. McCauley treated several callers with astonishing contempt, and went as far as to accuse one of being a member of the National Front. It seems McCauley learnt his lesson from that PR disaster, and has steered clear of the spotlight since that ill-advised flirt with fame, letting his manager do all the talking. He's much better at it. Who are your rivals? The south-west corner of England and the term "football hotbed" aren't often uttered in the same breath, except when proceeded by the words "it isn't one". Thus, encounters between Argyle and neighbours Exeter and Torquay are disappointingly low-key affairs. Exeter fans have never thrown bags of piss at us, and Torquay supporters have certainly never considered purchasing the airspace over Home Park to taunt us with airborne slurs - as Manchester City cunningly attempted recently to their beloved rivals across Manchester. That said, we love beating them both and have made a habit of doing so in recent seasons. Argyle have always been the biggest club out of the three: bigger ground, better support and traditionally loftier league status. It's only in recent years that our Devon neighbours have been able to convincingly question our claim that we are the pride of the county - and two seasons ago we achieved the unthinkable - finishing below both the Gulls and the Grecians for the first time in our history. For real passion and palpable hatred, we'd need to start playing Burnley again. Other than that, the Bristol clubs always ensure large turn-outs at Home Park, mainly due to the fact that we consider the size of both to be similar to our own. Torquay and Exeter are both small-town clubs in our eyes, and should be too small to worry about - no arrogance here! Kit Argyle fans take great pride in our sole status as bearers of the colour green in the English game - we don't have much else to be proud of - and many were shocked at the club's decision to play in a home strip of white this season. Alright, so the white of the shirt is punctuated by green pinstripes, but the fact remains that you wouldn't catch Manchester United or Liverpool wearing anything but red on their own patch, and could you imagine Celtic ever dropping their famous green? The latest news though, is that green will be making a comeback in next season's home strip - and the fans are to be given the chance to decide exactly what the players will run-out in next season. Club mascot Word has it that kind-hearted Argyle officials once dished out free match tickets to residents of the local mental hospital. That practice ceased some years ago, but one of those lucky few somehow managed to slip through the net, and continues to take advantage of the club's sense of community spirit. Disguising himself as Yosemite Sam, the canny loon spends his Saturday afternoons rocking back and forth in the centre circle, and scaring young children with his hare-brained antics. Pilgrim Pete - as he calls himself - marked his sixth season as Plymouth Argyle's official mascot by bundling over Cheltenham's Robin-type thing, his first run-in with one of his peers and his only brush with controversy to date. He's harmless enough, but the way he prances around the place, you'd think someone had stuck a hot pasty in his pants - bless him. Merchandise It's a shame the world's poverty stricken countries couldn't find a use for Pilgrim Pete teapots - the Argyle club shop has got thousands of the bloody things, and no one seems to want them here. Home Park heroes Rapidly playing his way into the Plymouth Argyle hall of fame is Frenchman David Friio. Signed until the end of the season by Paul Sturrock, the former FC Valence midfielder is improving by the game, and Argyle fans everywhere will be urging the club to offer him a permanent contract when the curtain comes down on the current campaign. Friio is composure personified, and makes Des Lynam look like Norman Wisdom on speed. When it comes to true heroes though, no Argyle player in recent years has come close to achieving the status of one Tommy Tynan, Plymouth's favourite scouser. 120 goals spread across six seasons during the 80s remains a painful reminder of just what we've been missing for the past decade, and the number nine shirt has yet to be filled in quite so spectacular a fashion. Favourite sons still plying their trade in the game include Manchester City defender Andy 'Jock' Morrison, who would receive a red-carpet return if he decided to finish his career where it began more than a decade ago, Mark Patterson, a hugely popular right-back cruelly stolen from us by Gillingham, and Marc Edworthy, now at Coventry City. Home Park villains Argyle supporters can moan with the best of them, but no member of the current squad is a regular target for the boo-boys. By far and away the least popular player ever to don the green shirt is the now retired centre-back Peter Swan. Peter Shilton signed the bastard for a club record £350,000 from Port Vale, during the close season after we missed out on promotion to the First Division. Swan was regarded as the final piece in the jigsaw, and expectations were sky high, especially when Swan scored an early goal in our first match of the new season at home to Brentford. That perfect start proved to be a false dawn though, and a more accurate sign of things to come was evident in Brentford going on to score five goals without reply. That season ended in totally unexpected relegation, and Swan was bundled off to Burnley - a match made in heaven in the eyes of Argyle's supporters. As soon as he was safely away from Devon, Swan launched a scathing attack on the club, the city, its supporters and even fate itself. Swan's dog died during that miserable season, a misfortune he tried to blame on his move south. Which makes him nuts, as well as crap. Home Park is where the heart is It's taken us the best part of a decade, but it looks like Argyle will finally be joining the band of lower division clubs touching up their grounds. After several false dawns - most of which involved potential deals with supermarkets - it seems Home Park will finally be opening its eyes to the modern era. Work on an 18,500, all-seater revamp of the old stadium should start in the summer, and one of the biggest grounds in the lower divisions will also become one of the best within a couple of years. Traditionalists will miss Home Park in its current guise, but the truth is the place is in dire need of a facelift. Crumbling paint-work and ancient turnstiles might be some people's idea of a good old-fashioned day out, but the makeover is long overdue. The Argyle experience Home Park is set amidst the tranquillity of Central Park, and the hustle and bustle found at other grounds on matchday is largely conspicuous by its absence when Argyle are at home. The Britannia is the closest pub to the ground, and despite its newly acquired status as a Wetherspoons pub, retains the matchday atmosphere that has made it a popular haunt for both home and away supporters. The Golden Hind - the first pub you'll see coming off the A38 - serves top nosh at decent prices, and is only a 15-minute walk away from the ground. A jaunt to the city centre won't kill you, either, and you'll be rewarded with a veritable feast of pubs. If you're lucky enough to play us at Easter time - Brighton fans - you'll be able to soak up all the fun of the fair. Literally. Every Easter, a whole procession of barf-inducing rides rocks up and dumps itself right outside the ground's main entrance. If you can put up with the host of spotty teenagers hanging out and trying to shag each other in the bumper cars, then it's an ideal way to waste a few pre-match minutes. (If I see any ugly Brighton fans alone in those bumper cars this Easter, I'll be sure to point you out to all and sundry as boisterously as I can.) What does the future hold for the Greens? Cautious optimism are very much the key words. Paul Sturrock has impressed all with his no-nonsense approach to management, and has the hopes of Argyle's long-suffering faithful firmly in his hands. If he can find an answer to our away day blues, we will be up there next season. As for the long-term, much depends on Dan McCauley to ensure that any on the pitch success is matched by an ambitious response from the boardroom. We've seen the guy do some crazy things over the years, and if he really wants to earn the recognition he craves, he will be well-advised to deliver on any promises he makes from now on. If the promising Sturrock-McCauley relationship continues to prosper, Plymouth Argyle Football Club may finally make a name for itself. When it happens, it will have been a long time coming. fields.headline: BBC drama clocks off Sunday slot
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Hit BBC drama Clocking Off is to be moved to a midweek slot, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Mar 14: Ballykissangel axed
Mar 5: Vying for VIPs
fields.body:
The hit BBC drama Clocking Off is to be moved to a midweek slot following mounting concern about the performance of key dramas on Sunday night.

BBC director of drama Alan Yentob confirmed the second series of the seven-parter starring Sarah Lancashire would be moved from the slot because he wanted to protect it from ITV's big Sunday night shows.

"Looking at the figures, we feel it would fit better in a midweek slot," said Mr Yentob.

His decision will cause controversy as it comes only days after Clocking Off creator Paul Abbott said he felt audiences would "stick with" the drama in a Sunday night slot.

BBC bosses are sensitive about another high-profile failure after recent flops including Take a Girl Like You and Rebel Heart.

Mr Yentob said the BBC was still "incredibly proud" of Clocking Off, which in its last series attracted audiences of up to 11m.

He denied the Sunday night battleground was a headache for the BBC, saying dramas like Monarch of the Glen and the Warren Clarke vehicle Down to Earth were providing "green shoots".

But he hinted at a shift towards more populist drama scheduled in midweek slots.

"There is room for more shows of some ambition which nevertheless connect with audiences in mid-range, midweek slots," he said.

fields.headline: Regional government: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Scant progress has been made so far on the issue of regional government, despite a 1997 Labour party manifesto commitment to explore the possibility. But the issue has recently begun to climb up the political agenda with hints that a green paper on regionalism may be produced soon. Simon Parker reports
fields.body:
English regional government has traditionally been a deeply unfashionable cause within the Labour leadership. The party's 1997 election manifesto promised referendums on the issue, but the policy's few supporters were unloved old Labourites such as deputy prime minister John Prescott, and they appeared to have little popular support. It seemed, in short, unlikely that Yorkshire or the west Midlands would get their own parliaments any time in the near future.

Late last year, however, the regions leapt back on to the agenda. The government released an initial study on how regional parliaments might work. The chancellor began talking about increasing the accountability of the regional development agencies (RDAs). Finally, at Labour's spring conference, Mr Prescott felt able to issue what sounded like the promise of a green paper on regionalism.

The arguments in favour of regional government are based on both democratic and economic considerations. Supporters say that there is already a tier of regional government in England, but that it is made up of quangos and government offices with little or no direct accountability to the people they serve. Elected regional politicians could change this situation, they argue.

The economic arguments are even more straightforward. Local councillors in some of the regions, particularly the north-east, say that Westminster does not recognise their economic and social plight, and so does not provide them with enough funding. The politicians believe that they could gain more clout in the UK and Europe if they were part of a regional parliament.

Local councillors also hope to gain more control over their regional economy as a means to attract more investment. As Michael Davey, chair of the north-east regional assembly, says, "When global inward investors look at a site in the north-east we want to be able to tell them, hand on heart, that we control all of the key regional elements in their decision making. This includes economic development, transport, housing, education, health, the environment and planning."

Ministers say they have already made a start on the regional agenda by creating the Greater London Authority and the nine English RDAs. Outside London, each agency is accountable to an unelected regional assembly made up of councillors as well as business and voluntary sector leaders. Until recently, these were largely talking shops, but that could change with the recent announcement of a £5m budget to help them fulfil their scrutiny role.

But disputes continue over what exactly regional government would do if it were ever created. Activists campaigning for a north-east assembly want a similar assembly to that in Wales. Meanwhile Labour's 1997 manifesto promised that regional government would have powers to co-ordinate transport, planning, economic development, and bids for European funding and land use planning.

Many believe that such an extra tier is entirely unnecessary. The Conservatives are passionately opposed to the idea. They claim that the eight regions are imposed from the centre and that local people do not identify with them. They believe that regionalism is the first step towards a federalized Europe, and that regional parliaments would draw power away from Tory power bases in county councils. They are also concerned about the possibility of creating extra costs and bureaucracy.

The most persuasive Tory argument against regional government is that there is simply no demand for it. Tony Blair is thought to be cool on the regional agenda, and this may be one of those rare points on which he and William Hague agree.

The difference is that Mr Blair is prepared to move forward - but only if popular support can be proven. As he told business leaders in Cardiff, "I have always taken the view that this is something that cannot be forced on people. People have got to want it. You have to be sure that this is what I call a people's desire and not a desire of the political class."

fields.headline: Napster in last-ditch rescue bid
fields.trailText:
12.45pm: Napster has found a technology partner that could just about save the song-swapping service's life, writes Amy Vickers.
Mar 8: Napster faces fresh lawsuits
Mar 8: Web whizz plans 'legal Napster'
Mar 7: Napster fails to satisfy court
Mar 6: Vivendi gives Napster hope
Feb 21: Napster offers £690m to settle copyright case
fields.body:
Napster has struck a deal with a technology partner that could save the song-swapping service's life.

The beleaguered service faces closure later today if it does not comply with a court order to remove copyrighted material from its site.

The deal with Gracenote, a world leader in music recognition services, should block copyrighted songs from being downloaded by users.

The move should go some way to convincing both the court and record companies that Napster is trying its hardest to work with them.

Gracenote's software will help Napster identify a greater number of user-defined variations in naming artists and songs.

This is crucial for the service because it has no way of controlling the way in which users deliberately misspell song titles to avoid the filters.

Napster is desperate to comply with a pre-trial injunction requiring it to remove all songs specified by copyright owners, or face closure within hours.

"This is a great moment for digital music. We're so pleased we could be a part of the solution that keeps the Napster phenomenon alive," said Gracenote president David Hyman.

Napster chief executive Hank Barry said yesterday the company was doing its best to block files but admitted the screening process remains "a work in progress".

The technology partnership could be seen as a last-ditch attempt to restore some faith in the song bootlegging service, but observers are not convinced it will do the trick.

"It's an improvement but it's not enough to make a difference," said Paul Myers, founder of Wippit, a soon-to-launch legal version of Napster.

He likened the move to the murder squad solving a case by using a shortsighted and slightly confused eye witness, but said it was better than before.

He said the Napster's previous attempts to resolve the issue wasn't "unlike the murder squad giving forensics the day off and trying solve a crime using a residential phone book".

The Recording Industry Association of America, on behalf of BMG, Warner, EMI, Universal and Sony, submitted 135,000 file names to Napster on Friday to have them blocked from the file-sharing service.

While Napster was ordered by the court to rid its service of song titles submitted by the RIAA within three days, it is expected Napster will be given a further stay of execution today.

fields.headline: Housing transfers: the issue explained
fields.trailText: Housing transfers represent one of the biggest shake-ups in social housing since the first council homes were built. Large scale voluntary transfers (LSVTs) as they are official known, were introduced in 1988 but in fact transfers have only recently been taken up on a large scale.
fields.body:
Housing transfers represent one of the biggest shake-ups in social housing since the first council homes were built. Large scale voluntary transfers (LSVTs) as they are official known, were introduced in 1988 but in fact transfers have only recently been taken up on a large scale.

Transfers allow councils to switch ownership and control of their homes to housing associations or local housing companies, both of which are referred to as registered social landlords (RSLs). Transfer can only take place if tenants of the homes involved vote in favour of the plan.

The main incentive for transfer, for councils and tenants, is increased investment. There is an estimated repairs backlog of up to £20bn for council housing. The public money available is unlikely to tackle this. Moreover, Britain's tough public spending rules mean councils cannot borrow money against their assets. But registered social landlords can, which is why so many councils are now opting for transfer.

Initially transfers only took place in Conservative-controlled shire districts. Labour controlled councils were opposed to the move. They saw RSLs as undemocratic and were worried about rising rents to support private loans. While Labour authorities were against the idea, the impact of transfers was likely to be limited because they controlled most of Britain's inner cities where social housing is concentrated.

Labour councils were hoping a Labour government would change the public borrowing rules so that transfer would be unnecessary. But after the 1997 election it soon became apparent the rules were here to stay. Moreover, since coming to power Labour has also done more to encourage housing transfers than the Conservatives, particularly in inner city districts.

At first Labour ministers claimed to be neutral about who controlled social housing, but behind the scenes it made transfers easier. Labour has increased the size limit of transfers; agreed to write off poor borough's housing debt; has allowed more time for transfers to take place, and abolished stamp duty on transfers.

Now Labour authorities are queuing up to transfer their homes. These include Birmingham and Glasgow - the biggest landlords in England and Scotland (where different incentives for transfer have been introduced).

In April 2000 the government introduced a housing green paper. In it minister's support for transfers became more explicit. An ambitious target of transferring 200,000 council homes a year was introduced. This was double what the outgoing Tory government had proposed in the run-up to the last election. But as a sop to councils, the government allowed them to escape the borrowing rules if they set their homes up at "arm's length" from the council. Crucially, however, this will only be open to the best performing councils - those that get "excellent" best value ratings by the audit commission's housing inspectorate.

If the new transfer targets are met, the number of RSL homes will soon exceed those in council control, and in 20 years time there will be very little council housing left.

But transfers are unlikely to go that smoothly. A growing minority of transfer schemes have failed after tenants voted against the idea. It is unclear how councils can access increased investment if transfer is not supported by tenants.

Furthermore, it is still unclear how many councils the government will allow to set up the new arm's length companies.
fields.bodyText: Housing transfers represent one of the biggest shake-ups in social housing since the first council homes were built. Large scale voluntary transfers (LSVTs) as they are official known, were introduced in 1988 but in fact transfers have only recently been taken up on a large scale. Transfers allow councils to switch ownership and control of their homes to housing associations or local housing companies, both of which are referred to as registered social landlords (RSLs). Transfer can only take place if tenants of the homes involved vote in favour of the plan. The main incentive for transfer, for councils and tenants, is increased investment. There is an estimated repairs backlog of up to £20bn for council housing. The public money available is unlikely to tackle this. Moreover, Britain's tough public spending rules mean councils cannot borrow money against their assets. But registered social landlords can, which is why so many councils are now opting for transfer. Initially transfers only took place in Conservative-controlled shire districts. Labour controlled councils were opposed to the move. They saw RSLs as undemocratic and were worried about rising rents to support private loans. While Labour authorities were against the idea, the impact of transfers was likely to be limited because they controlled most of Britain's inner cities where social housing is concentrated. Labour councils were hoping a Labour government would change the public borrowing rules so that transfer would be unnecessary. But after the 1997 election it soon became apparent the rules were here to stay. Moreover, since coming to power Labour has also done more to encourage housing transfers than the Conservatives, particularly in inner city districts. At first Labour ministers claimed to be neutral about who controlled social housing, but behind the scenes it made transfers easier. Labour has increased the size limit of transfers; agreed to write off poor borough's housing debt; has allowed more time for transfers to take place, and abolished stamp duty on transfers. Now Labour authorities are queuing up to transfer their homes. These include Birmingham and Glasgow - the biggest landlords in England and Scotland (where different incentives for transfer have been introduced). In April 2000 the government introduced a housing green paper. In it minister's support for transfers became more explicit. An ambitious target of transferring 200,000 council homes a year was introduced. This was double what the outgoing Tory government had proposed in the run-up to the last election. But as a sop to councils, the government allowed them to escape the borrowing rules if they set their homes up at "arm's length" from the council. Crucially, however, this will only be open to the best performing councils - those that get "excellent" best value ratings by the audit commission's housing inspectorate. If the new transfer targets are met, the number of RSL homes will soon exceed those in council control, and in 20 years time there will be very little council housing left. But transfers are unlikely to go that smoothly. A growing minority of transfer schemes have failed after tenants voted against the idea. It is unclear how councils can access increased investment if transfer is not supported by tenants. Furthermore, it is still unclear how many councils the government will allow to set up the new arm's length companies.

fields.headline: Sheltered accommodation with a difference
fields.standfirst: Almshouses have been here for centuries, providing homes for a fortunate few. And they are hardly going out of fashion yet.  Christopher Middleton reports
fields.trailText: Almshouses have been here for centuries, providing homes for a fortunate few. And they are hardly going out of fashion yet. Christopher Middleton reports.
fields.body:
It's half past nine in the morning, and a crowd of German tourists has come to look at Elsie Avery's home in Canterbury. She is 88, a retired Margate patisserie worker, and the reason 30 Dusseldorf schoolteachers are taking photographs of her front door is that she lives at St John's Hospital Almshouses - built in 1084 to provide housing for the elderly, and still fulfilling that function some nine centuries later.

Like all the other 33 residents at St John's, Elsie has her own key to her own flat, looking out over a courtyard that is altogether more Oxbridge than OAP. From one window, she can see the spires of Canterbury cathedral; from the other, the lopsided Tudor gatehouse - through which she pops to the shops - and the Norman refectory and 11th-century privy.

She appreciates the photogenic surroundings, but what she really likes about living at St John's is that it allows her to retain her independence, while at the same time feel part of a community. "I've got my own place, my own things - and plenty of company if I want it", she says. "The great thing is, though, there's no one telling me what to do."

Such enthusiasm is increasingly echoed elsewhere. Almshouses are far from a thing of the past: the number of places they offer is rising by 5-10% a year. "The majority of almshouse charities in this country are in a state of expansion or refurbishment," says Anthony Leask, assistant director of the Almshouse Association. "We expect to see that increase continuing, given that the number of pensioners will go up by 50% over the next 30 years."

The word "independence" keeps coming up among residents. Elsie Avery and seven fellow residents are at the weekly coffee morning not because they have been herded into the common room, but because they have chosen to come. They're not big on organised activities here.

"We made a conscious decision not to put a television in the common room," says St John's bursar, Richard Akister, a former bank manager. "People have TV sets in their own flat. We are very much not a nursing home, and very much not the kind of place where people are wheeled in front of the box and left there all day."

The kind of place it is, though, is a peculiar mixture of modern commercial concern and medieval charity. St John's brings in £50,000 a year from renting out the dozen shops that line the almshouse frontage, in the city's busy Northgate. It also gets interest on money that has been invested for five centuries; it even gets £13.33 annually from Henry II, who granted it 25 groats a year in perpetuity as a kind of royal community service following his part in the Thomas à Becket murder in 1170.

The upshot of all this is that, like the other 1,750 almshouses in Britain, St John's offers residents private sheltered accommodation at a distinctly subsidised rate. The weekly rent of £46.50 (£72.50 for the more modern flats) is less than half of what people would pay on the open market. And if they were to try to buy a leasehold flat in a sheltered scheme, it would cost £50,000-£90,000 plus up to £5,000 a year in service charges.

For their rent, the residents of St John's get to live in an environment which is not only safe, friendly and picture-postcard pretty, but also has a care manager (to help liaise with health and social services departments) and a gate leading straight into Sainsbury's. In fact, the St John's trustees helped fund a new £1m residential wing by selling some of the back garden to the supermarket.

There are three main qualifications for residence: you must be over 65, have some link with Canterbury (work or family) and be unable to afford proper housing. A church connection can come in handy. Resident Anne Green, 89, was the warden of a clergy house throughout her working life, while Pat and Joyce Barry, both 85 and the scheme's only married couple, ran a diocesan retreat.

Indeed, there is a well-attended medieval chapel at St John's - as at its fellow almshouse, St Nicholas, in nearby Harbledown, which was set up in the 12th century as a hilltop community for lepers. Its church was built with a sloping floor to aid sluicing and disinfecting following a service.

In 1276, there were as many as 100 lepers living at St Nicholas, known then as the Hospital of the Wood of Blean. But as leprosy began to die out towards the end of the 14th century, the community admitted those whose afflictions were limited to old age and poverty. Today, St Nicholas has just 14 residents, who look out over rolling Kent countryside. The ancient church bell summons them the 50 yards to services. "You don't have to be a Christian to live at either St John's or St Nicholas," says Akister. "But you do need to feel comfortable in a group of people who are."

You don't need to be female, either, but women outnumber men by three to one - a figure mirrored throughout the estimated 40,000 almshouse population in the UK.

One notable exception is Sutton's Hospital (with the medieval connotation of hospitality rather than illness), in London's Charterhouse Square. All 40 of its residents - or "brothers", as they are called - are men, aged between 60 and 96. They pay £130 a week for their own Tudor bedsit, meals and laundry included.

The almshouse is less than 100 yards from the plush Barbican estate and Smithfield meat market, but it is set in beautiful, cloistered surroundings. It is funded by the bequest of Elizabethan industrialist Thomas Sutton, who made a fortune from coal mining and money lending. Before his death in 1611, he arranged that all his worldly wealth should be used to set up a school for bright young boys (Charterhouse, now in Godalming, Surrey) and an almshouse for needy old gentlemen. Among the first to take up residence was George Fenner, one of Francis Drake's sea captains.

Such was the extent of Sutton's wealth that, for four centuries, the trustees have been able to run the almshouse on the interest earned. Likewise, St John's in Canterbury has made good use of the lands and property it was given by its founder, Archbishop Lanfranc, in the 11th century. It also did well in the 20th century, when it sold off 75 acres for the University of Kent to be built on.

Because of their private incomes, many almshouses do not qualify for public sector money unless they can show they are doing work for which the state might otherwise pay. An example was when Trinity Hospital almshouse, in Salisbury, built a new development for frailer residents (designated "very sheltered" accommodation) and got half the £1.1m cost from the district council and the housing corporation.

The guiding principle at Trinity is that residents should remain under the charity's umbrella until they die. The same applies at Sutton's Hospital, where 24-hour nursing care is provided for those brothers who can no longer look after themselves. At St John's, however, as at many other almshouses, there is no such option.

"We have just built a new wing to house those residents who are finding their old flats hard to cope with," says bursar Akister. "The older properties are so narrow it's impossible to get a Zimmer frame round the corner, and extremely difficult to fit two people into the bathroom at the same time - which makes it hard for care assistants to give residents a bath.

"But we make it clear to everyone who comes here that we are not a hospital or a nursing home, and that when they can no longer look after themselves they will have to leave."

Opinion at the coffee morning is that totally care-dependent residents would compromise the principle of independent living. "This is a lovely place, just as it is", says one woman. "We all just hope we'll go before we have to leave - if you see what I mean."

Age-old help

The first recorded almshouse was set up in 937, by King Athelstan, at York. Today, 1,750 almshouse charities operate in the UK, some with just three cottages, others with as many as 1,000 properties. Altogether, they provide about 30,000 homes, mostly flats or one-storey houses.

While many of the early ones were set up by the Church, after the 16th century city livery companies, mayors and landowners stepped in. In the 19th century, industrialists also did their bit.

webTitle: Milan sack Zaccheroni as Berlusconi gets involved

fields.headline: Milan sack Zaccheroni as Berlusconi gets involved
fields.standfirst: Champions League round-up
fields.trailText: AC Milan have sacked their coach Alberto Zaccheroni in the wake of the club's exit from the Champions League.
fields.body:
AC Milan have sacked their coach Alberto Zaccheroni in the wake of the club's exit from the Champions League.

Milan drew 1-1 with Spain's Deportivo la Coruna last night, failing to get the win they needed to reach the quarter-finals.

The club said Zaccheroni had been dismissed and that they thanked him for his "commitment and dedication during his three seasons with the club".

They immediately appointed Cesare Maldini as Zacc's replacement but whether the former Italian national coach. and father of club captain Paolo, will remain in charge beyond the end of the season is unclear.

The five-times European Cup winners are languishing in eighth place in Serie A after a run of just two wins in 18 league and cup matches since mid-December.

It seems clear the decision to axe Zaccheroni was made by president Silvio Berlusconi who immediately after Tuesday's Champions league exit criticised Zaccheroni and promised to return to an active role at the club.

"We are out and that is a big disappointment. It means I will start to take a role in the club again," Berlusconi said.

"I have kept my reserve about the performances because I wanted to respect the autonomy of the technical staff and I have suffered in silence.

"But the results show I was right," he said referring to his long standing dispute with Zaccheroni over tactics.

Zaccheroni joined Milan from Udinese in the summer of 1999 and won the Italian league title in his first season at the San Siro.

Last season AC Milan finished third in Serie A, qualifying for the Champions League. But after finishing top of their first phase group, ahead of Leeds United and Barcelona, they managed just one win in the second group phase.

Zaccheroni's contract was due to run out at the end of this season and Turkish coach Fatih Terim, the former Galatasaray coach who quit Serie A club Fiorentina in February, had been widely tipped to take over in the summer.

However, Italian soccer regulations prevent coaches working with two teams in one season, so even if Terim is Milan's future coach he cannot take over now.

The most likely scenario is for Milan to appoint a caretaker coach until the end of the season with former full-back and current youth team coach Mauro Tassotti the most obvious choice.

Former Italy coach Cesare Maldini, father of team captain Paolo, is also available and is currently on Milan's books as chief scout. He could be handed a short-term role, possibly alongside Tassotti.

As well as Terim, former Juventus and Inter Milan coach Marcello Lippi has been mentioned as a possible AC Milan coach for next season.

webTitle: Indian MPs label PM a thief

fields.headline: Indian MPs label PM a thief
fields.trailText: Angry opposition politicians called the prime minister a thief and shut down the Indian parliament today, as they demanded the government resign over a bribery scandal that was revealed by journalists with hidden cameras.
fields.body:
Angry opposition politicians called the prime minister a thief and shut down the Indian parliament today, as they demanded the government resign over a bribery scandal that was revealed by journalists with hidden cameras.

The president of the ruling party, Bangaru Laxman, resigned last night after an internet media company, Tehelka.com, released videotapes of him accepting 100,000 rupees (£1,498).

The videos portrayed a string of party, defence ministry and military officials discussing or receiving bribes to facilitate a fake arms deal.

In its first reaction to the revelations, the government suspended army Major General PSK Choudhury and four other defence ministry officials who had appeared on the tapes.

"Strict action will be taken against any other official if any delinquency of conduct is established in due course," defence ministry spokesman PK Bandopadhyay said.

Prime Minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee later won the backing of the National Democratic Alliance, the ruling coalition.

"All members of the NDA coalition have expressed solidarity with the NDA," said Murasoli Maran, leader of a key alliance partner, the Dravida Munnethra Kazhagham party.

Both houses of parliament adjourned for the day as the uproar made it impossible for anyone to be heard.

Punching their fists in the air, lawmakers of the Congress party and other groups left their seats and stood before the elevated chair of the speaker, GMC Balayogi, in the Lok Sabha or lower house, pointing angrily at the ruling party lawmakers.

"There is talk in every street, the prime minister is a thief," several opposition members shouted in Hindi.

As prime minister Atal Bihari Vajpayee entered the house, senior Congress party lawmaker Buta Singh and other party lawmakers shouted, "He's a thief," Press Trust of India reported.

After the adjournment, Mr Vajpayee told reporters, "Let their be a discussion in the house." Commenting on the release of the tapes, he added, "There is something fishy."

VK Malhotra, a leader of Vajpayee's Bharatiya Janata Party, said that no cabinet minister had been implicated in the Tehelka revelations, nd no defence deal had been finalised. "We are ready for any sort of inquiry," Mr Malhotra said.

The Tehelka.com tapes, which were played on several private television channels last night, showed Mr Laxman accepting bribes from two journalists posing as defence manufacturers. They said that it was for the "party fund."

Today, Jana Krishnamurthy was chosen acting president of the party, Star News channel reported.

On Tuesday, Mr Laxman said that he had turned the money over to the party, and that the men he had believed were businessmen never mentioned an arms sale. Accepting commissions to arrange defence contracts is illegal in India and carries a prison sentence of up to seven years.

A special court is currently investigating a 1986 scandal involving payments allegedly made by Swedish arms manufacturer Bofors to procure a deal to sell howitzers to the Indian army. The scandal led to the downfall of prime minister Rajiv Gandhi's Congress party government in 1989.

His widow, Sonia Gandhi, now leads Congress and the opposition in parliament, which has seized on the Tehelka.com investigation to challenge the Vajpayee government's image of being corruption-free.

"The mask has fallen. They should step down," said Margaret Alva, a Congress spokeswoman. "We have heard rumours for a long time, but today we have it all on tape."

The ruling alliance appeared to be holding today after last night's late cabinet meeting rejected the proffered resignation of defense minister George Fernandes. Tehelka, which means "to create a commotion," is an internet news media firm that started up last year with an expose on a cricket match fixing scandal.

The media firm said that it copied the name of a London security business, printed letterheads and sent its reporters out posing as defence contractors to reveal what it claims is a system of bribery and payoffs in government deals.

The reporters pretended to be pushing a 40m rupees (£599,634.94) deal for hand-held thermal cameras and other defence equipment.

"Our job was to blow the whistle on corruption in India's defence procurement. We wanted to nail them down," Tarun J Tejpal, editor-in-chief of Tehelka.com, told a news conference yesterday.

webTitle: Don't let debt problems prevent a fair mortgage deal

fields.headline: Don't let debt problems prevent a fair mortgage deal
fields.standfirst: Borrowers - especially those who are financially vulnerable - should shop around in order to get the best on offer from both their broker and lender. Rachel Gordon reports
fields.trailText: Borrowers - especially those who are financially vulnerable - should shop around in order to get the best on offer from both their broker and lender. Rachel Gordon reports
fields.body:
People with a history of debt, including county court judgements and bankruptcy, can now obtain a fairer deal with their mortgage: there is now far more choice on the market, with better deals, too. But some borrowers, who are often already in a financially vulnerable position, continue to be ripped off - by brokers charging high fees, and lenders tying customers in and charging huge rates of interest.

Among those who are offering more competitive loans to those with debt problems are the Bank of Scotland subsidiary, The Mortgage Business, Chelsea Building Society and Bristol & West. Many of the mortgage products are sold on the advice of specialist mortgage brokers, as high street lenders turn away many people with credit problems.

Last year, about 400 people complained to the Mortgage Code Compliance Board, saying that the broker had not returned fees paid once the mortgage had fallen through, even though this is a legal requirement.

Those considering seeing a broker should check they abide by the Mortgage Code. Lenders, too, have been slammed for charging vastly inflated rates and tying customers in. While standards lenders can offer redemption tie-ins of up to three years, those insisted on by adverse credit specialists could be far longer.

Bristol & West said it wanted to raise awareness about some of the bad deals on offer and of the amount of people affected by debt problems.

Denzil Morgan, head of specialised lending for Bristol & West said: "People with black marks on their credit history can be made to pay for their mistakes forever." He said while a number of high street lenders wanted to cash in on the non-standard market, they tended to give their operations different names.

Examples include Verso from the Britannia Building Society and First National, a subsidiary of Abbey National. "The only reason we can see for these banks and building societies to set up these operations is to avoid brand contamination. We believe using our main brands means a fairer deal for customers," he said.

Morgan added that a common ploy by less reputable lenders was to offer an enticing headline rate followed by a loaded rate for the remainder of the mortgage term. Bristol & West said it also differed from other providers through offering pre-completion counselling. This means borrowers can arrange specific dates to pay the mortgage when their salary is paid in, and they know who to contact if there is a likely problem.

But anyone taking out a mortgage after debt problems should expect to pay a higher rate, at least for a shorter period, such as two years, as lenders say these people are higher risk. Even so, this should not be extortionate and there should be the opportunity to repair a credit history.

Within three years, and providing the mortgage is being repaid satisfactorily, the borrower should return to a standard variable rate, either with the existing lender or to a high street one.

Managing director of specialist broker Jim White's Mortgage Solutions, Jim White, said: "The adverse credit mortgage market generally receives bad press, focusing on rip-off brokers and greedy lenders. These do exist, but there is a more reputable side."

Who is affected by adverse credit?

 One in four people are turned down for a mortgage on the high street. This represents some five million households.

 A poor credit history can be triggered by forgetting to pay a final demand bill, arguing about payment of a bill with the issuer, or mix-ups over direct debits.

 People with debt problems are not all from lower socio-economic classes. Borrowers with Bristol & West's adverse credit products include accountants, teachers, police officers and managing directors.

 The main reasons for poor credit histories include financial mismanagement, business failure, divorce, job losses and illness.

 A CCJ is registered against an individual's name for six years.

fields.headline: Park quits Capital board
fields.trailText: 11.30am: Capital Radio programmes chief Richard Park has resigned from the board, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Richard Park, director of programmes at Capital Radio, has resigned from Capital's board to concentrate on the creative side of the business.

Mr Park, who has been at Capital for 13 years and is one of commercial radio's most respected programmers, will continue to work with the radio company as a creative consultant.

But the move will free him up to work on other broadcasting projects, which could include a return to presenting.

"His board-level role has meant Richard has had less time to focus on programming," said a Capital Radio spokeswoman.

"This will free him up to do more of what he is good at - being creative.

"He has even suggested he might like to return to presenting," she added.

Mr Park will not be replaced and will continue to work on key projects for Capital such as Party in the Park and Wildstar, the Capital-owned record label that launched R'n'B star Craig David.

Under the terms of his new contract, Mr Park will not be able to work for a rival radio station.

"Richard's contribution to Capital Radio has been enormous and I am confident this new role will benefit him and us by allowing him to concentrate on what he does the best and enjoys the most," said David Mansfield, chief executive of Capital Radio.

"The directors would like to thank Richard for his enormous contribution to the board over the past nine years.

"We look forward to working with him in this new relationship," Mr Mansfield said.

Mr Park joined Capital in 1987 and was behind the launch of Capital Gold in 1988. He presided over the expansion of Capital's businesses around the country.

Capital has become one of the three big national players along with GWR, which owns Classic FM, and Emap, the owner of London's Kiss 100 and Manchester's Piccadilly Radio.
