webTitle: Dirty money cleans up for Bollywood blockbuster

fields.headline: Dirty money cleans up for Bollywood blockbuster
fields.trailText: A star-studded Bollywood film has become a box office hit across India, despite protests from rightwing Hindu activists and allegations that it was made with mafia money.
fields.body:
A star-studded Bollywood film has become a box office hit across India, despite protests from rightwing Hindu activists and allegations that it was made with mafia money.

The film, Chori Chori Chupke Chupke (Steal Steal Quietly Quietly), has played to packed houses since its release last week, and has confounded recent attempts by detectives to clean up an industry famous for the murky nexus between its leading personalities and the mafia.

The movie has attracted the kind of publicity that most directors could only dream of but for all the wrong reasons. Its producer, Nazeem Rizvi, is languishing in prison, accused of attempting to kill several Bollywood stars. Its financier, Bharat Shah, has been locked in a neighbouring cell since early January. Both men are accused of making the film with underworld money and of colluding with one of India's most feared mafia dons, Chhota Shakheel.

It might come as some consolation to them that Chori Chori Chupke Chupke, which stars Salman Khan, India's answer to Richard Gere, has fascinated huge audiences intrigued by its underworld links.

The film has all the ingredients of a Bollywood hit, including a love triangle and a patriarchal cricket-playing grandfather.

"Its got all the makings of a great entertainer," said Gitanjali Chaturvedi, a student, yesterday as he emerged from a three-hour showing at a plush Delhi cinema. "It's got good singing and dancing, pretty women, exotic foreign locations, Salman Khan and backless cholis (blouses)."

Writing in the Times of India, the critic Nikhat Kazmi described it as a "modern ode to the ancient Indian family" and praised its"overwhelming feel-goodness".

Not everyone is happy, though. Armed guards have been posted outside cinemas in Delhi and Bombay after members of the ultra-nationalist Shiv Sena disrupted several showings on Friday. At least 12 people have been injured and more than 200 protesters arrested following pitched battles between rightwing Hindu activists and police in several cities. Two protesters attempted suicide.

The activists object to the alleged links between Pakistan's secret service and the Karachi-based Indian gangsters who appear to have picked up the tab for the film's £1.4m production costs.

Not that they are likely to see any return on their investment. After arresting Mr Rizvi in December as he tried to flee his Bombay apartment, detectives seized the prints of Chori Chori Chupke Chupke and handed them over to the court receiver.

The film, which had been due for release on December 22, was finally cleared for distribution last week. The court ruled that all profits should go to an unlikely beneficiary - the Maharashtran state government which runs Bombay.

Meanwhile, the affair has unnerved Bollywood's elite, many of whom have been questioned about their links with the underworld. Detectives have grilled the movie's three main stars - Salman Khan and the actresses Preity Zinta and Rani Mukherjee - as well as 60 other celebrities.

Last week police produced a 1,800-page dossier with details of phone conversations between Mr Shah, a wealthy diamond merchant, and Mr Shakeel in which the pair allegedly plotted to extort money from a Bollywood promoter.

Police also claim that Mr Rizvi used his links with Mr Shakeel to pressurise stars into agreeing to take part in the film, and the producer is accused of trying to kill India's most bankable young star, Hrithik Roshan, and his producer father Rakesh. He has already survived an assassination attempt.

Mr Shah and Mr Rizvi deny any wrongdoing, but their attempts to win bail have so far been turned down.

The film's commercial prospects appear unharmed by the scandal, however, with record bookings for the first weekend.

fields.trailText:
3.30pm TV overnights: Vanessa's eviction from the Big Brother house gave the show its biggest high yet, writes Jessica Hodgson.
Julie Burchill on Big Brother
Nasty Nick Bateman's verdict

<A HREF="http://www.mediaguardian.co.uk/broadcast/story/0,74
fields.body:
The eviction of Vanessa Feltz from the Celebrity Big Brother house boosted audiences to the show's biggest high yet, pulling in more than 10m viewers, according to unofficial overnight figures.

The population's thirst for the celebrity version of last year's smash reality show was seemingly unquenchable, grabbing 5.7m viewers for Channel 4 and a 23% audience share.

BBC1's 10.35pm update also took almost 5m viewers, 29% of audience share.

However, the unfolding melodrama was not enough to knock ITV's A Touch of Frost off the top spot.

The David Jason vehicle pulled in 7.9m viewers, 33% of audience share.

Channel 5's watching-paint-dry reality show Touching the Truck performed a startling rally last night, regaining almost all of the viewers it shed last night.

The programme, which features 20 contestants battling to keep some part of their body attached to a £33,000 truck, opened well on Sunday night, with 1m viewers.

On Monday, the programme went neck and neck with EastEnders for the first time, and lost 400,000 viewers.

Last night, with EastEnders going out at the earlier time of 7.30pm, Touch the Truck picked up again in the ratings, taking it back to 900,000 viewers.

The show, fronted by Dale Winton, has proved strangely compelling to some critics because of the sheer boredom factor.

Yesterday eight of the 20 contestants were forced to bow out.

fields.trailText: Plus: Robin Williams plays mean opposite Al Pacino; Benjamin Bratt in line for psycho thriller
fields.body:
 Gwyneth Paltrow is about to undergo a change of image. Shocking though it sounds, the slender star looks set to bloat out for a role in the Farrelly brothers' new comedy Shallow Hal. Paltrow will pull on a "fat suit" in order to play Jack Black's love interest in a tale about a boorish lad about town who learns to see the inner beauty of women. Empire Online quotes director Bobby Farrelly as saying that Gwyneth will play: "A big, fat girl she's game for it. She's ready to try some new stuff."

 Reportedly sick of playing winsome do-gooders and cuddly jesters, Robin Williams looks set for an audacious image change in his new picture too. The smirking one is in final negotiations to play a shadowy killer who blackmails Al Pacino's angst-ridden policeman in the American version of Insomnia. The remake of the 1997 Norwegian thriller by Erik Skjoldbjaerg begins shooting on April 9 in Alaska with Memento creator Christopher Nolan in the director's chair.

 Benjamin Bratt - still best known as Julia Roberts's latest squeeze - is in negotiations to join Dawson's Creek star Katie Holmes in the psycho-thriller Abandon. The directoral debut of Traffic writer Steve Gaghan will focus on a young woman who is haunted by visions of her ex-lover.

fields.headline: Lowest unemployment figures in 25 years
fields.standfirst: Full text of the green paper
fields.trailText: The prime minister  this morning welcomed a fall in unemployment figures to below 1m  - by announcing stringent new conditions for claiming benefits under the New Deal.
fields.body:
The prime minister this morning welcomed a fall in unemployment figures to below 1m - by announcing stringent new conditions for claiming benefits under the New Deal.

Figures released today show that the number of jobless claiming the dole has fallen to below the "benchmark" million mark for the first time in more than 25 years.

Using the fall to launch a government green paper on unemployment, Mr Blair said: "We do not rest on our laurels. One million people, even just under one million people, is still too many out of work."

Official figures put the jobless total at 996,200 - just 3.4% of the working age population.

The government used the news to send out three of its biggest hitters - the PM, chancellor Gordon Brown and social security secretary Alistair Darling - to launch a proposal which will copy the US system by withdrawing benefits from claimants who refuse to take up one of the four options on offer.

The Chancellor announced that before receiving benefit, unemployed people will have to be interviewed about job opportunities and the steps they are taking to get back into work.

There will be a new compulsory "skills check up" for unemployed claimants and a pilot project requiring the unemployed to take up skills training.

Anyone who repeatedly refuses to take part in one of the schemes will have their benefits withdrawn for up to 26 weeks.

Mr Blair called the measures "innovative and practical", adding: "We are willing to do whatever it takes to give people the skills, confidence and opportunities to move into work.

"We are on a genuine crusade to achieve full employment.

"That is why we are setting out the next steps on jobs with a package of proposals on employment aimed at helping disadvantaged people in disadvantaged communities open up the pathways to work."

Mr Brown added: "I want every child in every part of Britain as they get up for school every morning, to see a whole community around them getting up and going to work."

Mr Blair said that for generations people had dreamt about returning to full employment and added: "That dream is now within our grasp."

Mr Blair said the government's focus would now switch to people who had been considered as unable to work, including lone parents, partners of the unemployed, and many disabled people. There had been very little support for these groups of unemployed.

Mr Brown said the claimant count had now fallen by 667,000 since the last election while the International Labour Organisation total - which still puts the total unemployed in the UK as above one million - was down by 556,000.

During the same period the number of people in work has increased by almost 1.2m.

The number of job vacancies has also increased by 40% since 1997.

Mr Brown said it was the toughness of the New Deal which had helped 270,000 young people into work.

He said: "It is the new rights and new responsibilities of the second stage of the New Deal that will move us closer to our ambition of full employment."

Mr Brown said £120m will be spent over the next three years creating action teams in areas hardest hit by unemployment.

Another £200m a year will be spent on offering training and advice to the long-term unemployed. A £40 million programme will be launched to help 30,000 reformed drug addicts find a job.

Mr Brown added: "Full employment is not just an economic cause that will make the economy more efficient. For all of us who have seen the devastating social effects of unemployment it is a crusade."

The government also announced today that a "radical" new service is to be launched at 50 locations across the country to help people back into work.

The service will gave claimants specialist job help including personal advisers to assist people find vacancies. Social security secretary Alistair Darling said the newly-created working age agency will aim to help everyone of working age as well as providing advice on benefits.

"From Scotland to Wales, from urban sites in the north-west to rural Devon, we will be inviting people claiming benefits to come into the office for an interview."

The historic drop was welcomed by trade union leaders.

GMB general secretary John Edmonds said: "Winning the war on unemployment has been one of this government's greatest achievements. "The Tories dismissed full employment as a left-wing fantasy but today it is within our grasp. This has gone a long way to erasing the stain of the Thatcher years."

The general secretary of public service union Unison, Dave Prentis, said: "Figures such as these help heal the economic wounds of a generation. "However, our ultimate goal must be full and fair employment, with an emphasis on levelling out regional differences."

fields.headline: Budget cash a disappointment
fields.standfirst: Last week's Budget announcement showed that while new government thinking is both regionally and regeneration focused, there's little money available in 2001-02 to back it up, writes Aaron Cahill
fields.trailText: Comment: Last week's Budget announcement showed that while new government thinking is both regionally and regeneration focused, there's little money available in 2001-02 to back it up, writes Aaron Cahill.
fields.body:
The extra £500m promised to regional development agencies (RDAs) as part of last year's comprehensive spending review was one of the main government hooks for regeneration.

So what is to be made of last week's Budget announcements on funding for the first year of this new order? If anything, 2001-02 looks like a standstill budget, meeting existing commitments from the retired single regeneration budget (SRB) programme.

There is little or no new money to start new schemes, making it little wonder there was no hurry to publish guidance on the new single budget that is replacing it.

Judiciously, the government has called 2001-02 a "transitional year", which means that a year's worth of regeneration allocations - totalling more than £1.2bn to 189 partnerships in last year's SRB round - will not be happening during the year beginning April 2001.

The blow to regeneration partnerships could be found writ large in an announcement which (predictably) was bullish about what RDAs would be doing in the future. A press release from the Department of the Environment, Transport and the Regions highlighted new budget flexibility and £5m for a bigger scrutiny role for regional chambers over the activities of RDAs. But flexibility and scrutiny over what?

The press release pointed out that 2001-02 allocations to RDAs totalled £1.347bn. What it failed to make explicit was just how much of this was to meet existing commitments from the previous six rounds of the SRB.

For London, the situation is little short of chronic: the £277m commitment from SRB actually exceeds the allocation available from the Treasury.

An additional £24m has had to be found to ensure the London Development Agency can meet its existing commitments. The picture for the other eight RDAs does not make impressive reading either.

What characterised previous rounds of the SRB programme, was the ability of government offices (and latterly the RDAs) to allocate resources up to seven years in advance.

This helped fund housing regeneration schemes like those in Stepney and (the much-maligned) Peckham Partnership. This is obviously one of the reasons why the RDAs find themselves carrying such heavy commitments forward, and it will be some years before RDAs finally get some financial flexibility to invest where they see fit.

But it does also indicate that RDAs will be unwilling or unable to commit funding in a way that regeneration partnerships have been used to.

So where does this leave the RDAs? Are they a triumph of style over substance, or the next stage of something important that will be the cornerstone of the regional and regeneration agenda?

The spate of recent statements should have made that clear, and while new government thinking is both regionally and regeneration focused, there's little money available in 2001-02 to back it up.

It is hoped that a few years down the line the picture will be different, with RDAs being given more money. And perhaps this is why they are biting their lips at the moment. But here and now, this year was to be the beginning of more money for regeneration out of the spending review.

And this makes the news about little new money for 2001-02 all the more disappointing.

 Aaron Cahill is a regeneration policy officer at the National Housing Federation.

fields.headline: Northern and Hell for high earners
fields.trailText:
6pm update: Staff at the Express believe that management have targeted those journalists who earn more than £50,000 a year, writes Lisa O'Carroll
Axe falls heavily at Express
fields.body:
Staff at the Express believe that management have targeted those journalists who earn more than £50,000 a year.

One source said those who were going to be axed would be offered six months pay.

The redundancies mean staffing levels at The Express and Sunday Express will fall from 440 journalists to 310.

Remaining staff may also be told they must work across all titles in the group including the Express' sister paper The Daily Star.

It may also mean staff could be called at short notice to write for OK! magazine, the lead title in Richard Desmond's Northern & Shell group.

"The atmosphere here is one of real anger. I think there could be a strike over this," said one journalist on the paper.

Another said: "They are trying to force Northern &Shell contracts on us. Does this mean we will be required to work on Forum or Asian Babes? It doesn't bear thinking about."
Axe falls heavily at Express

webTitle: So bad it's good: Julie Burchill on celebrity Big Brother.

fields.headline: So bad it's good
fields.standfirst:
It hardly sounded promising: a bunch of second-rate personalities dropped into a reheated gameshow. But celebrity Big Brother has proved irresistible TV. And it's the very pathos of its faded and fragile contestants that makes it so compelling, says Julie Burchill

'Nasty' Nick Bateman: 'A bunch of desperate celebrities.'
Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: It hardly sounded promising: a bunch of second-rate personalities dropped into a reheated gameshow. But celebrity Big Brother has proved irresistible TV. And it's the very pathos of its faded and fragile contestants that makes it so compelling, says Julie Burchill.
fields.body:
It seemed such a good idea at the time. Take the sure-fire car-crash appeal of the Big Brother format and stick it in a blender with the celebrity-snooping that threatens to consume western society in a vast vat of froth. Give it a quick whizz until it's nice and sticky and down in one in aid of Comic Relief. And it has turned out to be great TV, though probably not in the way it was intended.

In the early days of its inception, rather dashing candidates were mentioned: the seriously famous (Mel B), the seriously screwed up (Chris Evans), and the seriously sexy and charismatic (Mariella Frostrup). Mmm, a window on Olympus! But there's many a slip, and somewhere along the line the prime cuts of fame dwindled down to the scrag ends.

Mind you, even within this airtight little kingdom there is still the ever-present hierarchy of fame. At the top of the ladder sit Jack Dee and Claire Sweeney, interestingly the only people in the house who could in any way be described as being talented; this reflects itself in their groundedness. Dee's straightness and lack of showbiz bullshit (hilariously, he nominated Vanessa Feltz for eviction "because she keeps banging on about what a good cause it's for, and it's getting boring") and Sweeney's amazingly saucy blue-collar charm sent them up in my estimation considerably - and in the case of Miss Sweeney, nearly made me question my sexuality all over again. She is obviously that one-in-a-million actor who is not at all thick, conceited or graceless as well as being the embodiment of a peculiarly Scouse sex appeal - sly, fly, self-mocking - and the perfection of her figure in her tight jeans and little tops is a revelation after all those years of Lindsay Corkhill's depressing chip-shop overalls. In short, phwooar!

In the middle of the pecking order we have Keith Duffy, the ex-pop singer and Chris Eubank, the ex-boxer, now both obviously hoping for some sort of gig in the meejah - "presenting", probably. Ah, "presenting" - the Holy Grail of the modern micro-celebrity. The growth of satellite television has created a boom town for the legions of media wannabes who have ambition but no talent, and sometimes it seems that every ex-page three girl, sports starlet or celebrity wife is bent on a job "presenting". (One day, surely, we'll run out of programmes for them to present, and the end result will be Presenters Presenting Presenters.)

These jobs seem attractive, especially to someone who is all attention-seeking and no skills, but for that very reason they are lethal, especially for women. Relying as they do on being rather than doing, on appearance rather than talent, the presenter remains in the permanent state of a prostitute lined up in a bordello, for ever projecting her hopefully superior charms in order to get the punter's money. And, of course, there is always someone younger, blonder, cuter coming up on the inside ...

The pathos of the short-term presenter is summed up heartbreakingly in the persons of Anthea Turner and Vanessa Feltz, the twin occupants of the lowest rung of the Big Brother ladder; as they fall apart - Vanessa messily and swiftly, Anthea more photogenically and professionally - it is horribly compelling, like watching a John Cassavetes film or hearing your neighbours' marriage break up in gory detail through the wall. They are the flimsiest, most damaged and most compelling creatures in the house, with none of the confidence born of talent that Dee and Sweeney possess, or the dumb macho swagger of Eubank and Duffy. Even their names - 19th-century literary inventions - seem to mock their lack of substance and roots.

The interesting thing about the famous is always the gap between "personality" - that which is touted to the public - and character, the raw, pink squirming thing inside the carapace. Both Turner and Feltz are perfect examples of people whose public personalities are the exact opposite of their real selves. Turner's cleaner than clean persona all along masked a woman completely driven by sex, while Feltz's wacky, madcap persona hides a woman of profound melancholy.

I often wondered why she pulled that hideously unattractive, pop-eyed rictus grin in every photograph taken of her, and now I understand; in repose, her face is simply the saddest I've ever seen, with the clownishly downturned mouth of the tragedy mask and restless, rejected eyes. People say of certain fat women - Dawn French is another - "Oh, she'd be so pretty if she lost weight," but in Vanessa's case the melted layers of fat have revealed a face that expresses little more than confusion and dismay.

The terrible precariousness of the professional presenters' position was revealed in the reactions of Turner and Feltz to their eviction nominations; tears. Tears, from two educated, adult women in their 40s! What is their mental age, you have to wonder? And what sort of psyche is so desperately dependent on the kindness of strangers that its withdrawal can actually make them cry real tears? If these people are not actually clinically depressed now, it can't be long before they are.

I'm inclined to blame punk; it was the punk ethos, after all, which preached that talent, creativity and charisma were unnecessary, and that wanting it was everything. Feltz is the logical end product of an age in which ambition is valued more highly than skills. Paradoxically, the piece of work that has caused Feltz the most distress is also the best piece of decent TV she's ever been involved in. Suddenly we could see what she was for ; singularly ungifted as a talk-show host and television presenter, she has come into her own as a sort of modern morality play about where the pursuit of fame for fame's sake gets you. Dee and Sweeney aside, it's hard to believe that anyone in the house will ever do anything that makes such an impression on the collective consciousness again, which is in itself a comment on the flimsiness of their alleged careers. The original Big Brother occupants were allowed to sink back into obscurity after their brief day in the Sun; by the time the repercussions from this melee die down, obscurity will seem infinitely seductive to these prancing, damaged puppets, who only ever really wanted love. Whether they will find it now is another matter.

Feltz is the logical end product of an age in which ambition is valued more highly than skills. Paradoxically, the piece of work that has caused Feltz the most distress is also the best piece of decent TV she's ever been involved in. Suddenly we could see what she was for ; singularly ungifted as a talk-show host and television presenter, she has come into her own as a sort of modern morality play about where the pursuit of fame for fame's sake gets you. Dee and Sweeney aside, it's hard to believe that anyone in the house will ever do anything that makes such an impression on the collective consciousness again, which is in itself a comment on the flimsiness of their alleged careers. The original Big Brother occupants were allowed to sink back into obscurity after their brief day in the Sun; by the time the repercussions from this melee die down, obscurity will seem infinitely seductive to these prancing, damaged puppets, who only ever really wanted love. Whether they will find it now is another matter. Talk about it Who do you think should get thrown out of celebrity Big Brother? webTitle: Ask Anna: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.

fields.headline: Ask Anna
fields.standfirst: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner
fields.trailText: The Guardian's consumer champion fights your corner.
fields.body:
All at sea

This page is often tear-stained with the woes of airline passengers, so here's a crumb of comfort for them: it could be a whole lot worse if you travel by ferry.

Peter Hoida and Caroline Hislam of Stroud had booked a 9am sailing from Cork to Swansea last October. They arrived early at check-in only to be told by Swansea Cork Ferries that the departure would be delayed until 6pm. At midnight they were still in the departure lounge and no announcement had been made. After queuing at the information counter, they learned that there would be no sailing that night. By then it was too late to find accommodation, so they spent the night in the departure lounge.

At 10am the next morning they were thrown out and told to phone for information the following day. This time the staff did agree to book a £45-a-night hotel room since they had no currency left for phoning (the room charge later turned out to be £90).

The next day the couple could not get through on the ferry phone lines so bought a passage with Stena leaving from Rosslare that afternoon. When they arrived at the port, they discovered that Swansea Cork ferries had an agreement with Stena and that some of the former's passengers had had substitute tickets issued for the Stena crossing, albeit 52 hours after their sailing was cancelled. Hoida and Hislam demanded a reimbursement of their expenses, but received only a refund for their cancelled passage and £50 voucher which, they say, is useless since they don't intend to travel with Swansea Cork again.

Swansea Cork blames poor weather conditions for the last-minute cancellation, and says that there is "very little that our staff could have done". Presumably they could have informed passengers that their tickets were valid on two other lines, but the company seems to think it was up to the passengers to find that out. If they couldn't get through, which Swansea Cork admits many couldn't, that's too bad.

According to the Passenger Shipping Association, provision of food and accommodation under such circumstances is at the discretion of individual ferry companies. It also points out that Swansea Cork recommends that passengers take out insurance to cover cancellations. One last hope for victims like Hislam and Hoida: the Association does offer a free arbitration and conciliation scheme.

No party

So keen are we all to escape our own kitchens that some more popular restaurants now charge diners who renege on their bookings. But what if the restaurant lets the customer down?

When Nicki Little of Leicester decided to splash out on a Christmas-cum-leaving party for 80 colleagues, she booked a room at Bar Moosh in Cambridge and was told that someone would be in touch regarding menu and prices. The following week a manager rang to report that another party (paying a higher rate) wanted to squeeze in on the same night, but that she could have the place to herself if she preferred. She did, and that's when things got mysterious.

The menu man never called and Little, who had sent out 80 invitations, tried in vain to contact him. After three weeks of silence, she revisited the bar and claims the same manager refused to see her. She was also told she couldn't leave a deposit. On her fifth visit she noticed that another party booking had been confirmed for the same evening, despite promises to the contrary, but she was allowed to leave a £200 deposit this time.

Three days later she received her first email from Bar Moosh. It said that her Visa payment had been voided either by herself or the bank, which the restaurant took to mean she no longer wanted the reservation. On inspecting her copy of the Visa slip, she noticed that "transaction void" was printed across the bottom. Her bank confirmed that the transaction had never been presented by the restaurant.

Three days before the event, and two months after her booking, Little had no venue for her party. Bar Moosh made a vague offer of compensation, but Little has heard nothing.

Consumer faxes the saga to the same employee who handled Little's case. He promises to respond within a week, but when we call back a week later it turns out that he has left the company. Despite several phone calls and emails from us over the next five weeks, the restaurant's licensee, John Varnom, who also runs Bar Moosh in Royston and the Green Man in Lowestoft, makes no response. In general, diners who find that their booking has not been honoured can seek reimbursement via the small claims court, providing they complain in writing to the restaurant first.

Bill of complaint

Colin Roe of London was dismayed to find a red reminder bill for an overdue gas payment on his doormat. There was the usual digit fest: an account number, a contact for reporting power failure, another contact for people having difficulty paying their bill, a meter number, unit price and the number of units consumed. A payment of £154 was due by March 1. The only oddity was a broad red strip at the bottom of the page saying such a demand "could send some people over the edge". In fact, the bill was a gimmick by the homeless charity Crisis, but Roe felt it misfired. "To make out a red bill in the name of an individual could have unpleasant consequences in the case of an elderly or confused person," he says.

Poor Crisis, whose aims were so well-meaning. "We tried to make it clear that it was not real. Unfortunately, some people who received it thought it was a real bill and we have received some complaints," says a spokeswoman. "Crisis never anticipated that it would be misinterpreted and are extremely sorry for any upset caused. We will not be using similar tactics again."

fields.headline: Unilever's Duncan set for BBC marketing job
fields.trailText:
10.30am: The BBC is believed to have hired Unilever's Andy Duncan as director of marketing to replace Matthew Bannister, reports Julia Day.

Dec 15: Turner-Laing takes acting role at BBC marketing
Oct 13: Bannister weighs up his options
Bannister - wrong man in wrong job?
fields.body:
The BBC is believed to have hired Unilever foods marketer Andy Duncan as director of marketing and communications to replace Matthew Bannister.

Mr Bannister quit the post in October after only six months in charge of the corporation's £73m marketing budget.

Since his departure speculation has been rife about his successor. Former BBC director of corporate marketing Jane Frost and Channel 5 marketing director Jim Hytner were both approached about the job.

Mr Duncan, 38, is category director, spreads and cooking products for Unilever Bestfoods Europe, which is based in Belgium.

He was previously marketing director for Van den Burgh's chilled food brands, having worked within Unilever for 16 years.

The BBC will be hoping Mr Duncan will bring some stability to its 400-strong marketing department, which has been rocked by restructuring and the departure of several senior marketers including marketing director Sue Farr last April.

A BBC spokeswoman said no appointment has been made.

fields.headline: Robert Ludlum
fields.standfirst: Prolific thriller writer whose conspiratorial plots of unimaginable evil defined the airport novel
fields.trailText: Prolific thriller writer whose conspiratorial plots of unimaginable evil defined the airport novel.
fields.body:
The thriller writer Robert Ludlum, who has died of a heart attack aged 73, in the gulf coast town of Naples, Florida, was one of a handful of authors who invented and came to define airport fiction. He enjoyed a 30-year writing career in which, according to his publisher, he sold more than 210m copies of his 21 novels.

Put crudely, Ludlum was the fictional arm of the globalisation of American culture. Before him, its popular fiction had been rooted in established genres - westerns, crime fiction, historical romance, sub-James Bond spy thrillers. Like Arthur Hailey and Tom Clancy, Ludlum blasted aside such boundaries, mirroring, as he did so, the rise of the modern Hollywood blockbuster. And yet he did not write his first novel, The Scarlatti Inheritance (1971), until he was in his 40s.

Ludlum was born in New York, and grew up in Short Hills, New Jersey. He left home as a teenager in 1941 and, getting a part in a touring play, tried to make it as an actor. His parents soon rescued him from Broadway, after which he spent two years with the US Marine Corps in the Pacific in the aftermath of the second world war. He then attended Wesleyan University, in Connecticut, where he met his actress wife, Mary Ryducha.

Together they went into the theatre, where Ludlum spent the next two decades working as an actor, with minor roles on television and on Broadway, and then as a producer, running what was allegedly America's first shopping-mall theatre, the Playhouse, in Paramus, New Jersey. In 1960, he produced The Owl And The Pussycat, using a then unknown actor named Alan Alda.

Having a famously deep voice, Ludlum also made some money doing voice-overs on the side; he once claimed that uttering the words "Plunge works fast", in a toilet cleaner commercial, put one of his sons through college. When the theatre business began to pall, he quit to write his first novel.

The key ingredients were there from the start - a grand conspiracy, and forces of unimaginable evil that only one individual could thwart. The Scarlatti Inheritance was a preposterous, yet compelling, yarn revolving around the notion that, back in the 1920s, a worldwide cabal of high-ranking Nazi sympathisers made a plan to ensure world domination. At the heart of the plan is a child called Ulster, reared specially for the job and now ready to go into action. There is only one person who can stop him - his mother.

The book was an immediate success, and Ludlum followed it up with a book a year through the 1970s, each one with the same signature-title construction. The Osterman Weekend (1972) was filmed (unmemorably) by Sam Peckinpah. The Bourne Identity (1980), perhaps the pick of the bunch, has just been filmed, with Matt Damon in the lead. One after another, the titles continued to sell more than 20m each, Ludlum's readers apparently happy enough despite the fact that his formula was becoming ever more transparent and repetitive.

Today, it has become the critical norm to rubbish Ludlum and his ilk as purveyors of semi-literate, rightwing tosh. This is unfair on several counts. For a start, no one survives long in popular fiction without having the ability to keep the pages turning. Secondly, Ludlum was not the rightwinger people tend to take mass-market thriller writers to be - the gung-ho Clancy is actually the exception to the rule. Indeed, Ludlum frequently cited living through the red-baiting McCarthy years as a key influence on his plots, which often revolved around neo-Nazi conspiracies and rarely evoked the "red menace".

Not that Ludlum should be read as a serious political commentator in the way that one might approach Eric Ambler or John Le Carré. He himself would probably have disparaged any such claims, being much given to remarks like, "I don't believe that my first name is Leo, or that my last name is Tolstoy. I'm a storyteller."

And that's right. His great talent was as a storyteller. Arguably, the key to Ludlum's success was precisely the fact that he took a historically political genre, the spy thriller, and turned it into pure escapism by making everything larger than life. He did this both literally - his books got longer and longer as time went on - and conceptually, since nothing less than the safety of the world was ever at stake, and the action could never be contained in a single continent. Which is part of what made him the perfect airport novelist: what better for a busy executive - or would-be executive - to read as he jets around the world than a novel that does likewise?

The other keystone of Ludlum's popularity was painstaking research. He explained that he spent about three months on research, and about 15 months writing his books. Thanks to that, his thrillers always had the air of being written by a man in the know, an important quality in popular fiction aimed at the male reader - and Ludlum is very much a writer of boys' books - who likes a hefty amount of factual information.

It is as if reading a novel would be an unforgivable indulgence if the reader did not learn something concrete from it; how to evade an infra-red security system, or the precise specification of the latest terrorist weapon. It is a trend that reached its logical conclusion in the work of Ludlum's successor, Clancy, whose books offer enough technical information for the reader to construct his own nuclear submarine.

As Ludlum's prodigious pace slowed a little, following a triple bypass in the mid-1990s, he launched a series, Robert Ludlum's Covert-One, in which his fictional ideas were fleshed out with the help of a co-writer, Gayle Lynds. However, hardcore fans were relieved to see him go solo again with his latest book, The Prometheus Deception (2000). It is typical Ludlum: a hero who realises that nothing is what it seems, a global conspiracy and endless double-crosses. This time, the menace is not neo-Nazism but the computerised surveillance culture.

Devotees will be glad to know that this will not be Ludlum's final work. At the time of his death, his publishers were quick to announce that he had been working on several books, which they were going to continue to publish.

He leaves his wife, two sons and a daughter.

Robert Ludlum, writer, born May 25 1927; died March 12 2001

webTitle: In brief: French film budgets soar in 2000

fields.headline: French film budgets soar in 2000
fields.standfirst: Plus: James Ellroy to write his first original screenplay
fields.trailText: Plus: James Ellroy to write his first original screenplay
fields.body:
 Amid all the self-congratulatory chatter about a buoyant British film industry, let no-one forget that the French aren't doing so badly themselves. Screen Daily reports that figures for 2000 paint a rosy picture for Gallic cinema. Although actual production dipped by a slight 3.3%, investment in French pictures rocketed by 16% to an impressive Fr4.5bn ($636,000). This leap was the result of a number of big-budget productions being given the green light, including Christophe Gans's period actioner Les Pacte des Loups, budgeted at Fr152m ($21.5m), and the crowd-pleasing Asterix and Obelix: Mission Cleopatra, which came in at a hitherto unheard of Fr317m ($44.9m). All in all, seven productions broke the Fr100m ($14m) budget barrier, compared to just two in 1999.

 Hard-boiled crime novelist James Ellroy will pen his first original motion picture screenplay with the urban cop thriller 77 for Paramount studios. According to the Hollywood Reporter, the film will focus on two LAPD men - one white and one black - who become embroiled in an unsolved police killing and a shoot-out between the LAPD and the Symbionese Liberation Army in the mid 1970s. Ellroy's Hollywood stock has been rising since the success of Curtis Hanson's adaptation of his novel LA Confidential. The self-styled "mad dog" of American crime fiction is currently writing a new version of the 1949 James Cagney classic White Heat for Village Roadshow Pictures and Warner Bros.

webTitle: Jobs go as walkers turn to tarmac

fields.headline: Jobs go as walkers turn to tarmac
fields.standfirst:
Lake District counts cost as holiday trade dries up

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Cumbria's tourist industry is losing up to £10m and 350 jobs a week. A letter sent out by the national park authority says: "Unless your visit is essential, do not visit the Lake District."
fields.body:
It was a beautiful day for a walk in Ambleside at the head of Windermere. But no one in boots, fleece and woolly hat could be seen on Loughrigg Fell above Ambleside and no one took the steep pull up Wansfell or strode out on the Langdale Pikes.

If they had, they would have infringed controls designed to prevent the spread of foot and mouth disease in Britain's most infected county (44 cases so far) and would have rendered themselves liable to a £5,000 fine.

Some walkers threw rucksacks over their shoulders and wandered the streets of Ambleside (pop. 3000), a town where more than half the local jobs depend on tourism. Others picked up a new leaflet offering "tarmac walks" on local lanes ranging from a three-mile ramble to a 15-mile "leg ache challenge".

Cumbria's tourist industry is losing up to £10m and 350 jobs a week, but local entrepreneurs want the world to know the Lake District is still in business. They winced at a letter sent out by the national park authority a couple of weeks ago, which said: "Unless your visit is essential, do not visit the Lake District."

That, said Chris Collier, chief executive of the Cumbria tourist board, was "a bit over the top". Once that message was broadcast, trade dried up "as if a tap had been turned off". A second letter from the authority began: "The Lake District national park is open."

"The most popular activities in the Lake District are touring by car and exploring towns and villages," said Ms Collier. "Walking comes only third. Footpaths and bridleways are closed, not the whole countryside. The landscape is still there to enjoy so long as you don't want to tramp across it."

Ms Collier wants an easing of the business rate to help operators. "We can't insure against it and businesses won't be compensated," she said at a crisis meeting called by the tourist board yesterday. "People are watching their whole livelihoods being washed away needlessly."

In Ambleside 10 staff, a fifth of the total, have been made redundant at Gaynor Sports, the town's biggest walking gear shop, now facing the worst crisis in its 30-year history. Don McPherson, the company's managing director, said he noticed a dramatic fall in business two weeks ago. "They had started roping off car parks and word got round that national park land was closed to fell walkers," he said.

By the end of the week trade had dropped by 50%. "There is great apprehension," he added. "People are asking how long this can go on."

A couple of hundred yards away, Richard Lee was making marmalade at Kent House, the bed and breakfast he has run with his wife Margaret for seven years. "Normally, we would be full every Friday and Saturday night throughout the year," he said. "But only two rooms were booked last weekend. We have lost two thirds of our business and cancellations have cost £2,000 so far."

Down the road at the headquarters of Heart of the Lakes and Cottage Life, a company with 240 holiday homes to rent and an annual rental income of up to £3m, staff are spending hours persuading sceptical customers not to cancel bookings.

Brochure orders and bookings are down about 40% on last year. "We will have to consider very carefully our next moves in terms of cutting costs," said Peter Jackson, a partner in the company. "We cannot consider that things are just going to right themselves. I daren't contemplate what happens if this goes on for eight months [as in the 1967 outbreak].

"It's so frustrating because the tourism industry is an innocent party. We are being crippled and in some cases ruined by the preventative measures. If they slaughtered every sheep in the Lake District, it wouldn't cost as much."

Henry Walker, managing director of a caravan park at Skelwith Bridge, opened up his site on March 1. "We had 140 caravans booked in for that first weekend," he said. "One turned up. This couldn't have happened at a worse time. But where there's a will there's a way. We have no option but to survive."

At yesterday's crisis meeting John Tattersall, chairman of the tourist board's commercial members' committee, looked on the bright side. "These townies will get fed up with walking up and down their terraced streets," he predicted. "Soon they will be itching to be back on the fells again. We are going to be inundated when this is over."

fields.headline: ITV joins Sky satellite partner
fields.trailText: 8am: ITV has finally come in from the digital wilderness by signing a multi-pound deal with the company that beams Sky to UK viewers. By Dan Milmo in Luxembourg.
fields.body:
ITV has finally come in from the digital wilderness by signing a £100m pound deal with the company that beams Sky to UK viewers.

The station will go on satellite from the end of the year, making it possible for Coronation Street, Who Wants to be a Millionaire? and The Bill to be available to Sky's 4.7m subscribers.

The deal, with Luxembourg-based Societe Europeenne des Satellites, is ITV's first step towards appearing on Sky's satellite package.

It could have major ramifications for OnDigital, the terrestrial broadcaster that is owned by ITV giants Granada and Carlton.

The BBC, Channel 4 and Channel 5 have been available on Sky Digital for several years, but ITV has held out to protect the interests of Carlton and Granada who tried to challenge Murdoch's pay-TV might with the terrestrial service.

However OnDigital lags significantly behind in the pay TV stakes with just over 1mn subscribers compared to Sky which will soon have 5m subscribers.

"We are delighted to have concluded this agreement with SES. This is an important first step towards ITV broadcasting on satellite," said Kate Stross, ITV finance and devlopment director.

SES owns the Astra series of satellites which distributes all of programmes available through's Sky digital package including the BBC, Discovery Channel, MTV and Sky's sports and movie services.

fields.headline: 12,000 victims of downturn
fields.standfirst: Falling revenues force Cable & Wireless and Motorola to cut jobs
fields.trailText: Two of the world's biggest telecoms companies have announced a total of almost 12,000 job cuts, writes Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
Two of the world's biggest telecommunications companies yesterday announced a total of almost 12,000 job cuts as the economic downturn continued to bite on both sides of the Atlantic.

Cable & Wireless is axing 4,000 of the 18,000 staff employed in its global division over the next 12 months, the company said as it issued a profit warning that took analysts and investors by surprise.

Two thirds of the division's workforce are employed in Britain, although it also has operations in Europe, Japan and the US.

Meanwhile Motorola, the world's second largest telecoms manufacturer, plans to reduce its staff by 7,700. This brings the total cut by the US company to more than 12,000 in the past three months.

Up to 700 jobs could go at Motorola's network base station plant in Swindon, Wiltshire. On top of that, the company wants to cut 7,000 jobs worldwide from its personal communications business.

These signs of economic distress come as global stock markets struggled to rise above two-year lows yesterday. Britain's main FTSE 100 index fell 105.8 points to a 27-month low of 5,720.7. Earlier the Nikkei 225 index had fallen 351.7 points to 11,819.7. The Dow Jones Industrial Average was also lower in early trading.

There was some limited relief for the technology driven Nasdaq composite index after four straight days of decline. The index gained just over 1% to 1,948.60 by noon yesterday, after falling below 2,000 for the first time in more than two years on Monday.

The sharp declines in American shares have prompted a fall in consumer confidence in the US and a drop in retail sales, which is further hurting corporate profits.

Motorola and Cable & Wireless blamed the cost cutting programme on economic slowdown in the US.

Mike Zafirovski, the president of Motorola's personal communications sector, said: "Unfortunately, this was a necessary next step for us to achieve renewal and stay competitive in today's dramatic business environment, particularly given the current slowdown in the economy."

Shares in C&W fell more than 20% after the company, which is one of the world's five biggest carriers of internet traffic, said that revenues were falling in both the US and Japan. The company blamed a 50% decline in prices for internet connectivity in the US over the past year as well as a drop in prices in Japan. Graham Wallace, the chief executive of Cable & Wireless, said: "Our response is to reduce costs aggressively, focus our resources on higher margin revenue and accelerate the deployment of value added services, such as managed web and application hosting."

C&W is to take an exceptional charge of £500m for the year to pay for its "continued transformation" and the establishment of C&W Global. A further exceptional charge of £450m is expected to be taken this year due network and software upgrade costs.

Shares of Motorola rose to $15.01 after the announcement, well below a 52-week high of $57.11 reached last March. The telecoms sector, which was expected to expand exponentially on the back of the increase in internet traffic, has been hit hard by the latest downturn.

There was also bad news in continental Europe yesterday when Siemens, the German manufacturing concern, issued a profits warning a day after it celebrated achieving a listing on the US stock market.

webTitle: Oscar hopefuls told to keep it brief

fields.headline: Oscar hopefuls told to keep it brief
fields.trailText: On the day that the Oscar organisers tell winners to keep their speeches short, bookmakers William Hill close the books on this year's Academy Awards
fields.body:
Gone are the days when the Oscar acceptance speech was an excuse for crashing melodramatics and poetic soliloquies. If Academy guidelines are followed, this year's ceremony could play more like a Pinter drama, with prospective Oscar winners told to keep to a terse 45 seconds apiece. Last year, Michael Caine (a winner for Best Supporting Actor) took about that long just to clear his throat.

The time limit was imposed at Monday's annual pre-Oscar lunch by Gil Cates, who has produced the televised Oscars for the past ten years. Over 100 nominees, among them some of the most powerful figures in Hollywood, listened as Cates gave his edict.

As a slight concession, the producer said that if the winners had specific people they wished to thank, the full list could be run the next day on the Academy's official website. As Cates stepped away from the mike, a tense moment of silence was broken by hearty laughter.

Meanwhile British bookmakers William Hill have closed the books on this year's Oscars. The odds are now fixed, with Julia Roberts the hot favourite to win Best Actress at 1/6, and Juliette Binoche (13/2), Joan Allen (8/1), Ellen Burstyn (9/1) and Laura Linney (16/1) trailing behind.

Gladiator is in poll position to take the Best Picture award at 1/5, followed by Traffic (7/2), Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon (7/1), Erin Brockovich (10/1) and Chocolat (25/1).

But the bookies seem less certain over the direction of the Best Actor award. They have Russell Crowe and Tom Hanks neck and neck on 5/6 apiece. The other, less fancied nominees - Ed Harris, Javier Bardem and Geoffrey Rush - are tied on 16/1.

webTitle: Scared silly: Controversial author Frank Furedi argues that irrational fear about children's safety is turning us into control freaks.

fields.headline: Scared silly
fields.standfirst: In his book Paranoid Parenting, controversial author Frank Furedi argues that irrational fear about children's safety is turning us into control freaks. Kids need their own space and parents need to chill, he tells  Joanna Moorhead
fields.trailText: In his book Paranoid Parenting, controversial author Frank Furedi argues that irrational fear about children's safety is turning us into control freaks. Kids need their own space and parents need to chill, he tells Joanna Moorhead.
fields.body:
Frank Furedi is not a relaxed parent. He can be laid-back about some things: his five-year-old son, Jacob, is encouraged to play in the woods near their family home, and Furedi hopes he will soon be able to cycle to school. But when it comes to illness, Furedi frets. He worries about his son's health. He can even quote you Jacob's temperature when he was last poorly. In short, he is paranoid - in common with all parents, he maintains.

"We all have our vulnerabilities, our areas of concern, our fears," says Furedi. "We all have something that can be played on and opened up, and which then becomes the basis of fear in our parenting."

So, Furedi is on a mission: he wants to make us aware of our paranoia so we can all cool it and be a bit more rational where looking after our kids is concerned. Thus the message of his new book, Paranoid Parenting, is: stop listening to the "experts"; tear up the handbook; and follow your instincts - where your child is concerned, you know best.

Of course, there is a certain paradox to all this, since Furedi himself is a type of expert - a sociologist at the University of Kent - and before you follow his advice never to read another parenting book, he would love you to buy this one. His ideas were formed, he says, after he became a father at the relatively advanced age of 48, and discovered that parenting had changed rather a lot in the decades between his own boyhood and that of his son.

In particular, what he noticed was that children were no longer left to their own devices. He describes it as a "colonisation" of the world of children by adults. As a consequence, he says, adults not only inhabit but control the lives of children to an alarming and unhealthy extent.

For Furedi, whose 1997 book The Culture of Fear examined the way risk is perceived in society, the most obvious manifestation of this control centres on fears about children's safety. The real risks, he argues, are magnified by irrational fears; and so kids' freedom and creativity are being limited. While Jacob is encouraged to play outside the Furedis' home in Faversham, Kent, many children are kept indoors - out of harm's way. But the harm, Furedi would have us believe, is largely imagined: yes, we read a lot about child abduction, murder and paedophilia, but the risks to our own children from these evils are minuscule. Our fears are fed by study after alarm-bell-ringing study alerting us to this or that childhood danger. Furedi disputes the idea that most of these studies originate in universities like his own. In fact, he says, many are market research reports masquerading as more serious analyses. The media are the villains of the piece, and here there is a whiff of Furedi's past as a member of the Revolutionary Communist Party, whose magazine Living Marxism had an unerring instinct for controversy and an abiding contempt for the "bourgeois press". But the result, he says, is a generation of parents who believe that their children are at real risk, and who are overreacting in their efforts to protect them.

"When I ask people why they limit their children's activities in a particular way," says Furedi, "they always say, 'I couldn't live with myself if anything happened.' In other words, they're talking about themselves, not about their children."

All this worry, he believes, is casting a shadow over family life. Take cot death, for example. Furedi says that when he and his wife, Ann, were expecting Jacob, the risks of cot death were often mentioned. "Every mother I know admits to having worried at some point that their child is at risk," he notes. "It's emblematic of the campaign that we've created."

The effect of this climate of fear on parents is exacerbated by the fact that more and more is expected from them, argues Furedi: "Take education: today's parents are expected to be amateur teachers, involved in every part of their children's schoolwork. It's certainly not enough to leave it to the school. I think that degrades education, because it means politicians can ignore the problems of schools.

"What I'm saying is that we've established this culture in which parents have a direct sense of responsibility for everything that happens to their children. What this means is that we've lost our autonomy."

Furedi thinks that because we now feel we have to take responsibility for every part of our children's lives, we take every threat to their safety too seriously. "It's not worth altering your behaviour and being on red alert for what are relatively small risks," he maintains. "We've got to accept that life contains risks and it's far better to be aware of them than to let them enslave our lives."

The counter-argument to all this is that today's parents are more knowledgeable about certain areas of parenting and more involved in their children's lives than parents in the 50s and 60s. But Furedi is having none of this. First, he says, it is naive to argue that the information we are being fed about, say, health risks in pregnancy is widening our choice or improving our parenting; in fact they often lead to enforced conformity. "Take the US, where in some areas pregnant women can be arrested for drinking in public," he says. "What begins as advice ends up as coercion."

Furedi concedes that there may be a positive aspect to parents being more involved in the lives of their children, but adds that: "The danger is, it becomes compulsive. What starts as involvement becomes this infinite process, and you lose the ability to draw a line between what your children should be doing on their own and what adults should be doing."

Furedi describes his own childhood - he grew up in Hungary in the 50s - as a happy one, despite a lack of material wealth and a father who had to work a 60-hour week. Interestingly, he admits that his mother, who had survived imprisonment in a concentration camp, was overprotective. His own desire to be hands-off about Jacob's upbringing, and to persuade the rest of us to take the same approach, is at least partly a reaction to that. "Our own parents probably did a reasonable job given the constraints they were under, and I don't think it's helpful to criticise them."

fields.bodyText: Frank Furedi is not a relaxed parent. He can be laid-back about some things: his five-year-old son, Jacob, is encouraged to play in the woods near their family home, and Furedi hopes he will soon be able to cycle to school. But when it comes to illness, Furedi frets. He worries about his son's health. He can even quote you Jacob's temperature when he was last poorly. In short, he is paranoid - in common with all parents, he maintains. "We all have our vulnerabilities, our areas of concern, our fears," says Furedi. "We all have something that can be played on and opened up, and which then becomes the basis of fear in our parenting." So, Furedi is on a mission: he wants to make us aware of our paranoia so we can all cool it and be a bit more rational where looking after our kids is concerned. Thus the message of his new book, Paranoid Parenting, is: stop listening to the "experts"; tear up the handbook; and follow your instincts - where your child is concerned, you know best. Of course, there is a certain paradox to all this, since Furedi himself is a type of expert - a sociologist at the University of Kent - and before you follow his advice never to read another parenting book, he would love you to buy this one. His ideas were formed, he says, after he became a father at the relatively advanced age of 48, and discovered that parenting had changed rather a lot in the decades between his own boyhood and that of his son. In particular, what he noticed was that children were no longer left to their own devices. He describes it as a "colonisation" of the world of children by adults. As a consequence, he says, adults not only inhabit but control the lives of children to an alarming and unhealthy extent. For Furedi, whose 1997 book The Culture of Fear examined the way risk is perceived in society, the most obvious manifestation of this control centres on fears about children's safety. The real risks, he argues, are magnified by irrational fears; and so kids' freedom and creativity are being limited. While Jacob is encouraged to play outside the Furedis' home in Faversham, Kent, many children are kept indoors - out of harm's way. But the harm, Furedi would have us believe, is largely imagined: yes, we read a lot about child abduction, murder and paedophilia, but the risks to our own children from these evils are minuscule. Our fears are fed by study after alarm-bell-ringing study alerting us to this or that childhood danger. Furedi disputes the idea that most of these studies originate in universities like his own. In fact, he says, many are market research reports masquerading as more serious analyses. The media are the villains of the piece, and here there is a whiff of Furedi's past as a member of the Revolutionary Communist Party, whose magazine Living Marxism had an unerring instinct for controversy and an abiding contempt for the "bourgeois press". But the result, he says, is a generation of parents who believe that their children are at real risk, and who are overreacting in their efforts to protect them. "When I ask people why they limit their children's activities in a particular way," says Furedi, "they always say, 'I couldn't live with myself if anything happened.' In other words, they're talking about themselves, not about their children." All this worry, he believes, is casting a shadow over family life. Take cot death, for example. Furedi says that when he and his wife, Ann, were expecting Jacob, the risks of cot death were often mentioned. "Every mother I know admits to having worried at some point that their child is at risk," he notes. "It's emblematic of the campaign that we've created." The effect of this climate of fear on parents is exacerbated by the fact that more and more is expected from them, argues Furedi: "Take education: today's parents are expected to be amateur teachers, involved in every part of their children's schoolwork. It's certainly not enough to leave it to the school. I think that degrades education, because it means politicians can ignore the problems of schools. "What I'm saying is that we've established this culture in which parents have a direct sense of responsibility for everything that happens to their children. What this means is that we've lost our autonomy." Furedi thinks that because we now feel we have to take responsibility for every part of our children's lives, we take every threat to their safety too seriously. "It's not worth altering your behaviour and being on red alert for what are relatively small risks," he maintains. "We've got to accept that life contains risks and it's far better to be aware of them than to let them enslave our lives." The counter-argument to all this is that today's parents are more knowledgeable about certain areas of parenting and more involved in their children's lives than parents in the 50s and 60s. But Furedi is having none of this. First, he says, it is naive to argue that the information we are being fed about, say, health risks in pregnancy is widening our choice or improving our parenting; in fact they often lead to enforced conformity. webTitle: Museveni decared winner in Ugandan elections

fields.headline: Museveni decared winner in Ugandan elections
fields.trailText: The Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni, easily won the country's hard-fought presidential election today, but his main challenger demanded a new poll after rejecting the vote.
fields.body:
The Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni, easily won the country's hard-fought presidential election today, but his main challenger demanded a new poll after rejecting the vote.

With results declared from all but 14 of 17,308 polling stations, Mr Museveni has taken 69.3% of the vote. The electoral commission said that his rival, Kizza Besigye, has just 27.8%.

"Therefore, President Yoweri Museveni is declared the winner of the 2001 presidential elections," commission chairman Aziz Kasujja announced.

Mr Besigye has already rejected the outcome. "I write to inform you that my task force and I vehemently reject the ... election results that are now being declared by your commission and demand fresh elections," Mr Besigye said in a letter to the today.

"We will not meekly submit to those who want to govern without the people's mandate, we shall resist them," he said. "We consider the results being declared null and void."

Mr Museveni was widely expected to win a final five-year term as leader of the east African nation, but the poll was hit by reports of vote-rigging and intimidation of Mr Besigye's supporters.

Mr Museveni's campaign spokesman, information minister Basoga Nsadhu, said that his candidate had won fairly.

"He (Besigye) should accept that he has been defeated," Mr Nsadhu said.

Mr Besigye has said that his agents had been chased from many polling stations or detained by the army during the voting. He also accused Mr Museveni's supporters of voting more than once.

Armed police were patrolling the streets of Kampala today, but no incidents were reported.

Mr Kasujja confirmed that he had received two letters from Mr Besigye's camp complaining about the electoral process.

"It is Besigye's right to deny the results because everybody has the right to complain. But people voted during the day and the votes were counted in broad daylight - I do not accept that there was rigging," he said.

Some international observers have said that they believed there were irregularities in some parts of the country.

"In a lot of places there was very little to be concerned about," noted one. "In some places there was a lot to be concerned about."

Local monitors have said that such irregularities may have "seriously compromised" the election.

"There have been various cases of irregularities and of particular concern are the districts of Rukingiri, Kabale, Mbale and Soroti," said Pam Okille-Etiang of poll monitors NEMGROUP.

"We have asked the EC (electoral commission) to investigate and seriously consider a rerun in these districts. The question we are now discussing is whether these irregularities have seriously compromised the whole election," Ms Okille-Etiang continued.

Mr Museveni took power as the head of a guerrilla in 1986. He was elected as president a decade later. He ended a period for Uganda under dictators Idi Amin and Milton Obote, during which hundreds of thousands of the country's people were tortured and killed.

Mr Museveni is credited with rebuilding the economy, introducing free education, improving women's situation and bringing Aids under control. He is also responsible for banning political parties, which he blamed for ethnic and sectarian hatred.

The Monitor
CIA factbook on Uganda

fields.headline: Voluntary sector lacks skilled managers
fields.standfirst: Improving the quality of management is one of the main challenges for the future development of the voluntary sector, writes Adam Woolf
fields.trailText: Improving the quality of management is one of the main challenges for the future development of the voluntary sector, writes Adam Woolf.
fields.body:
Improving the quality of management is one of the main challenges for the future development of the voluntary sector, according to Ben Kenighan, head of the Voluntary Sector National Training Organisation in England (VSNTO).

The VSNTO is one of a network of 73 national training organisations recognised by the government. It aims to help the voluntary sector develop the necessary skills to help the sector grow and flourish in the future.

Speaking at the launch of the VSNTO's workforce development plan for the voluntary sector in London, Mr Kenighan said the social and economic benefits to volunteering were well documented. However, shortage of experienced managers was now a growing problem for the voluntary sector.

He said, "Our research shows the biggest skills shortage facing the sector is management skills. Voluntary organisations are increasingly having to compete with other sectors for the best management talent. The demand for managers across the economy as a whole is set to increase as a result of relatively low unemployment and the continuing shift towards a service economy."

He pointed to the VSNTO's skills foresight report which last year revealed that 30% of organisations have problems with recruitment of managerial posts. Forty per cent also identified skills gaps in planning and forward thinking, and 30% said that managing staff was a weakness.

Another reason why there was a shortage of managers within the voluntary sector was "because the sector had a disproportionate number of managers compared to other sectors. This was because many paid staff supervised and managed volunteers".

Management skills were therefore highlighted as one of the four skills shortages in the workforce development plan. The plan stated that, to date, training had not adequately addressed this problem. Most voluntary organisations find training expensive, both in terms of time and money. It is therefore inaccessible to the vast majority of the sector. For voluntary organisations from rural areas transport is also a particular problem.

The other skills gaps were task specific. They were ICT (information, communication and technology) and fundraising. The area of professional, specialist and technical skills was also a stated as a problem area.

Finding the right courses and training agency is also a problem for voluntary organisations who are often confused as to which qualifications are most appropriate for their staff.

The workforce development plan also stated that voluntary organisations should "take a systematic approach to management development for all managers and potential managers".

Organisations should also make fuller use of alternative ways to developing learning. More details of these are given in another VSNTO publication, Leading Managers. This has been produced as a guide to management development in the voluntary sector. The publication outlines a checklist of essential skills needed by voluntary sector managers. It also describes the different ways in which they can improve their management skills.

These include formal training and different types of on the job development techniques such as mentoring and non-managerial supervision, coaching, secondments, shadowing, job swaps, networking and Action Learning Sets (where six to eight mangers meet regularly for mutual support and to discuss particular issues or problems).

However, managing should not only be left to the people called "managers". There are more than 500,000 trustees who sit on one or more management committees. They can help by ensuring paid and unpaid staff receive regular supervision and appraisals. They can also encourage on and off the job training and set up a training budget, if funds allow. Funders, services users and volunteers can also play their part.

 Leading Managers: A guide to Management Development in the Voluntary Sector and the Workforce Development Plan 2000 are both available from the Voluntary Sector National Training Organisation on 020 7520 2497.

fields.headline: HMV spurns Waterstone's buyback
fields.trailText: Tim Waterstone's attempt to buy back the Waterstone's book chain appeared to have collapsed yesterday as HMV Media flatly rejected his £180m bid.
fields.body:
Tim Waterstone's attempt to buy back the Waterstone's book chain appeared to have collapsed yesterday as HMV Media flatly rejected his £180m bid.

The entrepreneur, who founded Britain's best known book retailer in 1982, was unable to agree with HMV on the value of the business and on the way its mounting debts would be settled.

In a statement, he said he was disappointed, adding: "It is probably best to allow a pause so that Waterstone's can concentrate on resolving its very pressing managerial and financial problems."

Some sources suggested that the deal was not necessarily dead.

Mr Waterstone has financial backing from PPM Ventures, the venture capital arm of the Prudential insurance empire. PPM set a deadline of Monday evening to be given exclusivity in negotiations.

HMV refused to offer exclusivity, because it was hoping for a higher offer. Competing interest came from the US retailer Borders, though its bid was closer to £100m.

HMV is under pressure to sell from its leading shareholders, including music group EMI, which owns a 43% stake. The book chain has turned in a disappointing performance since HMV bought it for £300m from WH Smith in 1998.

Mr Waterstone, a director of HMV Media until two weeks ago, has been critical of the management of the book chain. He believes it should stock a wider range with less emphasis on bestsellers. He has the sympathy of leading figures in the literary community. Author Will Self last year attacked the chain's gradual "cultural impoverishment".

Waterstone's attracted unwelcome publicity last year by sacking Robert Topping, manager of the Deansgate branch in Manchester, for stocking too many obscure books.

Mr Waterstone insisted that his offer was "the best price that could have been expected".

fields.headline: ITV to open negotiations with Sky
fields.trailText:
10am: ITV is to enter negotiations with BSkyB that will see the network appear on Sky Digital before the end of the year. By Dan Milmo .
ITV under pressure to join Sky
ITV comes in from digital wilderness
fields.body:
ITV sources have confirmed it will enter negotiations with BSkyB that will see the network appear on Sky Digital before the end of the year.

Well-placed insiders said the network will finally appear on the BSkyB platform after signing a £100m satellite broadcasting deal.

"The intention is to conclude a deal with Sky for conditional access to its platform so that ITV can become part of the Sky package," said one source.

It will mean viewers who already subscribe to Sky no longer have to go through the irritating process of switching from satellite back to conventional TV services to watch ITV programmes.

It will also boost ITV's ratings significantly - its share of viewing had dropped significantly in Sky homes because viewers couldn't be bothered to switch back to conventional TV to tune in to ITV.

The source added that both sides "have the will to strike a deal", although negotiations will be "very tough."

It is an open secret that ITV and BSkyB have clashed over the price of using Sky's conditional access system, with ITV insiders claiming the £20m-a-year price is too steep.

However, industry sources said a deal was "entirely feasible", as Channel 4 managed to put its E4 channel on Sky Digital after just five days of negotiations.

"ITV needs to go on Sky Digital, because it needs an electronic programming guide listing in order to be accessed by viewers and conditional access technology," said one source.

ITV today struck a deal with Luxembourg-based satellite group Societe Europeenne des Satellites to broadcast on digital satellite for the next 10 years.

Viewers will be able to pick up local programmes because ITV is broadcast 16 different versions of the TV network in keeping with its regional obligations.
