fields.headline: Home rules?
fields.standfirst: A report out today suggests working mothers harm their kids' education.  Kate Figes takes it with a pinch of salt
fields.trailText: A report out today suggests working mothers harm their kids' education. Kate Figes takes it with a pinch of salt.
fields.body:
The perpetual onslaught against working mothers rears its ugly head again today with the publication of a study from the Joseph Rowntree Foundation which implies that under-fives with full-time working mothers are less likely to grow up into successful A-level students than those whose mothers work part-time or stay at home. The research has found that those who didn't work increased the chances of their children getting one A-level by 12%, while those who worked part time increased their children's chances by 6%.

All research needs to be treated with scepticism. This was a study of 1,236 people born in the 1970s, when times were very different. Working mothers were rarer; high-quality daycare was almost nonexistent; and our knowledge of the psychological development of under-fives was scant. There were no early music classes, no dance or drama workshops, and few nursery schools with Montessori equipment encouraging the basic learning skills that we take for granted today.

A great deal happens in children's lives between the ages of five and 18 that can affect their attitudes to education; without knowing their individual life stories, it is hard to tell surely whether they would have dropped out or failed A-levels anyway. It is obvious, but no less striking, that the children of educated working mothers stood a better chance of getting A-levels than those lower down the social scale.

John Ermisch, co-author of the report with Marco Francesconi at the University of Essex, agrees that other factors inevitably influence educational outcomes: "There are a lot of other things that you can't control, but I was a bit surprised by the size of the difference. My preconception was that what parents did with their time when they were not working would muddy the waters so much that the difference would be less."

For every research paper that suggests working motherhood damages children, others indicate more positive effects on the social and cognitive development of children. At the Institute of Child Health, Ian Roberts con ducted a systematic review of childcare research and found that, on balance, it was good for children, provided they were in high-quality care. A trained nursery worker, able to stimulate and excite a child with a wide variety of educational toys for part of the day, is likely to be of far greater benefit than a bored or preoccupied full-time mother who plonks the baby in front of the television for hours at a time. Other research indicates that stay-at-home mothers are more likely to be depressed and feel isolated. Depressed mothers interact far less with their babies, which is in itself a developmental downer.

When this research is put into the wider context of what is happening within education, whether or not mothers are working must surely be secondary to what is happening within our schools. Educational standards are higher than ever for those children who manage to stay the course, and unprecedented numbers of young people now go on to some form of higher education. But, at the other end of the scale, rising numbers of disaffected children fail to see the point of getting an education at all when both of their parents are unemployed (presumably with their mother at home) and they live on run-down estates where the schools struggle to buy books and keep their charges in the classroom.

From pre-conception onwards, parents are bombarded with research that centres on the welfare of their children and the way that parents can unwittingly damage them. At best, parents feel confused about the implications. Most, however, feel a great deal worse. They feel they are to blame for every minor mistake, for eating the wrong foods or living with too much stress while pregnant, guilty about opting for a caesarean rather than a natural birth, guilty about preferring reading the newspaper to engaging in vigorous interactive play with their toddler, and guilty about going back to work when most have little choice but to do so.

Yet other research has shown that, despite our guilt (or perhaps because of it), parents today are spending more "quality time" with their children than ever before. Jonathan Gershuny - by coincidence, a sociologist also based at the University of Essex - found that even full-time employed women in 1995 devoted more time to childcare than non-employed mothers did in 1961. Meanwhile, as Ermisch is willing to concede, we still do not have a systematic overview of what constitutes good childcare: "Society can do a great deal to make it easier for mothers to stay at home more when their children are small, but I'm less clear about what the individual can do. Psychologists don't have the answers either on the best types of childcare; the jury is still out on that."

Clearly, we could do with more research.

The research has found that those who didn't work increased the chances of their children getting one A-level by 12%, while those who worked part time increased their children's chances by 6%. All research needs to be treated with scepticism. This was a study of 1,236 people born in the 1970s, when times were very different. Working mothers were rarer; high-quality daycare was almost nonexistent; and our knowledge of the psychological development of under-fives was scant. There were no early music classes, no dance or drama workshops, and few nursery schools with Montessori equipment encouraging the basic learning skills that we take for granted today. A great deal happens in children's lives between the ages of five and 18 that can affect their attitudes to education; without knowing their individual life stories, it is hard to tell surely whether they would have dropped out or failed A-levels anyway. It is obvious, but no less striking, that the children of educated working mothers stood a better chance of getting A-levels than those lower down the social scale. John Ermisch, co-author of the report with Marco Francesconi at the University of Essex, agrees that other factors inevitably influence educational outcomes: "There are a lot of other things that you can't control, but I was a bit surprised by the size of the difference. My preconception was that what parents did with their time when they were not working would muddy the waters so much that the difference would be less." For every research paper that suggests working motherhood damages children, others indicate more positive effects on the social and cognitive development of children. At the Institute of Child Health, Ian Roberts con ducted a systematic review of childcare research and found that, on balance, it was good for children, provided they were in high-quality care. A trained nursery worker, able to stimulate and excite a child with a wide variety of educational toys for part of the day, is likely to be of far greater benefit than a bored or preoccupied full-time mother who plonks the baby in front of the television for hours at a time. Other research indicates that stay-at-home mothers are more likely to be depressed and feel isolated. Depressed mothers interact far less with their babies, which is in itself a developmental downer. When this research is put into the wider context of what is happening within education, whether or not mothers are working must surely be secondary to what is happening within our schools. Educational standards are higher than ever for those children who manage to stay the course, and unprecedented numbers of young people now go on to some form of higher education. But, at the other end of the scale, rising numbers of disaffected children fail to see the point of getting an education at all when both of their parents are unemployed (presumably with their mother at home) and they live on run-down estates where the schools struggle to buy books and keep their charges in the classroom. From pre-conception onwards, parents are bombarded with research that centres on the welfare of their children and the way that parents can unwittingly damage them. At best, parents feel confused about the implications. Most, however, feel a great deal worse. They feel they are to blame for every minor mistake, for eating the wrong foods or living with too much stress while pregnant, guilty about opting for a caesarean rather than a natural birth, guilty about preferring reading the newspaper to engaging in vigorous interactive play with their toddler, and guilty about going back to work when most have little choice but to do so. Yet other research has shown that, despite our guilt (or perhaps because of it), parents today are spending more "quality time" with their children than ever before. Jonathan Gershuny - by coincidence, a sociologist also based at the University of Essex - found that even full-time employed women in 1995 devoted more time to childcare than non-employed mothers did in 1961. Meanwhile, as Ermisch is willing to concede, we still do not have a systematic overview of what constitutes good childcare: "Society can do a great deal to make it easier for mothers to stay at home more when their children are small, but I'm less clear about what the individual can do. Psychologists don't have the answers either on the best types of childcare; the jury is still out on that." Clearly, we could do with more research.

fields.headline: Children of working mothers 'at risk'
fields.trailText: Children of mothers who worked full time during most of the pre-school years do less well at A-level and are more at risk of unemployment and psychological stress, according to controversial research published today by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.
fields.body:
Children of mothers who worked full time during most of the pre-school years do less well at A-level and are more at risk of unemployment and psychological stress, according to controversial research published today by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

Academics at Essex University followed the fortunes of 1,263 young people born in the 1970s to investigate links between the parents' patterns of work and the children's subsequent wellbeing.

They found there was a trade-off for mothers spending less time with children under five because of full-time work commitments. The advantages of raising family income were offset by the risks of reducing their children's long-term attainment at school.

The study, by John Ermisch and Marco Francesconi of the university's institute for social and economic research, did not identify such clear disadvantages if fathers worked full time or mothers worked part time.

Professor Ermisch, an academic whose previous work included explosion of the myth that young women became pregnant to jump the housing queue, said the findings supported the need for progressive employment policies. "Entitling parents to more time with young children can be justified as a potential investment in the labour force of tomorrow," he said.

Unlike previous research, the Essex project looked at pairs of brothers and sisters whose only detectable difference was the amount of time spent by their parents at work.

Children of mothers who worked full time for about 18 months during the pre-school years had a 64% chance of passing an A-level. The odds fell to 52% if the mother worked full time for an additional year.

Longer periods of full-time working increased the probability of unemployment when the child reached adulthood from 7% to 9%. The chances of psychological stress also rose from 23% to 28%. But the probability of daughters giving birth before their 21st birthday reduced from 3% to 1%.

If mothers worked part time for long periods, their children were 6% less likely to get an A-level but they were 2% less likely to suffer mental problems later in life.

Since most fathers of children born in the 1970s were in full-time work during most of their children's upbringing, it was harder to measure the consequences. But if fathers spent longer at work when their children were very young, it was likely to lead to a 6% reduction in the A-level pass rate. The children of those fathers were less likely to be unemployed or suffer psychological stress.

Prof Ermisch said: "The young people in our study were pre-schoolers more than 20 years ago when working parents may have had fewer options in terms of alternative childcare.

"Even so, the implication of our findings is that if parents have less time to spend with young children before they start school, there may be long term consequences.

Mary MacLeod, chief executive of the National Family and Parenting Institute, said: "This is a comprehensive study that reinforces the need for parents of young children to have as much choice and flexibility as possible in balancing work and parenthood."

The government should build on last week's budget announcement of two weeks' paid paternity leave for fathers and increased maternity pay.

"We need to be cautious about making cast iron judgments on working mothers from one study ... For many mothers full-time work is a necessity, not a lifestyle choice. I hope this research won't be used as another stick to beat them," said Ms MacLeod.

Sue Monk, chief executive of the campaigning group Parents at Work, said the Essex study did not look at the quality of childcare provided when parents were at work. American research showed that good childcare improved children's later academic performance.

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said the study showed the government was wrong to bias the tax and benefits system in favour of two-earner couples and institutionalised childcare. "Parents with young children should be free to choose whether and when they return to work," he said.

Research yields conflicting advice

Today's report from Essex University may perplex mothers who were reassured by previous studies:

 In 1999 Elizabeth Harvey of the University of Connecticut found no long-term difference between children whose mothers worked full time in their first three years and those whose mothers did not. Early differences in obedience and academic achievement did not persist.

 A Canadian study in 1998 found the money earned by working mothers was good for children because it improved living standards.

 Last year Heather Joshi and Georgia Verropoulou of London University's institute of education found a slight risk children read less well if mothers worked while they were under five - and were 10% less likely to do A-levels. But poverty, family history and mother's education were bigger influences.

 Research last year by Bristol University found half of mothers returning full time switched to part time within two years, and 19% gave up work completely.

 Preliminary findings from Kent University show only 60% of mothers intending to return full time did so by the time babies were six months; the trend was to do less work than intended.

webTitle: 'A bunch of desperate celebrities trying to advance dwindling careers': 'Nasty' Nick on celebrity Big Brother.

fields.headline: 'A bunch of desperate celebrities trying to advance dwindling careers'
fields.standfirst:
'Nasty' Nick Bateman complains that his showbiz successors have it easy: there isn't even a camera in the loo

Julie Burchill: So bad it's good.
Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: 'Nasty' Nick Bateman complains that his showbiz successors have it easy: there isn't even a camera in the loo.
fields.body:
Every time I watch Celebrity Big Brother, I think: what they hell are these people doing in my house? Apart from Claire Sweeney and Jack Dee, they are a bunch of desperate celebrities trying to advance their otherwise dwindling careers. It's for charity, but I would question what is really motivating them. Vanessa Feltz and Anthea Turner seem desperate to consolidate their fame. The very inclusion of Anthea in the show is a huge PR disaster. If she had been voted out of the house first, it would probably have stopped her career dead.

It is obvious from their reactions that they had no idea how hard it would be, in particular how humiliating being voted out of the house is. Big Brother has given them many more concessions than those we had: they don't have a camera in the loo or the bathroom, they have radiators all over the house and they were allowed to bring in hairdryers and rollers. We don't find out what percentage of the vote the loser got, to spare their blushes. If anything too risqué happens, you know they won't show it. The producers are constantly protecting them, so that what the viewer is left with is celebrity tittle-tattle that he could have got from a magazine.

What makes the show so boring is that these people are basically plagiarising what happened in our house during the original Big Brother. Someone smuggled a mobile phone in and they are even using our catch phrase "it's only a game show". I took part because I thought it would be fun; they are pursuing hidden agendas. Vanessa, in particular, seemed to take it far more seriously than she should have.

The most real people so far are Keith Duffy and Claire Sweeney. They are just out to enjoy themselves, while the rest are acting up and not being themselves. Jack Dee is a breed apart. He is odd man out. He has got a big enough profile and people love him. I'm very surprised he has done it. I didn't feel at all sorry for Vanessa when she cried. These are intelligent people. It is only a game show. If they take it personally, they shouldn't have been on it in the first place.

Before they agreed to take part, I'm sure their agents said: "Look, we're happy for our people to go in there, but there are certain things that can't go out." And that means that it is boring to watch. Just look at the viewing figures. They are a fraction of what the original figures for Big Brother were. It is interesting, but it is not captivating. The public are obsessed by the trivial when it comes to celebrities, but because we are already so familiar with these people's characters, and because they are so hopelessly playing up to camera, it is very false. The producers tried to get bigger names to take part, but they were turned down. What we are left with is a house full of C-list celebrities. It's not like the original at all.

Talk about it
Who do you think should get thrown out of celebrity Big Brother?

webTitle: Eton hits top 100 charities index amid public benefit debate

fields.headline: Eton hits top 100 charities index amid public benefit debate
fields.trailText: Eton College has burst into the top 100 charities index, prompting fresh debate about the appropriateness of independent schools having charitable status.
fields.body:
Eton College has burst into the top 100 charities index, prompting fresh debate about the appropriateness of independent schools having charitable status.

The exclusive Berkshire school is 72nd in the index run by Charity Finance magazine and Barclays bank. In the year to December 1999, it had income of £28.2m, including £23.4m from fees and grants.

The development comes as the voluntary sector is deliberating on the case for modernising charity law, including the argument that all charities - whether registered with the charity commission or not - should have to prove public benefit as the main determinant of their status.

Eton is an exempt charity, not registered with the commission. In a consultation paper, the charity law reform advisory group of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) proposes that all charities demonstrate public benefit in terms of issues such as access to facilities. An NCVO spokeswoman says: "We do need a tighter definition of what is for public benefit, but we would not want to pre-judge the consultation exercise."

Eton currently runs summer courses for pupils from state schools, including up to 50 from deprived Harlesden in north London, and offers what it calls "social service" activities in the local community. In 1995, a £3m national lottery grant was controversially awarded to build a community athletics centre on college land.

The top 100 charities index's highest new entrant, at 45, is Daughters of the Cross, a religious body involved in education, care and nursing. Most of its income, put at an average £36.6m, comes from fees and charges to local authorities.

Other new entrants are: the United Bible Societies Trust (56), Trustees for Roman Catholic Purposes (65), the Imperial War Museum (75), the Lowry Centre Trust (82), the Birmingham Hippodrome Theatre Trust (86) and the Prince's Trust (87).

The index's top five charities remain unchanged, being - in order - the Wellcome Trust, the Nuffield Nursing Homes Trust, the National Trust, the Church Commissioners for England and the Salvation Army.

The charity commission meanwhile has formally recognised conservation of the environment as a charitable purpose in its own right, issuing new guidance for charities in the field. Previously, the purpose had been recognised only informally. John Stoker, chief charity commissioner, says: "This guidance brings clarity to the status of organisations set up to protect our built and natural environment, from castles to coastlines."

The change is the latest product of the commission's review of the register of charities. Earlier moves extended the definition of charitable purpose to embrace urban and rural regeneration, relief of unemployment and promotion of community capacity building.

The commission is now consulting on the extent to which museums and arts galleries can be charitable.

fields.headline: Sun confident in 'stalker' appeal
fields.trailText: Executives at the Sun said last night they were confident a legal ruling that the newspaper could be sued for harassment under legislation designed to combat stalkers would be thrown out by the court of appeal.
fields.body:
Executives at the Sun said last night they were confident a legal ruling that the newspaper could be sued for harassment under legislation designed to combat stalkers would be thrown out by the court of appeal.

A judge last week held that a civilian clerk for the City of London police, Esther Thomas, could sue the paper under the Protection Against Harassment Act.

The ruling has profound implications for the media because it suggests people who feel their privacy has been invaded by journalists can use it to seek damages, rather than rely on complex and largely untested human rights legislation.

The Guardian disclosed yesterday that a private ruling at Lambeth county court, in south London, gave Ms Thomas permission to pursue her case against the Sun.

Articles in the Sun reported that a complaint by Ms Thomas against the behaviour of four officers led to the demotion of two sergeants and a £700 fine for a constable.

Ms Thomas, who was described in the Sun's articles as a "black clerk", alleges she received hate mail after the story appeared.

"We believe this judgment is fundamentally flawed," a spokesman for the Sun said.

"The Protection Against Harassment Act 1997 was formulated to deal with stalking; it was never intended to challenge or restrict what newspapers can publish.

"Also, the judgment completely fails to recognise what is already established law in this field, namely that 'the 1997 act was not intended by parliament to clamp down on the discussion of matters of public interest'.

"The controversial nature of the judgment was obviously recognised by the county court judge in question, since he ordered that any appeal should go directly to the court of appeal, where we are confident it will be reversed."

The 1997 act does not define what actions could amount to harassment but it specifies there must be a "course of conduct". One article in a newspaper may not amount to harassment, but a follow-up story could result in a writ similar to the Thomas case.

Walter Greenwood, a media law expert and co-editor of the Essential Law for Journalists textbook, said: "This is the first time, as far as I am aware, that this legislation has been used against a newspaper."

fields.headline: Heggessey axes Ballykissangel
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Ballykissangel has been axed by BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey, writes Jason Deans.
fields.body:
Ballykissangel, the one BBC drama that challenged ITV's Sunday night monopoly, has been axed by BBC1 controller Lorraine Heggessey.

She has decided not to order another series just three episodes into an eight-part run.

The series has been running for five years but has lost its sparkle since the death of actor Tony Doyle last year and the departure of Stephen Tompkinson and Dervla Kirwin two years ago.

BBC1 schedulers attempted to give the show a boost by running the first episode on a Thursday night, immediately after the Phil Mitchell shooting in EastEnders.

That drew 7.7m viewers, but the show has struggled since moving to its regular Sunday night slot against ITV blockbuster Heartbeat.

Last Sunday Ballykissangel slumped to just 4.8m.

In its heyday with original stars Kirwin and Tompkinson, who played Ballykissangel's landlady and priest respectively, the show pulled in audiences of well over 10m.

"Ballykissangel is coming to a natural end at the conclusion of this series," said a BBC spokesman.

"The drama has had a terrific run but it has been decided that Fitzgerald's Bar will close for the last time at the end of the current series."

A new Australian priest, played by Robert Taylor, has been introduced to spice up the current series.

Another new character, stable owner Avril Burke, is played by Tony Doyle's daughter Susannah Doyle.

Doyle, who played Ballykissangel's wily entrepreneur Quigley, died last year from a heart attack.

webTitle: Trust chief quits following waiting list scandal

fields.headline: Trust chief quits following waiting list scandal
fields.trailText: The chief executive of the of the world-renowned Stoke Mandeville hospital trust has stepped aside in the wake of a waiting list scandal that has already caused the resignation of its chairman and three board members.
fields.body:
The chief executive of the of the world-renowned Stoke Mandeville hospital trust has stepped aside in the wake of a waiting list scandal that has already caused the resignation of its chairman and three board members.

Sue Nicholls was last night relieved of her duties and transferred to Buckinghamshire health authority while an internal investigation takes place into the trust's defective waiting list management systems.

The trust has been ordered by regional officials to explain how more than 37 breaches of the government's 18-month maximum waiting time guarantee were, over a long period, concealed from the Department of Health (DoH).

Until a patient made a formal complaint in January, the trust had consistently claimed it had no patients waiting longer than 18 months, a claim reflected in the most up-to-date official DoH figures.

The complaint triggered an independent review by the waiting list auditors, the National Patients Action Team, which was asked by NHS regional officials to produce a report into the affair.

The report, published last week, revealed 37 people were waiting longer than 18 months for treatment and that more would be indentified in due course.

The former chairwoman of the trust, Gillian Miscampbell - a Conservative county councillor - resigned, along with three non-executive board colleagues when the report was made public.

It found that the trust suffered "a fundamental failure of systems over a long period", had a "lack of knowledge and expertise in waiting list management" and "poor information systems".

It is not clear whether Ms Nicholls is to return to the trust. Last night it was announced an "interim" chief executive will join the trust on 1 April - Fiona Wise, currently chief executive of Enfield community care trust.

The hospital trust manages the specialist spinal injuries unit made famous by its association with TV personality Sir Jimmy Saville, who has led high profile fundraising campaigns on its behalf.

fields.headline: Defendants offered state lawyers
fields.trailText: Residents of Liverpool, Middlesbrough, Birmingham and Swansea who are charged with a criminal offence will be able to choose to be defended by a new US-style public defender from next May.
fields.body:
Residents of Liverpool, Middlesbrough, Birmingham and Swansea who are charged with a criminal offence will be able to choose to be defended by a new US-style public defender from next May.

The Lord Chancellor's Department will be piloting over four years the controversial new system, initially in four areas, with another two to follow.

For the first time in England and Wales, cases will be prosecuted and defended by state lawyers. A similar scheme in Scotland is halfway through a five year pilot.

In England and Wales, solicitors on the staff of the new public defender service will act as duty lawyers advising suspects in police stations, representing them in magistrates court and organising their defence in the crown court.

The public defenders will have to compete for clients with the private practice law firms. The parent body, the legal services commission, is considering local advertising to boost the public defenders' profile and attract clients.

The idea of state employed defence lawyers was strenuously opposed by the bar, which argued that a state defence service would be starved of funds, as the crown prosecution service was at its start, and unable to attract the best lawyers.

Critics argue that having state lawyers on both sides could lead to cosy carve-ups between prosecution and defence. They cite public defender systems in some parts of the US which are underfunded, swamped with cases and seen as delivering a third-rate service. But in other parts of the US and in Canada, public defender services work well.

Solicitors are also suspicious of the service, fearing it will take away their clients and seduce their staff by paying higher salaries.

Lord Bach, the minister responsible for criminal justice, and Steve Orchard, the chief executive of the legal services commission, promised yesterday that public defenders would not suffer the same work overloads and shortage of resources which have plagued the crown prosecution service.

fields.headline: ITV poised for Sky Digital deal
fields.trailText:
9.30am update: ITV is expected to negotiate a deal with BSkyB's digital TV package platform following its deal with satellite group SES. By Dan Milmo.
Mar 14: ITV comes in from digital wilderness
fields.body:
ITV is expected to bite the bullet and negotiate a deal to appear as part of BSkyB's digital TV package platform following its deal with satellite group SES.

The station will be available on satellite by the end of the year, but it has yet to sign up to the Sky Digital package.

Sky has always maintained the "Channel 3 slot" in the hope that ITV would come on board and now it looks increasingly likely that will happen.

"It would make sense for ITV to reach an agreement with Sky. If ITV goes on Sky's electronic programming guide, it would be easier for Sky viewers to find the network," said one source.

ITV is paying £10m a year over 10 years to SES to broadcast its programmes, but BSkyB is understood to be demanding £20m a year to put the likes of Coronation Street on Sky Digital.

"In the analogue age, everyone wanted to be in a listings magazine. So in the digital age, everyone needs to be on an electronic programming guide," added the source.

Today's announcement raises questions about the chances of the UK government meeting the proposed analogue switch-off deadline of 2006.

The balance of power now lies with Sky Digital - one of the reasons viewers were urged to buy into the rival OnDigital service was because the digital version of ITV and its sister station ITV2 were exclusively available on the terrestrial digital network.

"We are delighted to have concluded this agreement with SES. This is an important first step towards ITV broadcasting on satellite," said Kate Stross, ITV finance and development officer.

UK viewers now have access to the BBC, BSkyB and ITV through SES digital satellite services.

"This is exciting news for the 4.7m Astra digital satellite homes in the UK. ITV's programming pedigree will further accelerate the demand for digital satellite in Britain," said Yves Elsen, commercial and marketing director of SES.

SES is shortly expected to announce a deal with one of three US targets - Loral, GE Americom or PanAmSat - which will make it the largest satellite company in the world.

fields.headline: ITV's satellite decision is long overdue
fields.trailText:
5.15pm: Ever since Sky Digital's launch, it has seemed inevitable ITV would have to bite the bullet, writes Maggie Brown.
Mar 14: ITV anticipates cash injection
10am: ITV to open negotiations with Sky
9.30am: ITV under pressure to join Sky
8am: ITV comes in from digital wilderness
fields.body:
And about time too. That is the immediate reaction to today's announcement from ITV that it will broadcast its services on the Astra digital satellite - the system dominated by BSkyB - by the end of the year.

Ever since Sky Digital launched in November 1998, it has seemed inevitable to objective observers - though perhaps not ITV's barons at Carlton and Granada - they would have to bite the bullet and swallow their pride.

They must become "platform" neutral", as the BBC puts it.

Hard evidence has amassed of ITV viewing slumping in digital homes - and ITV2 languishing unseen - because neither service was instantly accessed via Sky's elecronic programme guide.

The resulting pressure from advertisers has made joining commercially urgent.

In January, the ITV network promised advertisers one of its key aims was to remain the most viewed channel in digital homes.

This is difficult to achieve without joining Astra, since neither ONdigital (with 1m subscribers) nor cable approached Sky's critical mass (5.25m direct-to-home customers, 4.7m digital customers).

But the decision also brings to the fore a little talked-about issue, which touches upon national interests and perhaps even security.

Unless ONdigital, the terrestrial digital operator, stages an amazing leap forward, Britain's "over the air" TV transmission network will be effectively controlled offshore by a Luxembourg company.

This is Societe Europeenne des Satellites, which is run from a rural chateau at Betzdorf.

Using a growing family of Astra satellites, initially designed for telecommunications signals, SES has used its nationally allocated orbital slots for pioneering pan-European TV and data satellite transmission.

This has directly aided Rupert Murdoch's global broadcasting thrust.

It started out with analogue signals in the 1980s, allowing a then infant Sky to launch multi-channel television first in the UK in 1989 and outsmart and then crush British Satellite Broadcasting.

Without this means of distribution, the rise of the Premier League and the growth of pay channels during the 1990s would have been far less assured.

By 1998, the Astra system was upgraded to high-powered digital satellite transmission.

This brought with it the means to offer hundreds of channels, near "video-on demand" staggered start times for films, and a revolutionary electronic programme guide that organises more than 250 channels by barcoded genre (entertainment, news, children, news, sport etc).

Combined with a second return path via the telephone, this creates a system for home shopping, internet services and a rise in TV-driven spending and betting.

The government is, of course, wedded to a policy of switching off analogue transmission.

This will enable the vacated frequencies to be sold and exploited by commercial communications networks.

Even though the first proposed deadline date for analogue switch-off, 2006, looks remote, by a strange twist of fate this policy thrust hands SES a major role in ensuring a national UK policy goal.

And also maintains a secure broadcast system that provides news as well as entertainment.

Also, ITV is an extremely complicated proposition - it requires tailor-made services because of its 16 regional feeds.

This "highlights the important role satellite can play in delivering local as well as pan-European services", said SES commercial and marketing director Yves Elsen.

Spare a final thought for ONdigital's plight.

One of its selling points was the presence of ITV, including ITV2. By the end of the year that will be no more.

Also, the deal with Astra paves the way for a total overhaul of ITV's planned digital services - children's and sports - further driving the satellite business.

With a churn rate almost double that of BSkyB's and with talk of a flotation stalled, could ONdigital be allowed to succumb to BSkyB's bearlike embrace?

fields.headline: Smith sticks to switch-off timetable
fields.standfirst: See how Chris Smith answered your questions
fields.trailText:
6pm: The culture secretary is pressing ahead with plans to switch off analogue TV in 2006, report Jason Deans and Lisa O'Carroll.
See how Chris Smith answered your questions
Mar 14: ITV decision long overdue
fields.body:
Culture secretary Chris Smith today confirmed the government is pressing ahead with plans to start the switch-off of analogue television in 2006, despite doubts about the take-up of digital TV.

In a discussion that covered a broad range of subjects, Mr Smith also said he had problems with Anne Robinson's remarks about the Welsh and he "reminded" BBC bosses of their responsibility not to plunge into a ratings-driven war with ITV.

On digital TV, he expressed surprising confidence that targets for starting to switch off the analogue network "between 2006 and 2010" could be met.

Mr Smith announced his blueprint two years ago but fears have grown that take-up of digital TV will plateau.

The government plans to phase in a digital-only system of TV distribution.

However, it has guaranteed it will not turn off the existing service until virtually everyone in the country has digital access.

"The take-up of digital television has actually been happening at a far faster rate than originally expected," said Mr Smith.

"There are already 5m homes with satellite, 1m with terrestrial and fast approaching 1m with cable," he said.

The culture secretary added, however, that broadcasters and manufacturers must do more to drive take-up.

"This is good progress but I, of course, recognise the next phase is going to be more difficult," he said.

Mr Smith said he was working with broadcasters, retailers and manufacturers on a public information campaign to "demystify digital" and help speed this process along.

"We have also announced - through the DTI - that we are insisting on better and clearer labelling of digital equipment to ensure the public are not misled about what they are buying," he said.

Mr Smith added it was "much too early" to take any decisions about whether the government, the BBC or other broadcasters would have to subsidise or give away set-top boxes to viewers who resisted the shift to digital TV.

"If these products behave as all other electrical goods do, the prices ought to tumble of their own accord."

But he said a key test in setting a date for analogue switch-off must be "affordability".

"The making of the switchover must be affordable to people on low incomes, including many pensioners," Mr Smith said.

The culture secretary was also quizzed for his views on Anne Robinson's Room 101 outburst against Welsh people.

"Decisions about the content of individual programmes is - and should be - entirely a matter for the BBC," he said.

"Having said that, I must say I do have some personal qualms about whether Anne Robinson was sensible in what she had to say."

Asked whether the BBC and ITV should be chasing entertainment-led ratings figures rather than delivering news, Mr Smith said news must remain "a vital ingredient of the public service output of both".

"I would be extremely concerned if the public service broadcasters started chasing ratings at the expense of quality," he added.

"This is especially true for the BBC. It needs to challenge us a bit, to provide a wide range of programmes and to give us the difficult things as well as the easy ones.

"I would want to remind the BBC very strongly of its responsibilities in this respect."

On the question of whether a single ITV would come about within five years, Mr Smith said: "Provided the competition rules are met - and provided, above all, the regional strength of programme-making is safeguarded - I would not necessarily object to a move in this direction.

"Ultimately, however, it would not be a political but a competition decision," Mr Smith added.

webTitle: NHS will pay for nicotine patches

fields.headline: NHS will pay for nicotine patches
fields.trailText: Smokers desperate to kick the habit received a boost last night when the government announced that it would make nicotine replacement therapies available on NHS prescription.
fields.body:
Smokers desperate to kick the habit received a boost last night when the government announced that it would make nicotine replacement therapies available on NHS prescription.

The move, which coincides with No Smoking Day today, was welcomed by anti-smoking campaigners, who said it would help all smokers but especially those who are unemployed or on low incomes.

By the end of next month GPs will be able to prescribe products such as nicotine patches, gum and inhalers which previously had to be bought from pharmacies. Certain therapies - including some patches, lozenges and gums - will also be on general sale in supermarkets and other shops.

The public health minister, Yvette Cooper, said: "We know that 70% of smokers want to give up, and nicotine replacement therapy is an effective treatment that doubles rates for people giving up. Making it available on prescription will ensure the widest possible availability to all smokers."

On making some nicotine replacement therapies available for general sale, she said: "It is absurd that people can buy cigarettes in supermarkets and newsagents but cannot buy patches or gums that they want to help them give up."

The Department of Health has estimated the cost of prescribing the nicotine replacement therapies at between £10m and £40m, depending on how many people take them up. About 13m adults in the UK smoke cigarettes.

But campaigners are sure that the new policy makes sound economic sense. There are 120,000 smoking-related deaths each year and smoking remains the UK's biggest single cause of premature death and ill health. It causes 30% of cancer deaths (and 82% of lung cancer deaths), 25% of heart disease deaths and 83% of deaths from bronchitis and emphysema.

A spokesman for the pressure group Action on Smoking and Health said last night: "We have campaigned for years for this. It is a way of treating 50 diseases associated with smoking before they happen. It has been a stupid anachronism that these therapies, which are so effective, are not available on the NHS."

Campaigners point out that smoking is heavily concentrated in areas of deprivation, among those on a low income and the unemployed, who might not try to give up if they had to pay for treatments.

webTitle: Mind report criticises use of ECT without proper consent

fields.headline: Shocking neglect
fields.standfirst: Mind report criticises use of ECT without proper consent
fields.trailText: Mind report criticises use of ECT without proper consent
fields.body:
Mental health charity Mind is acting today to spark fresh debate about electro-convulsive therapy (ECT) before the passing of new legislation on treatment of mental illness. The charity claims to have evidence that the controversial practice is used indiscriminately, without proper consent, and often leads to devastating after-effects.

While ECT is seen by some as a lifesaver, a survey of Mind supporters suggests that two in three of those who have received it would not agree to it again. More than half were not aware that they could refuse consent to the treatment, by which patients are given an electric shock to cause a therapeutic seizure.

The findings are based on the experiences of 418 patients who have received ECT. To many lay people, the idea of pumping up to 400 volts into the brain of someone who is mentally ill seems barbaric - an impression confirmed by the film One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest, when Jack Nicholson is forcibly treated by uncaring staff.

But such images are a "travesty of the truth", according to the Royal College of Psychiatrists (RCP), although it has previously warned that ECT has been administered by inadequately trained staff, without enough supervision and sometimes with out-of-date equipment. Use of the procedure has been declining since the 1950s - it is banned in some countries - but the Department of Health's own figures show that 1,300 treatments are still carried out each week in England.

The RCP maintains it is "one of the most effective treatments we have". Unlike anti-depressants, which take time to work, it has an immediate effect and is particularly useful where a depressed person has been refusing food and drink and is at risk of kidney failure.

Many of the respondents to the Mind survey, however, would argue that the price they have to pay is too high. In Shock Treatment, a report of the survey, they describe how their lives have become broken and fragmented after courses of ECT - with 40% reporting permanent loss of past memories, and 36% having difficulty concentrating. Almost three-quarters of the total sample, and two-thirds of those given ECT most recently, said they were not given any information about possible side-effects.

Margaret Pedler, head of policy development at Mind and author of the report, says that as well as memory loss, some people who had had ECT were left unable to concentrate, read, write or play musical instruments. One woman, from Staffordshire, said: "Most upsetting was that I could not remember the birth of my daughter or anything about her first year."

One man, from Derbyshire, who has had more than 10 courses of ECT treatment in the last 45 years, says he still forgets family members' names. He describes the treatment as humiliating. "I was sexually abused when I was a boy, and suffered severe depression ever since. I think I should have been given counselling. Instead, I just feel as if I'm being punished all the time."

The survey does, however, show how some people have been helped by ECT. One woman, from Hertfordshire, says: "The effect of the treatment was amazing. All psychotic thoughts diminished and I started to feel as if I was finally being lifted from the big black hole I had been in."

While Mind accepts that the treatment does work in some cases, it wants patients to have access to independent advocates and an information leaflet giving full information of side-effects. Patients should also be able to sign advance directives saying they do not want ECT, should they be detained under the Mental Health Act.

Pedler says: "It is clear that people are still not given enough information about temporary and permanent side-effects, and this means that those who are giving their consent are not doing so out of informed choice. No one who is capable of giving informed consent should have ECT against their will. "

The RCP maintains there are already stringent safeguards over the use of ECT and strict procedures governing when it may be given without consent. Geoff Searle, a spokesman for the college, says Mind's survey is biased and cannot be taken seriously. There is, he argues, no scientific evidence that ECT causes permanent damage - long-term memory loss being a feature of depression, irrespective of the treatment.

"People must not lose sight that ECT is an effective treatment when used at the right time and in the right way," says Searle. "We do not understand how it works, but it saves lives."

Shock Treatment is available, at £5 inc, from Mind, 15-19 Broadway, London E15 4BQ (020-8519 2122).

fields.headline: Razorfish orders more job cuts
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Internet consultancy Razorfish is to cut more jobs just weeks after shedding 20% of its staff, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
Razorfish, the internet consultancy that briefly became one of the new-economy stars in New York, is to cut more jobs just weeks after shedding 20% of its staff worldwide.

The company, which was founded in 1995 and has 11 offices and 1,600 employees around the world, offered workers in its London, Boston and San Francisco offices voluntary redundancy at the end of last week. Staff have until today to decide whether to accept the terms.

The company refused to say exactly how many people would lose jobs, but a spokesman said more than 20% of the 160 staff in the London office are likely to be cut.

The job losses will include creative staff, strategists, technicians and back-office workers, and will be finalised at the beginning of next week. Many will stem from the merger of management and back-office functions at the London and Amsterdam offices.

The firm, which focuses on interactive TV, the internet and mobile technology, has seen its market value collapse from$4.6bn last February to less than $100m.

There are no plans for office closures and the company, which had been reported to be seeking additional funding, yesterday said it hoped it would not need to raise more money to remain afloat.

"The aim of this cost efficiency is so that we won't need more funding",the spokesman said.

It is Razorfish's third round of job cuts since October.

fields.headline: Payout to jailed asylum seekers
fields.standfirst: £80,000 award could lead to avalanche of claims
fields.trailText: Two asylum seekers who each spent three months in prison after being convicted of travelling on forged passports have been awarded a total of £80,000, in the first of a rash of claims which could cost the government millions.
fields.body:
Two asylum seekers who each spent three months in prison after being convicted of travelling on forged passports have been awarded a total of £80,000, in the first of a rash of claims which could cost the government millions.

The Home Office faces a barrage of compensation claims after the high court ruled in 1999 that prosecutions of asylum seekers for using false papers breached Britain's obligations under the 1951 Geneva convention on the status of refugees.

The court delivered a strong rebuke at the time to the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the crown prosecution service. Lord Justice Simon Brown said no one in the criminal justice system had given "the least thought" to article 31 of the convention, which states that asylum seekers should not be penalised for entering a country illegally.

As a result, he said, many were in prison who should not be there. The married couple, who each received £40,000, have asked not to be identified. The husband, 29, and the wife, 22, left Albania just before Christmas in 1998 intending to travel via Heathrow to Canada.

They were stopped, like most of those prosecuted, by airline passport checkers rather than immigration officials, and turned over to the police.

They were taken to court the next day and advised to plead guilty by a duty solicitor because they had no defence to the charge. They were convicted and sentenced to six months in prison, of which they served three.

Their solicitor, Fiona Lindsley, from the London law firm Birnberg Peirce & partners, said the couple were "overwhelmed and delighted" by their award. The payment will come from the Home Office ex gratia compensation scheme, which pays out in cases of serious default, and in miscarriage of justice cases where the accused person has been completely exonerated.

Ms Lindsley said her claim on the husband's behalf had emphasised the horrors of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London, where he served his sentence, drawing on official reports. The wife spent her term at Holloway prison in north London.

The couple have since been accepted as genuine refugees and granted permission to stay in Britain indefinitely.

Ms Lindsley said she was dealing with around 10 cases, some involving compensation worth considerably more because there was evidence of severe trauma. In one case, an asylum seeker from Iran had pictures to show he was sent to prison with still unhealed sores from whipping.

Lawyers had expected an award of £10,000 for a typical case. Between 500 and 1,000 are thought to have been prosecuted each year between 1994, when prosecutions were stepped up, and the judgment in 1999. Most sentences were for six months, some were nine months, and a few 12 months.

Ms Lindsley said Amnesty International argued in a 1996 report that the prosecutions breached the convention.

webTitle: Holiday dot.com's one way ticket south

fields.headline: Holiday dot.com's one way ticket south
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: Lastminute one year on. By John Cassy.
fields.body:
In better times Martha Lane Fox might have spent yesterday morning surfing the Lastminute.com website for gifts for her staff to mark today's first anniversary of the e-commerce firm's stock market flotation.

Instead she was stuck in a taxi on an industrial estate on the outskirts of Paris, simultaneously trying to explain to her driver in her best French that Lastminute's local office was only a couple of blocks away and to the journalist on the other end of her mobile phone why better times were just around the corner.

But, as far as the London stock market is concerned, Lastminute is only going in one direction: south.

Yesterday the shares were on the way down again, ending 2p above their all-time low of 52p, as technology stocks across the board came under heavy selling pressure.

Exactly a year ago the rush to own a piece of what was Europe's hottest dot.com catapulted Lastminute shares to an all time high of 555p and a valuation of around £800m. It was briefly valued at more than the WH Smith retail chain - even though its turnover was less than an average WH Smith store.

Today, following a 90% fall in its share price, Lastminute's business is deemed to be worth £27m, after the £65m cash it has in the bank is stripped out.

Despite the torrent of negative personal publicity Ms Lane Fox and co-founder Brent Hoberman have endured since then, the 27-year-old refuses to be beaten. "We're more determined than ever," she said yesterday. "If you look in the flotation prospectus at where we said we'd be by now and at what the analysts were expecting, you'll see that we're way ahead of where we should be.

"It's just a great shame that there is such a huge disconnection between investor sentiment and customer satisfaction.

"Brent and I obviously would like to do something for the poor shareholders who bought in and now find themselves sitting on paper losses but we always said that this was a long-term vision and it was not for people looking for a quick gain in a month or so."

Lastminute has doubled in size since the float by buying French e-commerce firm Degriftour and brought a wise old head on to the board in the shape of former Asda boss Allan Leighton.

Yet that has counted for little in share price terms as technology shares across the board have come under heavy selling.

The Nasdaq and Techmark indices have more than halved in value since a year ago, with e-commerce firms particularly hard hit.

Analysts warn that the 200,000 private investors who bought shares in the Lastminute flotation should not expect any upside soon.

"The market is currently in a state of realism," said Phil Clarke, analyst at Goldman Sachs. "It is becoming clear only a small number of consumer e-commerce companies have sustainable long-term business models. The next 12 months for Lastminute will be all about getting their heads down, growing the business and consolidating the acquisition."

Mr Clarke does believe Lastminute will be one of the few survivors because with £65m in the bank it has enough to take it through to break-even, forecast for September 2003.

Others are less sure. They were disappointed by the company's decision to stop disclosing how each international division is performing.

Heidi Fitzpatrick, a Lehman Brothers analyst, said: "It is disappointing that their disclosure has become more cloudy. They have built a fabulous brand that has become very well known for very little money and I'm an admirer of the management team.

"But when a company stops disclosing certain figures it can often be a red warning flag. The next two quarters are very important." Ms ane Fox dismisses the fears. She said Lastminute would continue to broaden its offer beyond travel-related items, which account for around 60% of revenues.

"The question is how far can they diversify from their core offering and take their customers with them," said Mr Clarke.

Observers believe the slowdown in advertising spending, which accounts for about 25% of Lastminute's revenues, could force the company to cut costs and possibly lay off some of its 600 staff. Ms Lane Fox denies such suggestions.

She is aware that the company needs to convert more of its 2.8m subscribers into customers. So far only 234,000 have ever bought from the site.

Analysts see a takeover of Lastminute on the distant horizon. "I can easily envisage Lastminute forming part of a greater entity. I don't think they'll be independent for ever." Mr Clarke said. Possible buyers could be big portals looking to strengthen their commerce offerings, leading US players looking for a local presence in Europe or bricks and mortar travel agents.

Today, following a 90% fall in its share price, Lastminute's business is deemed to be worth £27m, after the £65m cash it has in the bank is stripped out. Despite the torrent of negative personal publicity Ms Lane Fox and co-founder Brent Hoberman have endured since then, the 27-year-old refuses to be beaten. "We're more determined than ever," she said yesterday. "If you look in the flotation prospectus at where we said we'd be by now and at what the analysts were expecting, you'll see that we're way ahead of where we should be. "It's just a great shame that there is such a huge disconnection between investor sentiment and customer satisfaction. "Brent and I obviously would like to do something for the poor shareholders who bought in and now find themselves sitting on paper losses but we always said that this was a long-term vision and it was not for people looking for a quick gain in a month or so." Lastminute has doubled in size since the float by buying French e-commerce firm Degriftour and brought a wise old head on to the board in the shape of former Asda boss Allan Leighton. Yet that has counted for little in share price terms as technology shares across the board have come under heavy selling. The Nasdaq and Techmark indices have more than halved in value since a year ago, with e-commerce firms particularly hard hit. Analysts warn that the 200,000 private investors who bought shares in the Lastminute flotation should not expect any upside soon. "The market is currently in a state of realism," said Phil Clarke, analyst at Goldman Sachs. "It is becoming clear only a small number of consumer e-commerce companies have sustainable long-term business models. The next 12 months for Lastminute will be all about getting their heads down, growing the business and consolidating the acquisition." Mr Clarke does believe Lastminute will be one of the few survivors because with £65m in the bank it has enough to take it through to break-even, forecast for September 2003. Others are less sure. They were disappointed by the company's decision to stop disclosing how each international division is performing. Heidi Fitzpatrick, a Lehman Brothers analyst, said: "It is disappointing that their disclosure has become more cloudy. They have built a fabulous brand that has become very well known for very little money and I'm an admirer of the management team. "But when a company stops disclosing certain figures it can often be a red warning flag. The next two quarters are very important." Ms ane Fox dismisses the fears. She said Lastminute would continue to broaden its offer beyond travel-related items, which account for around 60% of revenues. "The question is how far can they diversify from their core offering and take their customers with them," said Mr Clarke. Observers believe the slowdown in advertising spending, which accounts for about 25% of Lastminute's revenues, could force the company to cut costs and possibly lay off some of its 600 staff. Ms Lane Fox denies such suggestions. She is aware that the company needs to convert more of its 2.8m subscribers into customers. So far only 234,000 have ever bought from the site. Analysts see a takeover of Lastminute on the distant horizon. "I can easily envisage Lastminute forming part of a greater entity. I don't think they'll be independent for ever." Mr Clarke said. Possible buyers could be big portals looking to strengthen their commerce offerings, leading US players looking for a local presence in Europe or bricks and mortar travel agents.

fields.headline: 360,000 emails a second in UK
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: The equivalent of 360,000 email messages are sent every second in Britain, writes Julia Snoddy.
fields.body:
The equivalent of 360,000 email messages are sent every second in Britain, underlining the spectacular growth in use of the internet, new figures revealed yesterday.

According to data from the London Internet Exchange, or Linx - a non-profit making group linking the networks of its 120 service provider members in the UK - for the first time last week the peak flow of internet traffic rose to six giga-bits per second.

This measure means the equivalent of 360,000 email messages are sent through cyberspace every second, and the announcement marks a 20% growth of internet traffic in the past two months.

The level is more than three times that which it reached nine months ago. At the beginning of last year Linx carried just over one gigabit per second of data through exchange points at peak times. The five gigabits level was passed in early January.

Linx handles more than 90% of the UK's internet data flow and is responsible for predicting traffic growth and efficiency of data movement. Mike Hughes, head of network architecture, said: "A good rule of thumb through the late 1990s was that traffic doubled every 100 days. We have seen a slight slowing down in growth over the past 12 months by that standard, but we are still adding 20,000 emails per second every month."

The peak daily level, according to the group, is reached in late afternoon and early evening - which reflects the growth of home users, including the rise in the use of broadband, "always-on" connections.

The rise in traffic is not only due to emails. It can come, for instance, from users accessing and browsing websites and downloading, which is recorded as a much heavier traffic flow than emailing.

More people are going online, too - the latest survey from the office for national statistics shows 7.8m households in Britain have web access, a 5% increase on the previous quarter, and those already connected are increasingly using the web as well as emailing more often.

According to Dan Stevenson, an analyst at Jupiter MMXI, the net research specialist, online use is increasing because cable companies are now offering internet connection for a fixed fee.

"We are seeing [service providers] growing very quickly in the UK. For the first time people don't have to worry about how long they are online for because they are using unmetred access products. People are staying online for longer because the cost per hour is no longer an issue," Mr Stevenson said.

 Net penetration in EU households grew a staggering 55% between March and October 2000, according to data from the European commission yesterday. In the period between March and October 2000, net access in households of the 15-nation block rose from 18%to 28%, while users totalled around 40% of the EU's 375m citizens. "Europe now has about as many internet users as the US," the commission said in a statement.

webTitle: Shock value ads pay for FCUK

fields.headline: Shock value ads pay for FCUK
fields.trailText: Fashion chain French Connection delivered good news from the dishevelled retail clothing sector, helped by its controversial advertising. By Julia Finch.
fields.body:
Fashion chain French Connection yesterday bucked the trend and delivered some good news from the dishevelled retail clothing sector.

While others wilt under the heat of tough price competition, French Connection announced profits up 20.7% to £19.1m in the last 12 months and sales up 24% at £194m.

The company, which has 122 British outlets and 25 in the US, is planning large scale gowth in Japan and the US - despite their present gloomy economic prospects. "People are still going to wear clothes", said chairman and chief executive Stephen Marks.

The first Japanese store opened earlier this month, and two more will open shortly. Mr Marks reckons there is long term potential for some 300 American outlets.

Many UK retailers - such as Body Shop, Sock Shop and Laura Ashley - have run into trouble after expanding into the US, but Mr Marks insists French Connection will avoid the pitfalls because it has been "succeeding for some time" and the roll-out will be slow.

He added that the business was booming in the UK due to strong products, good design and good image. "The whole package is linked to looking after our customers. They are more intelligent these days and more people should remember that."

He said he was "amazed" by Marks & Spencer's continued decline: "They seem to go from bad to worse."

French Connection is building a global brand, due in no small part to its controversial advertising. Earlier this month its "Fcukinkybugger" ads generated enormous publicity when they were banned from television due to their "unacceptable level of innuendo".

Advertising watchdogs said they were "shocked and surprised" the company had "the gall to send the script in". But Mr Marks, whose 60% stake in the firm is worth nearly £80m, is unabashed, and is plastering the nudge-nudge logo on a string of new products.

fields.headline: Mobile phones go pop
fields.trailText: 8.30am: Peter Powell's multimedia company Worldpop has started trials of pop quiz games played on mobile phones, writes Julia Day.
fields.body:
The regular Monday night music quiz at the local boozer could soon lose its allure.

Pop music trivia fans may soon be testing their knowledge over mobile phones, courtesy of Peter Powell.

The former Radio 1 DJ's multimedia company Worldpop has started trials of pop music quiz games played over mobile phones.

Two quiz games - a "name that tune" game and a music trivia game - are being piloted with a small sample of people from Worldpop's 4.5m-strong database.

But the name of the company sponsoring the games is shrouded in secrecy.

Worldpop, the first ever sponsor of the top 40 broadcast by the BBC, is also close to clinching a deal with a major high street retailer to offer location-based marketing services.

The company has just signed to run a mobile phone text messaging service at the dance music festival Ericsson@homelands.

The service, the first of its kind at a music festival, will allow registered audience members to receive exclusive news, special offers, travel information and last-minute updates, before, during and after the event.

But event sponsors and advertisers will be offered the opportunity to use the services to send special offers and news to the 50,000 ravers attending the event.

"With the text-message trend spiraling within youth culture, Ericsson@homelands is the ideal situation for brands to target their audience directly," said Geoff Smith, joint managing director of Worldpop.

The company is in talks with organisers of other music festivals about setting up a similar service.

Worldpop last summer ran a text message service in Ibiza, offering thousands of clubbers free entry into clubs.

It intends to run another Ibiza service this summer.

fields.headline: ASA clears Spitfire ads of offence
fields.trailText: 8.30am: A brewery that was ordered to remove posters for its Spitfire beer is to continue with the campaign, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
A brewery that was ordered to remove posters for its Spitfire beer from London Underground trains has vowed to continue with the controversial campaign after advertising watchdogs cleared it of any wrongdoing.

London Underground told Shepherd Neame it would have to take down the posters because they could be offensive to German tourists.

But in a ruling that will prove an embarrassment to Underground managers, the Advertising Standards Authority yesterday exonerated the campaign.

The Faversham brewery, Britain's oldest, complained it was the victim of political correctness when Underground managers ordered the removal of the adverts after just a week.

The brewer maintained the posters, which featured the Spitfire logo with the statement, "The Bottle of Britain" and lines including "Have the sunbeds - we're going to the bar" and "Votz zo funny about zeez posters", were meant to be lighthearted.

The ASA said the campaign, which attracted 19 complaints on counts of racism and homophobia, did not disparage Germans or gay men and was unlikely to cause serious or widespread offence.

"We are delighted the ASA agrees with the overwhelming majority of people, who accept the ads as lighthearted and tongue in cheek," said Jonathan Neame, managing director of Shepherd Neame.

"We fully intend to continue with our 'Bottle of Britain' theme in future campaigns."

Separately, the ASA has censured Tiny Computers over a national press advert that encouraged consumers to break the law.

The advertising watchdog upheld a complaint against an advert that read, "With this Tiny PC you could be copying CDs on Christmas Day."

The fact copying CDs is illegal was only mentioned in a small footnote at the bottom of the page.

The ASA ruled the footnote was neither big enough nor clearly linked to the headline and ordered Tiny to drop the line from its advertising.

fields.headline: Berry spearheads kids' radio push
fields.trailText:
8.30am: Nick Berry has pledged his support for new children's radio station Abracadabra, reports Ben Dowell.
Mar 13: Alli's radio bid offers Time Out
fields.body:
Actor Nick Berry has thrown his weight behind the campaign for children's radio.

He has said he may even give financial backing to new children's radio station Abracadabra, which was unveiled this week.

Abracadabra is among nine new stations and two existing ones to be broadcast on the third and last remaining digital multiplex in London.

Mr Berry said it will fill a much-needed gap in the market, which is only served by Radio 4's half-hour weekly slot for children.

"The BBC used to say nobody listened to children's radio, which is simply not true," he said.

"My kids love the radio and I am right behind this - I am seriously considering investing money in it.Ó" The inclusion of Abracadabra in the portfolio formed a crucial part of the licence application.

The consortium is backed by former Carlton television boss Lord Waheed Alli, among others, and contains stations for what he called the "digitally disenfranchised".

Stations will focus on folk music and jazz and special frequencies will be devoted to London's Irish and Asian communities.

However, former TV presenter Susan Stranks, who has fought for years for a station dedicated to young children, was cautious.

"It is a foot in the door for children's radio, the first footprint in a great march," she said.

The cheapest digital radio set retails for around £300.

Related story

fields.headline: Sun confident in 'stalker' appeal
fields.standfirst: MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The Sun said last night it was confident a legal ruling that the paper could be sued for harassment under legislation designed to combat stalkers would be thrown out by the court of appeal.
fields.body:
Executives at the Sun said last night they were confident a legal ruling that the newspaper could be sued for harassment under legislation designed to combat stalkers would be thrown out by the court of appeal.

A judge last week held that a civilian clerk for the City of London police, Esther Thomas, could sue the paper under the Protection Against Harassment Act.

The ruling has profound implications for the media because it suggests people who feel their privacy has been invaded by journalists can use it to seek damages, rather than rely on complex and largely untested human rights legislation.

The Guardian disclosed yesterday that a private ruling at Lambeth county court, in south London, gave Ms Thomas permission to pursue her case against the Sun.

Articles in the Sun reported that a complaint by Ms Thomas against the behaviour of four officers led to the demotion of two sergeants and a £700 fine for a constable.

Ms Thomas, who was described in the Sun's articles as a "black clerk", alleges she received hate mail after the story appeared.

"We believe this judgment is fundamentally flawed," a spokesman for the Sun said.

"The Protection Against Harassment Act 1997 was formulated to deal with stalking; it was never intended to challenge or restrict what newspapers can publish.

"Also, the judgment completely fails to recognise what is already established law in this field, namely that 'the 1997 act was not intended by parliament to clamp down on the discussion of matters of public interest'.

"The controversial nature of the judgment was obviously recognised by the county court judge in question, since he ordered that any appeal should go directly to the court of appeal, where we are confident it will be reversed."

The 1997 act does not define what actions could amount to harassment but it specifies there must be a "course of conduct". One article in a newspaper may not amount to harassment, but a follow-up story could result in a writ similar to the Thomas case.

Walter Greenwood, a media law expert and co-editor of the Essential Law for Journalists textbook, said: "This is the first time, as far as I am aware, that this legislation has been used against a newspaper."

webTitle: Pure gold and not-so-simple success for Popstars band

fields.headline: Pure gold and not-so-simple success for Popstars band
fields.trailText: The band formerly known as Popstars has notched up the fastest selling single for three years and is heading for a number one hit, writes Matt Wells.
fields.body:
The band formerly known as Popstars has notched up the fastest selling single for three years and is heading for a number one hit.

More than 160,000 copies of Hear'Say's debut, Pure and Simple, were sold on Monday - more than many number one singles sell in a week. Westlife, who currently top the charts with Uptown Girl, sold 43,000 copies on the same day. Pure and Simple's is the biggest sale for any band's debut single since records began, and the biggest first day sale for a single since Elton John's Candle in the Wind '97 sold 655,000 copies on day one.

Insiders say the single will sell at least 500,000 copies and possibly as many as 700,000 by the end of the week.

ITV will show on Sunday the last episode in the Popstars series which chronicles the band's creation.

fields.headline: Stefano Hatfield: View from America
fields.standfirst:
He is an expert on advertising in Europe and America and has won plaudits for his insightful musings about the industry over the past 10 years. Every Wednesday morning Stefano Hatfield, now based in New York heading up Ad Age Global, will bring our readers a taste of Madison Avenue.
This week he examines the success of Budweiser's well-travelled 'Whassup?' campaign.
fields.trailText: March 14: Budweiser's 'Whassup?' campaign has travelled in a way few 'international' campaigns do, writes Stefano Hatfield.
fields.body:
A new Budweiser commercial is a cultural event in the US, comparable to a glossy magazine launch or the release of a movie. It generates column inches and portentous semiotic analysis.

Only the hype that used to surround a new Levi's advert compares in the UK. But, it's tougher for advertising to have such influence in the US. In Britain the advertising industry is Hollywood, here it lags behind the music and television businesses, let alone Tinseltown.

This week August Busch IV, scion of the brewing family Anheuser-Busch, maker of Budweiser and others, was named advertiser of the year by the Cannes International Advertising Festival, the advertising world's premier event. It's proof that despite being designed for the domestic American market, "Whassup?" has travelled in a way few purpose-made "international" campaigns do.

What's the secret? As the US endures its worst downturn in a decade, this question will be asked often. Advertising needs heroes and success stories.

Anheuser-Busch's commercials are loved by the American public and the advertising industry alike while having real impact on its business. It currently has a record share of domestic beer sales, with volume growth almost double the rate of the overall market.

"Whassup?" symbolises the breezy, natural ease of the middle-American urban centres in Budweiser's heartland. These are not the city ghettoes of gritty cop dramas, but the suburban America of the pizza delivery man and watching the game on TV.

Budweiser is central to the cultural life of young American males. It's the beer your dad used to drink. And that became the problem in the early 90s. The brand had become dowdy.

Enter a new marketing chief, August Busch IV ("the fourth"), son of the chairman, August Busch III. He ended an 80-year association with a local St Louis agency to appoint DDB Chicago and Goodby Silverstein. A succession of famous campaigns ensued - "I love you man", "Louie the Lizard", the Budweiser frogs, and now, of course, "Whassup?".

Much of this success is down to a single-minded belief in advertising, its effectiveness, and how to achieve it. "The fourth" demands his agencies be daring. He uses research, but personally decides which adverts air, sometimes allowing gut instinct override research.

Budweiser, almost uniquely, has three campaigns running simultaneously for different messages, rather than cramming them all into one spot - one about its contemporary appeal, one about quality, and one about the company's values, featuring "the third" and "the fourth". To be frank this last campaign is a bit sick-makingly earnest for British taste, but it's designed for suburban Cincinnati not London.

Anheuser-Busch also takes an uncompromising approach to media buying, which it does itself. It believes in making a splash in the Super Bowl, and buying exclusive category rights to major American sporting events. As a result its major rival Miller is relatively invisible despite spending hundreds of millions of dollars on successive campaigns trying to play catch-up.

Anheuser-Busch appears to understand both its own brand, and its place in American culture. The result is that Budweiser is the beer Joe Sixpack has reclaimed from his dad.
