These are not the city ghettoes of gritty cop dramas, but the suburban America of the pizza delivery man and watching the game on TV. Budweiser is central to the cultural life of young American males. It's the beer your dad used to drink. And that became the problem in the early 90s. The brand had become dowdy. Enter a new marketing chief, August Busch IV ("the fourth"), son of the chairman, August Busch III. He ended an 80-year association with a local St Louis agency to appoint DDB Chicago and Goodby Silverstein. A succession of famous campaigns ensued - "I love you man", "Louie the Lizard", the Budweiser frogs, and now, of course, "Whassup?". Much of this success is down to a single-minded belief in advertising, its effectiveness, and how to achieve it. "The fourth" demands his agencies be daring. He uses research, but personally decides which adverts air, sometimes allowing gut instinct override research. Budweiser, almost uniquely, has three campaigns running simultaneously for different messages, rather than cramming them all into one spot - one about its contemporary appeal, one about quality, and one about the company's values, featuring "the third" and "the fourth". To be frank this last campaign is a bit sick-makingly earnest for British taste, but it's designed for suburban Cincinnati not London. Anheuser-Busch also takes an uncompromising approach to media buying, which it does itself. It believes in making a splash in the Super Bowl, and buying exclusive category rights to major American sporting events. As a result its major rival Miller is relatively invisible despite spending hundreds of millions of dollars on successive campaigns trying to play catch-up. Anheuser-Busch appears to understand both its own brand, and its place in American culture. The result is that Budweiser is the beer Joe Sixpack has reclaimed from his dad.

fields.headline: Birthday blues
fields.standfirst: Saba Salman finds no cause to celebrate housing benefits
fields.trailText: Saba Salman finds no cause to celebrate housing benefits
fields.body:
On what was only its second birthday, in 1984, a leader in the Times dismissed it as "the biggest administrative fiasco in the history of the welfare state". Next month, the fiasco otherwise known as housing benefit will be 18 years old - but the bureaucratic nightmare which began at its birth has only worsened.

Thousands of claimants are in debt, with delays in payment forcing them into rent arrears. Others are at risk of eviction. Intended to help the most vulnerable, Britain's crumbling housing benefit system appears to be doing the very opposite.

To coincide with the 18th anniversary, the National Housing Federation (NHF), representing 1,400 housing associations, has produced a report into the failures. The report, Housing Benefit - No Cause to Celebrate, reveals that 1.5m of Britain's 4m housing benefit claimants, are owed money - totalling up to £1.6 bn.

A straw poll of 500 people surveyed for the report found that two-thirds were owed an average £1,102, experiencing delays of up to five months. According to the NHF, housing associations are owed a total £84m in late benefit payments.

Although housing benefit was introduced in 1982, its roots lie in housing subsidies launched in 1919 to make council rents more affordable. By 1972, local authorities were obliged to provide rebates for their own tenants and allowances for private tenants. The existence of two schemes was confusing, and so housing benefit was born. But it was introduced with such haste, and without any support to councils, that administrative chaos ensued.

A Commons social security select committee report last year blamed the chaos on privatisation and red tape. The volume of claims overwhelms contractors who run housing benefit services. In Lambeth, south London, a backlog of 40,000 claims last year forced the Labour council to spend £1.5m helping its contractor, Capita, to process paperwork.

As for red tape, in 1999 there were 85 government-inspired regulation changes, mostly to do with fraud detection. They required new computer software and a reorganisation of how claims were processed. Councils were given little warning of the changes. Today's NHF report states: "Some initiatives designed to tackle fraud have themselves become part of the problem. Information required by the government's verification framework lengthens the process considerably and puts off some of those genuinely entitled to claim."

The system also suffers in-built problems. Where housing benefit is paid direct to the landlord, it is paid four weeks in arrears. This automatically puts the tenant in arrears, since their tenancy will usually require rent in advance.

Another complication arises when a claimant's employment situation changes - even if it is just a few hours' work - and the claim has to be adjusted. In some cases, housing benefit stops completely; in others, benefit is paid as before and, months later, the claimant is told they have been overpaid.

Debra (not her real name), a lone parent from London with two young children, had a part-time job at a shop last summer. At Christmas, her local authority decided she was no longer eligible for housing benefit. Now she owes £800. She says: "Before I took the job I kept checking with advisers that I'd be better off. Not once did they warn me by how much my housing benefit could drop. I feel betrayed."

Benefit also has to be amended if recipients have adult children or ex-partners living with them. The amount received is reduced, the assumption being that the non-dependants can make a contribution to the rent.

Last year, a pressure group of London's biggest housing associations, known as G15, became so exasperated with the housing benefit system that it urged the government to strip councils of their responsibility for it. The government's housing green paper came down against such a drastic step, but suggested "expert help teams" to support struggling authorities.

And while no one expects the anti-fraud measures to be scrapped, landlords and benefit officers agree that the government must simplify the system. The NHF says claimants should be eligible for awards of housing benefit for a fixed period - maybe six months - and that the policy on non-dependants must be reviewed. It says the four-weeks-in-arrears rule should end and landlord and tenant representatives must be involved in the help teams to improve administration.

Experts are also demanding more research into whether the introduction of the verification framework was worth the negative impact on efficiency and the human cost of the crisis. Jim Coulter, the federation's chief executive, says: "Housing benefit administration is bringing misery and hardship for some of the least well-off and most vulnerable. Over its 18 years of life, it has become too bureaucratic, too complex and has lost its way."

Housing Benefit - No Cause to Celebrate is available free from the National Housing Federation on 020-7843 2234.

fields.headline: Front...to back
fields.trailText: cuttings
fields.body:
Carry on mating
Residents of Ebford, Exeter, are helping toads to mate in nearby ponds by carrying them in buckets across a busy road.
Metro, 28.2.01 (Roger Price, Wethersfield)

Stretching it
A former lorry driver from Crawshawbooth, Lancashire, who has worn a neck brace since being injured in a fall from his cab 14 years ago is planning a compensation claim after being told he should have worn the brace for only four weeks.
Rossendale Free Press, 23.2.01 (Hilary Cowley, Leicester)

House music
Staff at an animal rescue centre in Southampton are trying to get abandoned cats and dogs used to everyday life again by playing them pop songs and the sounds of vacuum cleaners.
Sunday Independent, 25.2.01 (M Hobbs, Southampton)

Test of time
A 101-year-old Benz two-seater car has earned an MoT certificate after being restored by staff at Birmingham's Discovery Centre museum.
Birmingham Evening Mail, 16.2.01 (Jon Gurling, Birmingham)

Don't knock it
An amateur inventor from Sharrington, Norfolk, has designed a doorbell that dogs can ring when they want to come in to the house.
Worcestershire Evening Mail, 23.2.01 (Simon Harley, Redditch)

Roll your own
Three men who handed over £6,000 for smuggled cigarettes at an M4 service station in Wiltshire later discovered that the cartons were filled with carpet off-cuts.
Western Daily Press, 1.3.01 (Francis Harvey, Exeter)

Just the job
A woman in Liverpool, who has put off her wedding for eight years while she saves for an operation to have the size of her nose reduced, won cosmetic surgery worth £3,000 in a radio competition.
Liverpool Echo, 2.3.01 (S Yates, Liverpool)

Steamed up
Eight fire crews called to a railway tunnel near Burgess Hill, West Sussex, after reports of smoke billowing out discovered a steam train travelling from London to Brighton on a trip organised by railway buffs.
Brighton Evening Argus, 12.2.01 (T Hallett, Burgess Hill)

Eggheads
Researchers at Glasgow University have discovered that the perfect way to crack eggs is with a palette knife, using 30 newtons of force and a wrist action similar to that used in casting a fishing a line.
Daily Post, 26.2.01 (Alexander Welsh, Llanidloes)

Cutting response
A hairdresser in Southend, Essex, called the police after a man threatened to smash the shop windows because he didn't like the way his girlfriend's hair had been cut.
The Law, 2.01 (R Hunt, Basildon)

Wheelie cool
Two specially-designed mountain bikes, fitted with flashing lights and sirens, have been issued to bobbies on the beat in Sheffield.
Sheffield Star, 26.2.01 (Marcia Farrell, Whitwell)

Hot tip
A thief who tried to steal a gas fire from a house in Gosport, Hampshire, dialled 999 after causing a gas leak when he cut through a pipe.
Daily Echo, 26.2.01 (Peter Tapper, Burnley)

Easy Cam, easy go
A letter took four months to reach the home of a woman in Cambridge after mistakenly being directed first to Cambodia.
Sunday Independent, 4.3.01 (L Peters, Cullompton)

Saw point
Residents in Headington, Oxfordshire, are protesting that a local man, who is a rainforest expert, plans to cut down 91 trees on his land.
East Anglian Daily Times, 27.2.01 (John White, Clacton-on-Sea)

webTitle: The culling of wolves in Norway

fields.headline: Crying wolf
fields.standfirst: Sue Wheat on the cull of a protected species that is leaving bad blood on the snow of Norway and turning traditional hunters into hunt saboteurs
fields.trailText: Sue Wheat on the cull of a protected species that is leaving bad blood on the snow of Norway and turning traditional hunters into hunt saboteurs
fields.body:
High in the wooded mountains between the frozen Gl ma and Atne rivers in south east Norway, Christian Ebbesden skis rhythmically over the deep snow.

Every autumn the young warehouse worker from Oslo goes hunting for deer. But Christian is not hunting today. Like his parents Tor and Inger, he has turned hunt-saboteur. The family are among some 100 people who take it in turns to go into the snow-covered mountains in the day and camp at night in temperatures as low as minus 35C.

Armed only with skis and mobile phones, their mission is to stop government rangers culling nine particular wolves. "My family love hunting, yes, but this killing of the wolves is disgusting. It's not hunting, it's butchery", Christian says.

The nine targets - a group of seven known as the Atndal pack and another two, the "Imsdal pair" - are some of the 80-100 wolves living in Norway and Sweden. This mountain area in the Østerdalen region close to the Swedish border is perfect wolf habitat, and the only place in Europe where the "big four" carnivores - wolf, bear, lynx and wolverine, a large and ferocious weasel - co-exist with their natural prey of moose, red deer, roe deer and reindeer.

But it is also prime sheep farming land and, because they graze on uncultivated grassland in the summer, the sheep are easy pickings for wolves. Some 827 were killed by wolves last year in Norway, and half of these were in this one area.

With Norway's rural policy crucial to its social and economic systems, the area's hundred farmers argue that the wolves must be killed because they threaten their highly-prized low-impact, sustainable agriculture techniques. "If we fenced our sheep in the valleys as the Swedes do, we wouldn't have enough grass for winter. And, anyway, it doesn't necessarily stop wolf attacks," says Lise Baarstard, who runs a sheep farm in Koppang with her husband Bjorn. "Our way is a better use of natural resources."

Last year the Baarstards lost 35 of their animals to wolves. Another farmer lost 42 in one night. "We're not against the wolf," Lise says, "but if we want people to live in these districts, we have to control the predators."

Government ecologists say that the cull will not affect the health of Scandinavia's wider wolf population. They say there is no danger of the genetic diversity being lost and argue that wolf numbers could rise in Sweden, where there is less danger to farmers.

But environmental groups such as WWF, as well as the Swedish government, oppose the cull, saying that a critical minimum of 200 wolves is needed for the population to be genetically viable.

Anyone killing a wolf in Norway is liable to six years' imprisonment. After hunting the animal almost to extinction, Norway signed a co-operation agreement with Sweden in 1998 to protect Scandinavia's endangered wolf. In 1997, its parliament set a first goal of eight to 10 family groups in southern Scandinavia (around 100 wolves), which it says has now been reached.

Norway's environment minister, Siri Bjerke, says the growth to 200 must happen in the Swedish mountains, where sheep farming is enclosed and sheep are at less risk. "I cannot win," she says. "I have made a commitment to maintain a population of wolves, not the opposite, as environmentalists accuse me of. But because of the conflict with farming, it won't be possible for much more growth."

She insists that there is scientific evidence that the cull would not jeopardise the wolf population.

Three wolves have been shot so far - two from a helicopter, one from a snowmobile - since the cull started on February 10. Protesters criticise the farmers' inflexibility and say the government is running scared, protecting its rural Labour stronghold. "The farmers are greedy and lazy," Christian says. "They want to leave their sheep unsupervised in summer and just collect the compensation. Every other profession has to be flexible to the market and to working conditions. Why not them?"

Lise and Bjorn Baarstard insist that money is not the issue. Their medium-sized farm earns them only about £8,000 a year (in one of the world's most expensive countries) and they get compensation at market rate, but this does not cover their costs. And it's not the point, anyway, says Lise. "Our family have been here for 100 years. We want to farm, not get paid for dead sheep."

And although critics say that many more sheep - 133,000 nationwide - die in the mountains every year from accidents or sickness, or are killed by wolverines, Lise insists that, in this area, the wolf is the biggest killer.

Three protest camps have been established in the valleys. In one - a large camouflaged Swedish army tent - sleeping bags are put on reindeer skins on the ice floor and clothes hang above a stove. Keeping things dry in these temperatures is a matter of life and death. The tent is surrounded by haystacks, but not for shelter. They were put there by a farmer to stop any more tents being erected. Another hostile action involved a 5am attack by Koppang youths who poured anti-freeze on the protesters' sleeping bags and dragged them outside. Locals insist the boys were not connected to the farmers and were just drunk.

Every day, the protesters - who go out in teams of 10 - and the hunters play cat and mouse. Just before sunrise, the hunters search for wolf tracks in the snow and the protesters erase them. When wolves are found, the hunters try to drive them out of the woods and the protesters talk loudly, sing and set their mobile phones ringing to frighten off the wolves.

The atmosphere between the two camps is civilised and very unlike the British hunting scene, where saboteurs are regarded as a dangerous enemy and hunters as cruel and anachronistic backwoodsmen: "I shared a fire with one of the hunters and talked about deer hunting," says Tor Ebbesden. "We agreed to meet, have a brandy and plan a hunt together after this."

What hits a nerve with the protesters is an abuse of Norway's hunting code. Hunting here is not elitist or even a sport. It is a cultural tradition. The unwritten rules are: hunt only for food, not pleasure; only shoot if you are sure to kill and not maim; don't put yourself at an unfair advantage (hunting from snowmobiles or helicopters is actually illegal). The gov ernment hunters, say the protesters, are breaking every rule.

"Do they really think that, if they get rid of these nine wolves, more won't come over from Sweden?," says Christian. "Of course, they'll come."

After a 10-hour day out in minus 15C, the hunters are on the other side of the valley enjoying dinner in a warm rented house. The protesters, they admit, have been extremely effective. They don't expect to kill all nine wolves by their April 6 deadline, but they don't seem angry. The protesters are merely part of their job. "It is their right to go wherever they please and to demonstrate. We could bring the police in, but we won't," says hunt leader Leonard Mikalsen.

He defends his men's techniques, however. "You cannot regard this as hunting. We are professionals. The government decided on this cull based on scientific evidence. The heli copters and snowmobiles are our tools. If you build a house, you don't use a hand-saw, you use an electric one - it is the same with us."

The myths of evil associated with the wolf means many people support the cull, although there have been no attacks on humans. "A wolf killed a dog a few yards from where our children play," says Laila Mølvig, a local. "The wolves should be killed." But others say they, like lynx, bear and wolverine (which take 13,000 sheep a year in Norway), have a right to live here.

Kai Eric Tordal, head of the Norwegian Nature Inspectorate running the cull, calls it "a sorrowful act". His is a countryside "protection" agency after all. His hunters have had death threats, he says, but will continue to implement the law. "We are caught between Scylla and Charybdis. If we are not eaten by one monster, we'll be eaten by the other."

"It is their right to go wherever they please and to demonstrate. We could bring the police in, but we won't," says hunt leader Leonard Mikalsen. He defends his men's techniques, however. "You cannot regard this as hunting. We are professionals. The government decided on this cull based on scientific evidence. The heli copters and snowmobiles are our tools. If you build a house, you don't use a hand-saw, you use an electric one - it is the same with us." The myths of evil associated with the wolf means many people support the cull, although there have been no attacks on humans. "A wolf killed a dog a few yards from where our children play," says Laila Mølvig, a local. "The wolves should be killed." But others say they, like lynx, bear and wolverine (which take 13,000 sheep a year in Norway), have a right to live here. Kai Eric Tordal, head of the Norwegian Nature Inspectorate running the cull, calls it "a sorrowful act". His is a countryside "protection" agency after all. His hunters have had death threats, he says, but will continue to implement the law. "We are caught between Scylla and Charybdis. If we are not eaten by one monster, we'll be eaten by the other."

webTitle: Profile: Grant Luscombe, director of the Landlife Trust

fields.headline: Wild idea that took root
fields.standfirst: Grant Luscombe, director of the Landlife Trust
fields.trailText: Profile: Grant Luscombe, director of the Landlife Trust
fields.body:
The red elephants of the Tsavo wildlife reserve in Kenya - red from the local clay dust - were virtually wiped out by poachers in a few decades. Grant Luscombe, director of the Landlife Trust, which opens its National Wildflower Centre (NWC) to the public on April 1, grew up in east Africa and loved the abundant wildlife, the endless savannah, the lakes as big as oceans and the coral coasts.

He likens the destruction of the rhinos and elephants to a more insidious loss in the English countryside. "There it was the Kalashnikovs and AK47s coming down from the troubles in the Horn of Africa which facilitated the ivory trade," he says. "Here it was the boom sprayer and the combine harvester after the war that decimated our wildlife. But unlike in Africa, where they have since been proactive to reintroduce the herds, here nobody noticed it. All the hedgerows and the patchwork quilt of the countryside still looks intact. But when you get up close, there's nothing there."

The scale of the problem is vast, says Luscombe, 48. Soils have been man-manipulated with the application of fertilisers and herbicides to the point where, according to English Nature, 95% of the 17m acres of lowland agricultural grassland in the UK has little or no ecological value. Wild flora has particularly suffered because water courses have been taken over by nettles. The early conservation movement inadvertently added to the problem by disturbing topsoils which had a massive weed seed bank of rough grasses, nettles, thistles and dock, triggering germination that swamped the wildflowers they were trying to reintroduce.

From east Africa, Luscombe fetched up in the less exotic location of Liverpool, where he studied geology and then set up the somewhat incongruously titled Rural Preservation Association. "I was sitting in a pub with two friends after graduating, thinking about what to do next," he recalls. "We could have done three months on an oil rig analysing mud, but we didn't fancy that. I was interested in nature conservation, so we decided to set up a charity."

As earth sciences graduates rather than botanists or naturalists, Luscombe and his co-founders approached wildlife conservation from a longer perspective. "We took substrates as the starting point, because rock defines the soil which defines the vegetation," he explains. But perhaps more importantly, the charity had a strong community remit. "We'd been involved in setting up a community association and housing co-op where we lived, and to run a nature conservation organisation in Liverpool we had to address the issues that people were concerned about, namely unemployment, debt and poverty."

Luscombe took as a model the ecological landscaping started in Holland after the war. "They were using native plants to create parks on quite a large scale," he says. "Of course, the conditions were very different - sandy peaty soils and high water tables, and also different social conditions and attitudes - but we took away the best examples and applied them as best we could."

From tiny derelict gap sites around Merseyside, Landlife now runs national woodland projects and has a working wildflower industry with cropping sites - mostly in Knowsley, the borough just outside Liverpool - which provides revenue for them and valuable rental income for farmers.

"It's about developing a creative conservation ethic," says Luscombe. "The phrase has become common currency and, although it's a contradiction in terms in a way, it does describe what we do - making places where wildflowers can flourish, and very much putting the common species back as much as the localised rare ones."

Wildflowers thrive in poor soils where there are light, water and nutrient stresses; as Luscombe points out, so-called derelict sites make perfect habitats. "In the 1980s, we argued that sites which had nature conservation shouldn't be classed as derelict because they had a beneficial after-use. Now we're having to argue it all over again with brownfield sites."

The NWC, a striking new building with a rooftop walk, is located close to Landlife's roots and its cropping sites in a rather neglected park in Knowsley. "We were lucky enough to get a millennium grant to make it happen, but we are not reliant on visitor numbers as we have our own research and revenue projects," Luscombe says. "It's very much a working centre, but with the opportunity to disseminate the message to community groups, schoolchildren and the public at large, and to hold conferences and encourage debate."

But the real imperative for the centre, he says, is climate change. "We need a twin-track approach. Local biodiversity action plans and habitat directives which came out of the Rio earth summit may not be sustainable if the forecasts on climate change are right. It's no good doing damp meadows in Devon if it's going to have the climate of the south of France by 2050.

"Creative conservation is not a substitute for existing habitats, and we need to make that distinction. We can't recreate ancient woodlands, and the impact of climate change is very much locked in now. But the wildflowers are a huge food source for many species that are on the decline in the countryside, and we have seen the reappearance of linnets, finches, skylarks, grey partridge, hares and insects.

"It's wonderful seeing the speed at which natural processes and the evolutionary dance kick in and how people respond to that."

The National Wildflower Centre will be open from April 1 to September 30, Wednesdays to Sundays, 11am-5pm. Entrance £3 adults, £1.50 children and concessions. Further information: 0151-737 1819.

fields.headline: Personal insult
fields.standfirst: Stresses and responsibilities are increasing - but pay isn't.  David Brindle  on the alarming problems of home carers
fields.trailText: Stresses and responsibilities are increasing - but pay isn't. David Brindle on the alarming problems of home carers
fields.body:
Whether home care work ever amounted just to a spot of dusting, and making a cup of tea for the elderly householder, is a moot point. But there is no doubt that the job has changed out of all recognition in recent years. And the strain is starting to tell.

According to a new survey by Unison, the public services union, 73% of today's home care workers frequently help their clients with medication, 56% at least occasionally do dressings and as many as 83% have assisted with catheters. In 1995, in a previous survey, 43% said most or nearly all of their work was still domestic, as opposed to personal care. Today, that figure is only 5%.

Just over half today's workers say they suffer back pain, commonly as a result of lifting clients, and eight in 10 think the role has become both more demanding and more stressful. Yet pay rates are typically less than £5.50 an hour, even in the local authority sector, and can be little more than the £3.70 statutory minimum. As Malcolm Wing, Unison's head of local government, says: "Pay levels have fallen behind those in local catering, cleaning and retail jobs and equivalent jobs elsewhere in the public sector. So it is hardly surprising that staff are voting with their feet and going to work in less demanding jobs for better pay."

This is not mere union propaganda. Bill McClimont, who chairs the UK Home Care Association, representing independent sector employers, says the recruitment picture is "patchy, but pretty dire as a whole". Where the home care workers of the future are going to come from is an increasingly alarming question.

An estimated 200,000 people are employed in home or domiciliary care in England alone - roughly the same as the car industry. About two-thirds are in the independent sector, with either for-profit providers or voluntary groups, which now delivers more than half all state-funded care. As recently as 1993, it was responsible for just 2%.

Although demand for home care is growing, with an ageing population and policy imperatives to help people stay out of long-term care, services are increasingly focused on the more dependent. As a result, the amount of state-funded care in England rose 3% in 1999 while the number of households receiving it fell 5%. This has been the general trend for the past decade and figures for last year, due later this month, are unlikely to buck it.

Philip Mickleborough, of care market analysts Laing & Buisson, confirms the dramatic change in the nature of the home carer's function. "I would agree it has become more demanding - and much more responsible," he says. "If you're Hoovering for somebody and you do it badly, then they have a dirty carpet. If you're helping them with their medication and that goes wrong, then the consequences can obviously be more severe.

"The important thing to bear in mind is that people who do this are working without supervision. They are on their own and there is no one there to consult or get guidance from."

While Mickleborough agrees that the job as it is today may well not appeal to those who did it when its essential nature was domestic - "home help" - he points out that others may be attracted for that very reason. "Helping someone to get dressed, perhaps lifting them into bed or taking them to the lavatory, is all very different," he says. "But there are many people who enjoy taking care of others, who get satisfaction from helping people in this way."

The Unison survey, conducted by NOP among more than 3,000 union members who completed questionnaires, lends some support to this. Notwithstanding the overwhelming concern about the job's growing stress, 35% said they were happy and satisfied at work and just 23% expressed a contrary view, the remainder not giving an opinion.

One respondent said: "Although I am off work at the moment with back pain, work-related, I enjoy my job and I do get a lot of satisfaction in knowing that I am helping to keep people in their own environment." Another commented: "Despite the negative comments, I love my job and hope to see things improve soon."

Almost all the respondents were employed by a local authority or had recently been transferred to a contractor. More than 97% were women and one in three was over 55, indicating a looming issue of replacing retirees. Ninety-six per cent said they normally looked after elderly people, but 75% said their clients also included those with dementia or mental health problems, 46% younger people with disabilities and 20% people with learning disabilities.

Only one in 10 of those surveyed said they never worked unsocial hours. One said: "I personally work from 7.30 to 10.30 every weekday night and alternate weekends. But I am not paid for unsocial hours. I get the same basic rate as daytime staff, which I feel is unfair." Another reported: "Split shifts sometimes means working from 7am to 11pm in one day, with a couple of hours off in between - not conducive to family life." A third said: "I am on the run all day, checking my watch for my next job. We are very short of good staff."

Whereas domestic tasks were largely done during the day, personal care tends to focus on helping people get up and helping them prepare for bed. Again, this shift has prompted a change in the type of person attracted to the job, militating against those with child care responsibilities.

As one respondent put it: "We carers, I feel, are taking on the job of district nurses almost." And the survey report, Homecare - the Forgotten Service, expresses concern at the kind of tasks - medication, dressings, catheter and even colostomy assistance - being expected of the workers without apparent specialist training. It asks: "Who should be doing this work, who should be paying for it and what would happen to clients if they stopped?"

Mickleborough points out that the immediate shortage of home care workers is likely to ease when the economy slows, with the disappearance of competing job vacancies in the retail and service sectors. He also believes that the development of "assisted living" or "very sheltered" housing schemes will help cluster demand, saving some carers the journeys between clients, and that technological advance will do away with the need for visits simply to check on the client.

Yet both Mickleborough and McClimont agree with Unison that home care is fundamentally underfunded. Unless and until local authorities are able to offer more for the service, facilitating the payment of better terms and conditions, they say it is always going to struggle to recruit and retain staff of the right calibre.

Home care contractors have faced a decade or more of prices being driven down, says McClimont. "What we need to see is local authorities setting a floor at least on pay and conditions, so that the competition takes place on the management of the service and the value that the provider is adding, rather than always bearing down on the workers' remuneration."

Homecare - the Forgotten Service is available free from Local Government, Unison, 1 Mabledon Place, London WC1H 9AJ.

webTitle: When the countryside is in the city

fields.headline: Green streets
fields.standfirst: Chris Baines on when the countryside is in the city
fields.trailText: Chris Baines on when the countryside is in the city
fields.body:
For those of us who live in towns but love the countryside, it is particularly ironic that we should be denied the right to roam in this, of all years. As we emerge from the cold, dark days of winter, I have a deep desire to stride out in the fresh air, soak up the spring sunshine and get back to nature. Now, just as the buds are bursting and the birds are singing, the rural countryside has been placed out of bounds because of foot and mouth disease.

Thank goodness for the urban countryside. The wild side of town cannot compare with windswept coastal cliff tops or wide open heath and moorland, but the downtown dawn chorus can out-sing farmland. And it is quite possible to walk for hours without the need to cross a road or stray outside wild green surroundings. While so much of the countryside has been industrialised, the green spaces in our towns and suburbs have become spectacularly successful as a post-industrial home for wildlife and for people.

Domestic gardens are the principal resource: millions of sheltered, flowery glades beneath the canopy of the urban forest. Almost all our most familiar wildlife has its origins in woodland - blackbirds, wrens, robins, bluetits, foxgloves, hedgehogs and speckled wood butterflies are just a few of the species that have successfully made the move from wildwood glade to domestic garden.

Indeed, so far as wildlife is concerned, our gardens must seem rather better than the original. When hibernating peacock butterflies and bumblebees emerge on unseasonably sunny March days, the rich supply of grape hyacinth nectar and crocus pollen can be a lifesaver. Ornamental fruits and berries feed the autumn birds and with the regular supply of sunflower seeds, peanuts and blocks of fat that millions of us offer, the urban forest is surely like paradise for birds.

Our generosity is paying dividends. Ten years ago, just 17 different kinds of birds were known to feed at artificial feeders. By this winter the number had risen to more than 80. My inner-city neighbours regularly see bullfinches and goldcrests, green woodpeckers, nuthatches, goldfinches and tree creepers, as well as at least 30 other species of garden birds. My own small garden pond is a breeding site for frogs and toads, great crested newts and a variety of water beetles and dragonflies. Despite strong competition from the local cats, tawny owls and kestrels find the area a happy hunting ground.

Very few of my more spectacular garden visitors live there. They just drop in from the surrounding landscape. A regular supply of food and water helps to turn my little "forest glade" into a wildlife super service-station - a focus for the creatures living just beyond the garden fence.

Public parks and formal open spaces play a crucial role because they offer big trees and safe and easy public access. However, they tend to be sterile - good for daisies, dandelions and magpies, but sometimes little else. Luckily, there is also a huge amount of unofficial open space. In old industrial areas such as Merseyside, the Black Country, South Yorkshire and South Wales, post-industrial dereliction has evolved into a wonderfully wild landscape - unsprayed with chemicals, overgrown with brambles and hawthorn, and enriched with lupins, michaelmas daisies, raspberry canes and other "exotic" species.

There are also neglected allotments, overgrown cemeteries, abandoned railway yards and other "backlands"- tangled wildlife habitat on a scale difficult to find beyond the city limits.

It is the way the various elements of open space are linked together that makes the urban countryside so successful. A few remnants of the old rural boundary hedgerows interconnect with railway embankments, road verges and canals to create a continuous mosaic of varied green space. The railway land has the great advantage of being almost undisturbed by people - an ideal sanctuary for timid species - and the canals are perfect for bringing people and wildlife together, with level footpaths all along one edge and, on the far bank, inaccessible wetland habitat within sight and sound, but rarely within reach.

Wildlife clearly benefits from the urban countryside, but so do all of us. The air is cleaner, thanks to trees in towns. The open spaces act as porous soak-aways in times of flood. Access to nature helps to relieve the stress of urban living - and the continuity of wildlife corridors provides real scope for a healthy bike ride to school or a walk to the shops.

At local level, people fight passionately to protect the scruffiest patch of urban undergrowth, but on a larger scale the value of the urban countryside is overlooked - particularly in the brownfield/greenfield debate. The so-called brownfields are, in many cases, far from brown. They are the wild green play spaces of childhood, and a successful sanctuary for so much of our wildlife.

Foot and mouth may have put farmland out of bounds, but we can still roam through wild green surroundings in our towns and cities. We hear much talk of urban sprawl and concreting the countryside. Perhaps this latest rural crisis may have come in time to stop us wiping out the wilder side of town.

Chris Baines is vice-president of the Wildlife Trusts and a Guardian country diarist.

However, they tend to be sterile - good for daisies, dandelions and magpies, but sometimes little else. Luckily, there is also a huge amount of unofficial open space. In old industrial areas such as Merseyside, the Black Country, South Yorkshire and South Wales, post-industrial dereliction has evolved into a wonderfully wild landscape - unsprayed with chemicals, overgrown with brambles and hawthorn, and enriched with lupins, michaelmas daisies, raspberry canes and other "exotic" species. There are also neglected allotments, overgrown cemeteries, abandoned railway yards and other "backlands"- tangled wildlife habitat on a scale difficult to find beyond the city limits. It is the way the various elements of open space are linked together that makes the urban countryside so successful. A few remnants of the old rural boundary hedgerows interconnect with railway embankments, road verges and canals to create a continuous mosaic of varied green space. The railway land has the great advantage of being almost undisturbed by people - an ideal sanctuary for timid species - and the canals are perfect for bringing people and wildlife together, with level footpaths all along one edge and, on the far bank, inaccessible wetland habitat within sight and sound, but rarely within reach. Wildlife clearly benefits from the urban countryside, but so do all of us. The air is cleaner, thanks to trees in towns. The open spaces act as porous soak-aways in times of flood. Access to nature helps to relieve the stress of urban living - and the continuity of wildlife corridors provides real scope for a healthy bike ride to school or a walk to the shops. At local level, people fight passionately to protect the scruffiest patch of urban undergrowth, but on a larger scale the value of the urban countryside is overlooked - particularly in the brownfield/greenfield debate. The so-called brownfields are, in many cases, far from brown. They are the wild green play spaces of childhood, and a successful sanctuary for so much of our wildlife. Foot and mouth may have put farmland out of bounds, but we can still roam through wild green surroundings in our towns and cities. We hear much talk of urban sprawl and concreting the countryside. Perhaps this latest rural crisis may have come in time to stop us wiping out the wilder side of town. Chris Baines is vice-president of the Wildlife Trusts and a Guardian country diarist.

webTitle: The effect of goverment policy on some of the poorest estates

fields.headline: Testing ground
fields.standfirst: For four years, Labour has been trying new policies and digging deeper in the public purse to deal with crime, health, education and poverty. During that time, BBC's Newsnight has been carrying periodic reports from one front line of deprivation - the Ordsall and Langworthy estates in Salford, Greater Manchester, which have been a focus of improvement initiatives. Now BBC2 has made a series of documentaries on the impact that Tony Blair's ideas have made. Here, four key professionals working in the area give  John Cunningham their verdict
fields.trailText: For four years, Labour has been trying new policies and digging deeper in the public purse to deal with crime, health, education and poverty. During that time, BBC's Newsnight has been carrying periodic reports from one front line of deprivation - the Ordsall and Langworthy estates in Salford, Greater Manchester, which have been a focus of improvement initiatives. Now BBC2 has made a series of documentaries on the impact that Tony Blair's ideas have made. Here, four key professionals working in the area give John Cunningham their verdict
fields.body:
Helen Buchanan, head teacher of St Clement's primary school, serving some of the poorest estates in Salford, has mixed views about the effects of Labour's policies. She has seen at first hand that some benefit changes, perversely, have made it harder for lone parents who want to work. She has mixed views about her school being in an education action zone (EAZ) but is delighted at the plentiful funds available for repairing buildings. "We're at the cutting edge of poverty here," says Buchanan. Keen to help local unemployment, she recruits parents as classroom assistants. But some say they are worse off working than claiming benefit. A lone mother, one of four assistants, found that her classroom job meant she moved off income support on to working families tax credit. With weekly dinner money totalling £18.75 for three children, and with full rent and council tax to pay, the woman was unable to manage on her school earnings. She asked to be cut to 16 hours, so she would again be eligible for benefits. All the social problems of the estates are evident in the school. The counter-attack against deprivation begins at eight every morning with the breakfast club, one of six at Salford schools provided by Kellogg's, as an EAZ sponsor. It is one of the few aspects of the zones which Buchanan says has worked. But a budget of £750,000 split among 18 schools "doesn't go anywhere", she observes. "The government was relying on the excitement of big business throwing money at education, but it never happened." Far better, she reckons, is the "excellence in cities" initiative. That has paid for a full-time learning mentor for four years. The role of the school is transformed by this way of providing pastoral care: the mentor "can do home visits for reluctant attenders; [run] anger management courses; liaise with multi-agency workers". And possibly best of all, the school having had to spend £78,000 over eight years on repairs to redress vandalism, are the funds flowing in under Labour for repairs and refurbishment: £25,000 for a security fence, £120,000 for central heating. "We're even redecorating for the first time in 18 years," she says.

Dr Lawrence Addlestone says: "I don't honestly see that anything any government has ever done has made any difference round here in the 12 years I've been a GP here." His five-partner practice has some 8,000 patients from the Langworthy area. He is sure that social problems have changed little, with the exception of never now seeing cases of malnourishment. Addlestone is critical of Labour for ending GP fundholding, which had been introduced by the Conservatives. "We found it very empowering, and managed to do a lot more for our patients," he says. "We've had to fight very hard to keep what we had. "We had started a chiropractic service, but money for that is now limited. We had a cardiologist who would come once a week to see heart patients, but that's been withdrawn by Manchester Royal Infirmary. We had the services of a counsellor but now have to go through a central service, so instead of appointments for depressed patients within a few days, it now takes two or three months." As for shorter hospital waiting lists, he says: "The impact has been on the statistics, not at the grassroots. Things have got slightly worse in some specialisms - orthopaedics, for instance - and some hospitals." The practice has access to three big hospitals, one of which often has a shorter waiting time than the others. Addlestone frequently finds himself sending off three referral letters at the same time for the same patient: the system just has to be played that way. He acknowledges that the new local primary care trust oversees the needs of an area covered by several practices and hospitals. "I suppose it is more equitable," he says, "but this government was supposed to bring everybody up to the highest standard - and all we've seen is that standards have gone down."

PC Paul Cusick says that, with the old-style beat bobby having been reinvented new-style by Greater Manchester Police, he needs to know as much about regeneration initiatives as crime initiatives on his patch of Salford. Crime in all its aspects on the estates is worrying, but fear of crime is even more potent, he says. And he is sympathetic to disaffected youth. "We have to move gangs of young people; but we do understand there are very few youth clubs and cafes round here. Sometimes there are groups of 30 or 40. But in all honesty, half the time the kids are only gathering like that because they're frightened of another gang - though they wouldn't admit it." Cusick reckons that the new partnerships among professional groups are an excellent way of working, "rather than keeping it in our own backyard". He adds: "Before, everything was bunged on the police, and it got to the point where we were doing everything." Early days yet, though, for spectacular results. "To look at the area, there's not been a vast improvement, I'm afraid. For the initiatives that have been brought in recently, we haven't got the cash yet. But we're hoping to get millions and millions from New Deal." That could mean new landscapes, new lives. And Cusick is optimistic - even though in his part of Salford, where sector policing has been introduced, his team of eight beat officers is two under strength.

Rita McNamara , education officer for the Salford youth offending team, is a fan of the home secretary - certainly as far as the Crime and Disorder Act is concerned. With magistrates now handing out action plans (of three months' duration) and supervision orders (which can run for up to three years), she says: "We're surrounding young offenders with a blanket of support." The new set-up means that McNamara shares an office with police, and health and social work staff. This brings the advantage that "we weave in and out of each other's cases in the youth action team". For the first time, she believes, the education needs of youngsters who start as truants, then turn to crime, are being properly addressed. And a proper effort is being made to insert them back into an appropriate niche in the education system. But she says the government must try even harder. "More money needs to be put into alternative provision; and more training for teachers on working with very, very disaffected children, because we're putting them back into the system, and teacher training doesn't teach them how to deal with that. "I would like all our young people to be comfortable enough to go back into the mainstream. And when it isn't possible, there should be an immediate place for them in other centres where their education needs are catered for - and I don't mean a second-class education. Young offenders are not stupid; they just need a different way in."

Real Estates will be broadcast on BBC2 on four consecutive nights, starting next Monday at 11.20pm.

webTitle: Survey aims to fill charities' IT gaps

fields.headline: Plugging in
fields.standfirst: Survey aims to fill charities' IT gaps
fields.trailText: Survey aims to fill charities' IT gaps
fields.body:
The Guardian is collaborating in a major survey of use of IT in the voluntary sector, designed to plug a gap in understanding of how charities are coping with new technology.

The survey is being conducted by IT specialists Tate Bramald, in association also with the Charity Finance Directors' Group and the Association of Chief Officers of Voluntary Organisations. Results are anticipated in early May.

The exercise aims both to provide an overview of how the not-for-profit sector is adapting to technological change and what its needs are, and to enable individual organisations to compare their record with others in the same sphere.

John Tate, chairman of Tate Bramald, says: "Having worked with the sector for 13 years, I realise how often there is fundamental misunderstanding of IT. The paradox is that there are enormous opportunities for the sector, whether in fundraising or keeping better control of costs."

For further information, and details of how to participate, see: www.tateb.co.uk

webTitle: Local authorities warned to speed up 'best value' measures

fields.headline: Fast-track attack
fields.standfirst: Local authorities warned to speed up 'best value' measures
fields.trailText: Local authorities warned to speed up 'best value' measures
fields.body:
Local authorities have been given a stern warning to pick up the pace on "best value" to deliver modernised town hall services.

The best value regime, which forces councils to review all their frontline and back-office services over a five-year period, is almost 12 months old. But in an assessment of progress so far, council inspectors have labelled many authorities unambitious and lacking urgency.

The assessment report, Another Step Forward, published by the audit commission's best value inspection service, makes clear that inspectors will be looking for major improvements in year two.

"Few authorities are ambitious or urgent enough in what they are seeking to achieve through best value," it says. "In many cases, best value reviews are focused on delivering incremental change or gently confirming the need to keep the status quo."

The inspection service also calls for councils to "focus on fewer, better, more strategic reviews" from April. Each council review leads to a visit from the inspectors. And in some reviews, there have been more inspectors involved than the number of staff employed in the service being scrutinised.

While this seems a poor use of inspectors' time, the commission is more concerned that small reviews will simply fail to deliver the fundamental transformation of council services that ministers have promised. Although it has stopped short of dictating which areas councils should package together in large reviews, it now says "review areas need to be a reasonable scale if they are to be capable of finding new ways to plan and deliver services".

For bigger authorities, this could mean 30-40 reviews over a five-year period, rather than 20 a year, which some councils are understood to have identified. Smaller district councils should be aiming for just four reviews a year.

In particular, the commission wants to see more "cross-cutting" reviews being tackled, covering areas such as crime, traffic and jobs. Looking at issues in a more holistic way, not confined by artificial boundaries between council departments, is seen as making much more sense to the public.

The report could force many local authorities into a rapid re-working of their review timetables. Councils are due to publish their second best-value performance plans at the end of the month, in which they will have to details plans for future reviews.

But moving to bigger reviews, and away from the culture of incremental change, will not be straightforward or guarantee improvements.

"Sometimes incremental change can be more effective than big changes," says Michael Hughes, director of research at local government research body Inlogov, based at Birmingham University. "There should still be a place for small, focused reviews, where there are particular problems or where there are clear opportunities for change."

Councils were initially delighted with the introduction of best value. Its forerunner - the compulsory competitive tendering regime, which forced councils to expose key support services to competition with the private sector - had few friends in town halls. But councils have slowly started to recognise the huge and relentless challenge of demonstrating continuous improvement under best value.

The inspection service is not immune from criticism itself. According to Hughes, some authorities that have been through inspections "question whether the inspectors know what they are doing".

Also, the commission promised 700 inspections in the first year of best value. But, to date, just 60 reports have been published.

And with general election purdah likely to be imposed shortly, this figure may not rise much more in coming weeks.

Another Step Forward is available from Audit Commission Publications on 0800 502030.

webTitle: Eton hits top 100 charities index amid public benefit debate

fields.headline: It's toff at the top
fields.standfirst: Eton hits top 100 charities index amid public benefit debate
fields.trailText: Eton hits top 100 charities index amid public benefit debate
fields.body:
Eton College has burst into the top 100 charities index, prompting fresh debate about the appropriateness of independent schools having charitable status.

The exclusive Berkshire school is 72nd in the index run by Charity Finance magazine and Barclays bank. In the year to December 1999, it had income of £28.2m, including £23.4m from fees and grants.

The development comes as the voluntary sector is deliberating on the case for modernising charity law, including the argument that all charities - whether registered with the charity commission or not - should have to prove public benefit as the main determinant of their status.

Eton is an exempt charity, not registered with the commission. In a consultation paper, the charity law reform advisory group of the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO) proposes that all charities demonstrate public benefit in terms of issues such as access to facilities. An NCVO spokeswoman says: "We do need a tighter definition of what is for public benefit, but we would not want to pre-judge the consultation exercise."

Eton currently runs summer courses for pupils from state schools, including up to 50 from deprived Harlesden in north Lon don, and offers what it calls "social service" activities in the local community. In 1995, a £3m national lottery grant was controversially awarded to build a community athletics centre on college land.

The top 100 charities index's highest new entrant, at 45, is Daughters of the Cross, a religious body involved in education, care and nursing. Most of its income, put at an average £36.6m, comes from fees and charges to local authorities.

Other new entrants are: the United Bible Societies Trust (56), Trustees for Roman Catholic Purposes (65), the Imperial War Museum (75), the Lowry Centre Trust (82), the Birmingham Hippodrome Theatre Trust (86) and the Prince's Trust (87).

The index's top five charities remain unchanged, being - in order - the Wellcome Trust, the Nuffield Nursing Homes Trust, the National Trust, the Church Commissioners for England and the Salvation Army.

The charity commission meanwhile has formally recognised conservation of the environment as a charitable purpose in its own right, issuing new guidance for charities in the field. Previously, the purpose had been recognised only informally. John Stoker, chief charity commissioner, says: "This guidance brings clarity to the status of organisations set up to protect our built and natural environment, from castles to coastlines."

The change is the latest product of the commission's review of the register of charities. Earlier moves extended the definition of charitable purpose to embrace urban and rural regeneration, relief of unemployment and promotion of community capacity building.

The commission is now consulting on the extent to which museums and arts galleries can be charitable.

webTitle: Almshouses and long-term care for the elderly

fields.headline: Des res charity
fields.standfirst: Almshouses have been here for centuries, providing homes for a fortunate few. And they are hardly going out of fashion yet.  Christopher Middleton on sheltered accommodation with a difference
fields.trailText: Almshouses have been here for centuries, providing homes for a fortunate few. And they are hardly going out of fashion yet. Christopher Middleton on sheltered accommodation with a difference
fields.body:
It's half past nine in the morning, and a crowd of German tourists has come to look at Elsie Avery's home in Canterbury. She is 88, a retired Margate patisserie worker, and the reason 30 Dusseldorf schoolteachers are taking photographs of her front door is that she lives at St John's Hospital Almshouses - built in 1084 to provide housing for the elderly, and still fulfilling that function some nine centuries later.

Like all the other 33 residents at St John's, Elsie has her own key to her own flat, looking out over a courtyard that is altogether more Oxbridge than OAP. From one window, she can see the spires of Canterbury cathedral; from the other, the lopsided Tudor gatehouse - through which she pops to the shops - and the Norman refectory and 11th-century privy.

She appreciates the photogenic surroundings, but what she really likes about living at St John's is that it allows her to retain her independence, while at the same time feel part of a community. "I've got my own place, my own things - and plenty of company if I want it", she says. "The great thing is, though, there's no one telling me what to do."

Such enthusiasm is increasingly echoed elsewhere. Almshouses are far from a thing of the past: the number of places they offer is rising by 5-10% a year. "The majority of almshouse charities in this country are in a state of expansion or refurbishment," says Anthony Leask, assistant director of the Almshouse Association. "We expect to see that increase continuing, given that the number of pensioners will go up by 50% over the next 30 years."

The word "independence" keeps coming up among residents. Elsie Avery and seven fellow residents are at the weekly coffee morning not because they have been herded into the common room, but because they have chosen to come. They're not big on organised activities here.

"We made a conscious decision not to put a television in the common room," says St John's bursar, Richard Akister, a former bank manager. "People have TV sets in their own flat. We are very much not a nursing home, and very much not the kind of place where people are wheeled in front of the box and left there all day."

The kind of place it is, though, is a peculiar mixture of modern commercial concern and medieval charity. St John's brings in £50,000 a year from renting out the dozen shops that line the almshouse frontage, in the city's busy Northgate. It also gets interest on money that has been invested for five centuries; it even gets £13.33 annually from Henry II, who granted it 25 groats a year in perpetuity as a kind of royal community service following his part in the Thomas à Becket murder in 1170.

The upshot of all this is that, like the other 1,750 almshouses in Britain, St John's offers residents private sheltered accommodation at a distinctly subsidised rate. The weekly rent of £46.50 (£72.50 for the more modern flats) is less than half of what people would pay on the open market. And if they were to try to buy a leasehold flat in a sheltered scheme, it would cost £50,000-£90,000 plus up to £5,000 a year in service charges.

In fact, the St John's trustees helped fund a new £1m residential wing by selling some of the back garden to the supermarket.

Resident Anne Green, 89, was the warden of a clergy house throughout her working life, while Pat and Joyce Barry, both 85 and the scheme's only married couple, ran a diocesan retreat.

Indeed, there is a well-attended medieval chapel at St John's - as at its fellow almshouse, St Nicholas, in nearby Harbledown, which was set up in the 12th century as a hilltop community for lepers. Its church was built with a sloping floor to aid sluicing and disinfecting following a service.

But as leprosy began to die out towards the end of the 14th cen tury, the community admitted those whose afflictions were limited to old age and poverty. The first recorded almshouse was set up in 937, by King Athelstan, at York. Today, 1,750 almshouse charities operate in the UK, some with just three cottages, others with as many as 1,000 properties. Altogether, they provide about 30,000 homes, mostly flats or one-storey houses.

webTitle: A new study of Tiger Bay's history of racial harmony

fields.headline: Mixed metaphor
fields.standfirst: Alison Benjamin on why it took an American academic to trace Tiger Bay's history of proving that racial harmony isn't just a dream
fields.trailText: Alison Benjamin on why it took an American academic to trace Tiger Bay's history of proving that racial harmony isn't just a dream
fields.body:
Cardiff is home to one of the oldest multi-racial communities in Britain. As the coal metropolis of the world for much of the 19th and 20th centuries, the Welsh capital attracted a kaleidoscope of immigrants to work aboard ships and to build and service its docks. In the 1950s, some 57 nationalities were counted among the 10,000 people living in Butetown, the mile-long stretch of dockland at the southern end of the city, commonly known as Tiger Bay.

American academic Glenn Jordan has been striving to track the area's 150-year history since he arrived on these shores 17 years ago. Instead of finishing a PhD, he set about creating an archive of local people's memories, documents and photographs. What started as a weekly oral history class in a community centre is now the Butetown History and Arts Centre (BHAC), which features in a new Joseph Rowntree Foundation report, Creative Regeneration.

"I deliberately chose to stay and build up an archive," Jordan says. "I had this bizarre experience of looking through historical records and the images I wanted were just not there. There was almost nothing of women at work, for example. Just a few Irish women loading potatoes. Yet there were thousands of women who worked on the docks."

Jordan, an African-American whose father was descended from a slave owner and whose mother was part-Cherokee, was drawn by Butetown's mixed ethnic heritage. What makes it unique, he says, is its level of intermarriage between male immigrants and Welsh women. "The social history of Butetown provides us with valuable lessons about how to live with others - with people of different skin colours, beliefs and ways of life - in an atmosphere of tolerance, respect and harmony."

Yet the popular image of Tiger Bay is as an immoral, lascivious hotbed of prostitution, gambling and violence. Rita Delpeche, a 69-year-old member of BHAC who is of Barbadian and Jewish origin, recalls: "There was so much love here in the old days. But outside Butetown, all the women were portrayed as prostitutes and the men as pimps."

Jordan was concerned to give local people the opportunity to represent their own history. He describes BHAC as an exercise in cultural democracy: "I wanted to empower people to control their own history, and that's about building up an historical archive that wouldn't otherwise be there. I also believe it is morally right to preserve the history of ordinary working-class people, many of them immigrants, who suffered and died helping to make Cardiff a great city. Future generations should be able to learn about their experiences - not just about the history of coal merchants and the lords of Bute."

The BHAC now boasts more than 450 hours of oral histories and 3,000 photographs, plus videos and docu ments. Letters, diaries, birth certificates, boarding house ledgers and passports have all been donated by Bay residents, or their relatives, as the community dies out. "It's not difficult to collect the material," says Jordan. "The hard part is properly cataloguing, storing and analysing it."

The material has been used to mount a number of exhibitions, produce a series of books, present slide shows at community venues and create a newsletter and resource pack distributed to 700 schools. The Rowntree report praises the project as "a vehicle for the community's struggle to maintain a pride in its past, in the face of urban decline, poverty, unemployment and social deprivation".

It was also impressed that volunteers gained experience in archive work, from cataloguing materials to training in oral archive transcription, and had received IT training to edit and design the newsletter. And it flagged up the centre's work with homeless young people on photographic projects exploring visions of identity.

At 48, Jordan - a large, ebullient man - has lost none of the passion and quest for social justice and equality that fuelled his involvement in high-school politics in California in the late 1960s. "We fought to get black teachers, to stop white teachers calling us negroes or coloured, to introduce black history courses and Afro-American literature," he says. "We won every demand, with great difficulty. It was amazing."

Surrounded by family and friends denied the opportunity to fulfil their potential - his father was a talented carpenter, barred from the trade on grounds of race - Jordan was one of the first generation of black students to enter California's Stanford University, where he studied psychology and the then new course of African and Afro-American studies.

At the same time as his own horizons were expanding, across the Atlantic the close-knit Tiger Bay community was being ripped apart by a slum clearance programme. Many of the area's oldest families were moved out, and their only link now is through the history project.

The birth of BHAC coincided with another transformation: in the mid-1980s, the Cardiff Bay Development Corporation was set up to oversee the £1.66bn regeneration of the docks. Jordan was confident his centre would play a part in plans to put the city on the global tourist map.

"I thought they'd be able to see what any fool could see - that any successful redevelopment would have to deal seriously with local cultural heritage," he says. "We proposed the establishment of a people's museum and arts centre, run by ourselves in a building supplied by the corporation. It would provide an essential heritage attraction in a redevelopment which had paid little attention to the multi-cultural history of the area."

But BHAC is still located in the small gallery space it moved into in 1996 with European funding. Jordan describes as "small-minded" the lack of support from the corporation, which has favoured waterfront developments of luxury warehouse apartments, restaurants and office blocks. "Look at the names of the new streets," he says. "Whoever named them hasn't a clue of the history. Mermaid Quay - it could be in New Zealand."

That lack of support means that BHAC has had to rely on funding from the national lottery charities board and the Home Office, which last November stumped up £280,000 under its "connecting communities" programme. This will enable the centre to employ a full-time gallery manager and to welcome back Jordan as director - a post he relinquished in 1995 in favour of a board position as president, allowing him to concentrate on his job as a senior lecturer in cultural studies and photography at the University of Glamorgan. "I hoped local people would run the centre themselves," he says. "But most of the people have only loose connections to the place now and aren't prepared to put in the hours and do the laborious tasks of transcribing tapes."

Despite this, Jordan has no plans to head home. He will continue to seek sanctuary from the "racism, conservatism, and injustice" of the US in the multi-racial harmony of Butetown's past.

Creative Regeneration: Lessons from 10 Community Arts Projects is published at £12.95 by Joseph Rowntree Foundation (tel: 01904-629241).

fields.headline: Harsh troth
fields.standfirst: In Britain's Muslim community, wedding close relatives is normal. But a genetic backlash is hitting children.  Janet Haslam on the public airing of a delicate issue
fields.trailText: In Britain's Muslim community, wedding close relatives is normal. But a genetic backlash is hitting children. Janet Haslam on the public airing of a delicate issue
fields.body:
Achild is crying somewhere upstairs in the three-bedroom terrace house in Edgbaston, Birmingham. His cries rise above the sound of other children's voices in the home. An adult calls out in Punjabi and his wailing is soon hushed, for there are enough hands to pick him up and see to his needs.

The child, 18 months old, is the youngest nephew of Ahmed Mohammed, head of this Pakistani household. The home is cosily warm, basically furnished and very busy, with doors slamming, footsteps running up and down stairs and heads peering around the living room door to see who has come to visit. The dwelling is home to four adults and 10 children, all related. No one complains about overcrowding. It's all about supporting each other and, when it comes to marriage, they keep it in the family.

Mohammed's wife, Shaheen, is his first cousin - his mother's sister's eldest daughter. Their parents agreed the union from the day the children were born. They were married in Pakistan in 1972. Several years later, when Mohammed's younger brother, Shezad, who lives with him, reached 18, he was packed off to the old country to meet his betrothed, Sevina, who is Shaheen's sister.

Cousin Freed Raja is the son of another aunt on the Mohammed brothers' maternal side. In 1971, at the age of 14, he was married to his 13-year-old cousin in Pakistan. She is the daughter of another maternal aunt.

This practice of wedding close relatives - known as consanguineous marriages - is common among Muslims all over the world, and particularly so in Britain. In Birmingham, almost 80% of arranged marriages in the 70,000-strong community are cousin-to-cousin or uncle-to-niece.

"I can name you at least 40 couples off the top of my head who are all in first-cousin marriages," says Raja, who is a community liaison officer for Birmingham city council. "It is such an important part of our culture. It has been practised since at least the 14th century. We do it because we believe it is important to keep a tight-knit, supportive family - especially here in Britain, where we need to keep our roots strong."

But the legacy of consanguineous marriages is taking its toll. There is a high rate of infant death among Pakistani families and even higher rates of chronic disease.

Among the families of the Mohammed brothers, Raja and another related couple alone, there have been eight miscarriages. Of a total 19 children, nine suffer from some form of disability, ranging from serious, life-threatening diseases to hearing impairment.

Shezad and Sevina have three children, two of whom are disabled. The first suffers from a musculo-skeletal problem: her neck shakes continuously and she has difficulty holding up her head. The second, a seven-year-old boy, has a learning disability and disorder of the central nervous system. He has to be carried and is incapable of any form of communication. Only those closest to him understand his needs. The couple's youngest child, the 18-month-old boy, so far appears healthy.

Ahmed's children are relatively lucky. Only one of his seven, a 13-year-old girl, has medical problems. Her skeletal deformities have required three operations to try to correct her twisted frame, which forces her feet inwards.

Of Raja's seven children, one has a lazy eye and two others have weak eyesight. Two of these three also have hearing problems and a fourth child had a double row of top teeth.

Gene pooling has cost another cousin several miscarriages. After 12 years of trying, she now has two children - but both are troubled. The elder boy of 17 has restricted growth and the daughter suffers the blood disorder, thalassemia.

Their problems are far from unusual, says Mamoona Tahir, a specialist registrar in public health for Birmingham health authority. She has collated research carried out over the past five years on perinatal mortality and infant morbidity. The studies reveal that infant mortality rates in the Pakistani community are 2.5 to three times higher than for any other group in Birmingham.

Tahir says: "There's nothing wrong in marrying first cousins; as such, it doesn't give rise to anything. But if you're carrying a gene that you've inherited from an ancestor, and your partner comes from the same family and he has the same gene too, when you have children the genes find a pair and this allows certain groups of conditions, such as auto-recessive illnesses, to manifest metabolic conditions, such as phenylketonuria, galactosemia and cystinosis.

"These illnesses require long-term care. It shortens the life span of the children, who are often severely disabled. With multiple problems, some will need transplants and most are mentally subnormal. For the families, it means years of suffering."

Overall, West Midlands has the highest perinatal mortality rate in England and Wales. On average, about 200 babies are stillborn or die within the first week of life each year in Birmingham - one of the highest rates in the country. And congenital abnormalities within the Pakistani community are responsible for about 40% of these deaths.

Another alarming statistic is that Pakistani babies are 10 times more likely to suffer an inherited metabolic disorder than are other babies born in West Midlands. And Muslim children under one year old are almost twice as likely to stay in hospital because of congenital malformations than other Birmingham babies.

These studies lay the blame for the disturbing figures firmly on the community's tradition of marrying relations. Research suggests that the number of congenital abnormalities in Birmingham's Pakistani community would fall 60% if the practice did not occur.

Now, for the first time , Birmingham health authority is challenging the centuries-old custom. For years it has put the problems down to socio-economic conditions. Poverty, poor housing, illiteracy and unemployment disproportionately affect the community.

But figures show that inter-relation marriages have a greater impact on the health of the children than do any of these factors. So this time, the health authority's warning to the Pakistani community is that if they continue to marry first cousins, they risk the health of generations of children to come.
