webTitle: The benefits of a scheme in which the car takes a back seat

fields.headline: Share options
fields.standfirst: Simon Birch calculates the benefits of a scheme in which the car takes a back seat
fields.trailText: Simon Birch calculates the benefits of a scheme in which the car takes a back seat
fields.body:
Our love affair with the car may be verging on the obsessive and threatening disastrous environmental and economic consequences. But a conference today will hear how we can renegotiate our relationship with the internal combustion engine and bring about a new car culture.

The solution, it will be argued, is to share vehicle ownership. "Car share clubs are an innovative alternative to owning a car, freeing the individual to choose the best transport option for their trip," says Antonio Roberts, of the Community Car Share Network (CCSN), which is hosting today's conference in Luton. "Ultimately, car clubs can reduce congestion and pollution and, with car club vehicles on average replacing five privately owned cars, the pressure on parking spaces is eased."

The network takes its cue from the experiences of European countries, where more than 100,000 people are members of some 100 clubs and use car sharing as an everyday part of their transport mix. "Over a decade of car share clubs has shown that, on average, members reduce their car mileage by half and replace this with a combination of public transport, cycling and walking," says Roberts.

The way a car share club works is that a member books a car by telephoning a call centre, then picks up the vehicle - usually parked within a 10-minute walk of the caller's house, with the keys kept in a nearby safe. The member notes the mileage in a log book at the beginning and end of every journey. Members pay a one-off £25 joining fee plus a returnable £100 insurance deposit, and there is a £10-a-month fee on top. Generally, members are charged £3 for the first hour of car use, £2 for each subsequent hour, and around 15p a mile.

These charges compare favourably with the experience of those in existing European schemes. People who clock up around 6,000 miles a year - that's about 45% of UK motorists - could save up to £1,500 on their annual motoring costs.

Today's conference marks a coming of age for car sharing clubs in Britain. Since CCSN was launched in 1999, its organisers have opted for a low-profile approach that has fostered the launch of 11 car clubs with total membership of just under 1,000.

"We didn't want to raise expecta tions and not be in a position to deliver a service," says Roberts. "As it takes time to reduce dependency on the car, it was vital that we were in a position to offer a service that was convenient, reliable and affordable."

Roberts admits that the environmental benefits of car share clubs are not a big factor when people come to decide about giving up their own vehicle. "Personal benefit is the primary motivating factor," he says.

Chas Ball, co-director of the car club service provider Smart Moves, believes that, for their long-term success, car clubs need not only careful nurturing but also the right set of conditions. "Currently, a number of factors are working against car clubs. For instance, the plummeting price of second-hand cars isn't helping, nor is the public perception of public transport, which, since the recent train crashes, has nose-dived."

However, Ball takes heart from what he sees as pro-active support from a growing number of local authorities. And while community-based car share clubs are taking their first tentative steps, employer-led schemes are enjoying something of a boom. "The response has been phenomenal in recent years," says Katherine Mitchell, of the Association for Commuter Transport (ACT).

Launched in 1997 with the aim of "promoting sustainable transport and reduced car dependency through the adoption of commuter travel planning", ACT now has more than 120 members, the majority of whom are blue-chip corporates ranging from Marks & Spencer and Boots to drugs manufacturers Pfizer and AstraZeneca.

"So many people now drive to work by themselves that company car parks soon get full up," Mitchell says. "If the company wants to expand, it often has no more available parking space." Company car share schemes usually involve lift-sharing, he says. "By offering these schemes, they can get more employees into their sites."

One of the biggest employer-led schemes is the Royal Bank of Scotland's, with more than half the 3,000 employees at its South Gyle business park operation, outside Edinburgh, now signed up to share lifts.

"Business parks have always faced bigger transport problems than the inner-city because of a lack of proper transport infrastructure," says David Graham, the bank's environment manager. "People just became exasperated by the gridlocked conditions that occur here everyday."

Graham estimates that the scheme has led to a reduction of 650 cars a day entering the business park. Its success, he says, has sparked interest among other companies based there.

The corporate market is also being targeted by one of six web-based companies now in the car share market, Paul Cutler's shareajourney.com.

"More than 70% of car drivers don't use any form of public transport because of the flexibility of the car," Cutler says. "The only realistic way to make any impact on road traffic congestion is to try to persuade people to join car sharing clubs."

Despite the strength of our attachment to the car, there is cautious optimism about the future of car sharing. As Chas Ball says: "Car clubs will become mainstream because local authorities, developers, employers and government will see that this is a way to give access to the car without us all having to own one."

Miles of smiles

Jo Rathbone joined Coventry's car club last July. She says: "Having given up my car I feel that I'm getting more control over my life. Not having immediate access to a car means that your life slows down ever so slightly. It's easier to say no to things, which is great."

As a social worker, 38-year-old Rathbone needed a car for work. But when she gave up her job three years ago, she and her husband, Dan, set up an informal car share arrangement with a neighbouring family. Having found that this trial run posed no problems, the couple had no hesitation joining the official Coventry car club, which was launched last July.

"The biggest advantage of the car club is that your car isn't parked outside your front door, so you don't jump in it for journeys that really don't need a car," says Rathbone. "You plan much more carefully for those occasions when you do need a car."

The couple now have access to two cars a 10-minute walk from their house, and use them for trips they can't make on public transport, whether it's visiting IKEA to load up with shelving or taking the children to parties and to see relatives.

As well as the money saved from not running a car, the family has benefited in other ways. "I bought a good bike with the savings we made and now I'm a lot fitter from cycling everywhere," says Rathbone.

"I also feel that I'm making choices that are not only good for me, but are good for my community and environment - and that feels really good."

Community Car Share Network is on 0113-234 9299; Smart Moves is on 024-7623 6292; the Association for Commuter Transport is on 020-7348 1987.

webTitle: Malcolm Dean: Unequal parts to the equation

fields.headline: Unequal parts to the equation
fields.trailText: Malcolm Dean: What was initially fuelled by Margaret Thatcher's loathing of all local government has been continued by Tony Blair's contempt for leftwing councils
fields.body:
Will the centralised state be less centralised in a second Labour term? Devolution has not stopped the accretion of power at the centre in England. What was initially fuelled by Margaret Thatcher's loathing of all local government has been continued by Tony Blair's contempt for leftwing councils.

What makes it more complicated is that it has also been driven by a democratic principle: rising opposition to unequal services. Opposition to "post code prescribing" is not restricted to the NHS.

Local government is changing. By June local councils will have opted for one of three new forms of government: elected mayor; cabinet and appointed leader; or elected mayor with council manager. Most councils want the second option. Local papers have ensured there will be local referenda for elected mayors in several cities by rallying 5% of registered voters to the cause.

There are several reasons for objecting to elected mayors - American import, potential Big Boss patronage, stalemated councils - but elected mayors are coming. They will add fizz, more media focus on local government, and a new separation of power. If Liverpool opts for one, will Manchester, Leeds, Birmingham be able to resist?

Within local government circles, there has been intense debate generated not least by separate groupings crudely representing old and new Labour. The former, the Local Government Information Unit (LGIU) published 18 essays yesterday ("A Democratic Future", LGIU, London). Referenda on elected mayors will widen the debate. Not before time. Local government accounts for 25% of government spending and 10% of the economy.

Both sides want to make the quangocracy (the 100,000 government-appointed or self-appointed people on thousands of unelected bodies spending billions on former local council-provided services) made more accountable. LGIU would like more services back in council hands and rightly contrasts the major changes which modernisers are imposing on councils with the minor reforms of quangos.

LGIU would like central government to take a spoonful of the joined-up medicine imposed locally. It points to conflicting objectives and contradictory incentives that multiple pilot schemes have introduced. One borough with nine different zones (covering health, education, employment, crime, housing poor parents, etc) has talked of having "more visions than St Theresa - more pilots than the RAF".

Lessons from successes (Sure Start) and disappointments (education action zones) need pulling together before tackling the biggest challenge: how much extra local democracy can be conceded before unacceptable inequalities occur?

fields.headline: Readers' letters
fields.trailText: society letters
fields.body:
DTTOs on an even keel

Claims that drug testing and treatment orders (DTTOs) are failing (Drugs flagship rocked, March 7) conflict with my research findings from Leeds, Liverpool, Nottingham and Thanet, Kent.

There is some variance between these areas but, in places where the probation service and treatment provider is well organised and committed, DTTOs are an effective alternative to prison. Probation officers, one with 25 years' experience, have expressed amazement that some of their hardened drug-using clients have responded positively to the programme.

I have spoken to drug users in bail hostels who are hoping that they come through their assessment to enable them to make a real go at changing their lives. Of course some will fail - drug treatment workers know full well that there is a high rate of attrition. The DTTO providers which do not pay attention to their clients' high level of needs will inevitably record the highest failures.

Put simply, some schemes do not appreciate that some clients welcome clear boundaries, consistency and a chance to change - a chance that treatment in prison can never offer.

Andrew Wilson
Visiting research associate, centre for analysis of social exclusion, London School of Economics

 Addaction would like to set the record straight regarding DTTOs. We strongly advocate well-designed and delivered DTTOs as a means of breaking the cycle of drug misuse and crime. They provide an excellent opportunity for treatment providers, probation services and the courts to supervise closely offenders in the community setting.

We are encouraged by the responses to date in the areas where we are delivering DTTOs, though they are not without complexities and difficulties which are a challenge to all localities. Addaction supports and welcomes the government's initiatives on tackling drug-related crime and will closely monitor the outcomes of DTTOs.

Helen Cantrell
National criminal justice development manager, Addaction

Wrong turn for trade

I live in Broomhall, directly opposite where the photograph was taken which accompanied your article on prostitution (Street wiser, March 7). No prostitute in her right mind would stand there - Broomhall Place is a cul-de-sac with no passing traffic.

Lesley Boulton
Sheffield

House crisis home to roost

Nick Davies, president of the Royal Town Planning Institute, naturally wants to defend his members from charges that they are responsible for the housing crisis in London and much of southern England (Letters, March 7). But his account is misleading.

The crisis is due to the way planning policy has been operated by governments and local authorities in the past 20 years. The restrictive planning regime - covering the London green belt since 1946, and adopted through most of southern England ever since - has protected great swathes of countryside and the "rural" settings in which so many people seem to want to live. And so long as development pressures were fairly evenly distributed around the country the system worked fairly well.

But then the Thatcher government deregulated everything except the green belt: the manufacturing base of other regions was put into freefall and the economy of London and the south was let rip - but without the space in which to grow. Demand for housing in the London region has boomed through three factors: migration, which pushed the population up; income growth (for at least half the population); and the tendency of people as they get richer to occupy far more housing space.

This booming demand has confronted a relatively fixed supply for 20 years, so it is no surprise that prices have mushroomed and been highly unstable.

Our job as planners - and I am one as well - is to point out this profound inconsistency and help devise solutions. A national re-think is required and should start now. The government subsidies for key worker housing, which Davies and others advocate, could just make matters worse: they add to demand, not to supply, and they only help those in a few public sector occupations.

If demand cannot be redistributed across the UK, then something will have to be done to boost housing supply in the south and bring house prices gradually down.

I am sure that Hamish Davidson can claim involvement in appointing some excellent top-level local government staff (The king-maker, March 7). However, no objective evidence suggests that authorities which use headhunters get better top people than those which don't.

Headhunting consultants do not always carry out the objective assessments they claim. I know of one London council executive director, appointed through headhunter involvement, who was notorious in her previous authority for claiming credit for others' work.

Few headhunters have the claimed extensive lists of contacts. Instead, they sound out other authorities for suggestions - the usual consultants' trick of having others do the work for them.

If consultants are getting 25% of appointees' salary, they have a strong interest in higher salaries for chief officers, increasing costs for local authorities. Headhunters add an unnecessary and expensive layer in the appointments process for which the public pay.

Roger Backhouse

fields.bodyText: DTTOs on an even keel Claims that drug testing and treatment orders (DTTOs) are failing (Drugs flagship rocked, March 7) conflict with my research findings from Leeds, Liverpool, Nottingham and Thanet, Kent. There is some variance between these areas but, in places where the probation service and treatment provider is well organised and committed, DTTOs are an effective alternative to prison. Probation officers, one with 25 years' experience, have expressed amazement that some of their hardened drug-using clients have responded positively to the programme. I have spoken to drug users in bail hostels who are hoping that they come through their assessment to enable them to make a real go at changing their lives. Of course some will fail - drug treatment workers know full well that there is a high rate of attrition. The DTTO providers which do not pay attention to their clients' high level of needs will inevitably record the highest failures. Put simply, some schemes do not appreciate that some clients welcome clear boundaries, consistency and a chance to change - a chance that treatment in prison can never offer. fields.headline: Housing benefit celebrates its 18th birthday
fields.standfirst: Saba Salman finds little to celebrate
fields.trailText: Saba Salman finds little to celebrate
fields.body:
On what was only its second birthday, in 1984, a leader in the Times dismissed it as "the biggest administrative fiasco in the history of the welfare state". Next month, the fiasco otherwise known as housing benefit will be 18 years old - but the bureaucratic nightmare that began at its birth has only worsened.

Thousands of claimants are in debt, with delays in payment forcing them into rent arrears. Others are at risk of eviction. Intended to help the most vulnerable, Britain's crumbling housing benefit system appears to be doing the very opposite.

To coincide with the 18th anniversary, the National Housing Federation (NHF), representing 1,400 housing associations, has produced a report into the failures. The report, Housing Benefit - No Cause to Celebrate, reveals that 1.5m of Britain's 4m housing benefit claimants, are owed money - totalling up to £1.6 bn.

A straw poll of 500 people surveyed for the report found that two-thirds were owed an average £1,102, experiencing delays of up to five months. According to the NHF, housing associations are owed a total £84m in late benefit payments.

Although housing benefit was introduced in 1982, its roots lie in housing subsidies launched in 1919 to make council rents more affordable. By 1972, local authorities were obliged to provide rebates for their own tenants and allowances for private tenants. The existence of two schemes was confusing, and so housing benefit was born. But it was introduced with such haste, and without any support to councils, that administrative chaos ensued.

A Commons social security select committee report last year blamed the chaos on privatisation and red tape. The volume of claims overwhelms contractors who run housing benefit services. In Lambeth, south London, a backlog of 40,000 claims last year forced the Labour council to spend £1.5m helping its contractor, Capita, to process paperwork.

As for red tape, in 1999 there were 85 government-inspired regulation changes, mostly to do with fraud detection. They required new computer software and a reorganisation of how claims were processed. Councils were given little warning of the changes. Today's NHF report states: "Some initiatives designed to tackle fraud have themselves become part of the problem. Information required by the government's verification framework lengthens the process considerably and puts off some of those genuinely entitled to claim."

The system also suffers in-built problems. Where housing benefit is paid direct to the landlord, it is paid four weeks in arrears. This automatically puts the tenant in arrears, since their tenancy will usually require rent in advance.

Another complication arises when a claimant's employment situation changes - even if it is just a few hours' work - and the claim has to be adjusted. In some cases, housing benefit stops completely; in others, benefit is paid as before and, months later, the claimant is told they have been overpaid.

Debra (not her real name), a lone parent from London with two young children, had a part-time job at a shop last summer. At Christmas, her local authority decided she was no longer eligible for housing benefit. Now she owes £800. She says: "Before I took the job I kept checking with advisers that I'd be better off. Not once did they warn me by how much my housing benefit could drop. I feel betrayed."

Benefit also has to be amended if recipients have adult children or ex-partners living with them. The amount received is reduced, the assumption being that the non-dependants can make a contribution to the rent.

Last year, a pressure group of London's biggest housing associations, known as G15, became so exasperated with the housing benefit system that it urged the government to strip councils of their responsibility for it. The government's housing green paper came down against such a drastic step, but suggested "expert help teams" to support struggling authorities.

And while no one expects the anti-fraud measures to be scrapped, landlords and benefit officers agree that the government must simplify the system. The NHF says claimants should be eligible for awards of housing benefit for a fixed period - maybe six months - and that the policy on non-dependants must be reviewed. It says the four-weeks-in-arrears rule should end and landlord and tenant representatives must be involved in the help teams to improve administration.

Experts are also demanding more research into whether the introduction of the verification framework was worth the negative impact on efficiency and the human cost of the crisis. Jim Coulter, the federation's chief executive, says: "Housing benefit administration is bringing misery and hardship for some of the least well-off and most vulnerable. Over its 18 years of life, it has become too bureaucratic, too complex and has lost its way."

 Housing Benefit - No Cause to Celebrate is available free from the National Housing Federation on 020 7843 2234.

fields.headline: Helping charities get fit financially
fields.trailText: Sound financial training for very small and start-up charities can make the difference between success and failure, according to a new study by the City Parochial Foundation and the Trust for London.
fields.body:
Fitness training for smaller charities

Sound financial training for very small and start-up charities can make the difference between success and failure, according to a new study by the City Parochial Foundation and the Trust for London.

The report, Financial Fitness, suggests that funders can have an important role to play in supporting training for small organisations. The report finds that good quality financial management training significantly improves the ability of small charities to grow and develop. It recommends that small charities first develop reliable manual accounting systems before they begin to consider computerised systems.

Grant givers should try to ensure that small and newly formed organisations have access to good, local and low-cost financial training, it says. Carol Harrison, finance director at the City Parochial Foundation says: "Despite the enthusiasm of those people in small and starting charities, if they donêt get proper financial training at an early stage they can sink quickly."

The report follows an earlier study, also by Peter Fairbairn, on the financial monitoring of funded organisations. For information on obtaining a copy of Financial Fitness contact the City Parochial Foundation on 020-7606 6145.

Stakeholder pensions

Charities will be among the organisations most affected by new requirements on employers to put in place stakeholder pensions.

These are low-cost, flexible pensions aimed at low or middle earners. They are launched next month, and by October 8 all organisations employing five or more staff and without their own occupational or group pension scheme must be able to offer a stakeholder pension facility.

Lucy French, business development manager at the National Council for Voluntary Organisations points out that a study in 1997 showed that only 14.2% of charities had their own pension schemes.

Many charities are unprepared for the changes and, like other employers, if they fail to take steps in time they could be subject to fines from the Occupational Pensions Regulatory Authority (OPRA). One of the complications for charities is that decision making can be a lengthy process.

OPRA has so far authorised 26 providers of stakeholder pensions and information on the pensions and on providers is available from their website.

The NCVO has been in talks with some stakeholder providers and aims to launch and promote its own scheme, in alliance with one or more authorised providers.

Accounts defaulters

The charity commission is naming and shaming charities that have persistently failed to submit accounts by posting their details on its website. The commission has dubbed the charities "triple defaulters" as they have not returned accounts on three occasions.

All the charities have incomes of over £100,000 and under the Charities Act should supply annual return forms, a trustees' annual report and their accounts to the commission within 10 months of the end of the financial year.

Chief charity commissioner, John Stoker, says: "This is part of a rolling programme of action against persistent defaulters. They may in the future find themselves subject to further publicity, a formal commission inquiry, or to prosecution."

The commission's ongoing programme is currently targeted at the nearly 17,000 charities which have a gross income or total expenditure of over £100,000. Persistent failure to provide statutory information to the commission can result in a fine of up to £2,500.

fields.headline: Ringing the changes
fields.standfirst: Gordon Brown introduced tax incentives for donors a year ago. Liza Ramrayka finds out what impact they have had on charities' coffers
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown introduced tax incentives for donors a year ago. Liza Ramrayka finds out what impact they have had on charities' coffers
fields.body:
When chancellor Gordon Brown's package of tax incentives to get Britain giving kicked in last April, charities were told that the measures - combined with the national campaign due to launch early this summer - could boost the sector's fortunes by £1bn a year. One year on, are finance directors starting to see that promise being fulfilled?

A key issue for any charity keen to take advantage of the changes is ascertaining whether the donor is a taxpayer, so the charity can reclaim tax on the donation. New research carried out jointly by the National Council for Voluntary Organisations and the Charities Aid Foundation suggests this message is beginning to get through. In a recent survey of 936 representative adults, over two-thirds had given to charity and 11.5% of these were taxpayers who had provided information about their tax status. Half of these givers were from social class C1 compared with 33% of previous tax-effective givers, and around one-third were aged 45-54 compared with 23% previously.

NCVO head of campaigns Campbell Robb believes the data demonstrates that charities and the public are starting to take advantage of the new incentives to give: "These figures clearly show that with a coordinated campaign, voluntary and community organisations will be able to really benefit from the new tax measures." The voluntary sector-led campaign aims to raise awareness of the tax changes and develop "an overarching brand for charitable giving". With government backing to the tune of £1m, it is expected to target key donor areas such as business, young people and wealthy givers.

Joe Saxton, head of not-for-profit at the Future Foundation think tank, welcomes the moves to encourage giving but says the sector could already be doing more to capitalise on the changes. The foundationÍs own research into public awareness of the tax changes found that only 19% of under-35s had heard about them compared with over 50% of those over 45. Three-quarters of giving respondents had not been approached to make their donation more tax effective, and only a fifth realised that donating shares was an option. "The evidence we have is that charities are not doing their job yet. Let's get them to make existing donations tax effective first so they are ready to cope with new ones," Saxton says.

Some charities have already taken the initiative. Last year Oxfam, the Red Cross and a number of other large charities teamed up to target supporters with a mailshot explaining the tax changes. Coordinated by marketing agency Pell & Bales, the mailing asked people to sign a form giving their permission to the charity in question to reclaim tax on their donation; it attracted a 36% response rate.

CAF is currently urging charities to promote the giving of shares before April 5 as a way of reducing donors' tax bills for the current tax year. It has seen share and stock donations leap to £26m from £8m in the last 12 months. CAF estimates only 1% of the population has donated in this way, yet 17% currently hold stocks and shares. "Clearly there is much more scope to encourage donations in this area," says CAF director of research Cathy Pharoah.

Tyne & Wear's community foundation received shares worth £250,000 last August from Ringtons, a family-owned tea company based in Newcastle-upon-Tyne. Local charities are now benefiting from the gift, which is held as an endowment, and cost the company just £100,000 to donate. "If we'd cashed in the shares and paid the money out to shareholders, we would have got £100,000 at most. This way there's an immediate income tax rebate and we give back to the communities that have helped us prosper," says Ringtons' chairman Nigel Smith. The umbrella group Community Foundation Network is calling on financial advisers and charities to help raise awareness of these concessions to business.

Payroll giving appears to be the success story of the last year, with the government's 10% supplement on donations until 2003 spurring both employers and staff into action. This is enhanced by the new obligation on the agencies that distribute payroll giving donations to do so within 60 days. Figures collated by agency South West Charitable Giving confirm a rise in donations in the nine months from April to December 2000, which stood at £33.7m compared with £23.4m for the same period in the previous year. At Centrica, more than 1,000 employees joined the payroll giving scheme following a promotional campaign last summer compared with only 450 before the introduction of the supplement.

Both promotions were carried out by professional fundraising organisation Sharing the Caring, which is due to launch or relaunch schemes for five blue-chip companies next month. "We are confident the government's national campaign target of doubling the amount raised for charities through payroll giving by April 2003 will be met," says chief executive Christine Jenkins. Whether the giving campaign will help to realise the potential of the new tax regime remains to be seen. In the meantime, Pharoah at CAF urges the sector to reassess its approach to how it promotes giving: "It's a question of charities rethinking their whole fundraising strategy, not just adapting conventional methods."

webTitle: What charity leaders want from the next government

fields.headline: A new manifesto
fields.standfirst: In the run-up to the forthcoming election, Nicola Hill asks a range of finance directors and voluntary sector leaders  what charities really, really want from the next government
fields.trailText: In the run-up to the forthcoming election, Nicola Hill asks a range of finance directors and voluntary sector leaders what charities really, really want from the next government
fields.body:
Stuart Etherington, chief executive, the National Council for Voluntary Organisations (NCVO)

The voluntary sector is now truly the third sector in every respect. One in 50 employees works for a charity, contributing the equivalent of more than 350,000 full-time jobs to the economy and as nearly £5bn to the GDP.

NCVO has set out its own election manifesto, which is an agenda for change for the next general election on behalf of the voluntary sector in England. We consulted our 1,700 members on the manifesto and its contents. The set of general principles and specific proposals contained in this manifesto could and should be adopted by all the political parties.

The manifesto's recommendations include a number of key fiscal measures, which can be easily implemented by any government to create the economic environment in which voluntary organisations can flourish. They include:

 Government funding of voluntary organisations should be undertaken on a long-term, multi-year basis, include the funding of core activities and meet the costs of engagement that voluntary organisations face.

 Government should introduce a VAT rebate scheme for the voluntary sector.

 Long-term financial and infrastructure support for the development of the sector must ensure that it has the capacity to train and develop its staff and volunteers.

We want the next government to look at taxation and find ways to fund the growth in charities that all political parties want to see. On the question of VAT, we are interested in those little niches that have been knocked into the rock by, for example, churches, which can reclaim VAT for repairs and museums for their entry fees. We want to see if we can open up that wedge a bit further.

However, we are wary of balancing the request for VAT relief against the extra statutory concessions that we already receive. If we shout too loudly, it might be peeled off the other end.

We are very keen to support any government scheme which gets more resources into the voluntary sector, but we are also very aware of the pressure this places on the voluntary sector to raise more voluntary income for matched funding. A future government needs to recognise that there is a cost connected to raising money for matched funding.

Stephen Burgess, charities consultant, Saffrey Champness, and former director of finance, Help the Aged

I expect there will be a return in the next 20 to 30 years to the older style of philanthropy, which characterised the late 19th and early 20th centuries. At that time, industrialists saw their role as providers of education, health and community support.

Over the past 20 years the welfare state has been eroded and the voluntary sector has stepped into the breach. We now need a return to philanthropy but within a modern context. Individuals and companies need to recognise it is in their economic interest to be better citizens. The government needs to encourage this and make more tax changes to encourage giving.

The changes so far are welcomed, particularly the incentive to give shares. But the government must look towards the US, where there has never been a break in philanthropy because of their less generous welfare state. Over there, companies are much better corporate citizens and are more involved with employees in supporting charities and encouraging payroll giving.

The suggestion at the time was that donations would tend to be larger to compensate for the tax relief bonus we used to get. My feeling is that this hasn't happened and charities have lost out. I would like to see this decision reversed by the next government.

The rules governing VAT exemption for charities are complicated and selective. Why not make charities VAT-exempt altogether?

My number-one wish would be for a simplification of the VAT system. At the moment there are 250 exemptions for charities to a law introduced in 1974 covering VAT. My second wish feels like asking Santa for something else when I've already had a big present. Last year, the chancellor's changes to gift aid brought a £3m boost to the NSPCC's income, but we would like the government to promote the changes more effectively. The tax relief on donating shares has not had much impact and the news of the change is taking time to seep through to those who could benefit.

James Davidson, finance director, Cancer Research Campaign

I would like the government to simplify the gift aid statement that donors have to sign. It is confusing and ponderous and could be a deterrent. It would be a shame if it is ruined by red tape.

The payroll giving scheme could also benefit from a change in rules to allow donors to transfer their promise to give to a charity when they move jobs. This could be a simple box on a P45.

And finally the perennial moan about VAT. I don't support a total rebate as I recognise the chancellor's need to balance the nation's books, but we need more clarity and consistency. The interpretation of VAT can vary across regions and even between two inspectors.

Les Jones, finance director and deputy chief executive, WWF (Worldwide Fund for Nature)

We would like the next government to show confidence in charities and look at ways it can use us more productively. It should also continue to raise the profile of charities' role in civil society.

The next government should work in partnership with the sector to make charities more accountable, with stronger regulation and accounting procedures.

The government must also be more generous financially. The phasing out of advance corporation tax means that the sector is no better off under Labour's first term. So we want something stirring from a second term if they are re-elected.

Charities should not be subjected to VAT; it should be a matter of right that we can reclaim the £500m a year the sector loses in irrecoverable VAT.

The government should also make sure that grant-giving departments such as the department for international development and the Home Office engage in joined-up thinking. Grants to the voluntary sector are often very complex and compliance can vary. We need more trust between government and the sector so that it can be given money in a less complex way.

Over the past year the government has introduced a series of important new tax incentives for charity. But there is some leftover business, and a new government, whatever its political colour, will be asked to consider the desirability of introducing new tax credits for social investment.

Everyone is now arguing in favour of creating effective partnerships between government, business and voluntary organisations. The voluntary sector is being asked to participate in major economic and social regeneration initiatives around the country. It is vital that social investment in such initiatives is backed up by appropriate tax incentives to charities and voluntary organisations in the same way business can obtain such incentives.

Just as important, loan finance is becoming increasingly important. Charities and non-profit enterprises, the social economy, should use their assets and borrow to undertake their work.

fields.headline: A matter of practice
fields.standfirst: New accounting guidelines were introduced at the start of this year and are designed to make charity finances more digestible for the lay reader. Patrick McCurry finds out how charities are grappling with the changes
fields.trailText: New accounting guidelines were introduced at the start of this year and are designed to make charity finances more digestible for the lay reader. Patrick McCurry finds out how charities are grappling with the changes
fields.body:
Charity accounting used to be a rather opaque area that few outside the finance directors' office really understood. It was often extremely hard, from reading the report and accounts, to work out what a charity was up to or to compare it with other voluntary organisations. That all begin to change in 1995 when the statement of recommended practice (Sorp) was launched, a new accounting framework aimed at improving consistency and accountability. Now, "son of Sorp" has been brought in to further improve the way charities present their financial situation. The new Sorp is being presented not as a radical change to the original but as an evolution.

It also puts a lot more emphasis on the reporting of activities and aims to give the reader of trustees' reports a much clearer picture of the charity's activities. "The overwhelming drive is to bring more openness to charity accounting and make it more accessible," says Alan Sharpe, finance director at bird welfare charity RSPB.

He adds that the changes are largely welcome, given the growing public and media scrutiny of charities. But it will still be up to charity managers and trustees to rise to the challenge of making accounts and reporting as easy to understand as possible.

"Unlike those who read the annual reports of commercial organisations, many of those supporting charities are not financially informed and so it will be up to us to present the information as clearly as possible," says Sharpe.

Among the changes, the new Sorp advises charities to publish statements of their policies on investments, grant-making and reserves. There will be a clearer presentation of how funds are raised and how much is spent raising those funds. Trustees will also have to say what controls they have in place to reduce operational and financial risks.

But some in the sector argue that the changes will not prevent the kind of blurring between what a charity says it has spent on fundraising and administration and what it has spent on charitable services. "A lot of charities disguise their central costs and you see big variations between charities in similar fields; I don't think the new Sorp will improve things here," says Jackie Bliss, director of finance and administration at child welfare charity Coram Family. Fears about public criticism that they are spending too much on central management have encouraged some charity finance directors to engage in "creative accounting". Bliss believes that perhaps more guidance is still needed on how to distinguish between central management costs and charitable spending: "It's still too easy to disguise central costs by putting some through the provision of direct services."

But she welcomes many of the changes in the new Sorp, such as the wide definition of what can be regarded as the costs of generating funds. The new Sorp, for example, will allow Coram Family to treat its investment management costs as fundraising not as overheads. "That means quite a lot to us because more than a quarter of our income is from investments," she says. There is some concern, however, that the requirement to show how much has been spent on specific fundraising activities and what has been raised in income could distort the true picture. Some fundraising campaigns require a large initial investment but only pay that back over several years, which could lead to an unbalanced picture by looking at the situation in one year in isolation, says Bliss.

Pesh Framjee, head of the charity unit at accountants Binder Hamlyn and a member of the committee that drew up the new Sorp, says the focus of many of the changes is on how the accounts are reported.

Trustees will have to look carefully at what the charity's policy is in areas such as reserves or investments and describe their general strategy for the organisation. "All this should focus trustees' minds on what the charity is doing and what it should be seeking to do," says Framjee.

The RSPB's Alan Sharpe notes that previously the trustees' report was quite prescriptive and there was a temptation to adopt a "checklist approach" without necessarily embracing the spirit of the exercise. "I think under the new Sorp, people will get a much clearer idea of what a charity is trying to do," he says.

Another area where a charity's activities will become clearer is in trading. Rather than just showing a lump sum of income, the new guidance on presenting information about the generation of funds means charities will have to show how much income comes from their shops, fundraising events and so on.

Risk assessment is another area of the new accounting guidelines that many smaller charities are concerned about. Framjee says questions of how risks are managed has been a significant issue for the corporate sector for several years.

"It would be wrong for people to see it as a compliance issue," he says: "It's like wearing a seatbelt: you should do it because it's good for the organisation, not because you feel you have to."

Sharpe says a lot of larger charities already have separate procedures in place to minimise risks to their operations: "It will be a case of bringing those measures together under an overall risk-control policy."

The new Sorp relates to accounting periods beginning on or after January 1 2001 and affects the accounts of charities with an income of more than £100,000 and all charitable companies.

Will the changes lead to the sell-off of 'old masters'?

Some charities are concerned that one element in the new Sorp could put pressure on them to sell off assets that were never meant to leave their hands.

This is because there will be a much tighter requirement on charities to account for "historic or inalienable assets", often works of art or other assets donated by either the founders or the supporters of the charity.

Charities will have to put a value on these assets and include them on the balance sheet. Coram Family's Jackie Bliss says that if these assets are truly inalienable, in other words if they are not able to be transferred or sold, listing their value in the accounts gives a false impression of wealth.

"It suggests to the reader of the accounts that the asset is a financial one and hence capable of being liquidated to increase cash reserves," she says.

The danger, says Bliss, is that it is only a short step from there for public and media comment to expect such assets to be sold, as an alternative to fundraising. "This is a very complex area. More work needs to be done to clarify this area of accounting," she says.

webTitle: The effects of funders' demands upon charities

fields.headline: Called to account
fields.standfirst: Charities are being stretched in different directions by funders' demands and it is costing them money. Heather Lamont explains why
fields.trailText: Charities are being stretched in different directions by funders' demands and it is costing them money. Heather Lamont explains why
fields.body:
Regulation and scrutiny have intensified sharply since the passing of the charities acts in 1992 and 1993. In England and Wales, all but the very smallest charities now have to submit an annual return and accounts to the charity commission.

No big deal, perhaps, and a degree of scrutiny is more than justified in a sector with an estimated annual income approaching £30bn a year, in which the constituent organisations enjoy tax breaks and privileged access to funding. But as you get bigger, the requirements become more challenging. Charities turning over £100,000 or more have to follow the commission's statement of recommended practice on accounting (Sorp).

The disclosures set out in this document make a good deal of sense when it comes to reporting charities' success in using their funds to pursue their stated objectives. Unfortunately the resulting format for charity accounts is so far removed from regular company accounts that many accountants who do not deal regularly with charities would be hard pressed to prepare them in the time it would take to knock out the accounts for a comparably sized limited company.

If a statutory audit is required, costs can really start to rise. For charities this happens automatically when incoming resources exceed £250,000 a year, far below the £1m threshold now in force for limited companies. A survey carried out late last year by Charity Finance magazine found that charities in the lowest income bracket for which an audit is compulsory, paid an average of £2,723 for their audit. That may not sound much, but for many charities, almost all income comes in the form of grants for specific projects.

Most auditors specialising in the charity sector believe that fees will rise over the next few years. One factor is the continuing trend among audit firms to merge. Firms combine to meet the sophisticated demands of large clients; this pushes up their overheads, which must be passed on.

At the same time, a shrinking pool of firms from which charities can buy specialist expertise is bound to reduce the incentive to compete on fees.

Meanwhile many organisations are being pushed into having a full audit even when the charity's income is well below the statutory threshold. Andrew Dinkenor, a community accountant working in south London, says: "The local authority requires that any group receiving a grant from it which has an income of £10,000 or more must have a full audit.

In addition, those in receipt of grants from different sources are likely to find that each funder has its own ideas about what information it needs. Reports to funders rarely call for information that a well-run charity wouldn't be recording anyway. But preparing it in the various formats and collecting back-up evidence takes time and money.

And while they are keen to impose rigorous reporting demands on charities, most funders are not so interested in paying for the time and expertise that goes into meeting those demands. It's a burden they have to live with, and the price to pay for funding from institutions. Kate Sayer, partner at charity auditors Sayer Vincent, believes that there's a limit to how far reporting structures can be aligned. As she points out: "There might be room for streamlining, but at the end of the day you have to be accountable to your funders."

 Heather Lamont is editor of Charity Finance magazine

webTitle: The effect of goverment policy on estates in Salford

fields.headline: The effect of goverment policy on estates in Salford
fields.standfirst: For four years, Labour has been trying new policies and digging deeper in the public purse to deal with crime, health, education and poverty. During that time, BBC's Newsnight has been carrying periodic reports from one front line of deprivation - the Ordsall and Langworthy estates
fields.trailText: For four years, Labour has been trying new policies and digging deeper in the public purse to deal with crime, health, education and poverty. During that time, BBC's Newsnight has been carrying periodic reports from one front line of deprivation - the Ordsall and Langworthy estates
fields.body:
Helen Buchanan, head teacher of St Clement's primary school, serving some of the poorest estates in Salford, has mixed views about the effects of Labour's policies. She has seen at first hand that some benefit changes, perversely, have made it harder for lone parents who want to work. She has mixed views about her school being in an education action zone (EAZ) but is delighted at the plentiful funds available for repairing buildings.

"We're at the cutting edge of poverty here," says Buchanan. Keen to help local unemployment, she recruits parents as classroom assistants. But some say they are worse off working than claiming benefit. A lone mother, one of four assistants, found that her classroom job meant she moved off income support on to working families tax credit. With weekly dinner money totalling £18.75 for three children, and with full rent and council tax to pay, the woman was unable to manage on her school earnings. She asked to be cut to 16 hours, so she would again be eligible for benefits.

All the social problems of the estates are evident in the school. The counter-attack against deprivation begins at eight every morning with the breakfast club, one of six at Salford schools provided by Kellogg's, as an EAZ sponsor. It is one of the few aspects of the zones that Buchanan says has worked. But a budget of £750,000 split among 18 schools "doesn't go anywhere", she observes. "The government was relying on the excitement of big business throwing money at education, but it never happened."

Far better, she reckons, is the "excellence in cities" initiative. That has paid for a full-time learning mentor for four years. The role of the school is transformed by this way of providing pastoral care: the mentor "can do home visits for reluctant attenders; [run] anger management courses; liaise with multi-agency workers". And possibly best of all, the school having had to spend £78,000 over eight years on repairs to redress vandalism, are the funds flowing in under Labour for repairs and refurbishment: £25,000 for a security fence, £120,000 for central heating. "We're even redecorating for the first time in 18 years," she says.

Dr Lawrence Addlestone says: "I don't honestly see that anything any government has ever done has made any difference round here in the 12 years I've been a GP here." His five-partner practice has some 8,000 patients from the Langworthy area. He is sure that social problems have changed little, with the exception of never now seeing cases of malnourishment. Addlestone is critical of Labour for ending GP fundholding, which had been introduced by the Conservatives.

"We found it very empowering, and managed to do a lot more for our patients," he says. "We've had to fight very hard to keep what we had. "We had started a chiropractic service, but money for that is now limited. We had a cardiologist who would come once a week to see heart patients, but that's been withdrawn by Manchester Royal Infirmary. We had the services of a counsellor but now have to go through a central service, so instead of appointments for depressed patients within a few days, it now takes two or three months."

As for shorter hospital waiting lists, he says: "The impact has been on the statistics, not at the grassroots. Things have got slightly worse in some specialisms - orthopaedics, for instance - and some hospitals." The practice has access to three big hospitals, one of which often has a shorter waiting time than the others. Addlestone frequently finds himself sending off three referral letters at the same time for the same patient: the system just has to be played that way. He acknowledges that the new local primary care trust oversees the needs of an area covered by several practices and hospitals. "I suppose it is more equitable," he says, "but this government was supposed to bring everybody up to the highest standard - and all we've seen is that standards have gone down."

PC Paul Cusick says that, with the old-style beat bobby having been reinvented new-style by Greater Manchester Police, he needs to know as much about regeneration initiatives as crime initiatives on his patch of Salford. Crime in all its aspects on the estates is worrying, but fear of crime is even more potent, he says. And he is sympathetic to disaffected youth. "We have to move gangs of young people; but we do understand there are very few youth clubs and cafes round here. Sometimes there are groups of 30 or 40. But in all honesty, half the time the kids are only gathering like that because they're frightened of another gang - though they wouldn't admit it."

Cusick reckons that the new partnerships among professional groups are an excellent way of working, "rather than keeping it in our own backyard". He adds: "Before, everything was bunged on the police, and it got to the point where we were doing everything." Early days yet, though, for spectacular results. "To look at the area, there's not been a vast improvement, I'm afraid. For the initiatives that have been brought in recently, we haven't got the cash yet. But we're hoping to get millions and millions from New Deal." That could mean new landscapes, new lives. And Cusick is optimistic - even though in his part of Salford, where sector policing has been introduced, his team of eight beat officers is two under strength.

Rita McNamara , education officer for the Salford youth offending team, is a fan of the home secretary - certainly as far as the Crime and Disorder Act is concerned. With magistrates now handing out action plans (of three months' duration) and supervision orders (which can run for up to three years), she says: "We're surrounding young offenders with a blanket of support." The new set-up means that McNamara shares an office with police, and health and social work staff. This brings the advantage that "we weave in and out of each other's cases in the youth action team".

For the first time, she believes, the education needs of youngsters who start as truants, then turn to crime, are being properly addressed. And a proper effort is being made to insert them back into an appropriate niche in the education system. But she says the government must try even harder. "More money needs to be put into alternative provision; and more training for teachers on working with very, very disaffected children, because we're putting them back into the system, and teacher training doesn't teach them how to deal with that. "I would like all our young people to be comfortable enough to go back into the mainstream. And when it isn't possible, there should be an immediate place for them in other centres where their education needs are catered for - and I don't mean a second-class education. Young offenders are not stupid; they just need a different way in."

Real Estates will be broadcast on BBC2 on four consecutive nights, starting next Monday at 11.20pm.

fields.headline: Taking SRI to big business
fields.standfirst: Rob Lake tells Jessica McCallin why he made the move from an NGO to a global investment company
fields.trailText: Rob Lake tells Jessica McCallin why he made the move from an NGO to a global investment company.
fields.body:
Rob Lake is typical of some of the NGO-to-City moves which have been occurring recently within the socially responsible investment (SRI) sector. He recently joined Henderson Global Investors as head of SRI Strategy, a job which involves taking the case for more socially and environmentally aware business practices directly to company management.

It's a job Mr Lake is familiar with from his previous role as director of policy at fair trade organisation Traidcraft, but also one he felt had reached its natural conclusion within the confines of an NGO.

"Specialist NGOs such as Traidcraft influence change through argument, but they have limited resources and can't do everything," he said. "I had had lots of contact with business over the past few years and was keen to continue working in the field of company engagement. Investors, as owners of a company, are very well placed to influence company management and, at the moment, the general trend is towards more active shareholding. As such, joining a city firm seemed like the logical next step."

The job at Henderson's was particularly attractive because its scope is wider than just SRI. Henderson is one of the first fund management companies to apply corporate governance principles - rules on how a responsible company should be run - to all its £120bn-worth of company holdings. One of Mr Lake's responsibilities will be monitoring compliance with corporate governance principles, a role that will bring him into contact with companies outside the traditional SRI sphere.

Although honest about the lure of his increased pay package, Mr Lake doesn't think this is the main motivation for NGO staff joining city firms. "You've got to want the challenge of making a business case for SRI. You've got to understand and use investment jargon and be able to present social and environmental issues in terms of risks to a company." After all, all that extra money won't automatically mean more money to spend on holidays. "When I first starting working in this area I had to buy two new suits and become much more au fait with cufflinks," joked Mr Lake.

fields.headline: Triodos profits from ethical policies
fields.trailText: Ethical banking is going from strength to strength with Triodos Bank, one of the UK's leading "green banks", reporting an 81% increase in net profits in 2000. Nicola Hill reports
fields.body:
Ethical banking is going from strength to strength with Triodos Bank, one of the UK's leading "green banks", reporting an 81% increase in net profits in 2000. Savings and investments grew by 32% and the bank's balance sheet grew by 34% last year and now totals £385m.

Triodos Bank is an independent bank founded in the Netherlands in 1980, and operates from headquarters in Bristol. It only lends to enterprises with social and environmental objectives. This includes charities, community organisations and social businesses. Savers can specify the type of areas where they would like their money invested.

The bank has done particularly well in the UK organic farming sector where lending has increased by an average of 260% per year over the last two years to the end of 2000.

Spokeswoman Susan Jenkins, said: "With these strong results and the exceptional growth of our banking activities in the organic market, we're now in an excellent position to bring this experience to the charity market, with our planned roll out of new charity banking services in 2001."

Triodos plans to launch new services for charities including a current account earning tiered interest on credit balances so there is no need to keep transferring money between accounts to get the best from funds.

fields.headline: SRI in big demand
fields.standfirst: Since new legislation passed last summer, the socially responsible investment sector has been struggling to meet the demand for its services, writes Jessica McCallin
fields.trailText: Since new legislation passed last summer, the socially responsible investment sector has been struggling to meet the demand for its services, writes Jessica McCallin.
fields.body:
It's all systems go in the socially responsible investment sector at the moment. SRI, as it's more commonly known, received a major boost last summer when new legislation was passed asking pension fund managers to state their views on social and environmental issues and since then the sector has been struggling to meet the demand for its services.

To anyone working in, or aspiring to work in SRI, this is very good news. People with experience and expertise are being headhunted like crazy.

Fund management companies, keen to cash in on the sector's exponential growth, are launching their own ethical funds and poaching fund managers from rival firms. Henderson Global Investors, for example, recently lost eight of its staff to Morley Fund Management.

In addition, traditional fund managers - those who only consider the financial performance of companies and not their social and environmental performance - are undergoing a retraining of sorts. To plug the gap created by its staff leaving, Henderson moved fund managers from its mainstream funds into its ethical ones. James Giuseppi from Henderson's SRI team said: "We are recruiting internally because it's incredibly difficult to find fund managers with both experience of SRI and a good investment performance record. We even used headhunters to try and find them, but didn't have much luck. There is a dire shortage of the right people."

However, this dire shortage of people is arguably more serious for the NGOs. Tempted, in part, by the significantly better remuneration packages offered by the city firms, NGO staff are leaving to join the fund managers in droves. The Worldwide Wildlife Fund (WWF), Traidcraft and the International Institute for Environment and Development are just some of the charities who have recently lost staff to the city. In fact, Brian Pearce's move from investment bank Warburgs to Forum for the Future appears to be the only city-to-NGO move in recent times.

NGOs are surprisingly philosophical about losing their staff. Paul King, head of business and consumption at WWF, explained: "Poaching staff is a fact of life and most of the NGOs involved in SRI take a longer-term view of the moves. Our staffs are not turning their backs on their principles, they are joining city firms to continue doing the work they were doing with us. This can only be a good thing and will help the NGOs to further their objectives."

And, in some cases, getting more social and environmental expertise into the city is one of the stated aims of NGOs. One of Forum for the Future's objectives is to train up city fund managers, so it is therefore delighted that so many people are joining the city.

This is not to say that having to recruit and nurture new staff is not frustrating, but NGOs are not letting it get in the way of their SRI work. In fact, most are massively expanding their SRI operations in line with the growth in the city. Brian Pearce's recent move to Forum for the Future is just the tip of the iceberg. The organisation intends to recruit three more sustainable business workers this year and three more next year. WWF is also expanding and diversifying its work. And War on Want, hot on the heels of the pensions regulations, relaunched its "Investing in Freedom" campaign and rewrote one of its job descriptions. Now, one member of staff spends a least one day a week focusing on ethical investment issues.

Academic institutions are also rising to the challenge of SRI and developing courses which meet its needs. Forum for the Future offers a masters degree in leadership for sustainable development. And similar degrees are offered by Imperial College London and Bath University. Graduates from these courses look set to walk into their ideal jobs, but until enough graduate, SRI specialists will remain a sought after commodity.

fields.headline: The Get Britain Giving Package
fields.trailText: Gift Aid
fields.body:
Gift Aid

 Abolition of the £250 minimum limit for donations so that tax relief applies to any donation, whether large, small, regular or one-off

 Simplified declaration involving donor name, address, recipient charity and description of gift

 Companies no longer have to deduct tax from their donations

Payroll giving

 Abolition of the £1,200 a year ceiling on giving through the pay packet

 A 10% supplement on all donations to charities until April 2003

 A 60-day limit on payroll giving agencies distributing donations to nominated charities

Donations of shares

 Tax relief of up to 80% for gifts to charity of listed shares and securities, already exempt from capital gains tax

Fundraising events

 Tax exemption on profits from up to 15 events of the same kind held in the same location in any financial year

 Tax exemption on profits from any number of events of the same type where the gross weekly takings do not exceed the sum of £1,000

webTitle: Senator keeps the grim reaper and Washington waiting

fields.headline: Senator keeps the grim reaper and Washington waiting
fields.standfirst: Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: As Strom Thurmond limps through the corridors of the Senate these days, his every move is followed with morbid fascination - the health of the 98-year-old political relic of the South could determine the fate of the Bush presidency.
fields.body:
As Strom Thurmond limps through the corridors of the Senate these days, his every move is followed with morbid fascination - the health of the 98-year-old political relic of the South could determine the fate of the Bush presidency.

The arithmetic is simple. The Senate is split 50-50 between Democrats and Republicans, giving Vice President Dick Cheney the casting vote on vital legislation. If Senator Thurmond, a Republican, dies or becomes incapacitated before the next election in 2002, his replacement will be nominated by the governor of his state, South Carolina, a Democrat.

Assuming the governor, Jim Hodges, follows party discipline, that would give the Democrats a Senate majority and a powerful barrier to George Bush's more partisan measures. US politics would suddenly look very different.

Little wonder, then, that Washington's political antennae quivered when Sen Thurmond was hospitalised last month for "exhaustion", which meant he could not cast his vote. He has had to give up his privilege as the oldest senator (ever) to bang the gavel at the start of sessions and he has to be helped along by his aides.

On the few occasions he speaks, he has to read from index cards provided by his staff, who now guide most of his political actions. He is too proud to wear a hearing aid, and when Mr Bush asked him on inauguration day how many presidents the senator had served under, Mr Thurmond was unable to hear the question.

The senator is the living embodiment of the modern history of the South. He launched his career in 1932 as a Democrat in the state assembly, and parachuted into Normandy on D-Day 1944, even though he could have claimed exemption because of his age. After the war, he turned against the Democrats when the party embraced civil rights for blacks.

He ran as a neo-Confederate "States' Rights" candidate promising his fellow whites: "We believe that there are not enough troops in the Army to force Southern people to admit the Negroes into our theatres, swimming pools and homes."

He switched to the Republicans in 1964 to back the right-wing maverick Barry Goldwater and has been the Senate's senior member for more than 20 years, breaking all longevity records years ago.

Most of Mr Thurmond's colleagues are too polite to speak openly of his departure, but he has begun preparing for such an eventuality. He is reported to have videotaped a message endorsing his estranged wife, Nancy, as his replacement, but she has denied any interest in the job.

In any case, it will be up to Mr Hodges to appoint a caretaker, and although the governor's office has been teasing the Democratic hierarchy that it cannot count on him choosing a party loyalist, it is generally assumed in Washington that he will do his duty.

Hence the obsessive focus on Mr Thurmond's wellbeing. However, his supporters are certain he will hang on until his term expires in 2003, when he will be 101.

They point to his extraordinary vigour, which they attribute to decades of abstention from tobacco and alcohol and a mania for exercise. He married Nancy, his second wife, when he was 66 and she was 44 years his junior.

For now, the Democrats can only wait patiently. As even Mr Hodges said: "The graveyard in South Carolina is full of people who thought Strom Thurmond would leave office."

In any case, it will be up to Mr Hodges to appoint a caretaker, and although the governor's office has been teasing the Democratic hierarchy that it cannot count on him choosing a party loyalist, it is generally assumed in Washington that he will do his duty. Hence the obsessive focus on Mr Thurmond's wellbeing. However, his supporters are certain he will hang on until his term expires in 2003, when he will be 101. They point to his extraordinary vigour, which they attribute to decades of abstention from tobacco and alcohol and a mania for exercise. He married Nancy, his second wife, when he was 66 and she was 44 years his junior. For now, the Democrats can only wait patiently. As even Mr Hodges said: "The graveyard in South Carolina is full of people who thought Strom Thurmond would leave office."

fields.headline: Oil in troubled waters
fields.standfirst:
The mysterious pardon of the fugitive oil dealer who employed a top Tory

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: The mysterious pardon of the fugitive oil dealer who employed a top Tory.
fields.body:
Why, do you suppose, did the last prime minister of Israel, Ehud Barak, and Israel's revered elder statesman, Shimon Peres, both intervene to ask Bill Clinton, as one of his last acts as US president, to pardon Marc Rich, a fugitive from American justice, wanted for a mere $48m in unpaid American taxes? Why did the Israeli foreign minister, Shlomo Bel-Ami, actually put the arm on the King of Spain to join his entreaties that Rich should be pardoned?

Was it simply that Mr Rich is a good friend of Israel and a generous donor to Israeli causes? Unlikely.

The strong probability is that Marc Rich deserved Israeli gratitude because he played a crucial part in helping Israel secure enough oil, at the time of the Arab oil boycott of 1973, to survive. I say the strong probability, because although this has never been mentioned in the miles of column inches devoted to "Pardongate", 15 years ago, when I was researching a book about some consequences of the oil crisis on the world shipping market, several informants assured me that Rich had indeed been involved in rescuing Israel in an hour of need.

Nothing less, you might think, would explain the truly extraordinary, high-level lobbying for a pardon for a fugitive commodities trader who was behind on his taxes.

The disreputable status of Marc Rich has attracted attention in this country not only because of the scandal of his last-minute pardon by an outgoing US president, but because throughout much of the 1980s, Rich also used to employ Alan Duncan, the friend of Conservative leader William Hague and currently shadow trade spokesman.

Marc Rich's Israeli connection is a matter for speculation. But what is not in doubt is that Rich was heavily involved in busting sanctions applied to another country. He certainly played a major part in finding oil from many sources, but conspicuously from Brunei, for the apartheid regime in South Africa.

In so doing, Rich found himself in a world of marine cowboys. It was peopled by Greeks under investigation for piracy, and by at least one Italian with dubious connections with the shadowy world where intelligence and fascism rubbed shoulders. In fact, the South Africans' desperate need for oil brought out of the woodwork a whole fauna of more or less shady businessmen from Hong Kong to Houston by way of the Piraeus and of Zug, the trim, Swiss lakeside town where Marc Rich had his headquarters.

Bill Clinton is idolised by millions of African Americans. Would they be quite so keen on him if they knew he had used his pardon power to help a man who had made large amounts of money by breaking the embargo, imposed by the sub-Saharan African countries and their Arab allies, on South Africa?

Until the fall of the Shah in 1979 the South Africans could get some oil from Iran. After he fell, they were in serious trouble. According to an American academic study, Sasol, the South African state oil company, turned to two men to save its supplies. One was a Dutchman, John Deuss, who until 1977 had been trading in Soviet oil. Within the year, Deuss found 18m tons of oil, most of it from Saudi Arabia.

As early as April 1979 Marc Rich had negotiated an initial contract to deliver 50m barrels of oil to South Africa. The oil, delivered through a company called Minoil, came from many sources, among them Brunei. But after mid-1981 Royal Dutch Shell, not wanting to incur the bad publicity and government pressure that could come from continuing to break the embargo, broke up its partnership with the government of Brunei. Marc Rich stepped in and arranged deliveries from Brunei himself.

Rich's activities and already brought him into odd company. In 1979, in the biggest casualty ever up to that time in terms of tonnage lost, the Atlantic Empress, of 292,000 tons dead weight, collided with the Aegean Captain, of 210,000 dwt, off Tobago in a storm. The Aegean Captain is believed to have been loaded with bootleg oil for South Africa, and to have been under charter to Rich or one of his companies at the time.

M ore bizarre was the fate of the Salem, a supertanker which secretly unloaded 192,000 tons of oil in Durban as part of an elaborate conspiracy involving representatives of the South African government and a number of businessmen. On January 17 1980 the Salem sank in one of the deepest trenches in the Atlantic off the coast of Guinea. The mere chance that brought a BP tanker to the scene and found the crew sitting with their duty frees in the lifeboats, led to the revelation that the Salem had been scuttled. Both the ship and the oil that had been unloaded at Durban had been heavily insured at Lloyd's.

The scuttling and insurance scam, presumably, was an elaboration of the basic plan, to use Salem to deliver oil to South Africa through the embargo. But telephone transcripts showed that the delivery of the oil at Durban was reported to the Salem's owner and a confederate in, of all places, Zug, where the owner had business connections.

The Salem's skipper, a certain Dimitrios, or "Jimmy", Georgoulis, is said to have practised driving a supertanker on another ship, the Albahaa B, which was also to have been used to deliver oil to South Africa, but blew up, allegedly as a result of incompetent cleaning of her tanks. The owner of the Albahaa B subsequently lost his life in a mysterious plane crash over the Sudan desert. There were rumours at the time that his plane had been shot down by the Libyan air force.

The great operation to get oil to the South Africans through the embargo is still surrounded by mystery, rumour, secrecy, even paranoia. But what is certain is that Marc Rich was up to his ears in it. Very probably, he built up his contacts in the oil shipping world, and in particular his acquaintance among those who were prepared to take a risk to life or reputation to make very considerable amounts of money, to his earlier experience of running the oil embargo of Israel.

Whatever Rich's precise involvement in the wilder shores of sanctions busting, there is no doubt at all that he was at the heart of the conspiracy to help the South Africans.

Godfrey Hodgson is director of the Reuter Foundation Programme at Green College, Oxford.

webTitle: British more worried about body odour

fields.headline: British turn up their noses at honest sweat
fields.trailText: A market research firm yesterday released a report which shows that the British worry more about body odour than continentals.
fields.body:
When Tony Blair became soaked in sweat during a rousing speech at last year's Labour party conference, the wags suggested he had replaced inspiration with perspiration.

The opposition tried to paint him as a desperate man struggling for support.

But voters elsewhere in Europe would have been impressed by his manliness and vigour, Alex Seron of Taylor Nelson Sofres, a market research firm, claimed yesterday in a report showing that the British worry more about body odour than continentals.

The study - in which 14,000 people were interviewed across Europe - showed that Britons are diligent users of deodorant and only one in four will admit to "having a problem with underarm odour" compared with France where almost three in five respondents happily confessed to underarm odour.

Alex Seron said in countries such as Italy and France, body odour was often associated with "traditional images of masculinity."
