fields.headline: Bear necessity
fields.standfirst: EM.TV considers Henson sale
fields.trailText: EM.TV considers Henson sale
fields.body:
Fallen stockmarket high-flyer EM.TV & Merchandising is considering selling Jim Henson Group, maker of the Muppets, the Hoobs and the Bear in the Big Blue House (left), a year after buying the business.

The Munich group - once a Neuer Markt darling - is likely to take a hefty loss on the $680m (£468m) it paid in cash and shares.

Disney, Viacom subsidiary Nickelodeon and HIT Entertainment are all tipped as possible buyers. Disney is reported to have offered between $200m and $250m at the end of last year.

Yesterday a spokeswoman for EM.TV said: "We are considering selling the Jim Henson Company. We are having some restructuring and the review of the Jim Henson Company is part of that."

She declined to comment on how much EM.TV might want for the business. The acquisition was one of a succession which left the group struggling with a heavy burden of debt.

EM.TV could also be forced to sell its 45% stake in production company Tele Munchen on anti-trust grounds if a rescue by media rival Kirch is finalised.

webTitle: E-district calls in the fraud squad

fields.headline: E-district calls in the fraud squad
fields.standfirst: More net news
fields.trailText: E-district.net, the entertainment website, yesterday said an investigation into allegations of forged financial statements had found that its revenue figures could have been exaggerated by 32 times.
fields.body:
E-district.net, the entertainment website, yesterday said an investigation into allegations of forged financial statements had found that its revenue figures could have been exaggerated by 32 times.

The AIM-listed firm, which last month dismissed chief executive Steven Laitman and saw trading in its shares suspended, said it has called in the fraud squad of the Metropolitan Police to look at financial documents that "appear to have been fabricated and manipulated".

Two other senior managers were also suspended and one has now resigned.

The alleged forgery stretches back before e-district's £100m plus stock market listing last spring and suggests that revenue, registered user and page impression numbers stated in the flotation prospectus were seriously misleading.

Revenues of £781,571 originally reported for the 17 months to December 31 1999 could actually be as low as £98,000, the company said. Revenues for the six months to the end of June last year may not be £1.04m as stated but closer to £32,000. Revenues for the year to December 31 2000 have not been reported but are now expected to be "negligible", it added.

The circumstances surrounding how monthly page impressions fell from 150m to 9m between May and June last year are "still being investigated".

Investigators from PricewaterhouseCoopers and Cap Gemini Ernst & Young believe that up to £1m was paid from bank accounts linked to Mr Laitman into e-district, giving the impression the sales were actually far higher than they really were.

Mr Laitman, who was e-district's biggest shareholder with a 44% stake, has had his funds frozen and is being sued for damages by the company. He could not be reached for comment but is reported to be ready to contest the action.

E-district's problems have raised concerns about the way that internet companies measure and audit their user numbers. Like many new media companies e-district is heavily dependent on advertising revenues.

fields.headline: Country Diary
fields.standfirst: No smoke without fire
fields.trailText: Tamar Valley
fields.body:
Tamar Valley

Opposite the lane from home, dun-coloured calves peer from beside their Limousin-cross mothers in Jeff's yard. The farm drive is shut with a No Entry sign and disinfectant-soaked straw. Downhill, inside a wired-off bank of Double Lents and faded snowdrops, David's 10 pet sheep and goats graze a steep field, once a market garden. West, on off-land, a small flock of sheep range between fields, now contained after they had escaped and wandered the roads a month ago.

From a mile to the south, Queenie speaks on the telephone - 260 more lambs were born last week, and the three of them work even harder, worried and tired, dragging extra feed to ewes and lambs confined to muddy, overstocked ground, banned from moving down the road to fresh pastures overlooking the river. At least they have enough home-produced hay and silage.

The chiffchaff has returned here and the daffodils are in brilliant flower, with a dozen old commercial varieties already blooming in original rows amongst dog's mercury and bluebells. However, Cotehele's Daffodil Day is cancelled, footpaths are closed, and burgeoning spring is blighted by distressing reports from mid-Devon and near Launceston, site of the nearest foot-and-mouth outbreak.

Carcasses are still to be burnt. There is anguish on farms taken over by MAFF officials, valuers and contractors with heavy machinery, digging trenches for Dantesque infernos and subsequent desolation and despoliation. To the east, on Dartmoor, shrouded in rainclouds, 2,500 livestock await slaughter on seven farms around the Two Bridges outbreak.

webTitle: Victims of miscarriages of justice 'dumped like sacks of garbage'

fields.headline: Innocent 'dumped like sacks of garbage'
fields.standfirst: Victims of miscarriages of justice given help to cope with life outside
fields.trailText: When John Kamara walked out of the appeal court last March he had six clear plastic prison bags full of his belongings, a £46 discharge grant and a travel warrant that expired at 8pm that night.
fields.body:
When John Kamara walked out of the appeal court last March he had six clear plastic prison bags full of his belongings, a £46 discharge grant and a travel warrant that expired at 8pm that night.

A victim of a miscarriage of justice who had been in prison for the previous 20 years, he was surprised by the swiftness of the overturning of his conviction and was unprepared for life on the outside.

With no support from any official agencies, Mr Kamara, from Toxteth, Liverpool, was bundled into a taxi to the north London home of Paddy Hill, one of the Birmingham Six.

Over the years since his release, Mr Hill has taken in a number of victims of miscarriages of justice because they had nowhere else to go. Only too aware of the problems his fellow "miscarriages" face, his is often an open door.

Today marks the 10th anniversary of the release of Mr Hill and the other members of the Birmingham Six. It also sees the official launch of the Miscarriages of Justice Organisation (Mojo) at the House of Commons. Founded by Mr Hill, Mojo will campaign for some kind of aftercare for people like Mr Kamara who are left on their own, in spite of years of institutionalisation.

"Innocent people are being dumped out of the court of appeal like sacks of garbage, all suffering from severe post-traumatic stress syndrome, without counselling or any psychological help," says the group's literature.

There is little in the way of help for those who have been victims of miscarriages of justice and are then sucked up by the potential vacuum that is life outside. In 1998 the home secretary, Jack Straw, rejected a call from Chris Mullin, the former chairman of the home affairs select committee, for special measures to assist in the care of released miscarriage of justice victims.

Many who have worked with victims have observed that they are profoundly scarred by their experiences and have difficulty in coping with life on the outside.

Adrian Grounds, a psychiatrist at the institute of criminology at Cambridge, examined Gerry Conlon of the Guildford Four and four members of the Birmingham Six and found that they were suffering from irreversible, persistent and disabling post-traumatic stress syndrome. He compared their mental state with that of brain damaged accident victims or people who had suffered war crimes.

Gareth Peirce, the solicitor who represented the Guildford Four and Birmingham Six defendants, said: "They come out with no money and no counselling. They have no references, it is difficult to open a bank account, you can't get a mortgage. They have no GP. You don't belong."

Judith Ward, wrongly convicted of the M62 coach bombing, was refused a £5,000 bank loan while she waited for an interim compensation payment and Michael Hickey, one of the freed Bridgewater Three, told a court he had stolen a ring from a Birmingham jewellers to highlight his case. He said: "I did it to say I've been given no money, nowhere to live, what am I supposed to do?"

Mr Hill has been travelling across the country, garnering support for his fledgling group. He said: "Compare what is available for innocent people as compared to guilty people and see what is done for them. When someone makes a decision for a guilty person to be released there is a chain of processes put in place which lasts for about three years. They take them out for a few hours at the weekend. Over a period of a few months those few hours gradually increase. Then they will be out all day and come back at night. They teach them all about modern technology. They are rehabilitated into the system. When they are released they have a place to live, probation services, aftercare services, all sorts of helplines.

"The innocent. One day your ass is sitting in a prison cell and the next day you are in the court of appeal. You are thrown out on the street like a sack of garbage and forgotten about. It's mind boggling coming out. Even in the queue for the supermarket you get wound up with all the computer stuff and credit cards."

Mr Hill said many either become alcoholic or addicted to drugs as a way of blocking severe psychological problems. For most, it is difficult to even sign on with a doctor because they have no paperwork.

Another "miscarriage" to take temporary residence at Mr Hill's home was Paddy Nicholls, who had been in prison for 23 years after being wrongfully convicted of murdering a friend. He was almost 70 when he was released in 1998.

"Paddy had had a stroke at Christmas and was released on bail in the February. They just threw him out. That's a man who was 70 years of age and could hardly walk. They threw him out at the gates of Albany prison. I had to go and pick him up. He had no medication, nothing, and on the way out they even took the tennis ball that they give to stroke victims off him," Mr Hill said.

A year after his release, Mr Kamara still struggles to negotiate this world, though he has found himself a fiancée and a place to live. Mr Kamara had been convicted of the murder of a betting shop manager in Liverpool but it later emerged that the prosecution failed to disclose 201 witness statements taken by Merseyside police to the defence lawyers at the original trial.

Mr Kamara said: "One minute I was sitting with a life sentence and the next minute I was free to go, but go where? I was given a travel warrant to Liverpool that expired at 8pm. I had no money for six to seven weeks. I had no legal documentation, no identity, you are a non person. The DSS granted me an emergency loan of £5 which I had to pay back within 28 days. I told them to keep it.

"The housing manager said because I was a miscarriage of justice why didn't I get a loan and buy myself a property because, he said 'you are going to get massive compensation'. That's how bad it is. Sometimes I thought 'fucking hell, it looks like I'll have to get arrested to get probation'. They seem to push you. They want you to commit a crime."

Six waiting for redress

The Birmingham Six were arrested after the bombing of the Mulberry Bush bar in the city on 1974, in which 21 died. All six were released in 1991 after the case against them was overturned. They had served 16 years:

 Paddy Hill

Founder of Miscarriages of Justice organisation. Lives in north London, has difficulty coping with everyday life

 Billy Power

Lives in east London with wife Nora. Works at homeless hostel. Struggles with everyday life and has had problems bonding with his children

 John Walker

Remarried with a young son, Marty. Living on pension in Co Donegal

 Gerry Hunter

Living in south London

 Richard McIlkenny

Reunited with wife Kathleen and living in Dublin

 Hugh Callaghan

Living in north London

All six await final compensation settlement

Gareth Peirce, the solicitor who represented the Guildford Four and Birmingham Six defendants, said: "They come out with no money and no counselling. They have no references, it is difficult to open a bank account, you can't get a mortgage. They have no GP. You don't belong." Judith Ward, wrongly convicted of the M62 coach bombing, was refused a £5,000 bank loan while she waited for an interim compensation payment and Michael Hickey, one of the freed Bridgewater Three, told a court he had stolen a ring from a Birmingham jewellers to highlight his case. He said: "I did it to say I've been given no money, nowhere to live, what am I supposed to do?" Mr Hill has been travelling across the country, garnering support for his fledgling group. He said: "Compare what is available for innocent people as compared to guilty people and see what is done for them. When someone makes a decision for a guilty person to be released there is a chain of processes put in place which lasts for about three years. They take them out for a few hours at the weekend. Over a period of a few months those few hours gradually increase. Then they will be out all day and come back at night. They teach them all about modern technology. They are rehabilitated into the system. When they are released they have a place to live, probation services, aftercare services, all sorts of helplines. "The innocent. One day your ass is sitting in a prison cell and the next day you are in the court of appeal. You are thrown out on the street like a sack of garbage and forgotten about. It's mind boggling coming out. Even in the queue for the supermarket you get wound up with all the computer stuff and credit cards." Mr Hill said many either become alcoholic or addicted to drugs as a way of blocking severe psychological problems. For most, it is difficult to even sign on with a doctor because they have no paperwork. Another "miscarriage" to take temporary residence at Mr Hill's home was Paddy Nicholls, who had been in prison for 23 years after being wrongfully convicted of murdering a friend. He was almost 70 when he was released in 1998. "Paddy had had a stroke at Christmas and was released on bail in the February. They just threw him out. That's a man who was 70 years of age and could hardly walk. They threw him out at the gates of Albany prison. I had to go and pick him up. He had no medication, nothing, and on the way out they even took the tennis ball that they give to stroke victims off him," Mr Hill said. A year after his release, Mr Kamara still struggles to negotiate this world, though he has found himself a fiancée and a place to live. Mr Kamara had been convicted of the murder of a betting shop manager in Liverpool but it later emerged that the prosecution failed to disclose 201 witness statements taken by Merseyside police to the defence lawyers at the original trial. Mr Kamara said: "One minute I was sitting with a life sentence and the next minute I was free to go, but go where? I was given a travel warrant to Liverpool that expired at 8pm. I had no money for six to seven weeks. I had no legal documentation, no identity, you are a non person. The DSS granted me an emergency loan of £5 which I had to pay back within 28 days. I told them to keep it. "The housing manager said because I was a miscarriage of justice why didn't I get a loan and buy myself a property because, he said 'you are going to get massive compensation'. That's how bad it is. Sometimes I thought 'fucking hell, it looks like I'll have to get arrested to get probation'. They seem to push you. They want you to commit a crime." Six waiting for redress The Birmingham Six were arrested after the bombing of the Mulberry Bush bar in the city on 1974, in which 21 died. All six were released in 1991 after the case against them was overturned. They had served 16 years:  Paddy Hill Founder of Miscarriages of Justice organisation. Lives in north London, has difficulty coping with everyday life  Billy Power Lives in east London with wife Nora. Works at homeless hostel. Struggles with everyday life and has had problems bonding with his children  John Walker Remarried with a young son, Marty. Living on pension in Co Donegal  Gerry Hunter Living in south London  Richard McIlkenny Reunited with wife Kathleen and living in Dublin  Hugh Callaghan Living in north London All six await final compensation settlement

fields.headline: Payout blow to asbestos victims
fields.trailText: Lawyers acting for thousands of asbestos victims have demanded government intervention after it emerged that many sufferers are to get only 5% of the compensation due.
fields.body:
Lawyers acting for thousands of asbestos victims have demanded government intervention after it emerged that many sufferers are to get only 5% of the compensation due.

The scandal follows the collapse of the insurance firm Chester Street Insurance Holdings Ltd, which faced multi-million pound payouts to industrial workers across the UK. It called in provisional liquidators in January, claiming it would be unable to meet claims from asbestos sufferers.

Deaths from asbestos related disease can take 20 to 50 years, and thousands of workers have won cases against employers for exposure to the dust. In Scotland alone an estimated 5,000 shipyard workers will die in the next 10 years.

The liquidators, PricewaterhouseCoopers, confirmed yesterday that a deal agreed with creditors meant that initial payments would be 5% of claims awarded. The scheme administrator, Dan Schwarzmann, said: "My job is to get as much money out as quickly as possible. We hope we can look to increase the payment percentage in later years."

Lawyers for victims say many will end up with nothing, once the costs of claiming compensation have been met.

Ian McFall of Thompsons solicitors said the news had been devastating. The firm is handling 2,700 asbestos related claims, two thirds against Chester Street. Workers exposed to the dust after 1972 have some protection through the Policyholders Protection Board, but many were exposed before that year, and the employers no longer exist.

"These are men who are terminally ill, who believed they would receive compensation that might give their families security," said Mr McFall.

Albert Bell, 58, who worked in Tyneside shipyards, found out in December that he had mesothelioma, a form of asbestos poisoning, and lodged a claim for compensation.

He said yesterday: "The government should step in like they did with the miners and sort this out. That was the only cover for my family."

fields.body:
In early editions of March 10 the bridge column on page 11, Sport, was accompanied by four hands of cards - one of which (the south) was wrong. Anyone wanting to re-read Zia Mahmood's column with four correct hands can do so by requesting a fax or postal copy from the office of the readers' editor, as below.

Under changes that took effect on January 11 to the Protection of Children Act, the maximum prison term was raised to five years for possession of child photos and images deemed indecent, and to 10 years for distributing them. A story about the Saatchi Gallery controversy yesterday on page 9 listed the previous, lesser, penalties.

A standfirst to a story about barristers, page 3, March 8, said: "Lawyers rile at report claiming they break trading rules." This report clearly riled some lawyers - but our construction should have read, "Lawyers rail at report".

A story revisiting the dispute over Florida's vote in last year's US presidential election said (page 13, March 12): "A comprehensive new survey of 'undervotes' in Palm Beach county shows that Al Gore would have gained 784 more votes than George Bush if every excluded ballot paper bearing a mark next to a candidate's name had been counted by officials." But a reference to the "butterfly ballots" that confused voters was inserted in the editing process - erroneous because these ballots overwhelmingly produced "overvotes", where more than one mark was recorded on the ballot paper.

A Chechnya story on page 15 yesterday referring to the 1998 kidnapping of three British telecommunications engineers was edited to shorten one word to telecom, which might have given the impression that the men worked for BT. They worked for Granger Telecom.

DD Guttenplan's new book - about the Holocaust related lawsuit launched against Deborah Lipstadt by David Irving - is published by Granta this month rather than in May, as we said at the end of the G2 cover story on March 12. The order details are as given, however.

The fictitious area around the non-existent river Tee has once again insinuated itself into the paper as Teeside (page 9, March 12, Mandelson muscles in on debate over north-south divide). The area is Teesside.

In a story headed Straight man Sanchez has the last laugh, page 2, Sport, March 12, Wimbledon was moved to London SE19 from its usual location in SW19 .

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Fight to save press archives
fields.body:
Fight to save press archives

A campaign to stop the British Library throwing out thousands of historic foreign newspapers was launched yesterday by US novelist Nicholson Baker.

The library has already disposed of 60,000 volumes of papers from its Colindale repository in north London. These include German papers covering Hitler's rise to power, and pre-revolutionary Russian papers.

Riding blind to beat the record

Blind bank worker Mike Newman, 39, of Sale, Greater Manchester, is preparing for 100mph to break the world record for blind motorcycling - despite getting on a bike for the first time last week.

He will race down an old RAF airstrip at Alvington Park, North Yorkshire, to raise money for Guide Dogs for the Blind.

Cleaning crew wins again

A group of cleaners have beaten odds of 1.6bn to one to scoop a big prize on the lottery for a second time and collect a cheque for almost £64,000. The 10 women and two men from Easingwold school, North Yorkshire, matched five numbers and the bonus ball on March 7 to claim £63,870. They also won £181,898 in June 1998.

'Dangerous' man escapes

The Metropolitan police last night warned the public to be on the alert after a prisoner escaped from a secure unit at the Central Middlesex hospital.

Ben Bonnard, 47, on remand from Brent magistrates court for alleged harassment of a woman, is a "danger to himself and others". Police said he needed psychiatric treatment.

Victoria Wood recovering

Comedienne Victoria Wood, 47, is recovering following an emergency operation in a north London hospital for a fibroid growth in her womb, her publicist said yesterday.

fields.headline: Payout to jailed asylum seekers
fields.standfirst:
£80,000 award could lead to avalanche of claims

Special report: refugees in Britain
fields.trailText: Two asylum seekers who each spent three months in prison after being convicted of travelling on forged passports have been awarded a total of £80,000, in the first of a rash of claims which could cost the government millions.
fields.body:
Two asylum seekers who each spent three months in prison after being convicted of travelling on forged passports have been awarded a total of £80,000, in the first of a rash of claims which could cost the government millions.

The Home Office faces a barrage of compensation claims after the high court ruled in 1999 that prosecutions of asylum seekers for using false papers breached Britain's obligations under the 1951 Geneva convention on the status of refugees.

The court delivered a strong rebuke at the time to the home secretary, Jack Straw, and the crown prosecution service. Lord Justice Simon Brown said no one in the criminal justice system had given "the least thought" to article 31 of the convention, which states that asylum seekers should not be penalised for entering a country illegally.

As a result, he said, many were in prison who should not be there. The married couple, who each received £40,000, have asked not to be identified. The husband, 29, and the wife, 22, left Albania just before Christmas in 1998 intending to travel via Heathrow to Canada.

They were stopped, like most of those prosecuted, by airline passport checkers rather than immigration officials, and turned over to the police.

They were taken to court the next day and advised to plead guilty by a duty solicitor because they had no defence to the charge. They were convicted and sentenced to six months in prison, of which they served three.

Their solicitor, Fiona Lindsley, from the London law firm Birnberg Peirce & partners, said the couple were "overwhelmed and delighted" by their award. The payment will come from the Home Office ex gratia compensation scheme, which pays out in cases of serious default, and in miscarriage of justice cases where the accused person has been completely exonerated.

Ms Lindsley said her claim on the husband's behalf had emphasised the horrors of Wormwood Scrubs prison in west London, where he served his sentence, drawing on official reports. The wife spent her term at Holloway prison in north London.

The couple have since been accepted as genuine refugees and granted permission to stay in Britain indefinitely.

Ms Lindsley said she was dealing with around 10 cases, some involving compensation worth considerably more because there was evidence of severe trauma. In one case, an asylum seeker from Iran had pictures to show he was sent to prison with still unhealed sores from whipping.

Lawyers had expected an award of £10,000 for a typical case. Between 500 and 1,000 are thought to have been prosecuted each year between 1994, when prosecutions were stepped up, and the judgment in 1999. Most sentences were for six months, some were nine months, and a few 12 months.

Ms Lindsley said Amnesty International argued in a 1996 report that the prosecutions breached the convention.

fields.headline: A yen for recovery
fields.standfirst:
A decade of economic mismanagement has led Japan to the brink of collapse. Will the prime minister's resignation make any difference?

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: A decade of economic mismanagement has led Japan to the brink of collapse. Will the prime minister's resignation make any difference?
fields.body:
In the middle of the 19th century Karl Marx used Great Britain as his case study for all that was wrong with capitalism as an economic system. Nothing that policy makers could do would stop the system lurching from expansion to depression. Today Marx might use a different example. Japan, the world's second biggest economy after the United States, is stuck in the doldrums. Its hapless policy makers have tried everything they can think of to turn the situation round, but nothing has worked.

Japan has been lurching in and out of economic and political crisis for most of the last 10 years, ever since the property bubble of the late 1980s burst, leaving the country mired in debt. This week's "resignation" by Prime Minister Yoshiro Mori (he said he was standing down as president of the Liberal Democratic party, the LDP, which in Japanese terms means the premiership), is only the latest instalment - and the names being put forward as contenders for the succession do not signal much change.

Finance ministers usually speak in a kind of code where unpalatable truths are disguised in soothing language so as not to frighten the markets, but Kiichi Miyazawa has now put on record that Japanese finances are in a catastrophic state. It is not the kind of language to assure investors.

It is not just public finances that are in deep trouble: Japan's entire economy is in a mess. The stock market is at a 16-year low, the yen is making even the sickly euro look like a star performer on the currency markets, and the financial system is virtually bankrupt.

The problem is intellectual bankruptcy among Japanese policy makers. The LDP's response to the stagnation of the economy has been to throw money at it. Since 1990, the government has unveiled 13 separate packages of new public works, bridges and roads, often leading to places nobody wanted to go. After each stimulus package the economy briefly revived, before relapsing again.

Trying to revive the economy with huge amounts of spending has left public finances in tatters. The chart shows how Japan's national debt has grown: it is now equivalent to 130% of its annual output or GDP - the highest ratio among the major economies. The annual budget shortfall - the gap between revenues and spending - is now nearly 10% of output, the largest deficit on record in the post-1945 era. Mr Miyazawa's admission that Japan's fiscal position is unsustainable is merely repeating what every international organisation, from the International Monetary Fund to the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development have been saying for years.

Eventually the Japanese government will have to repay its creditors, which will require either higher taxes or spending cuts. But adding to the fiscal pressures is Japan's demography. The population is ageing, fast.

Tokyo seems to have realised that fiscal policy has reached the end of its useful life in tackling Japan's problems. But monetary policy has proved to be a useless weapon as well. Interest rates have been close to zero for most of the 90s, except for a brief period last summer when the Bank of Japan raised rates by half a percentage point and succeeded in killing off a nascent recovery.

Japan faces a classic Keynesian "liquidity trap" - it cannot cut borrowing costs further because interest rates cannot go below zero. JM Keynes observed that in situations such as this, monetary policy is about as useful as pushing on a piece of string, He advocated using fiscal stimulus when monetary policy becomes ineffective, but this is a road that Japan has been down and discovered it too is a dead end.

So what now? Last Friday Tokyo unveiled its latest solution - a package of measures designed to eliminate bad debts from the banking system and to encourage small investors back into the stockmarket. A government-backed bank will takeover ailing financial institutions, assess their assets and provide enough money to recapitalise them.

Solving the banking crisis would help restore some credibility to the Japanese financial system, but it is not the silver bullet that is going to solve the economic crisis. Paul Krugman, the American economist, believes the only way out is for the Bank of Japan to start printing money to reflate the economy. Japan may need inflation as the only way of reducing real interest rates. It would also encourage consumers to spend; at the moment, because prices are always falling, Japan's shoppers are discouraged from buying.

Paul Krugman does not believe that the banking package will do much to revive the economy. He says the central problem is still that consumers and corporations are saving too much and borrowing too little, not usually a symptom of a bad banking system which tends to overlend rather than underlend. Are such attitudes "culture", over which the rational tools of economic policy makers have no leverage?

Anyway, printing money appears to be too unpalatable a remedy for either the government or the Bank of Japan to swallow. But with the prime minister's resignation under way, the head of the central bank's can be expected to follow shortly. Now the question is whether the political system is capable of throwing up a new leader with the imagination and nerve to adopt the desperate measures necessary. The precedents are dismaying.

Charlotte Denny is the Guardian's economics reporter and Larry Elliott economics editor

webTitle: Pass notes No 1838: The Canonesses of the Holy Sepulchre

fields.headline: Pass notes No 1838
fields.standfirst: The Canonesses of the Holy Sepulchre
fields.trailText: The Canonesses of the Holy Sepulchre.
fields.body:
What are they then? They're nuns, special singing nuns.

Oh yes, I've heard of them before. In fact, I hired one for my mate's stag night. That's a different sort of nun. These keep their wimples on.

That doesn't sound very rock'n'roll. Bet they've no drug habits either. Nun that I know of.

Oh please. Anyway, the Canonesses have just released a charity CD entitled Eternal Light: Music of Inner Peace.

Sort of a follow-up to The Bangles' smash hit Eternal Flame? Well, yes, only with a bit more about Jesus.

Of course. And where do the sisters hail from? New Hall at the Priory of the Resurrection, in Chelmsford, Essex.

fields.headline: Minister quits amid corruption scandal
fields.trailText: India's defence minister, George Fernandes, last night offered to resign after a website published an investigation that appeared to show senior political figures involved in defence procurement accepting large bribes.
fields.body:
India's defence minister, George Fernandes, last night offered to resign after a website published an investigation that appeared to show senior political figures involved in defence procurement accepting large bribes.

The report also prompted the resignation of the president of the ruling Bharatiya Janata party. It comes 11 days after allegations of insider trading were levelled at the Bombay stock exchanges's former president, Anand Rathi. He is accused of passing market sensitive information to other brokers.

Mr Rathi, who denies any impropriety, resigned last week saying he wanted to "maintain the dignity of his office". Since the scandal came to light the stock market has dropped by more than 12%.

The finance minister, Yashwant Sinha, yesterday proposed measures to strengthen the power of the market's regulator and improve confidence. He said that the government would ensure that the markets "operate in a fair and transparent manner".

Ever since he presented a reforming budget last month, India's stock market has been afflicted by global stock market falls and fears of a payment crisis at home.

fields.headline: America slides down Tokyo road
fields.standfirst:
The US heading for Japan-style chronic deflation? One economic visionary predicts just that

Special report: George Bush's America
Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: The US heading for Japan-style chronic deflation? One economic visionary predicts just that.
fields.body:
In normal circumstances, a warning from the new president of Harvard that America today looks suspiciously like Japan 10 years ago would barely be worthy of mention. Academics often say controversial things just to be noticed.

These are not normal times, with Wall Street gripped by a severe bear market and yesterday's darlings - the dot.coms - going bust in droves. This was no ordinary president of Harvard, either, but Larry Summers, who until the middle of January was treasury secretary of the United States and rated as one of the most brilliant economists of his generation.

Mr Summers has thought a lot about Japan, regularly lecturing hapless Japanese officials at international gatherings about their failure to take the measures necessary to restore health to Asia's first and most successful tiger economy. Now he is out of political office he can afford to posit a frightening scenario: that America could become the new Japan.

Speculative bubbles

On the face of it, this seems laughable. The US economy is still growing, albeit at a slower pace, after its longest period of expansion since records began in the 1850s. Unemployment is historically low and American companies are world leaders in the new technologies. The same could have been said of Japan at the end of the 1980s, when the country was enjoying full employment, had been growing strongly since the end of the second world war and boasted many of the world's biggest companies. For Sony, Toyota and Nissan then, read Microsoft, Intel and Cisco now.

Both saw the emergence of speculative bubbles at a time when inflationary pressure was weak. Even when the Nikkei-Dow was racing towards 40,000 and land prices in Tokyo were going through the roof, inflation was only rising at about 3% a year, similar to the US over the past year. This was unusual in the post-war period, when developed countries became accustomed to relatively high inflation, but a regular feature of economic life in the 19th century when there were clearly defined business cycles driven by the interplay of technical advance, profitability and speculation. Mr Summers has suggested that the US, like Japan, could be returning to an older type of economic cycle.

During the Victorian era, when labour was relatively weak, the cycle would kick off with rising demand which fed through into higher profits. The increase in profits would stimulate higher investment and higher productivity, driving down unit costs, keeping inflation under control. This was the benign phase of the cycle, seen in Japan in the mid-1980s and the US in the mid-90s. Then the problems began.

Attracted by the lure of high profits and confident that the good times would last for ever, investors would finance enterprises with no chance of making a decent return. At some point, invariably far too late, reality set in. The speculative bubble was pricked and much of the unprofitable investment was scrapped as the economy went into recession. Fearful of the future, consumers saved more and spent less, pushing prices lower.

This is where things went seriously wrong for Japan. Policymakers were slow to recognise that the fall in the Nikkei was both permanent and serious, and initially tightened policy rather than easing it. This blunder of enormous proportions turned low inflation into outright deflation - a period of falling prices.

Japan's policymakers found that deflation, once entrenched, was hard to cure. The normal remedy for boosting growth - cheaper borrowing - is much less effective when prices are falling because it is impossible to make real interest rates low enough. Instead, Japan was forced to fall back on fiscal policy, injecting larger and larger doses of public spending into the economy in an attempt to boost demand. This had a limited success and the effects are now wearing off.

Could the US follow this pattern? There is no reason why not, particularly if policymakers are slow to wake up to the risks. Even if they respond quickly, there is trouble ahead. One feature of the stock market boom of the late 90s was that Americans used speculation as a substitute for saving. As times take a turn for the worse, the fear is that they will start to save more, adding to the squeeze on corporate earnings and profits. Even economists who believe the US is going through a "phoney" recession, with the real downturn yet to come, say it will take more than a few months of retrenchment to work off the wild excesses of the past few years.

'Crashing share prices'

Charles Dumas, at Lombard Street Research, says that even after the 60% drop in the Nasdaq in the past year the bear market has further to go. "At any stage, crashing share prices could precipitate either a sharp upswing of consumer savings or serious financial trouble in over-leveraged America - or both."

For the time being, there are good reasons for thinking that America will not be faced with a Japan-like slump. First, the likelihood is that policy will be loosened far more quickly than it was in Japan. America is still mentally scarred by the Great Depression of the 1930s; so much so that policymakers are quick to act whenever there are signs of a recession. Fed chairman Alan Greenspan has already cut rates twice this year and will undoubtedly cut them again next week. The daily dripfeed of economic bad news means George Bush is already finding it much easier to sell his package of tax cuts to Congress and the country at large.

Second, the severity of the Japanese bust was exacerbated by the slump in land prices, which is still not over. Property was used as collateral for loans, with the result that Japan's financial sector is sitting on mountain of bad debts.

Third, America's hire and fire culture will ensure that the corporate sector takes the measures necessary to restore profitability more rapidly than under Japan's consensual structure. Lay-offs by Motorola and Cisco are evidence that this process is already under way.

Some titans of industry lionised for their wisdom during the market's bull phase will find the headlines less to their liking on the way down. Mr Greenspan, too, has his reputation on the line. He will be high on the list of possible scapegoats if the US really does catch a whiff of the Japanese disease.

fields.headline: At this price? Taylor Woodrow
fields.trailText: It is strange to remember the sense of drift around Taylor Woodrow 12 months ago, when the shares had been driven down to 110p - almost half the level they are today.
fields.body:
It is strange to remember the sense of drift around Taylor Woodrow 12 months ago, when the shares had been driven down to 110p - almost half the level they are today.

Much has happened over the last year to convince the investment community that the construction firm has rebuilt its sense of purpose, not least by snapping up rival Bryant. But Taylor Woodrow has also taken firm action on the construction side, shutting down unprofitable operations and cutting costs.

Taylor Woodrow reported strong annual results, with profit before tax up 64% to £201.5m from £122.6m last time on sales static at £1.5bn. Earnings per share adjusted for the sale of businesses rose 17% to 24.3p and the dividend has been increased 12.3% to 6.12p. Return on capital employed rose a healthy three percentage points to 18%.

UK housing performed strongly, raising its operating profits by 35% to £43.6m with international housing not far behind. Operating profits there rose 32% to £113.6m.

Construction sales fell by a hefty 27% due to the downsizing, and operating profits plummeted from £2.8m to £1.1m. But this was in line with expectations. US operations performed well over the 12 months to 31 December but are starting to be affected by the economic slowdown.

The chief executive, Keith Egerton, is confident that his business will not be badly hit - pointing out that in crucial areas for the company, such as Florida, Taylor Woodrow is involved in land development rather than housing construction.

Back in Britain, the situation seems positive and the Bryant merger will provide the promised £15m of savings a year. Larger players could also benefit most from government pressure to develop more brownfield sites.

The company's shares shed 3p in early trading due to profit-taking, but ended the day down 3.5p at 201p.

Taylor Woodrow is building itself a sturdy future but that is adequately reflected in the price at present. Hold.

fields.headline: Pru wins few converts
fields.trailText: Prudential's record-breaking "merger" with American General kept the tongues wagging yesterday as the insurer's shares remained weak, gaining just 6p to 778p, barely recoving any of their 14% slide after the £30bn deal was announced on Monday.
fields.body:
Prudential's record-breaking "merger" with American General kept the tongues wagging yesterday as the insurer's shares remained weak, gaining just 6p to 778p, barely recoving any of their 14% slide after the £30bn deal was announced on Monday.

With Pru's shares so close to their two-year lows, some predicted that a rival might be tempted to swoop on the company, despite the £200m compensation needed to pay American General if it is left partner-less.

Some even wondered whether Pru had rushed into the deal because it needed the additional bulk to deter an unwanted suitor already detected.

Others looked for problems in its existing US business, Jackson Life, to explain the high price offered for American General.

Yet brokers at Deutsche Bank said longer-term merits of the deal made the shares a buy.

webTitle: Racing: Cheltenham to name new Festival date

fields.headline: Cheltenham to name new Festival date
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Cheltenham are confident that they will be in a position today to make a decision regarding the rescheduled Festival meeting, which should have started yesterday.
fields.body:
Cheltenham are confident that they will be in a position today to make a decision regarding the rescheduled Festival meeting, which should have started yesterday.

The choice for the three-day gathering rests between April 17-19 or April 24-26. However, the preferred option for the last week in April would precipitate a direct clash with Punchestown if the Irish government allows that meeting to go ahead.

The other three-day slot brings with it its own set of logistical complications as it comes in Easter week and pits Cheltenham against the Craven meeting at Newmarket.

Edward Gillespie, the managing director at Cheltenham, said yesterday: "The whole thing keeps swinging one way and then the other.

"There have been three outbreaks in Gloucestershire, but a suspected outbreak in Northern Ireland has not been confirmed. At one time it looked like we would be in a position to make an announcement tonight, but now it will probably be tomorrow.

"As it stands, there will be a Festival on one of those two weeks. We intend to have all the 20 races.

"The idea of perhaps just having the Champion Hurdle and Gold Cup was something that would have only been considered a long way down the line. I would say that as long as Cheltenham doesn't fall within an exclusion zone or racing is completely banned there will be a Festival this year."

There might be a Festival, but there will not be much of an ante-post market after the decision of the major bookmakers to refund all ante-post bets on the Cheltenham Festival was given the approval of the Tattersalls Committee.

There had been criticism of the decision in some quarters as the races concerned could still be staged at a postponed Festival next month. However, the organisation agreed that all such bets should be void as the races have been reopened.

A statement from the Tattersalls Committee said: "Tattersalls Committee announce that all ante-post bets for the cancelled Cheltenham meeting are void as covered by their existing Rule 4A (3). The rule voids such bets if the 'conditions' of the race entry are changed prior to the horses coming under starter's orders."

Racing is still a long way from coming under starter's orders as regularly as usual and now one of the additional fixtures, scheduled to make up for the shortfall, has also been cancelled.

Officials at Ayr have announced that their additional meeting on Monday has been abandoned.

Chris Kennedy, Ayr's marketing manager, said: "In view of the foot and mouth outbreak, the committee has taken the decision not to race."

Saturday's Winter Derby meeting at Lingfield, and the day's other programme at Market Rasen, are still on track.

fields.headline: Railtrack adds to points failures
fields.trailText: There was a smell of fear in the City yesterday. Nowhere more so than from the beleaguered investors in Railtrack whose shares fell by 68.5p to 779p on new anxieties about the company's financial stability.
fields.body:
There was a smell of fear in the City yesterday. Nowhere more so than from the beleaguered investors in Railtrack whose shares fell by 68.5p to 779p on new anxieties about the company's financial stability.

Though its public relations image could hardly be worse, the owner of the rail infrastructure added to its woes by admitting that it was asking the government for more cash handouts.

Railtrack was far from alone in wallowing in misery. Its troubles came on a day when the London market closed at its lowest level for more than two years: 5,720, down 105 points.

Anxieties about the health of the so-called global economy, essentially Japan and the US, were once again the root of the problem. More difficulties in the hi-tech sector merely exacerbated the anxiety.

Cable & Wireless stunned the City with a profits warning which left the one-time telecoms darling down a hefty 138p at 545p, a record low. The financial services authority, the City regulator, is said to be looking into the circumstances surrounding the statement.

British Telecom, the rival which faces an uncomfortable meeting with fed-up investors next week, was able to register a 1.5p gain on the day to end at 535p despite widespread expectations that a £5bn rights issue is imminent.

Among the big players in the FTSE, BP and Shell did little to help the index's plight, both falling by around 3% to 571.5p and 561p respectively.

Shire Pharmaceuticals was down 9p at £11.30 leaving arbitrageurs on both sides of the Atlantic a little less green about the gills than they might have been after a warning from the drugs company that its £2.7bn merger with Canada's BioChem might be delayed.

Competition regulators in Canada have asked for more time to consider the deal, which could delay matters up to a month beyond the scheduled completion on March 30.

At one point Shire's shares were ahead despite heavy falls across the drugs sector. This was due to a hurried readjustment of positions by scores of hedge funds which have been trying to make money at the margins of the all-share transaction.

The arbitrage artists, who have positions in BioChem, have been trying to keep Shire's shares down for a 15-day pricing period prior to completion. If they are successful, Shire will have to offer more shares for BioChem. The delay knocked their calculations out of kilter, triggering a rapid unwinding of short positions on the Hampshire-based company.

The delay is a byproduct of administrative problems within Canada's industry ministry after a recent change in the law, and is unlikely to have any effect on the logic of the merger.

Having largely escaped the effects of the technology sell-off in recent months, drugs and biotechnology shares finally came in for a hammering yesterday.

Julie Simmonds of Beeson Gregory said: "Until now things had been holding up very, very well. There hasn't been any bad news, although there also hasn't been much good news to drive the sector forward - everyone's terrified of putting out anything and drawing attention to themselves."

fields.headline: Defendants offered state lawyers
fields.trailText: Residents of Liverpool, Middlesbrough, Birmingham and Swansea who are charged with a criminal offence will be able to choose to be defended by a new US-style public defender from next May.
fields.body:
Residents of Liverpool, Middlesbrough, Birmingham and Swansea who are charged with a criminal offence will be able to choose to be defended by a new US-style public defender from next May.

The Lord Chancellor's Department will be piloting over four years the controversial new system, initially in four areas, with another two to follow.

For the first time in England and Wales, cases will be prosecuted and defended by state lawyers. A similar scheme in Scotland is halfway through a five year pilot.

In England and Wales, solicitors on the staff of the new public defender service will act as duty lawyers advising suspects in police stations, representing them in magistrates court and organising their defence in the crown court.

The public defenders will have to compete for clients with the private practice law firms. The parent body, the legal services commission, is considering local advertising to boost the public defenders' profile and attract clients.

The idea of state employed defence lawyers was strenuously opposed by the bar, which argued that a state defence service would be starved of funds, as the crown prosecution service was at its start, and unable to attract the best lawyers.

Critics argue that having state lawyers on both sides could lead to cosy carve-ups between prosecution and defence. They cite public defender systems in some parts of the US which are underfunded, swamped with cases and seen as delivering a third-rate service. But in other parts of the US and in Canada, public defender services work well.

Solicitors are also suspicious of the service, fearing it will take away their clients and seduce their staff by paying higher salaries.

Lord Bach, the minister responsible for criminal justice, and Steve Orchard, the chief executive of the legal services commission, promised yesterday that public defenders would not suffer the same work overloads and shortage of resources which have plagued the crown prosecution service.

fields.headline: City diary
fields.trailText: Ever wonder why BT's top management - Peter Bonfield "of the Vanities" and Sir Iain Vallance - have more and more people calling for their collective heads to roll? BT's corporate performance has been woeful over recent months, and a couple of vignettes illustrate just what a desperate company the former monopolist has become.
fields.body:
 Ever wonder why BT's top management - Peter Bonfield "of the Vanities" and Sir Iain Vallance - have more and more people calling for their collective heads to roll? BT's corporate performance has been woeful over recent months, and a couple of vignettes illustrate just what a desperate company the former monopolist has become. Item one is the news that BT charges police up to £150 every time the Old Bill asks to see a subscriber's bill or other details (such as name and address) as a part of criminal investigation. Other telecoms operators, such as NTL, give their assistance free, according to Silicon.com. Item two comes from the Samaritans, which has cancelled its contract with BT because the network's technology could not cope with the weight of calls to the Samaritans' helpline. About 20% of callers were getting an engaged tone - not a happy situation. So the charity has decided to sign up with Cable & Wireless.

 There was speculation by analysts earlier this week that if Bonfield and Vallance were sacked/fell on their swords, BT's share price would zip up by £1 apiece. If that is right then it adds up to something like £6.5bn of shareholder value locked up there. Hmmm.

 Expect a warm welcome at Harvard University for the world's slimmest economist, Larry Summers - the man who gave literal meaning to the phrase "larger than life". Out of a job as treasury secretary since Bill Clinton left office, Larry is set to become president of Harvard. But his previous career at the World Bank has come back to haunt him. In 1992 Lardy signed a memo suggesting pollution be exported to the third world, stating: "I think the economic logic behind dumping a load of toxic waste in the lowest-wage country is impeccable and we should face up to that." As a result students and staff at Harvard have protested against the appointment. Larry now describes the infamous memo as an error - "It was a long time ago," he says. But this may not be the last of the Summers' whine.

 There was enough turmoil in the markets yesterday as it was, but poor Morgan Crucible (which makes bodies for black cabs, among other things) caused trouble with its results for last year. A gremlin infected the company's profit figures on the official stock exchange news service: "Line three, Underlying pre-tax profit for 2000, should have read £95.1m and not £5.1m," read the amendment. The shares fell 4% before recovering, presumably because of the error. "I shall find out what happened," growled chief executive Ian Norris - ominously for some poor devil out there.

 From the Nonsense On Stilts Department. A press release limps on to the desk from charity Age Concern: "Funerals - no longer a taboo subject". Um ... were they ever a taboo subject?

 Say what you like about Siemens (and with a name like that, there are plenty of possibilities), but its timing is delicious. Here's a picture of happy Siemens executives (including, in the centre, Dr Heinrich von Pierer, the president and chief executive) taken on Monday on the floor of the New York stock exchange, celebrating the company's listing. That was the same day the market saw its worst one-day fall since 1998. Yesterday, Siemens also announced a nasty profits warning. Thumbs-down all round from the market, I'm afraid.

 Would the gentleman with the northern accent who rang on Monday claiming to be alookalike of Hans Snook (the brains behind Orange mobile phones) please call back. Or send photos.

fields.headline: Risks from DU 'insignificant'
fields.standfirst: Special report: depleted uranium
fields.trailText: The environmental risks from contamination by depleted uranium ammunition used in the war in Kosovo are insignificant, a United Nations report concluded yesterday, but its authors also said that they remained unsure about the long-term health consequences of DU.
fields.body:
The environmental risks from contamination by depleted uranium ammunition used in the war in Kosovo are insignificant, a United Nations report concluded yesterday, but its authors also said that they remained unsure about the long-term health consequences of DU.

The UN Environment Programme's (UNEP) final report on the environmental impact of DU after the Kosovo conflict in 1999 recommended a clean-up of the 112 exposed sites there, which still appears not to have been carried out despite preliminary warnings issued two months ago.

Radioactive and toxic contamination to passers-by was rated as "insignificant to non-existent" following tests based on samples gathered from 11 of the sites last November; this finding, however, did not include the cases in which people had had direct contact with the fragments or ingested the particles.

At five sites, UN inspectors found virtually intact DU penetrators, the bullet-shaped core and tip of the shell, which had survived explosions because of soft soil.

The report also called for an extensive examination of sites in Bosnia, where about three tonnes of DU ordnance used during Nato attacks is thought to have remained untouched for five years, "to reduce scientific uncertainty on the impact of DU on the environment, particularly over time".

"There are still considerable scientific uncertainties, especially related to the safety of groundwater in the long term," Pekka Haavisto, the Finnish head of the investigative team, said.

Samples had established, however, that drinking water was safe so far.

Most of the recent science on the behaviour and dangers of DU has been based on natural uranium, but the scientists from five European radiological laboratories on the team found evidence that pieces of DU were more liable to disperse into the soil and to become soluble.

Mr Haavisto said reported cases of leukaemia and other illnesses among western troops in the region were low and could not be linked directly to DU.

"Then we come to the crucial question: Are there some other sources, other risks, which we don't know about? We know that some of those servicemen have also been to Bosnia-Herzegovina."

While traces of plutonium were found around the sites, it said the amounts were so small that they were less of a hazard than the uranium. There was concern, however, about "huge variations" in plutonium levels in the pieces of munitions.

fields.headline: Regional fallout
fields.standfirst:
When Silicon Valley sneezes

Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: In Silicon Valley, the heart of the hi-tech boom, sales of Porsches are down and only a handful of househunters bid for any one property at a time. In the mid-west, former workers in the US car industry are claiming benefit in ever-increasing numbers.
fields.body:
In Silicon Valley, the heart of the hi-tech boom, sales of Porsches are down and only a handful of househunters bid for any one property at a time. In the mid-west, former workers in the US car industry are claiming benefit in ever-increasing numbers.

The sharp slowdown in the US is hurting those areas that most benefited from the unprecedented expansion, so the states that pushed to attract dot.coms and related manufacturing businesses are now suffering.

Yet the region to feel the most pain to date has been the old rust belt area of the mid-west. Declining sales in the motor and other industries have led to rising unemployment in states such as Michigan, Wisconsin and Illinois. The manufacturing sector, which geared up production to meet the growth expectations of the hi-tech and related sector, was hurt by last year's rising interest rates and has been unable to protect workers from the downturn.

According to government figures, unemployment in Michigan jumped from 3.3%to 4.5% in the year to January. Jobs increased in California and Texas, which provided more hi-tech jobs than any other state, during that period. The unemployment rate in Santa Clara County rose only marginally to 1.6% in January - close to 1949 levels and less than half the national average.

Jim Glassman, senior US economist at JP Morgan Chase, said: "A lot of people working in the tech sector are not exactly unemployable. When a dot.com folds up, they simply go and get a real job." Some of the most recent boom towns are showing signs of rising unemployment and declining revenues, however. Hi-tech corridors in North Carolina and New Mexico, both states which recently attracted start-ups that could not afford the high west coast prices, are suffering badly.

Not that the heartland has avoided pain. In San Francisco, "for rent" signs proliferate and many of the wannabe millionaires have quit. People no longer have to sleep in their cars to avoid paying some of the highest rents in the country.

Kevin Logan of Dresdner Bank in New York says there is evidence that working hours and pay are being cut, rather than jobs. Ian Shepherdson at High Frequency Economics says the outlook is bleak."The pain spread will across the whole of the country within the next six months," he predicts.

webTitle: Identity crisis has Japan in turmoil

fields.headline: Identity crisis has Japan in turmoil
fields.standfirst:
Crisis of faith in party, state and finances rocks country

Special report: Japan
fields.trailText: If it had not been for the protesters, a passer-by might have mistaken the annual conference of the Liberal Democratic party in Tokyo yesterday for a mass funeral.
fields.body:
If it had not been for the protesters, a passer-by might have mistaken the annual conference of the Liberal Democratic party in Tokyo yesterday for a mass funeral.

Coaches and limousines disgorged thousands of mostly elderly men in dark suits who pressed with an air of preoccupation into the Budokan martial arts hall. Their sense of unease, frustration and pessimism was palpable - and understandable.

As elderly grandees and regional delegates slowly filed in, the Nikkei average of the Tokyo stock exchange was plunging to 16-year lows, the yen was weakening to levels not seen since early 1999 and the opposition party was submitting a censure motion in parliament against the prime minister, Yoshiro Mori.

This conference had been billed as the last hurrah for the unloved premier, who signalled his intention to resign last Saturday. But as Japan slipped closer towards economic and political turmoil, many delegates acknowledged that it could also be the swan song for a party that has ruled Japan for all but one of the 46 years since it was formed.

"I think this will be the last convention of the LDP, unless we open up," said Taro Nakayama, a former foreign minister. "We've held on to power for too long. The whole nation is suffering from system fatigue."

The secretary general, Makato Koga, said the party faced the biggest crisis since its foundation in 1955. Other senior politicians said it was past the point of recovery.

"This is not one party, it's a conglomerate that encompasses everything in hell," said Ken Mizota, an MP whose seat is in danger in a July upper house election that the LDP is expected to lose by a landslide. "It would be better if we made a clean split."

The growing sense of self-loathing in the LDP reflects a national crisis of confidence that has built up over the past 10 years of economic stagnation - a period widely referred to as "the lost decade".

In part, that anxiety is the product of globalisation as foreign firms take over domestic giants like Nissan and Yamaichi Securities, while new sounds, images and ideas flood into the country through the internet and satellite channels.

Equally, though, Japan could be described as a victim of its own success. Having spent more than 150 years trying to catch up with the west, the economic bubble of the 1980s suddenly propelled Tokyo to superpower status. When that bubble burst so did the national aspirations.

"Japan simply lost its way," said Ryu Murakami, one of the country's most influential novelists. "We never thought about what we'd do after we achieved our goal."

For a nation that has long put a heavy priority on the need to teach a "way" for everything from bushido (the way of the warrior) to chado (the way of tea), the sudden loss of direction has been traumatic and liberating.

Most of the losers are those who were once closely associated with the LDP. Office workers at large firms, who were once revered as corporate warriors and rewarded with jobs for life, now fret about resutora (restructuring) and falling social prestige.

Unemployment is at a record high of 4.9%, bankruptcies are surging and the suicide rate among middle-aged men is alarming.

A growing number of young graduates are shocking their parents by taking up part-time work that gives them more freedom.

The past few years have seen a rash of scandals surrounding bureaucrats who gave favours in return for trips to hostess bars, surgeons who killed patients by leaving implements inside their bodies, and police who continued with mah-jongg drinking parties rather than respond to urgent calls for assistance.

Confusion and turmoil have been most apparent in education. Amid record levels of violent juvenile crime, teachers are warning of a breakdown in classroom discipline and falling academic standards.

Psychologists say that up to a million teenagers are withdrawing from society, holing up in their rooms where they feel more comfortable relying on their parents and playing with a computer than making friends and fending for themselves.

It has hardly reached the stage of a youth rebellion, but Japan's media was horrified earlier this year when 20-year-olds at regional coming of age ceremonies heckled the speakers (often bigwigs in the local LDP) and set off firecrackers.

In response to such concerns, the LDP has flip-flopped in the past five years between pushing for more individualism and creativity - seen as crucial if Japan is to adapt to fast-moving global trends - and reviving the prewar aim of nurturing social morality and group consciousness - to counter what is often depicted as the pernicious influence of the west.

In most schools, the contrast between the two approaches is strikingly clear in the appearance of sports teams: in baseball - a sport that has long been Japanised to embody the spirit of sacrifice, hard work and team loyalty - the players arealmost militarily regimental, often sporting uniform skinhead haircuts; whereas in football - seen as an international and modern game in which individual skill is emphasised - the players are far more likely to have dyed hair and dreadlocks.

Women have the most to gain from the changes taking place in Japan. Under traditional Confucian values, they were expected to obey their fathers and husbands and in the workplace they were often relegated to the status of "office flowers" whose primary purpose was to be decorative.

In recent years, however, they have put off marriage and children and been more inclined to divorce. As a result, Japan's birth rate has plunged to 1.34 for each woman, one of the lowest levels in the world. The gerontocracy of the LDP has been slow to realise that women's bargaining power has increased sharply because Japan needs them to make up the gap in the workforce and to have more children.

Women voters, however, have noted the change. "I used to think that politics was something best left to men, but now I increasingly find myself listening to women politicians and thinking they seem much more honest and capable," said Yuko Abe.

With Mori's ratings at 6% and the LDP barely above 20%, young members and those from urban constituencies know the party must change to survive.

But like Japan after the climax of its economic-growth drive, the LDP is struggling to find a Plan B. Delegates said yesterday they were worried that no obvious candidates had come forward to replace Mori.

Towards the prime minister, who described himself on Monday as someone who had been treated like a "little baby picked up under an overpass", there was a surprising amount of sympathy, as well as resignation about the impact of his departure on the party and Japan.

"I don't think Mori's resignation will change anything," said one elderly regional delegate who declined to give his name. "We've become a powerless people with no one to follow. Eventually Japan will fix itself, but it'll take 20 or 30 years."

For a nation that has long put a heavy priority on the need to teach a "way" for everything from bushido (the way of the warrior) to chado (the way of tea), the sudden loss of direction has been traumatic and liberating. Most of the losers are those who were once closely associated with the LDP. Office workers at large firms, who were once revered as corporate warriors and rewarded with jobs for life, now fret about resutora (restructuring) and falling social prestige. Unemployment is at a record high of 4.9%, bankruptcies are surging and the suicide rate among middle-aged men is alarming. A growing number of young graduates are shocking their parents by taking up part-time work that gives them more freedom. The past few years have seen a rash of scandals surrounding bureaucrats who gave favours in return for trips to hostess bars, surgeons who killed patients by leaving implements inside their bodies, and police who continued with mah-jongg drinking parties rather than respond to urgent calls for assistance. Confusion and turmoil have been most apparent in education. Amid record levels of violent juvenile crime, teachers are warning of a breakdown in classroom discipline and falling academic standards. Psychologists say that up to a million teenagers are withdrawing from society, holing up in their rooms where they feel more comfortable relying on their parents and playing with a computer than making friends and fending for themselves. It has hardly reached the stage of a youth rebellion, but Japan's media was horrified earlier this year when 20-year-olds at regional coming of age ceremonies heckled the speakers (often bigwigs in the local LDP) and set off firecrackers. In response to such concerns, the LDP has flip-flopped in the past five years between pushing for more individualism and creativity - seen as crucial if Japan is to adapt to fast-moving global trends - and reviving the prewar aim of nurturing social morality and group consciousness - to counter what is often depicted as the pernicious influence of the west. In most schools, the contrast between the two approaches is strikingly clear in the appearance of sports teams: in baseball - a sport that has long been Japanised to embody the spirit of sacrifice, hard work and team loyalty - the players arealmost militarily regimental, often sporting uniform skinhead haircuts; whereas in football - seen as an international and modern game in which individual skill is emphasised - the players are far more likely to have dyed hair and dreadlocks. Women have the most to gain from the changes taking place in Japan. Under traditional Confucian values, they were expected to obey their fathers and husbands and in the workplace they were often relegated to the status of "office flowers" whose primary purpose was to be decorative. In recent years, however, they have put off marriage and children and been more inclined to divorce. As a result, Japan's birth rate has plunged to 1.34 for each woman, one of the lowest levels in the world. The gerontocracy of the LDP has been slow to realise that women's bargaining power has increased sharply because Japan needs them to make up the gap in the workforce and to have more children. Women voters, however, have noted the change. "I used to think that politics was something best left to men, but now I increasingly find myself listening to women politicians and thinking they seem much more honest and capable," said Yuko Abe. With Mori's ratings at 6% and the LDP barely above 20%, young members and those from urban constituencies know the party must change to survive. But like Japan after the climax of its economic-growth drive, the LDP is struggling to find a Plan B. Delegates said yesterday they were worried that no obvious candidates had come forward to replace Mori. Towards the prime minister, who described himself on Monday as someone who had been treated like a "little baby picked up under an overpass", there was a surprising amount of sympathy, as well as resignation about the impact of his departure on the party and Japan. "I don't think Mori's resignation will change anything," said one elderly regional delegate who declined to give his name. "We've become a powerless people with no one to follow. Eventually Japan will fix itself, but it'll take 20 or 30 years."

fields.headline: Schröder wades into payment row
fields.standfirst: Embarrassed by the delays, residents of a small German town take it upon themselves to compensate a Polish victim of forced Nazi labour
fields.trailText: The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, will try when he meets industry chiefs today to end an embarrassing deadlock over a national plan to compensate Nazi-era slave workers.
fields.body:
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, will try when he meets industry chiefs today to end an embarrassing deadlock over a national plan to compensate Nazi-era slave workers.

One million former slave labourers, mainly from central and eastern Europe, who were drafted in by the Nazis to provide a wartime workforce have waited for years to be compensated.

But the programme, which calls for a DM5bn (about £1.6bn) contribution from industry to be matched by the government, is in utter confusion.

There are major delays in paying out the compensation, because industry chiefs insist on receiving immunity from prosecution from future lawsuits for the payout.

Last week New York judge Shirley Wohl Kram refused to throw out a key court case against German banks in case the compensation fund fails to deliver the money.

Mr Schröder has intervened in the standoff following stiff criticism from Jewish groups and lawyers who claim that the German industry heads are deliberately dragging their feet, sending damaging signals to the rest of the world about the country's willingness to face up to its past.

Embarrassed by the deadlock, the inhabitants of a north German village have taken it upon themselves to compensate one Polish victim.

The villagers of Grödersby held a whip-round and delivered the DM2,000 proceeds this week to Henryk Baran, 72, who was forced to work in the village by the Nazi regime.

Local newspapers in Poland reported that Mr Baran was speechless as he was handed 20 crisp DM100 notes, brought to him in his small prefabricated apartment in Krotoszyn, in western Poland, by two of Grödersby's residents.

"I'm very moved that there are young people who have not forgotten the children who were deported to the Third Reich to work," he told a local paper. "This money was collected by the children and grandchildren of the people who carried out these crimes but are now dead."

Mr Baran is one of around 500,000 Polish victims forced to labour for the Nazis.

He was put to work at Grödersby's dairy in 1944, when he was 15, and liberated by British troops the following year.

"The constant delays in compensating the slave labourers have really annoyed us, and we wanted to act," Grödersby resident Günther Plänitz said. "This was about trying to breakthrough the passivity."

The Polish-German Recon ciliation Foundation also began issuing payments of 1,400 zlotys (£240) to 5,000 of the oldest victims this week. The foundation said it expected to be reimbursed by the German fund later, but said the situation was getting critical as dozens of the victims are dying every day.

More than 40,000 other victims over the age of 80 are due to receive cheques by post in the next two weeks, Mateusz Chachaj, the foundation's spokesman, said.

He said he had faith in the German industry bosses to reach an agreement.

"I'm optimistic that German industry will meet the shortfall in its own time, and out of a sense of moral responsibility," he said yesterday in Munich.

About DM1.4bn has yet to be paid into the fund.

Jewish leaders, lawyers and compensation organisations have accused German industry of deliberately causing the hold-up to keep the money for as long as possible.

Pressure is building on Mr Schröder to reach an agreement before he visits Washington at the end March for talks with President George Bush.

A group of North American rabbis who travelled to Berlin yesterday pushed for a change in the fund law to allow for immediate payments.

webTitle: US air controller directed warplane to wrong target

fields.headline: US air controller directed warplane to wrong target
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: A US serviceman at the scene of the accidental bombing in Kuwait which killed six people on Monday directed the mistaken attack and then belatedly   called on the pilot to abort the mission, US officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
A US serviceman at the scene of the accidental bombing in Kuwait which killed six people on Monday directed the mistaken attack and then belatedly called on the pilot to abort the mission, US officials said yesterday.

The officials said a forward air controller mistakenly directed the US Navy F-18 Hornet's bombing and tried too late to call it off. Five American servicemen and one New Zealander were killed, and a number of other soldiers, including a Kuwaiti, were injured.

The Hornet from the aircraft carrier Harry Truman accidentally dropped explosives on observers during a practice run at a bombing range 30 miles from the Iraqi border.

Kuwait television showed the aftermath - smoke-blackened military vehicles on the barren sands of the Udairi bombing range where the joint US-British-Kuwaiti exercise took place. Other reporters were barred from the area, approximately 30 miles north-west of Kuwait City. AP
