fields.headline: Uganda's Museveni leads in 'rigged' elections
fields.trailText: The Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni, has taken more than 70% of the vote in early returns, although the main opposition alleges widespread ballot-rigging.
fields.body:
The Ugandan president, Yoweri Museveni, has taken more than 70% of the vote in early returns, although the main opposition alleges widespread ballot-rigging.

With votes in a fifth of constituencies counted, Kizza Besigye - Mr Museveni's first real challenger in 15 years in office - polled 19% of the vote.

"We are looking at not below 65% total. This will be an overwhelming win," the information minister, Basoga Nsadu, predicted.

But Ann Mugisha, publicity secretary of the Besigye campaign, said: "We are rejecting the results of the 2001 presidential elections. This is because of the gross fraudulent malpractices and the intimidation and violence against our polling agents, which made us unable to confirm the results in very many districts.

"The overall picture is that this election has been grossly rigged by the incumbent - helped by the incompetence of the electoral commission."

She said members of the Besigye task force had been barred from the tallying room in the electoral commission yesterday afternoon. "We believe that there was a crisis meeting in that room because the overall results showed there were 12.5 million voters," she said. Uganda has 10.5 million registered voters.

Foreign journalists visiting the western district of Rukungiri during Monday's voting were told that armed men chased away voters, seized ballot papers and ticked them in favour of Mr Museveni. Elsewhere, residents said they turned up to vote only to find that their names had already been ticked off.

More than 70 foreign observers have yet to give their assessment. However, the head of Uganda's independent election monitoring group said he did not believe serious vote-rigging had taken place.

"The reports of malpractices we have so far come from just a few place in the country. It does not look like there has been massive rigging," said the Rev Canon Grace Kaiso, the group's coordinator.

The presidential elections have been the most exciting Ugandans have seen for years - but they have been marred by allegations of violence, intimidation and harassment.

Dr Besigye, a former ally and personal physician of Mr Museveni, has alleged that the president has used state security organs to intimidate his supporters. In the most notorious incident, presidential guards opened fire on a crowd of Besigye supporters, killing one of them.

webTitle: Peru's ex-leader accused of ordering death of rebels

fields.headline: Peru's ex-leader accused of ordering death of rebels
fields.standfirst: Bodies of hostage-takers exhumed in siege inquiry
fields.trailText: The bodies of 14 Marxist rebels killed during a commando raid on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima in 1997 are being exhumed to try to establish if they were executed in cold blood.
fields.body:
The bodies of 14 Marxist rebels killed during a commando raid on the Japanese ambassador's residence in Lima in 1997 are being exhumed to try to establish if they were executed in cold blood.

Peruvian prosecutors are investigating whether the former president, Alberto Fujimori - who took great pride in personally directing the operation to rescue 72 hostages after a four-month siege - should be tried for human rights violations and murder.

Peru's former leader fled the country last year to live in Japan after a vote-buying scandal. This month a Peruvian judge ordered Mr Fujimori to appear in court on charges of dereliction of duty, although Japan and Peru have no extradition treaty.

On Monday five graves under unmarked crosses were unearthed on the shanty town outskirts of Lima, as Marxist sympathisers shouted "Spilt blood will never be forgotten!".

Forensic experts are now examining the rebels' bodies to see if there is evidence of gunshot wounds at close range, which would indicate that they were not shot in self-defence or in combat.

The postmortems are expected to take 10 to 15 days. "There are ...sufficient indications that on the day of the retaking of the ambassador's residence by members of the armed forces, three rebels were taken alive," said Ronald Gamarra, a state human rights prosecutor.

"Apparently, a commando proceeded to execute them when they were in custody."

The siege started during a VIP party. The hostages were held by the 14 members of the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement for 126 days.

All the hostage-takers died in the rescue, as well as one hostage and two soldiers.

In January relatives of the slain guerrillas filed a criminal complaint accusing Mr Fujimori, his fugitive ex-intelligence chief Vladimiro Montesinos, and former military chief Gen Nicolas Hermosa of human rights violations and extra-judicial murder.

The complaints were filed after Hidetaka Ogura, a Japanese embassy employee who was held hostage, told Peruvian radio last December that he had seen three rebels captured alive during the raid.

Four years ago, local media reported that when Peruvian special forces stormed the mansion, two young female rebels tried to give up, yelling "We surrender, we surrender!" before being cut down by commando gunfire.

"I want to know the truth. I don't believe anything that Fujimori has said," said Maria Fernandez, 54, the mother of one of the dead guerrillas.

Mr Fujimori denied the reports at the time but admitted in an interview that he gave an order to "neutralise" all the rebels.

He said his priority was to rescue the 72 hostages alive, and that while no one was killed for revenge, the soldiers did not wait to find out what each rebel's intentions were.

Japanese officials have shown no sign that they intend to force Mr Fujimori's return, but the Peruvian justice minister, Diego Garcia Sayan, said that if charges were lodged, the case would fall under the jurisdiction of international human rights law and Mr Fujimori could be prosecuted in Japan.

Newspaper reports in Peru have speculated that the Japanese authorities are under pressure to pursue the case because the residence was considered Japanese territory.

fields.headline: Europe turns heat on Israel
fields.standfirst:
France leads call for action over blockades of Palestinian cities and human rights abuses as EU seeks greater role in Middle East

Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: France leads call for action over blockades of Palestinian cities and human rights abuses as EU seeks greater role in Middle East
fields.byline: Ian Black in Brussels and Suzanne Goldenberg  in Jerusalem
fields.body:
Israel could have a key agreement with the European Union suspended if it does not end human rights abuses and blockades of Palestinian areas in the West Bank and Gaza.

In their first practical response to the Middle East crisis, EU governments are considering punitive measures to underline that the policies of the new Likud prime minister, Ariel Sharon, are not acceptable, the Guardian has learned.

Robin Cook and fellow EU foreign ministers are to review options next Monday after Chris Patten, the commissioner for external relations, warned Israeli leaders yesterday that their economic stranglehold must be lifted.

"It does not seem to us that everything that is being done in the West Bank and Gaza can be justified in security terms," Mr Patten said during a visit to the area with Anna Lindh, the foreign minister of Sweden, the current holder of the EU's rotating presidency.

France is leading calls for tough diplomatic action against Israel, seeking to boost the EU's role in a region traditionally dominated by the US at a time when the new Bush administration has not made its policies clear.

In a strongly worded paper on the Middle East submitted to EU governments last month, the French foreign minister, Hubert Védrine, argued: "Europeans have shrunk from making the effort needed to overcome their contradictions and apprehensions [and] are not prepared to pay the political price of a genuine role, and have become accustomed to their role as bit players.

"The EU should make the US recognise that it is legitimate for Europe to take its own approach to peace. If the union really wishes to pay a role, it must escape from the situation where defining a common position comes down to seeking the lowest common denominator in platitudinous declarations or ritualised diplomatic tours."

The EU could decide to suspend all or part of its 1995 association agreement with Israel - which includes high level political dialogue, cooperation in several key areas and valuable trade preferences worth millions of pounds a year - with immediate effect. Britain and Germany would be unlikely to favour such action but France would have the backing of Spain and Greece.

EU diplomats said last night that other less drastic measures under consideration included suspension of cooperation with Israel in the areas of science and technology or agricultural liberalisation talks.

The EU-Israel agreement was only ratified last year after the previous Likud prime minister, Binyamin Netanyahu, was replaced by the Labour leader, Ehud Barak, who was in turn defeated by the hardline Mr Sharon last month.

Israel bowed to its critics yesterday by easing its blockade of cities in the West Bank and the Gaza Strip. Two roads to the West Bank town of Ramallah were reopened.

But the Palestinian information minister, Yasser Abed Rabbo, said the changes were cosmetic and aimed "at deceiving the world that the closure has been lifted".

Washington warned Israel on Monday that if the economic pressure brought about a collapse of the Palestinian Authority, then it would harm prospects for peace.

The Israeli army sealed off the West Bank and Gaza when the intifada erupted, blocking more than 100,000 workers from jobs in Israel that are the lifeline of the economy.

Since then, the army has intensified its stranglehold on Palestinian cities, sealing off roads with concrete blocks and mounds of earth, positioning armoured personnel carriers at the entrances to towns and, in the last few weeks, digging an 11-mile waterless moat around the desert town of Jericho.

Mr Patten said the EU urged Mr Sharon to transfer £36m in tax revenues it has withheld from the Palestinian administration. He said the siege, which has cost the Palestinian economy at least £1bn and driven up unemployment, was counter-productive.

"If the economy continues to deteriorate in the West Bank and Gaza and if more people lose their jobs, if the Palestinian administration is undermined as a potential centre of authority, it will be more difficult to deal with security issues," Mr Patten said.

In his visit to the Gaza Strip on Monday, Mr Patten also issued a warning to Yasser Arafat, saying the EU did not want to continue its financial bail-out unless the Palestinian leader ended corruption and imposed some order on the Palestinian Authority.

fields.headline: Yesterday in Parliament
fields.trailText: All the day's events in politics.
fields.body:
Good day

Archaeologists. A group of them marched on parliament in an event so unusual that historians could not remember a precedent. Led by Dai Morgan Evans, secretary of the Society of Antiquaries, they urged the government to ensure that sites and monuments records, the bedrock of national archaeological data and a crucial tool in judging the sensitivity of development sites, are kept up to date by local authorities.

Quote of the day

Shadow home secretary Ann Widdecombe told a Westminster press conference: "I have to say bluntly that we are being ruled by dictators - and I don't use that as a rhetorical flourish, I mean it."

Today

Commons: International development questions . Prime minister's questions. Criminal justice and police bill, remaining stages. Lords: Debate on tax rises and IMF warning on spending increases.

fields.headline: Norris Turney
fields.standfirst: Gifted saxophonist who made his name with Duke Ellington
fields.trailText: Gifted saxophonist who made his name with Duke Ellington.
fields.body:
A fter several decades of low-profile activity in America's jazz hinterlands, the saxophonist Norris Turney, who has died aged 79, earned himself undying fame when he replaced the celebrated alto-saxophonist Johnny Hodges in the Duke Ellington orchestra in 1969.

Originally drafted in to cover for the indisposed Hodges for just two weeks, Turney was called back to sit amid the trombones when a player went absent before a European tour, transposing brass parts and playing them on alto saxophone. This seemingly random process ensured he was on hand to take over when Hodges collapsed and died suddenly in his dentist's waiting room.

Always a Hodges fan, Turney carved out a niche for himself with Ellington, soloing valuably on alto and flute. His prowess on the latter instrument was recognised when Ellington wrote Fife as a flute feature for him, a first in the Ducal canon.

Turney was from Wilmington, Ohio, itself a jazz back-water, but conveniently near to Dayton and Cincinnati. Encouraged by his parents to take up piano and, later, the saxophone, he was always interested in jazz and, a professional at 18, earned his spurs at a Cincinnati strip joint, the Cat And Fiddle, before embarking on the classic apprenticeship for an aspiring jazz musician - swapping bands (including the Wilberforce Collegians) or fronting his own, crisscrossing the state from Columbus to Toledo and back again to Cincinnati. He played there for two years with AB Townsend's band at the Cotton Club, the city's leading entertainment outlet for African-Americans.

His next move was to join the Peter-Pillars Orchestra, a St Louis big band with a nat- ional reputation, but, within a year, he had transferred to Chicago with Tiny Bradshaw, who later became prominent in rhythm & blues.

Turney's first real brush with jazz celebrity came in 1946, when he joined the Billy Eckstine Orchestra, a powerhouse packed with emerging bebop stars, including Fats Navarro, Gene Aninions and Art Blakey, which provided, he recalled, one of the great thrills of his career. When Eckstine broke up the band, Turney returned to Ohio, before "scuffing" mainly in New York, the only highlight being an extended gig in Philadelphia with veteran guitarist Elmer Snowden, one of Ellington's earliest mentors. Back in New York from 1960, he began to build a decent reputation as both a teacher and player, also fitting in a season with Ray Charles.

During his four-year stint with Duke, Turney's big sound - like Hodges', but with a harder edge - attracted considerable critical appreciation, as did his flute virtuosity. He went on to win the 1970 and 1971 Down Beat critics' poll, and created an exciting solo identity on Ellington albums and in concert appearances around the world. He persuaded Duke to allow him to contribute original compositions to the orchestra's repertoire, including Checkered Hat, a tribute to Hodges.

Oddly, Ellington rewarded Turney's versatility by making him uncomfortable on the bandstand, doubling up the tempo on a solo feature so that Turney found it impossible to play. Turney packed up his instruments and walked off the stand in mid-number.

He then spent a decade of show work on Broadway before returning to jazz as a freelance. He became a fixture with George Wein's Newport All Stars, playing the European summer festival circuit regularly, alongside top soloists like Clark Terry and Scott Hamilton. He was also in demand for the new wave of repertory orchestras, most notably trumpeter Wynton Marsalis's Lincoln Centre Jazz Orchestra.

Settled back in Dayton, he recorded and toured, including a well-received 1997 European trip involving the British bassist Dave Green. He also participated in the Duke Ellington conference held in Britain in May 1997.

Stanley Dance called Turney a "well-schooled, well-mannered musician of thoughtful appearance". He is survived by his wife Marilee, and by three children from an earlier marriage.

Norris William Turney, jazz saxophonist, born September 8 1921; died January 17 2001

webTitle: Westminster row after threat to charity's collection.

fields.headline: Art outcry
fields.standfirst: Westminster row after legal threat to charity's collection
fields.trailText: Westminster row after legal threat to charity's collection.
fields.byline: Maev Kennedy, arts and heritage correspondent
fields.body:
A plan to open one of London's least known art collections to the public is in danger of collapse in a legal dispute over the charitable status of the collection and its owners, MPs heard yesterday.

The Coram Foundation, in Bloomsbury, holds works by Gainsborough, Reynolds and Hogarth, such as Hogarth's The March to Finchley. The collection, valued at £17m, dates back to the 18th century, when fashionable artists, led by Hogarth, took up the cause of the foundling hospital begun by a wealthy merchant seaman, Captain Coram, after he literally stumbled over an abandoned baby lying in a gutter.

The foundation, whose original role has been transformed into a range of services for children, had intended to establish a separate trust, which would hold the pictures for 25 years and create a new public museum in the headquarters building to display the pictures.

A £3m lottery grant had already been agreed in principle. But the legality of the project has been questioned by the solicitor general, Ross Cranston, who says it goes beyond the charity's aims of caring for children. The former Labour health secretary, Frank Dobson, yesterday joined Tories including Peter Brooke and former attorney general Sir Nicholas Lyell in attacking the move during a debate in Westminster Hall.

"We are really between a rock and a hard place on this one," Gillian Pugh, chief executive of the Coram Foundation, said last night. The loan agreement was reached after months of discussion with the Heritage Lottery Fund and the Charity Commissioners.

"We believed that our plan was the best way of realising the value of the pictures while keeping them on the wall and allowing the public to enjoy them, in a way which has never been possible before."

fields.headline: Susan Gow
fields.standfirst: A life with Labour - from Downing Street to Brussels
fields.trailText: A life with Labour - from Downing Street to Brussels.
fields.body:
Susan Gow, who has died from a brain tumour aged 53, was a stalwart - and, in the wider world, unsung - member of Harold Wilson's staff at 10 Downing Street in the 1960s. She was also a convinced European and among the first wave of Britons to join the European Commission staff in Brussels.

After leaving school at 16, her first job was with the Parliamentary Labour party at the House of Commons. She moved to Downing Street soon after Labour's election victory in October 1964 to work for Wilson's political secretary, Marcia Williams, now Lady Falkender. Thus, in her late teenage years, Susan Lewis, as she then was, stayed late in the evenings providing administrative support and friendship to Williams and the rest of Wilson's kitchen cabinet.

Susan's family lived in Tite Street, Chelsea. Her father, Bert, was head waiter at the Café Royal and her mother, Betty, held a key role, responsible for membership, at Labour party headquarters. Indeed, Susan was almost born into the party. Certainly, she remained loyal to it, stoutly defending its record, and what it stood for, as others showered criticism on it during the lean, divisive times of the 1980s and early 1990s.

She also believed that Wilson had received an unfair press - a view borne out by recent releases from the Public Record Office over, for example, his principled stand against apartheid.

Her unyielding loyalty was reflected during the personal recriminations - many directed at Marcia Williams - after Labour lost power in 1970. Despite repeated attempts by journalists, some of them her personal friends, to cajole, even bribe, her to spill the beans, she resolutely refused to do so - in stark contrast to other members of Wilson's entourage.

Between 1970 and 1973, Susan took on a number of jobs, including a spell in Paris, where she worked for a travel firm which took her to Romania and Bulgaria, and as personal assistant to Richard Crossman, then editor of the New Statesman.

When Britain joined what was then the European Economic Community in 1973, she was in the vanguard, serving in the cabinet of George (now Lord) Thomson, the former Labour foreign office minister who had been appointed as one of the UK's first two European commissioners. She later joined the staff of Agenor, a leftwing magazine devoted to closer pan-European cooperation.

In Brussels, she met Carl Wilms-Wright, but the marriage lasted only about two years. Later, in 1980, she married David Gow, then the Scotsman's European correspondent. Back in London, where David had joined the Guardian, Susan took on a number of jobs, including campaigning for third-world rights with the World Development Movement, before working for Joan Lestor, Labour's aid and development spokeswoman.

For what were to become the last years of her life, the family moved to south Wales, where she had difficulty in finding a job to fulfil her interests and talents, although she finally took on work for the Welsh national assembly.

Susan was extremely modest, always asking about others. She will be remembered for her extraordinary generosity and selflessness. She is survived by her husband David, the Guardian's industrial editor, their adopted daughter Gemma, and granddaughter Nicole.

Susan Jane Gow, researcher and political activist, born May 26 1947; died March 8 2001.

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: Anyone who feels this column concentrates on incestuous media stuff at the expense of what the editor likes to call "proper stories" will feel foolish after today's lead
fields.body:
 Anyone who feels this column concentrates on incestuous media stuff at the expense of what the editor likes to call "proper stories" (and there are critics, not all of them in this building), will feel foolish after today's lead. It concerns our report on Tony Parsons's vicious attack in the Mirror on the Times's Caitlin Moran, who complained to the Telegraph when an unnamed journalist wrote calling her "a silly cow" after she attacked Michael Parkinson's TV show. There, was that so bad? Since then, Caitlin is in touch ... and would you believe it, the writer of that letter "was, indeed, [the Telegraph's] Michael Henderson", although what Hendo has since apologised for calling her was in fact an "ugly little trollop". As for the splenetic Parsons, Caitlin observes: "It's hardly fucking Beowulf to call a woman who gave birth five weeks ago 'fat'. Still, I do sometimes regret my No Personal Insults rule, as I've wanted to point out that Tony Parsons has a face like a single, lonely buttock with two raisins for eyes for some time now."So," she concludes, "has Henderson done this kind of thing before?" Another avid reader there then. Stand by, Caitlin, and we'll email the back catalogue.

 Having cracked the Hendo puzzle, we turn to another mystery figure, in this case the man my friend Alastair Campbell (the prime minister's spokesman) apparently rescued from muggers one recent night on Hampstead Heath. All that brief press reports say is that he was "a Lib Dem activist", so my colleague Marina Hyde has sought further particulars from Number 10, where press officer James Fletcher has shown further signs of insolence. We will learn of her progress tomorrow when, purely for balance, we will also return to Number 11 and the curious matter of Gordon Brown's raven locks.

 Over at Tory central office, meanwhile, the election's imminence plays on the nerves of the normally good natured Amanda Platell. Mr Hague's press chief flew into a frightful bait last week, we gather, on discovering that Conservative press officers had all changed their mobile phone rings to the theme from Mission Impossible.

 Yesterday we congratulated the organisers of 3G Expo, a conference in May about how to succeed on the internet, on booking as a keynote speaker the boulevardier Andrew Neil, who is well known in this field as the angel of death. Pondering the notion of starting day two with Andrew discoursing on "How to succeed and prosper in the information age", we ring Redman Media and ask if it's a tried and tested technique to kick-start attention spans with a hilarious joke like this one? "Well, I don't know if it will be funny," says coordinator Sam Cooper. Well, we'd certainly hope so given that three of the four internet ventures of Andrew's listed on your brochure appear to have folded. "Well, he didn't tell us that. But maybe he'll choose to look at his own failures and other people's successes." Mm. "After all, he's such a respected figure." Indeed, indeed.

 There is no word from Imperial College (partly perhaps because we haven't bothered to ask) on whether a recently advertised post has been filled. The college was seeking a manager of "the last civil nuclear research reactor in the UK". Don't panic or anything, but the vacancy arose, says the advert, "due to unforeseen relocation of the current post holder". Oh dear. The salary is somewhere between £28,275 and £36,740, and experience of nuclear reactors would help. Oh yes, one other pointer for anyone tempted to apply late on the off chance. "Professional safety qualifications would be an advantage."

webTitle: US and Japan buy British body parts

fields.headline: UK attracts tissue test business
fields.standfirst: US and Japan buy British body parts to avoid regulation
fields.trailText: Japanese and American drugs companies are testing new medicines on the tissue of dead British people to avoid tight restrictions on the use of human organs in their own countries.
fields.body:
Japanese and American drugs companies are testing new medicines on the tissue of dead British people to avoid tight restrictions on the use of human organs in their own countries.

Pharmagene, the Hertfordshire based firm that specialises in testing on body parts, yesterday reported surging demand for its services from overseas companies, despite announcing a 55% increase in annual losses to £6.5m.

Pharmagene has a library of more than 250,000 samples of liver, heart, bowel and lung that have been removed, with the permission of patients and relatives, during operations or post mortems.

Six of Pharmagene's 20 customers are Japanese. Chief scientific officer Robert Coleman said: "It's extraordinarily difficult to get access to human tissue in Japan. Until recently, it was illegal."

Such samples are hard to get hold of in Japan. Mr Coleman said: " It's really not within the Japanese ethos - they're very, very uncomfortable about donations and the use of tissue."

In the US, red tape means that human tissue is tied up for some time after being removed from bodies, so it is often not fresh enough for clinical use. Mr Coleman said: "You can get absolutely anything out there - you can get whole human heads if you want them. But it takes a lot of red tape, and you usually only get frozen material."

Pharmagene has a network of 16 hospitals supplying newly removed organ samples. Its trial work can reduce the need for the pharmaceuticals industry to test medicines on animals.

Pharmagene signed deals with 18 companies last year, including 10 repeat customers. However, the company's revenue fell from £1.26m to £1.03m, due to a policy of only accounting for income when contracts are completed.

The company floated last year with an initial market value of £142m. Its shares fell 8.5p to 104p, in line with a sell-off in biotech stocks yesterday, giving the business a capitalisation of £52m.

Pharmagene is planning to open an office on the east coast of the US, to attract more American customers. The firm's supply of donations in this country was briefly put into doubt by the Alder Hey hospital scandal earlier this year, in which surgeons removed the organs of dead children without permission. This deterred nurses from asking relatives' permission for donations to Pharmagene.

Mr Coleman said the supply of human tissue was now steady. If anything, he said he would welcome a tightening of restrictions to give donors more confidence about the way tissue samples are used.

Pharmagene has its own drug development operation, with research under way on new treatments for migraine and irritable bowel syndrome.

 Biocompatibles revealed positive news on its coronary stents - tiny pieces of scaffolding used to hold open damaged arteries. The healthcare firm's US partner, Abbott Laboratories, has found that the stents cause a 43% reduction in restenosis - the type of recurrent heart trouble recently experienced by US vice-president Dick Cheney. Unlike most stents, Biocompatibles' products contain a drug to prevent new blockages. The shares jumped 17.5p to 248.5p.

webTitle: Credit Suisse sees tough times ahead

fields.headline: Credit Suisse sees tough times ahead
fields.trailText: Credit Suisse which is taking the axe to 10% of its 7,000-strong City workforce, yesterday admitted that the coming year would prove more "challenging" because of economic uncertainties.
fields.body:
Credit Suisse which is taking the axe to 10% of its 7,000-strong City workforce, yesterday admitted that the coming year would prove more "challenging" because of economic uncertainties.

Fresh from taking over Donaldson, Lufkin and Jenrette, the US-based investment bank, Credit Suisse reported higher than expected profits for 2000 of SFr5.8bn (£2.4bn).

As a result of integrating DLJ into Credit Suisse First Boston, up to 700 City jobs will be lost. A number of redundancies were made by the end of last year, but some positions were lost as recently as last week.

While the takeover has resulted in some high profile departures, the bank insisted that 90% of executives it had asked to remain had done so.

Yesterday, the bank admitted that while some parts of the business might feel the impact of any downturn in the global economy its diversification would allow it to withstand the worst. "As a group we are so broadly based that we are very confident for the current year," said Lukas Muehlemann, chairman and chief financial officer.

The bank aims to diversify its profits away from the notoriously volatile investment banking business through its asset management arm, which specialises in managing money for wealthy people.

The bank revealed yesterday that it intends to seek a US listing of its shares later this year. It also plans to start buying back its shares on the Swiss stock exchange.

The bank aims to diversify its profits away from the notoriously volatile investment banking business through its asset management arm, which specialises in managing money for wealthy people. The bank revealed yesterday that it intends to seek a US listing of its shares later this year. It also plans to start buying back its shares on the Swiss stock exchange.

webTitle: Royal Bank defends £15m for US chief

fields.headline: Royal Bank defends £15m for US chief
fields.trailText: A new row over boardroom pay is likely after it emerged that one of the Royal Bank of Scotland's top executives, Larry Fish, was paid $22m (£15m) last year.
fields.body:
A new row over boardroom pay is likely after it emerged that one of the Royal Bank of Scotland's top executives, Larry Fish, was paid $22m (£15m) last year.

The pay award made to Mr Fish, an American, under a seven-year performance plan, was just one of the bumper payments to senior directors of the Edinburgh-based bank.

Fred Goodwin, the chief executive, was paid £2.2m including a"special bonus" of £814,000 for his efforts in the takeover battle for NatWest last year. His predecessor, Sir George Mathewson, who is to become non-executive chairman next month, received £2.2m including a £759,000 special bonus. Sir George also made a £1.8m gain on stock options.

The payments are for the 15 months to the end of December 2000 - rather than the more traditional 12 months - because of a change to the bank's reporting period. It is the special bonuses to directors, which the bank announced last September, that could cause difficulties with shareholders. The bank's gauge of its performance, which does not include a measurement against its peers, may also rankle with some shareholders.

Peter Montagnon, head of investment affairs at the Association of British Insurers, has yet to receive the remuneration report, but said: "In principle, the position of the ABI is to reward performance which has been demonstrably attained. That means we prefer the benefit to accrue when it is clear the takeover has been successful. A year is not a very long time."

Viscount Younger of Leckie, the bank's chairman, defended the pay of Mr Fish, who runs Citizen's Bank from Boston. "Without question Larry Fish is a top performer and over the last seven years has done a magnificent job building Citizen's into a powerful financial services group within New England. Larry's remuneration is on a par with peers in the US. The Royal Bank of Scotland has never been afraid to pay for excellent performance," said Viscount Younger, who himself was paid £379,000.

Other directors to receive special bonuses were Iain Robertson, who runs the corporate banking arm and was paid a total of £2m before a £1.4m gain on stock options. Norman McLuskie, who runs the retail operation, took home £839,000, excluding a £2.3m options gain.

A spokesman said: "Our remuneration structure is performance based and reflects a period during which the bank's share price has been a top performer in Europe. We concluded the largest takeover in UK banking history exceeded all targets for delivering merger benefits, established the group as the seventh largest company in the UK and the number three bank in Europe."

webTitle: Notebook: Royal Bank - trebles all round the board

fields.headline: Royal Bank? It's trebles all round the board
fields.standfirst: Pay proves cause for celebration
fields.trailText: It's party time in the Royal Bank of Scotland's boardroom. The men who snatched control of NatWest last year have rewarded themselves with some serious money.
fields.body:
It's party time in the Royal Bank of Scotland's boardroom. The men who snatched control of NatWest last year have rewarded themselves with some serious money. There is £15m for Larry Fish, the boss of the bank's American subsidiary Citizen's Bank. Mr Fish, however, works in the United States and is paid there, where "greed is good" rules about executive rewards apply.

More worrying for British shareholders, perhaps, is the £814,000 pat on the back bonus for Fred Goodwin, the new chief executive, and £759,000 for his predecessor, Sir George Mathewson. Corporate banking supremo Iain Robertson was given £773,000.

Jolly well done, chaps, but is this largesse for a special performance not just a little premature?

It takes time for acquisitions to deliver on their promises - certainly longer than the year since Royal Bank of Scotland's victory. The large majority of mergers and acquisitions do not fulfil their initial promise.

There is also the not unimportant matter that Royal Bank doles out its special bonuses for top work without reference to how its peers have performed. As Lord Younger pointed out yesterday, Royal Bank has never been afraid to pay top dollar for top operatives. It has a history of agreeing humungous pay deals.

It was Royal Bank, under George Mathewson, that set the pace 10 years ago when it paid shedloads of cash to Peter Wood, the founder of its Direct Line insurance subsidiary. His annual bonus reached £18m and was described by the then shadow trade secretary, Robin Cook, as "obscene".

Not something Labour would do now, as proved last week when the DTI showed its truly wimpish tendencies by saying it would not force companies to put remuneration matters to a shareholders' vote.

Ultimately it cost Royal Bank £42m to buy out Mr Wood's bonus.

Royal Bank justifies the bonuses paid to Mssrs Goodwin, Mathewson and Robertson by pointing to the company's storming results and soaring share price.

But the top men have already been rewarded for this achievement with their share options. Sir George made a gain of £1.8m on his share options last year, Mr Robertson cashed in options that provided a £1.4m windfall. Mr Goodwin has not cashed in any so far but is sitting on a pile worth £2.5m.

Share options are designed to reward executives for their success in raising the company's share price. At Royal Bank, the NatWest takeover looks good so far, and the options have done exactly what they are designed to do. The bank points out that the extra bonus scheme was announced last year, but it still essentially means being paid twice for the same thing.

Ethical fix

After taking a month-long battering over its failure to make affordable drugs available in Aids-ravaged Africa, GlaxoSmithKline has come over all ethical and dropped a tobacco baron from its board.

The official line yesterday was that non-executive director Derek Bonham had stepped down voluntarily to devote more time to his other interests, which incidentally include chairing the board of Imperial Tobacco.

However, insiders admit that shareholder pressure has played a part: investors feel that cigarettes and health care do not mix. GlaxoSmithKline, nursing a badly bruised public image, is so scared of any further controversy that it agreed Mr Bonham should go.

This sets an intriguing precedent. A trawl through the rest of Glaxo's board reveals a startling variety of unhealthy outside interests.

To kick off with alcohol, Sir Christopher Hogg sits on the board of Allied Domecq, and Sir Ian Prosser chairs Bass. Few could dispute that spirits, beer and pubs are bad for the health of GlaxoSmithKline's customers.

Among GSK's American contingent, Donald McHenry is a director of Coca-Cola - which causes the tooth rot that Glaxo's Aquafresh toothpastes attempt to prevent. Paul Allaire, meanwhile, earns an annual stipend from sitting on the board of Sara Lee, which makes coffee, hot dogs, strawberry cheesecake and Wonderbras. Some of those must have triggered a few heart attacks.

Glaxo's chief executive, Jean-Pierre Garnier, is a director of United Technologies - which makes components for military aircraft used to bomb people and civil airliners which just might give you deep vein thrombosis. Non-executive director Peter Job lists shooting among his pastimes, hardly a right-on hobby.

In fact, about the only Mr Clean is finance director John Coombe, who sits on no other corporate boards and spends his spare time blamelessly playing bridge and golf.

He may be the most boring man in the company but if this climate persists, Mr Coombe could soon be president, chairman and chief executive.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Europe airlines 'to consolidate'
fields.body:
Europe airlines 'to consolidate'

Europe's three biggest airlines will absorb the other major carriers in the region in the next few years, the head of Air France said.

US consolidation would force Europe to follow suit, boiling its own industry down to a handful of groupings based on Air France, British Airways and Lufthansa, the French airline's chairman Jean-Cyrill Spinetta said.

Regulatory obstacles to consolidation could be broken down within 10 years, with a US-European air services trade treaty leading the way, he said.

IR35 faces court challenge

A lawyer for a group of IT contractors told the high court yesterday that the government's IR35 regime was "liable to cause significant and damaging distortions of competition and movement of businesses and workers in relation to the UK knowledge-based contracting industries".

IR35, due for implementation next month, is designed to clamp down on "disguised employment" by countering tax avoidance among individuals who, but for the fact that they work through companies, would be deemed to be employed by their clients.

The Professional Contractors Group is seeking court orders to strike down the new measures as being incompatible with European laws.

Club Med warns on profit

Leisure group Club Méditerranée issued a profit warning yesterday, saying it no longer expected to reach its sales and profit growth targeted for this year.

The news, which came just two months after the company forecast double-digit growth, sent Club Med stock into a tail-spin. The shares lost 12.75% to €89 after being suspended limit-down earlier.

"It's not surprising given the environment in the sector," said one fund manager. "Their medium-term strategy is good but in the short term there is little good news to expect in a less rosy context."

Napster in deal with Gracenote

Song-swap company Napster yesterday said it reached agreement with Gracenote, a maker of music recognition services, to help it exclude files from its service under a court-ordered injunction.

fields.headline: Greenpeace flays 'selfish' Mobil
fields.trailText: A battle for hearts and minds in the City was under way last night as Greenpeace accused the world's biggest energy group, ExxonMobil, of "irresponsibility" after it demanded $1trillion (£715bn) of new oil and gas spending in the next decade.
fields.body:
A battle for hearts and minds in the City was under way last night as Greenpeace accused the world's biggest energy group, ExxonMobil, of "irresponsibility" after it demanded $1trillion (£715bn) of new oil and gas spending in the next decade.

The environmental group believes its message is beginning to get through with 40 fund managers and analysts agreeing to attend a special climate change summit at the London Stock Exchange next week.

Stephanie Tunmore, climate campaigner for Greenpeace UK and organiser of the seminar, agreed that massive levels of new investment were needed to keep up with growing energy demand. She said: "It is irresponsible and selfish to suggest this should come from fossil fuels that damage the environ ment and affect the lives of millions of people."

Ms Tunmore believed that increasing regulation emanating from the Kyoto Protocol and the intergovernment panel on climate change would force oil groups to concentrate on alternatives.

But Lee Raymond, chairman of ExxonMobil, told a natural gas conference in Qatar on Monday that the world would struggle to meet growing energy demands even using oil and gas. "Meeting the energy supply challenges may require over $1trillion in new investment in exploration and production facilities over the next decade," he said.

Mr Raymond was confident that oil would remain the world's leading source of energy over the next 20 years but estimated demand for gas would grow 50% faster than oil.

fields.headline: Economists maul 'boom' Budget
fields.standfirst: Special report: Budget 2001
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's budget came under fire yesterday from a high-powered panel of economists for risking a return to "boom and bust".
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's budget came under fire yesterday from a high-powered panel of economists for risking a return to "boom and bust".

Three out of four giving evidence to the Commons Treasury committee said the chancellor had given too much away to please voters in the run up to election, putting at risk the prospect for lower interest rates.

Geoffrey Dicks, of the Royal Bank of Scotland, said the economy would receive a fiscal boost worth 1% of GDP this year at a time when it was already growing above its long-term trend. Real household disposable income would grow by 4.25%-4.5%, the biggest increase since the 1988 boom.

"It's far from prudent, it's risky and expansionary," Mr Dicks said. The chancellor was in the perverse position of hoping for a hard landing in the US to justify his fiscal stance.

Tim Congdon, of Lombard Street Research, said he was concerned that Mr Brown's fiscal loosening would stoke inflationary pressure in 2002-03, risking a return to the familiar pattern of boom and bust.

Martin Weale, director of the National Institute of Economic and Social Research, said the chancellor had attempted to walk a tightrope between inflation and supporting growth. "My concern is that he's gone a bit too far towards inflation and therefore interest rates are likely to be a bit higher than may be desirable," he said.

However Kate Barker, chief economic adviser at the Confederation of British Industry, said the fiscal loosening was well timed to ward off the threat of slowing global growth. "I think the Budget is still just the right side of prudent," Ms Barker said.

All of the panel agreed that taxes would have to rise in the next parliament if Mr Brown wanted to maintain the pace of growth in public spending envisaged over the next three years and keep the budget deficit stable.

webTitle: Leader: The political threat from economic decline

fields.headline: Scenes set for turbulence
fields.standfirst: The political threat from economic decline
fields.trailText: At the sharp end of deepening global economic instability sit countries such as Indonesia and other developing nations in south-east Asia and beyond.
fields.body:
At the sharp end of deepening global economic instability sit countries such as Indonesia and other developing nations in south-east Asia and beyond. While US investors and Japanese bankers may take a financial bath, such countries face a potential political tidal wave that threatens to inundate not only their governments but also their democratic institutions.

A vow yesterday by Indonesia's army commander "to save this nation ... if a chaotic situation erupts" showed how a severe economic downturn could make a bad situation very much worse. Indonesia only recently banished the military-backed Suharto dictatorship and established truly representative governance. Despite a bold devolution plan enacted this year, it is struggling to contain ethnic and religious strife of which the Dayak "head-hunter" violence in Kalimantan is but the latest example. President Wahid Abdurrahman was already in deep trouble, abandoned by his vice-president, lacking parliament's support, accused of corruption, and facing daily demands that he resign. After Jakarta's stock market and the rupiah tumbled on Monday, Amien Rais, head of the People's Consultative Assembly, declared dramatically that "our nation is falling apart". Just how much longer Mr Wahid can survive, and what will follow, is now closely linked to wider economic turbulence far beyond Jakarta's control.

Although the political situation in the Philippines, Malaysia and Thailand is less acute at present, the instability a prolonged recession could create in these countries, too, heavily dependent on US and Japanese investment and trade, is both worrying and unpredictable.

Having dumped Joseph Estrada last January, the new Philippines government led by President Gloria Macapagal-Arroyo has endured endless rumours of military coups while battling to come to terms with a budget deficit this year of nearly £4bn and a £35bn external debt. Still beset by rampant corruption, crushing poverty and secessionist agitation, there is little spare capacity in Manila for overcoming crises made in Tokyo and New York. And what goes for the Philippines goes, with a vengeance, for all the peoples of Asia's and Africa's least-developed nations, for whom a first world recession may mean less debt forgiveness, less aid, and - for it is a vicious economic-political cycle - less respect for democratic values and human rights by governments fighting to keep a grip.

All of which makes the repeated failure of Japan's oligarchs to reform moribund political and financial structures the more inexcusable and irresponsible. The amazingly inept prime minister, Yoshiro Mori, belongs to a ruling class that has long failed both to grasp Japan Inc's need of a thorough management shakeout and to take on a regional leadership role. Yet while Japan has preferred to let the US carry that latter burden in the past, the Bush administration now also seems increasingly reluctant to step in to help the most vulnerable victims of capitalism's crises. That's yet another policy in need of a rethink, Dubya.

webTitle: Leader: recruitment of soldiers in Scotland

fields.headline: Send reinforcements
fields.standfirst: The army is going to Advance...
fields.trailText: In a further lurch towards the privatisation of almost everything, the recruitment of soldiers in Scotland is to be entrusted to a private employment agency called Search, which is setting up a special division called Advance to handle the business.
fields.body:
In a further lurch towards the privatisation of almost everything, the recruitment of soldiers in Scotland is to be entrusted to a private employment agency called Search, which is setting up a special division called Advance to handle the business. If the agency hits its target of boosting Scotland's annual recruitment rate of 2,000 by 10%, the scheme may be extended to England, and those traditional figures with minimal haircuts and militant whiskers, recruiting sergeants, will ply their trade no more. In their place will come civilians armed with computers - far better equipped, it is felt, to target likely customers.

Old recruiting sergeants will turn in their graves. They had their own methods of targeting, honed in their years as NCOs. "I need three volunteers," was their war cry then, "you, you and you". They would not have claimed all the credit for the record surge of recruitment at the start of the first world war, initially so successful that the stipulated mini mum height and chest measurements for new recruits had to be raised to hold back the hordes. But they certainly served their purpose as Kitchener's magic faded, averting their gaze from the evidence that potential signings were too short or too young to qualify. "You're under age" they would tell aspirant soldiers who confessed to the truth. "Come back tomorrow and we'll see if you're still under age then." That was how at least two 13-year-olds found their way in, and one private who was 12 when he joined and served six weeks on the Somme.

"In prosecuting their efforts they are not to ignore any stratum of the population, or any locality of the country," said guidelines laid down at the end of Victoria's reign. With army recruitment down 14% during the last three months of last year, and the MoD pledged to repair a shortfall of 8,000 by 2005, that commandment at least will apply as much to Advance as it ever did to their sturdy, bristling, uniformed precursors.
fields.bodyText: In a further lurch towards the privatisation of almost everything, the recruitment of soldiers in Scotland is to be entrusted to a private employment agency called Search, which is setting up a special division called Advance to handle the business. If the agency hits its target of boosting Scotland's annual recruitment rate of 2,000 by 10%, the scheme may be extended to England, and those traditional figures with minimal haircuts and militant whiskers, recruiting sergeants, will ply their trade no more. In their place will come civilians armed with computers - far better equipped, it is felt, to target likely customers. Old recruiting sergeants will turn in their graves. They had their own methods of targeting, honed in their years as NCOs. "I need three volunteers," was their war cry then, "you, you and you". They would not have claimed all the credit for the record surge of recruitment at the start of the first world war, initially so successful that the stipulated mini mum height and chest measurements for new recruits had to be raised to hold back the hordes. But they certainly served their purpose as Kitchener's magic faded, averting their gaze from the evidence that potential signings were too short or too young to qualify. "You're under age" they would tell aspirant soldiers who confessed to the truth. "Come back tomorrow and we'll see if you're still under age then." That was how at least two 13-year-olds found their way in, and one private who was 12 when he joined and served six weeks on the Somme. "In prosecuting their efforts they are not to ignore any stratum of the population, or any locality of the country," said guidelines laid down at the end of Victoria's reign. With army recruitment down 14% during the last three months of last year, and the MoD pledged to repair a shortfall of 8,000 by 2005, that commandment at least will apply as much to Advance as it ever did to their sturdy, bristling, uniformed precursors.

fields.headline: More sleep
fields.trailText: So, I'm not alone. The average mother is existing on just five hours' sleep a night, even after 18 months (New fathers sleep on ..., March 13).
fields.body:
So, I'm not alone. The average mother is existing on just five hours' sleep a night, even after 18 months (New fathers sleep on ..., March 13). Being able to walk, talk and function on even a basic level is quite miraculous on such little sleep, but I suspect that many of these mothers are, like me, also working full-time and possibly spending long hours commuting.

Family-flexible work policies are all very well, but working 8 till 4 or 10 till 6 doesn't help that much when you are only able to function after heavy doses of Diet Coke. Lack of sleep leads to lack of confidence at work, errors and depression, as well as broken relationships. In new Labour speak, this can't be good for the economy - let alone women's health.

So what is the answer? Working part-time (difficult in London where mortgages are so high)? Sleep cubicles at work? Hoping your body adapts to four hours' sleep a night, like Margaret Thatcher, but without going mad in the process?

What we need is a revolution in the way British people think about work and more equal wealth distribution, so that it is not just the rich who can afford the childcare and shorter working hours which allows them the luxury of sleep. Unfortunately, I am too tired for a revolution. Call me in 16 years.
Mandy Garner
London
mandy.garner@virgin.net

fields.headline: Versions of Shatilla
fields.trailText: As an admirer of Michael Elkin's work as a BBC correspondent I read David Sells' obituary (March 13) with interest, and in particular his reference to the massacre of Palestinians at the Shatilla and Sabra refugee camps.
fields.body:
As an admirer of Michael Elkin's work as a BBC correspondent I read David Sells' obituary (March 13) with interest, and in particular his reference to the massacre of Palestinians at the Shatilla and Sabra refugee camps.

When Elkins came up with his original, inaccurate report, we in the BBC World Service newsroom were not at all happy with it. We knew that the Israeli army must at least have allowed it to happen (in fact they guarded the camps' perimeters as the Phalangist militias did their work); we also knew, having seen the first television footage as it came in from the Lebanon, that Elkins had totally failed to grasp the scale of the killing.

I told him all this on the line from Jerusalem, and he went away a very angry man. Angry because Israeli military sources he had trusted had betrayed him - and probably, knowing Michael Elkins, angry because of what the Israeli army had done.

Elkins promised to find out the actual facts, and in due course came up with his second "fantastic" piece, which gave an accurate account of what had happened - from his own sources, and not from us. He then told us not to try to contact him again for 24 hours, because he was going into hiding - rightly or wrongly fearful for his life because of what he had revealed.
David Spaull
Former editor, BBC World Service News
Dspaull@aol.com

webTitle: Letter: Persuasion won't work with Mugabe

fields.headline: Persuasion won't work with Mugabe
fields.trailText: The reason Robert Mugabe has not been persuaded to stop dismissing judges, bombing the independent press, murdering opponents and occupying commercial farms is not, as Liz McGregor appears to believe (Softly, softly, March 13).
fields.body:
The reason Robert Mugabe has not been persuaded to stop dismissing judges, bombing the independent press, murdering opponents and occupying commercial farms is not, as Liz McGregor appears to believe (Softly, softly, March 13), his affront at "criticisms from a colonial master" or because he considers advice from a younger and less experienced Mbeki "impertinent".

Mugabe has only one objective: maintaining his own corrupt, violent and brutal rule, whatever the cost to the country as he drives Zimbabwe towards bankruptcy, in order to continue lining his own pockets and those of his cronies.

The idea that he could be persuaded to accept a "graceful exit" is therefore laughable. Yes, British diplomacy has not succeeded, but nor has South Africa's or anyone else's. Perhaps more likely to produce results would be an increase in international pressure in the hope of engineering a "palace coup", with senior Zanu-PF government members removing Mugabe themselves (as eventually happened to Milosevic).

Denigration of the MDC opposition, which has behaved admirably in the face of sustained attacks by Mugabe's police, can only serve to bolster the man you correctly call a tyrant.
Walter Hain
London
adwal@peterhain.org

webTitle: Letters: And the case for Vaz

fields.headline: And the case for Vaz
fields.trailText: It is not Keith Vaz who is disgraced but the media for hounding a good man with lies and distortions. Even the Guardian (Leader, March 13) misrepresents the report of the committee on standards and privileges which cleared Mr Vaz of all but one of 18 allegations.
fields.body:
It is not Keith Vaz who is disgraced but the media for hounding a good man with lies and distortions.

Even the Guardian (Leader, March 13) misrepresents the report of the committee on standards and privileges which cleared Mr Vaz of all but one of 18 allegations. It is untrue that the committee could not rule on eight allegations "because Mr Vaz had refused to give them the information they needed". After the commissioner reported to the committee, leaving eight inquiries uncompleted, the committee interviewed Mr Vaz twice, as well as several other witnesses. Mr Vaz provided the committee with all relevant information available to him and the committee rejected all the allegations left uncompleted by the commissioner.

Instead of applauding his welcome exoneration the media has largely focused on his supposed "obstruction" of the commissioner's investigation. The committee nowhere uses this expression. It concluded merely that if Mr Vaz and other witnesses had answered the commissioner's questions fully and promptly she would have been able to complete her report in a much shorter time. The committee also said that Mr Vaz was wrong to tell the commissioner in December - eight months after the investigation started - that he would not answer further questions from her.

Mr Vaz had answered a very large number of questions by the commissioner since the investigation started in February last year. On June 7 the commissioner wrote to me, as his solicitor, as follows: "...Mr Vaz has been helpful in discussing these matters and in providing me with written replies and information and you are correct in saying that Mr Vaz has already responded to all the allegations other than informing me whether he had recommended Mr Zaiwalla for an honour. I am glad to receive now the response from Mr Vaz that he recommended Mr Zaiwalla for an honour..." The delay in responding on the last point was caused simply by Mr Vaz having punctiliously sought advice from the Speaker as to whether he could properly disclose so confidential a matter.

When the investigation had dragged on until December Mr Vaz informed the commissioner through me that he believed he had already answered all relevant questions but would be happy to answer any questions which the committee wished him to answer - as he subsequently did. If he was wrong to invite referral to the committee after eight months it was hardly a grievous error.
Geoffrey Bindman
Bindman & Partners

fields.body:
Further to Bob Bird's comments (Letters, March 13), I note that the Labour war room (Brown's round table generals draw up battle plans, March 13) has the same number of toilets as the Tory one. What does this say about the output of the two main political parties?

Simon.Pape@powergen.co.uk

 Thank goodness someone has had the courage to stand up to the Sun newspaper (Sun can be sued for distress, court rules, March 13). Esther Thomas could finally bring the Murdoch tabloid to account for the distress that it causes to innocent people. Best of luck Esther - you'll need it.

London
Barry.O'Dea@nihha.org.uk

fields.headline: The case against Vaz ...
fields.trailText: It is, to say the least, disappointing that a newspaper with a great liberal tradition such as yours should merely shrug your shoulders and conclude that the Keith Vaz affair boils down to nothing more than a need to redefine the meaning of the word "proper" (Leader, March 13).
fields.body:
It is, to say the least, disappointing that a newspaper with a great liberal tradition such as yours should merely shrug your shoulders and conclude that the Keith Vaz affair boils down to nothing more than a need to redefine the meaning of the word "proper" (Leader, March 13).

Mr Vaz may well be innocent of all the allegations against him. But members of parliament and others in public office not only have to act with propriety, but have to be seen to be doing so.

After the Hammond whitewash, one would have expected you to have slammed the conclusions of the Commons standards and privileges committee, rather than engage in a discussion on semantics. Mr Vaz and his constituency party showed their contempt for both Elizabeth Filkin and the Commons committee - and therefore, as our representatives, for us, by deliberately obstructing their work.

Robert Sheldon, as chairman of the Commons committee, just sweeps the whole affair under the carpet, thereby confirming the suspicion in many peoples' minds that a parliamentary committee is not a fit means to judge alleged parliamentary misdemeanours. It needs an independent body - which, presumably, Elizabeth Filkin is supposed to be. Yet she is also treated with contempt - both by Mr Vaz and by Mr Sheldon.

It is particularly galling that this has happened under a (so-called) Labour administration, and that the "Downing Street spokesman" gives Mr Vaz a blanket assurance of support and regards the matter as closed. Clem Attlee wouldn't have tolerated it.
Fred Brooks
Redgrave, Suffolk
fred@redgrave.screaming.net

 There was something oddly familiar about Keith Vaz's attack on the "purveyors of lies and malice", a strange echo of Jonathan Aitken's boast that he would "cut out the cancer of bent and twisted journalism".
Harry Harmer
London
harryharmer@hotmail.com

 Keith Vaz and his political masters need to reflect deeply about the impression that will be gathered by the public over his refusal to cooperate.

Like so many other voters, I do not wish to be rid of the sleazy characters we associate with the previous government, merely to have them replaced with seemingly sleazy characters associated with this one.
Tom McMaster
Manchester
t.mcmaster@salford.ac.uk

 Having frustrated enquiries into eight further allegations, how is it that Keith Vaz can complain that "present procedures give too much latitude to the purveyors of lies and malice"?

Truth can silence the purveyors, but the Labour party's and Keith Vaz's silence leads to two conclusions: a cover-up is going on and the watchdog should be fitted with more and longer teeth.
Bob Holmes
Axbridge, Somerset
HOLMESR923@aol.com

fields.headline: Rod Liddle's diary
fields.standfirst: Do you know who I am?
fields.trailText: Do you know who I am?
fields.body:
A focus group, convened to provide information about the Today programme, was asked the question: what is the editor like?

It wasn't rhetorical. The marketing people were trying to find out how differently listeners perceived the "new" Today programme under my stewardship. The focus group decided that my predecessor was middle-aged, upper middle class, public school and decent. They described me in the following terms: "Thirty-something gay friend of Peter Mandelson. Thinks he's trendy but he isn't."

They were also asked: if the Today programme were a sort of food, what would it be? I think we were angel hair pasta with truffle oil and seared Jerusalem artichokes, whereas we used to be roast beef and Yorkshire pudding with a bowl of soup - Crosse and Blackwell, presumably, not that poncy Covent Garden stuff - to start.

Then they asked these baffled people what car we'd be. A people carrier was the answer, which suggests that the focus group participants were muddling their cultural signifiers.

That was nearly two years ago and there hasn't been much focus-group activity since then, which is disappointing for me, because as you can appreciate from the above, they're hilarious - but probably good news for the licence payer. I'm inexpert at the marketing side of things and it must be true that focus groups and the like provide a valuable service, otherwise they wouldn't be used. But I was always wary of them as a means of determining what programmes should be about. You ask people what they want to hear more of and invariably they say foreign affairs, serious policy issues, analysis, and I have the faint conviction that this is what they think they're meant to say. And they usually say they don't want to hear politicians arguing with each other.

And this brings us, ineluctably, to Keith Vaz. Most things lead back to Keith, for me, these days. He's become, in a sense, my irreducible core. (He nearly spoke to us the other morning. And then, suddenly, he didn't. Such a tease.) The Keith Vaz business is the stuff of "Westminster Village", as Alastair Campbell calls it, the fixation of an obsessed media but scarcely causing a ripple in the big world beyond. Focus on the issues, like unemployment and the economy, and forget about Keith, say the party managers. And forget about Wafic Said, too, and that tittle-tattle about Robin Cook. Nobody is really very interested.

Maybe they're right, the party managers, the focus groups; everybody seems to agree. In fact, I can remember the Conservatives saying much the same thing four years ago.

 Rod Liddle is editor of BBC Radio 4's Today programme. His column appears every Wednesday.

fields.headline: The madding crowd
fields.standfirst: Word of the week: Nutter
fields.trailText: It is said that Eskimos have a hundred words for snow. It might tell us something about our national character that the English language has almost as many words and phrases for madness - most of them flippant or facetious (no accident that it was PG Wodehouse who coined "loony-bin").
fields.body:
It is said that Eskimos have a hundred words for snow. It might tell us something about our national character that the English language has almost as many words and phrases for madness - most of them flippant or facetious (no accident that it was PG Wodehouse who coined "loony-bin").

A new government research survey worries over this. A poll of 16-24-year-olds published this week has found young people admitting to the casual use of "abusive" terms for the mentally ill. "Nutter" was the most popular, but they also confessed to "psycho", "schizo", "loon" and "mental". Implying an analogy, researchers note that most of them considered it wrong to use racist language.

Weeding speech of jocular words for "mental health problems" promises to be hard work. The terms identified by the report are a tiny sample from the lexicon. What about bonkers, barmy, barking, batty, dotty, potty, loopy, crazy, crackers? Not to speak of all those metaphorical phrases: off his head, not all there, off his rocker, round the bend, out to lunch, lost his marbles, off his trolley (a Victorian coinage, referring to a passenger falling off a trolley-bus as it rounds a curve) or out of his pram (a Neil Kinnock malapropism that has taken up residence in the language).

Even the official language of psychiatry passes easily into demotic usage. It is hard to be sure that "schizo" is simply abusive when "schizophrenic" is now a jokey word for "in two minds". "Paranoid" (especially in the rejoinder, "there's no need to be paranoid!") is rooted deep in everyday speech. Since the 1930s, "certifiable" - originally a word for the grim business of declaring a person legally insane - has been readily used of anybody with a madcap scheme. And there is a dark origin for "the men in white coats", said to be coming for any starry-eyed politician.

These words and phrases are on a gradient running all the way from idiosyncrasy to psychosis. "Nutter" is a prime example. It has always been close to "nuts", "nutty" (as a fruit-cake) and "nut-case", which are as likely to be affectionate as abusive. The first two meant amorous or fond ("he's nuts upon her") before they ever meant insane. "Nutter" itself, first recorded from the 1950s, has always meant either a deranged person or an engaging eccentric.

Such words can be used cruelly, but their plenitude also suggests some kind of delight (albeit satirical) in the varieties of human oddness. Perhaps too their frequency tells us of a half-conscious recognition with which the researchers would presumably concur: that none of us is any more immune from going nuts than from any other illness.

Not to speak of all those metaphorical phrases: off his head, not all there, off his rocker, round the bend, out to lunch, lost his marbles, off his trolley (a Victorian coinage, referring to a passenger falling off a trolley-bus as it rounds a curve) or out of his pram (a Neil Kinnock malapropism that has taken up residence in the language). Even the official language of psychiatry passes easily into demotic usage. It is hard to be sure that "schizo" is simply abusive when "schizophrenic" is now a jokey word for "in two minds". "Paranoid" (especially in the rejoinder, "there's no need to be paranoid!") is rooted deep in everyday speech. Since the 1930s, "certifiable" - originally a word for the grim business of declaring a person legally insane - has been readily used of anybody with a madcap scheme. And there is a dark origin for "the men in white coats", said to be coming for any starry-eyed politician. These words and phrases are on a gradient running all the way from idiosyncrasy to psychosis. "Nutter" is a prime example. It has always been close to "nuts", "nutty" (as a fruit-cake) and "nut-case", which are as likely to be affectionate as abusive. The first two meant amorous or fond ("he's nuts upon her") before they ever meant insane. "Nutter" itself, first recorded from the 1950s, has always meant either a deranged person or an engaging eccentric. Such words can be used cruelly, but their plenitude also suggests some kind of delight (albeit satirical) in the varieties of human oddness. Perhaps too their frequency tells us of a half-conscious recognition with which the researchers would presumably concur: that none of us is any more immune from going nuts than from any other illness.

webTitle: David who? An outsider has got Glyndebourne's top job.

fields.headline: David who?
fields.standfirst: An outsider has got Glyndebourne's top job. Does this mean the ruling dynasty want to take back control?
fields.trailText: An outsider has got Glyndebourne's top job. Does this mean the ruling dynasty want to take back control?
fields.body:
Nicholas Snowman's abrupt resignation from Glyndebourne last autumn introduced unexpected turbulence into what is usually seen as one of the most smoothly organised opera companies around. Whatever the reasons for his departure - and we are unlikely ever to know exactly what the breaking point was - the vacuum it left could easily have been destabilising. Snowman had taken over in 1998 as general director. It was a time of transition: having been at the helm since 1965, George Christie was in the process of passing the executive chairmanship of the company to his son Gus, while the music director Andrew Davis and the director of productions Graham Vick were due to depart in summer 2000.

As soon as the vacancy was known, the rumour mill went into overdrive. Numerous names were linked with the post, and reported sightings down in Sussex of distinguished musical administrators from both sides of the Atlantic only fuelled the speculation. But no firm favourites emerged, and when the announcement of the new general director was made on Monday, it turned out to be someone who had never been mentioned in gossip at all - David Pickard, who is currently chief executive of Britain's top period-instrument ensemble, the Orchestra of the Age of Enlighten ment.

The 40-year-old Pickard has been with the OAE since 1993, and has done a very good job there, steadily increasing the range and importance of the orchestra's activities. Before that he had worked in festival and opera administration: he was at Covent Garden in the mid-1980s, and ran the much lamented Kent Opera just before its Arts Council-induced demise in 1990. The OAE has worked regularly at Glyndebourne since 1989, so Pickard presumably knows how the place runs, but nevertheless he is not someone with a proven track record in an opera company of this stature; that alone makes him a surprise choice, and indicates a shift in thinking among the Christie dynasty about the future control of the opera house.

When Snowman took over from Anthony Whitworth Jones, he brought with him strong ideas about how he wanted the opera seasons at Glyndebourne to evolve; there was no doubt that he saw himself as much the artistic leader of the company as its head of administration. He was intent on expanding the repertoire, putting on much larger works - Verdi's Otello is scheduled for the coming season - and there was talk of staging The Mastersingers and The Trojans too, as well as commissioning new opera, and attracting a much wider international spectrum of performers. By the time he left many of his initial plans were in place, though all the longer-term ones have been unpicked since his departure, suggesting that he had been a little too robust in his attitude to the status quo. Glyndebourne is a conservative place, with a faithful audience that knows what it likes, and has the financial and social clout to make its feelings known. As an insider suggested to me, by making such radical plans, Snowman had played into the hands of those who had been suspicious of him from the start.

It would be surprising if, artistically at least, Pickard will be able to enjoy the same decision-making freedom his predecessor was allowed, however briefly, and he will not be expected to rock the boat as violently as Snowman evidently did. With George Christie still very much on the scene - he now has the title of president of Glyndebourne Productions - the likelihood is that the family will re-exert its influence over what is put on and who delivers it. Glyndebourne, after all, came into existence as a family enterprise, founded by George Christie's father John in the 1930s, just because he enjoyed opera in general and Mozart in particular. Though it has become ever more prestigious, it has never lost sight of that ethos; Pickard's role will be to keep the balance between those who hanker after the days when opera at Glyndebourne was an entertainment for a large extended family, and those who want to see it more at the cutting edge of the art form.

Running Glyndebourne has always been seen as a plum opera job, but in the future it may not be such an easy ride.
