webTitle: Poor Professor Higgins! Trevor Nunn on My Fair Lady

fields.headline: Poor Professor Higgins!
fields.standfirst: In George Bernard Shaw's original play, Eliza and Henry don't even get it together. No wonder My Fair Lady is miles better than Pygmalion
fields.trailText: In George Bernard Shaw's original play, Eliza and Henry don't even get it together. No wonder My Fair Lady is miles better than Pygmalion.
fields.body:
Occasionally we must admit that an adaptation into a new form can actually improve on a great original. There is a strong body of opinion that Verdi's Otello is better than Othello, Falstaff more coherent than The Merry Wives of Windsor, West Side Story more immediate and affecting than Romeo and Juliet. There is certainly a case for My Fair Lady to be part of this tradition, since it not only supersedes Pygmalion dramatically, but provides the work with an ending implied by but missing from the original play.

Shaw was almost two thirds through his writing lifetime when he hit the jackpot with Pygmalion. In the Roman poet Ovid's first treatment of this mythic tale, King Pygmalion of Cyprus, a sculptor in his spare time, creates a statue of his ideal woman, falls in love with it and, Aphrodite having granted his prayer for the figure to be brought to life as Galatea, marries her.

Anybody aware of Shaw's radical reputation in 1912 would have surely found it inexplicable that he had embarked upon his own dramatic adaptation. After all, a king fantasising about and possessing a love object of his own creation would seem to be unpromising material for a Fabian socialist and proponent of feminism.

Shaw's abiding obsession was with our language, with the inconsistencies of its spelling and pronunciation and the inadequacies of its alphabet and principles of punctuation. By turning his Pygmalion into a professor of phonetics, Shaw transformed the existing plot into a fable through which he could focus on some of his favourite targets: class, the inequalities of English society, snobbery. But inevitably, too, it made his "Pygmalion" - male fantasist figure Henry Higgins - into something like a self-portrait.

Shaw avoided any necessity for intervention by the gods: the metamorphosis in his play is accomplished by a girl from the gutter sloughing off her dialect and being taught pronunciation, social behaviour and self-confidence, achieving the status of a princess. But what of the other strand of Ovid's tale, the emotional relationship between Pygmalion, the creator, and Galatea, the creation, ending in marriage?

A close reading of Shaw's play reveals that his intention was indeed to create this emotional attachment. Uncharacteristically, he calls his comedy A Romance in Five Acts. The stream of hints in Pygmalion that Higgins will become emotionally attached to Eliza is constant, climaxing when, unable to cope with her departure - prompted by his failure to recognise her as a woman of feeling and sensibility - he searches for her. When he finds her, he blurts: "Get up and come home and don't be a fool."

Shaw gives Eliza a double triumph. She conquers fashionable London society, and she becomes independent of her teacher ("I'm not afraid of you and can do without you"). But Shaw is still a step away from finding an ending.

In early performances the actors actually refused to go along with Shaw's unresolved conclusion. In response to Higgins's final order for her to buy some gloves for him, Eliza had departed the play with, "Get them yourself"; but in performance Mrs Patrick Campbell was in the habit of returning as the curtain fell to enquire, "What size?" Moreover, as the company took their bows, Herbert Beerbohm Tree as Higgins would present his Eliza with a bouquet, before they posed together in what was unmistakably a wedding photograph tableau. Shaw allegedly disapproved but did not forbid, and their additions were allowed to continue.

Shaw was never very good at endings, but the last lines of the published version of Pygmalion in 1916 surely amount to his worst. Higgins tells his mother that Eliza will marry the vacuous and indolent Freddy Eynsford-Hill, and then laughs in repeated mockery at the stupidity of this arrangement - serving only to underline the problem that this outcome is not prepared for by the play, and that the consignment of his heroine to an unhappy, unintelligent and unworthy future leaves a sour taste.

The explanation for this conclusion has nothing to do with the lame contrivance of Shaw's Afterword, printed in 1916, in which he first denies that he means anything romantic by his use of the word "romance", and proceeds to detail a miserable, impecunious life of drudgery and dependence for Eliza. But this breathtakingly vindictive betrayal can be understood in relation to Shaw's real-life obsession with his leading actress.

Give Higgins and Eliza autobiographical identity as Shaw and his protegee Mrs Pat and all becomes clear: Shaw wanted his close relationship with her to continue, but didn't dare propose that it should have a sexual content. A shared life "for the fun of it" was as far as the "Irish pope" was prepared to go.

In between the first performance of the play in 1914 and the publication of the text in 1916, a momentous change had occurred in Shaw's private life. Mrs Pat had married a handsome, aristocratic and empty-headed young man called George Cornwallis-West, despite a flow of letters from GBS begging her not to. Shaw was clearly hurt and felt rejected by the actress he thought owed her fame to him. The 1916 ending and afterword are revealed as a private message willing Mrs Pat to a wretched life in a bad marriage.

Shaw again addressed the problem of how to resolve his play when he agreed to write a film script based on it for Gabriel Pascal. The movie ends with the brilliant invention of a despairing Higgins sitting alone, listening to his recording of Eliza's voice and becoming aware that the last sentence has been spoken live, because his pupil has returned. Shaw hinted that hands other than his had been involved in the screenplay. As he accepted his Oscar for writing it, he was asked about his view of the variant ending. "It's of no consequence," he replied. That's as near to a blessing as anybody could expect.

The ending of the 1938 film was adopted in its entirety by Alan Jay Lerner in My Fair Lady his brilliant adaptation of Pygmalion for the musical stage. But this was not his only improvement. Even leaving out of account the almost unperformable verbosity of some sections of Shaw's play, its repetitiveness and the long diversion investigating the financial circumstances of Eynsford-Hills, Pygmalion is more static than Lerner's adaptation and places the most intriguing and significant action offstage.

It's actually quite a shock to discover that Pygmalion contains no elocution lessons, no moment of celebration when Eliza has "got it", no visit to Ascot, no triumph at the ball, no return by Eliza to Covent Garden to discover that she passes unrecognised through the scenes of her past life, and no moment when we see her appalling father in his home territory, as a member of the "undeserving poor". So much of the world we assume Shaw created just isn't there.

Better still, Lerner searches out the possibilities of musical expression with unerring analytic accuracy, from Higgins's opening diatribe, through the first glorious celebration of Alfred Doolittle's fecklessness, Higgins's disparagement of female friendship, the celebration of Eliza's phonetic breakthrough on The Rain in Spain, and her glorious eruption of independence Without You. Perhaps most triumphantly, I've Grown Accustomed to Her Face dramatises the battle within Higgins and indeed the battle within Shaw, before resolving whether he will allow himself to feel or not.

But the real achievement of Lerner's adaptation is his insight that the story requires not one, not two, but three personal journeys. Doolittle is changed into a respectable member of the reviled middle classes; Eliza is changed into an new woman once her "guttersnipe" habits are expunged; but the third metamorphosis is of Professor Higgins, who is transformed finally and movingly from a man unable to express his feelings into a more complete emotional human being. Pygmalion is a collection of very brilliant theatrical and comic ideas, but My Fair Lady quite simply is a masterpiece.

 Trevor Nunn is artistic director of the National Theatre. My Fair Lady, directed by Nunn, is at the National Theatre, London SE1 (020-7452 3000), from tomorrow.

webTitle: Taff but not naff: Irish and Scottish writers are the toast of British theatre.

fields.headline: Taff but not naff
fields.standfirst: Irish and Scottish writers are the toast of British theatre. Now it is the turn of the Welsh.  Krishnendu Majumdar reports
fields.trailText: Irish and Scottish writers are the toast of British theatre. Now it is the turn of the Welsh. Krishnendu Majumdar reports.
fields.body:
How ironic that the Arts Council of England chose to announce an extra £100m in spending on theatre over the next three years on the set of a Welsh play, Art and Guff. Wales has often been the poor relation when it comes to showcasing new playwrights: whereas Scotland has the Traverse in Edinburgh and England the Royal Court in London, Wales has no similar institution to attract the energy of young voices.

Sgript Cymru, the new national writing company for Wales, and the producer of Art and Guff, was an antidote to this situation. After surviving a complicated birth last May, it has become the new focal point for Welsh writers who write in either language, and has a budget of £170,000 per year (though it receives £90,000 less than previously provided by the Arts Council of Wales). As well as producing Cath Tregenna's Art and Guff, which premiered at the Soho Theatre, London, Sgript Cymru was also behind the national tour of Gary Owen's Crazy Gary's Mobile Disco, which stopped off at London's Lyric Studio this week.

Wales seems to suffer in comparison with Ireland and Scotland when it comes to expressing its identity through theatre. New work from Ireland is everywhere, and the influence it exerts on British theatre can be traced back over 300 years - from Sheridan, Wilde and Synge to the likes of Sebastian Barry, Conor McPherson and Gary Mitchell. With runs in the West End and all over Britain, Irish and Scottish writing has now been legitimised. Wales has no visible canon, so the only way to create a history and theatrical identity for ourselves is through new writing. But why is new Welsh theatre so conspicuously absent from the mainstream?

Jack Bradley, literary manager of the National Theatre in London, says the strength of regional voices lies in "their inherent musicality - whether it be the hard east-coast demotic of David Mamet, the plangent, lyrical quality of Conor McPherson or the modern north London argot of Patrick Marber". Yet the Welsh use of English has traditionally been ridiculed - "look you, Boyo" language is somehow hard for English ears to take seriously.

Writer and director Ian Rowlands is in the vanguard of trying to create a national theatre for the Welsh language. In his latest play, Pacific, he writes, "We are the first and last colony," and dismisses reinvention "for it presupposes that we had been allowed to invent ourselves in the first place". He claims that the Welsh have only "survived in the way that England has wanted us to mutate. Now's the chance for us to invent and define ourselves for the first time."

Sgript Cymru artistic director Bethan Jones, who ran the Welsh-language new writing company Dalier Sylw for 10 years, suggests that Welsh-language writers stopped writing state-of-the-nation plays in the 1980s. "Welsh-language plays have moved on from the crisis of identity to plays about people, relationships and situations. Up until now those writers who wrote in English strained to find an authentic voice."

Some, though, still champion their Welshness. The lyrical, emotional writing of Ed Thomas is unashamedly "state of the nation". With the feted House of America, he made the theatrical pilgrimage to London, but found his last play, Gas Station Angel, less well received. Thomas's mercurial work subverted cliches and showed that Taff is no longer naff; the old stereotypes were transcended, and the way Welsh people defined themselves was taken in a new direction.

New Welsh work is no longer insular. Sgript Cymru is working with the UK's most accomplished touring company of new work, Paines Plough, to take Crazy Gary's Mobile Disco around the country. Gary Owen's remarkably confident first play peels away the cracked veneer of a small town - which just happens to be set in Wales. Audience reaction around Britain has been positive, although director Vicky Featherstone initially wondered how people outside Wales would respond. She says she wasn't just looking for a "Welsh" play, but for "contemporary work that hits the mark", adding: "Gary's work has an incredibly honest energy."

For Welsh theatre to truly thrive, we have to be comfortable with multiple Welsh identities rather than a single face. Simon Harris, associate director of Sgript Cymru, says, "I want to escape a climate where a play is thought to be saying 'this is Wales', with all the attendant pressure and incompleteness. Instead, we need to give rise to a range of new archetypes, fresh voices expressing the true pluralism and diversity of the country. Only then will we be creating a new mythology for ourselves."

Britain has always had the odd writer from the "first and last colony" who has escaped Wales for a wider stage. But now there is a resilient energy emanating from young Welsh writers who aren't hung up about who they are, but are more concerned with the quality of the stories they tell. It may be too soon to evaluate their worth, but their promise lies in the strength of the stories.

 Art and Guff is at the Soho Theatre, London W1 (020-7478 0100), until March 31, and at Chapter Arts, Cardiff (029-2030 4400), from April 4. Crazy Gary's Mobile Disco is at the Lyric Studio, London W6 (020-8741 2311), until April 7.

He claims that the Welsh have only "survived in the way that England has wanted us to mutate. Now's the chance for us to invent and define ourselves for the first time." Sgript Cymru artistic director Bethan Jones, who ran the Welsh-language new writing company Dalier Sylw for 10 years, suggests that Welsh-language writers stopped writing state-of-the-nation plays in the 1980s. "Welsh-language plays have moved on from the crisis of identity to plays about people, relationships and situations. Up until now those writers who wrote in English strained to find an authentic voice." Some, though, still champion their Welshness. The lyrical, emotional writing of Ed Thomas is unashamedly "state of the nation". With the feted House of America, he made the theatrical pilgrimage to London, but found his last play, Gas Station Angel, less well received. Thomas's mercurial work subverted cliches and showed that Taff is no longer naff; the old stereotypes were transcended, and the way Welsh people defined themselves was taken in a new direction. New Welsh work is no longer insular. Sgript Cymru is working with the UK's most accomplished touring company of new work, Paines Plough, to take Crazy Gary's Mobile Disco around the country. Gary Owen's remarkably confident first play peels away the cracked veneer of a small town - which just happens to be set in Wales. Audience reaction around Britain has been positive, although director Vicky Featherstone initially wondered how people outside Wales would respond. She says she wasn't just looking for a "Welsh" play, but for "contemporary work that hits the mark", adding: "Gary's work has an incredibly honest energy." For Welsh theatre to truly thrive, we have to be comfortable with multiple Welsh identities rather than a single face. Simon Harris, associate director of Sgript Cymru, says, "I want to escape a climate where a play is thought to be saying 'this is Wales', with all the attendant pressure and incompleteness. Instead, we need to give rise to a range of new archetypes, fresh voices expressing the true pluralism and diversity of the country. Only then will we be creating a new mythology for ourselves." Britain has always had the odd writer from the "first and last colony" who has escaped Wales for a wider stage. But now there is a resilient energy emanating from young Welsh writers who aren't hung up about who they are, but are more concerned with the quality of the stories they tell. It may be too soon to evaluate their worth, but their promise lies in the strength of the stories.  Art and Guff is at the Soho Theatre, London W1 (020-7478 0100), until March 31, and at Chapter Arts, Cardiff (029-2030 4400), from April 4. webTitle: Fiddler in the fast lane: Charlotte Higgins talks to Vadim Repin.

fields.headline: Fiddler in the fast lane
fields.standfirst: Violinist Vadim Repin went from child prodigy in Siberia to Porsche-driving playboy in Monaco.  Charlotte Higgins  talks to an astounding musician
fields.trailText: Violinist Vadim Repin went from child prodigy in Siberia to Porsche-driving playboy in Monaco. Charlotte Higgins talks to an astounding musician.
fields.body:
Vadim Repin - moon-faced, suave - is puffing contentedly on a Cuban cigar in the Hotel de Russie, Rome. Film stars stay here now, but it was once the holiday home of tsars and tsarinas, the violinist says. He has come a long way since his childhood in Novosibirsk.

Repin is not the only prodigy to emerge from that Siberian city. He grew up sharing a teacher with his friend Maxim Vengerov. There is video footage of the two - Vengerov in a frilly shirt, Repin distinctly puddingy - touring the west as teenagers with pianist Evgeny Kissin in the mid-1980s. "Maxim's presence did a lot of good for me, and vice versa," says Repin. "Being dramatically better than everybody else usually slows you down. You can think too much of yourself and become complacent. But knowing that nearby there is someone who is so wonderful makes you work hard."

It is fortunate, perhaps especially for Repin, that the two are greatly different players. Vengerov, with his Charlie Chaplin grin and mobile, comic face, is a showman. Repin's approach is less obvious. He doesn't take your breath away, as Vengerov does, but there is more of the poet in him: he plays like someone who has lived a little. The two share an unimpeachable technique, imparted by their teacher, Zhakar Bron.

"He is an extraordinary teacher," says Repin. "He can explain points clearly, and has an extraordinary understanding of the fundamentals of violin playing. At the same time, he is a remarkable player. This combination is extremely rare."

An important part of Bron's regime, says Repin, was to programme regular performances so his pupils would develop a taste for the concert platform early. "The children were able to understand what the profession is all about. It's not about practising hard all the time - it's about creating something on stage, about having a relationship with the public." But wasn't that a huge pressure? "It was a pressure, but it meant that, from the beginning, I understood the goal of my work. You cannot expect a child to practise for five or six hours a day unless she or he understands the goal - the emotions you get back when you perform."

Repin, 29, started studying with Bron at five and a half, having learnt the basics for six months at a local music school; the regime of six hours' practice a day started when he was 10. "It was, of course, a huge effort. But it paid off," he says. "By the time I was 10 I was performing in concerts abroad. It was incredible. I felt like an artist already. It was like a drug. It's still like a drug."

But still, doesn't all this talk of "work" and "profession" sound a little hard when applied to tiny children? "When I go to the US, say, I meet parents who tell me about their musical children, but they are worried they won't succeed and say they should study something else and continue with music afterwards if they want to.

"In Russia this attitude would never exist. There, once you decide that you want to do music it becomes your goal, the purpose of your life. That attitude is hard - but it is better to do one thing with all your effort."

In fact, it was Repin's mother, a hospital sister who still lives in Novosibirsk, who decided his destiny for him. "She saw how I played with musical toys when I was a baby; how I picked out tunes quickly. It was her idea that I should become a musician. It became her obsession."

And his. Repin tells how, cycling back home from a rehearsal when he was in his teens, he fell asleep during a raging storm and came a cropper against a lamppost. A broken collarbone prevented him from playing for three months. "Yes, I had been practising too hard," he concedes.

Repin can't imagine doing anything but music - "I think about it last thing at night and when I wake up in the morning." Like many of his compatriots he cut his teeth on Russian music: he recorded Prokofiev's Violin Concerto No 2 and Shostakovich's Violin Concerto No 1 in 1995, moving on to performing Brahms and Mozart later - with the help and advice of Yehudi Menuhin ("a very beautiful and inspiring man, a sort of icon to me; a great example of humanism"). He calls Shostakovich's First Violin Concerto "one of the three absolute giants, along with the Beethoven and Brahms concertos. It is one of those rare pieces that makes you forget about everything as soon as you play it. Shostakovich to me is unique, in the sense that he was a writer of history as much as of music."

The concerto had a troubled birth. It was composed in 1948 for Russian violinist David Oistrakh, but the premiere was delayed until 1955, when Stalin was safely dead. It's a disturbing, intense, darkly witty piece of work. Does being Russian aid Repin's understanding of this writer of history? "It helps that I can talk to Mstislav Rostropovich, who knew Shostakovich. It helps that I am Russian. But, on the other hand, musicians are like actors. If you perform a piece, you have to dedicate yourself to its character as an actor would a part. It is a question of sensitivity."

Nowadays Repin's punishing regime is less to do with six hours' practice a day than the endless trudge from city to city and country to country. He is often accompanied by his almost ludicrously chic girlfriend. Home, for just three or four days a month, is Monaco. "It is always brilliant weather. I can escape there. There is always something interesting going on - a chess tournament, or Formula One, or an exhibition."

He used to drive a Porsche in Monaco, which gave him a reputation as a bit of a playboy. "When I was growing up we never had a car," he says. "I always dreamed of having something fast and sporty. So when I earned some money I bought a second-hand Porsche. But it was a short-lived pleasure. Once you've felt it, you've felt it. So I sold it. It is a sacred dream for all violinists to buy a beautiful violin so, although I cannot say I'm the cleverest person financially, I'm trying not to blow everything I earn." He smiles his charming smile, and lights another cigar.

 Vadim Repin performs the Brahms Double Concerto with Mischa Maisky and the Royal Concertgebouw Orchestra under Riccardo Chailly on Monday at the Royal Festival Hall, London SE1 (020-7960 4242). His latest disc, of music by Bartok, Strauss and Stravinsky, is out on Erato.

fields.headline: Clinton may face pardons trial
fields.standfirst:
Prosecutor to investigate all last-minute clemency cases
Special report: George Bush's America
fields.trailText: Prosecutor to investigate all last-minute clemency cases.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's hopes that the furore over his presidential pardons might subside were blown apart yesterday when the US justice department allowed a New York federal prosecutor to begin a criminal investigation of all 177 last-minute clemency cases.

The huge expansion of the inquiry into the pardons and commutations issued by Mr Clinton in his last hours in the White House means that the former president, members of his family and his associates could potentially face criminal charges if prosecutors find evidence that any of the pardons involved offers of cash or other favours.

Until yesterday, the New York prosecutor, Mary Jo White, had been examining only three high profile pardons, those of the fugitive financier Marc Rich, a case involving four Hasidic Jews convicted of fraud, and an allegation that Roger Clinton, the former president's half-brother, received up to $200,000 for helping a Texas man to win a pardon.

The decision by the new US attorney general, John Ashcroft, to let Ms White loose on all 177 pardons potentially transforms the argument about the decisions that Mr Clinton made on January 20. Until now, he as suffered nothing worse than a personal public relations catastrophe. But Ms White's investigation may lead to criminal charges against him, his wife Hillary, their close relatives and some of their oldest confidants.

"She is going to be doing the investigation of all of these cases," a justice department official told the Los Angeles Times yesterday, which broke the story.

"It is yet to be decided if she will refer some evidence to other jurisdictions for prosecutions, if that develops."

At the heart of the investigation will be the pardons which emerged from the intensive lobbying by friends and colleagues of the Clintons, and which circumvented the traditional procedures by which pardon candidates have their cases reviewed by justice department legal officials.

Although previous presidents issued many more pardons than Mr Clinton did, and although some of his predecessors also issued "stealth pardons" in highly suspect circumstances, he appears to be unique in issuing so many last-minute pardons on the basis of personal connections, and without going through the normal procedures.

So far the pre-eminent examples of this type were the pardons of Mr Rich and his business partner Pincus Green.

More than 30 of the pardons and commutations he issued on his last day were not reviewed by the justice department's pardon attorneys, a process which normally takes between 18 and 24 months and is designed to provide a full assessment of the facts and issues involved in a possible act of clemency.

Most of the cases that escaped such scrutiny were advocated by people close to Mr Clinton, including his brother-in-law Hugh Rodham, his close friend Harry Thomason, and major Democratic political donors, such as Beth Dozoretz and Mr Rich's former wife, Denise.

One of the most prominent of the new cases Ms White is examining is the early release from prison of a convicted Los Angeles drug dealer, Carlos Vignali, whose case was pressed by several prominent local LA officials as well as by Mr Rodham, who was paid $200,000 by Mr Vignali's father, Horacio, for his help. Mr Rodham subsequently returned the money.

The decision by Mr Ashcroft - who until last November was a conservative Republican senator - to refer all the cases to Ms White rather than use his power to appoint a special prosecutor to look into them gives the Bush administration the best of both worlds: it takes the pardons furore out of the immediate headlines, a development for which the White House has been pressing Republican congressional leaders, but it preserves the possibility that the Clintons and their friends may eventually end up in court.

Ms White, a Clinton appointee, will be able to decide whether to prosecute any cases herself or refer them to federal prosecutors in other parts of the US.

fields.headline: Radio pick of the day
fields.trailText: A Kosovo Homecoming | The Duvet Lady | High Resolution
fields.body:
Just a year ago Emma Rippon presented the second installment of A Kosovo Homecoming (11.0am, Radio 4), in which she tracked the return of Iliriana Kacaniku to the divided town of Mitrovica. Iliriana, of Albanian descent, discovered then that her old flat was in the heart of the enclave established by Nato troops for the town's threatened Serbs. Things have barely improved. Few people have a dependable income, electricity and water supplies are erratic, and ethnic murders continue.

Billie Whitelaw gives another astonishing performance in The Duvet Lady (2.15pm, Radio 4), written by Peter Tinniswood to draw on her quite special talent as a solo performer. The drama centres on Edna, a chirpy little creature safely tucked in her armchair in the warmth and comfort of her duvet. She recalls the balmy days of her youth when she was a star tennis player and her beauty brought young men (and old) swarming around her.

Adam Hart-Davis launches a series recalling past triumphs of science and technology. The first tale of High Resolution (9.0pm, Radio 4) is that of the five successive Eddystone lighthouses, which have alerted mariners to the Cornish coastline for 300 years. Henry Winstanley built the first two from timber, his second falling victim in 1703 to the greatest storm in British history. The fourth was John Smeaton's technological marvel of 1759 - lovingly preserved to this day.

fields.headline: The genuine article
fields.trailText: The Art Of Crime | The Men Who Changed Football
fields.body:
In the final part of The Art Of Crime (C4), a pair of conmen reflected on their chequered careers. Neither liked the term "conman". "It's a horrible word", complained Daniel Riordan, who had spent 20 years robbing gullible high street businesses by pretending to be an auditor sent from head office. Tony McManus, an art dealer who specialised in fakes, preferred to think of his activities as a form of psychological warfare, in which he earned his success by outsmarting his customers.

Riordan's yarns about legging it out of back doors and fire escapes with used notes fluttering from his pockets typecast him as a simple scam-artist prone to acting on the spur of the moment. "I've got this sense about me," he admitted. "I can look at someone and go, 'ooh, I can do them'." When he was arrested for the last time, after becoming a regular star of Crimewatch and trying to stave off the inevitable by getting all his mates to ring up the programme to give false information about his whereabouts, the scene had the air of an Ealing comedy. "It was all over," he confessed. "It was like, 'let's run the credits'."

But if Riordan was merely a low-life opportunist, Tony McManus was a subtler and more intriguing case. Although he admitted he had no moral qualms about deceiving his clients, and thought that anybody stupid enough to be taken in by him deserved everything they got (or rather, lost), it was almost possible to see what he meant when he claimed, regarding some of his activities, "that to me is business, that's not crime".

One of his craftier ploys was to sell a customer a fake painting, guaranteeing in writing to buy it back from them 12 months hence for more than they'd paid for it. As he pointed out, this was a better offer than you'd get from your bank manager. He'd be as good as his word, then sell the painting on to another customer at a price still further inflated. This would keep his cash flow going and increase the perceived value of the painting. Was he committing a worse crime than selling somebody an unsuitable and over-priced pension, or an endowment mortgage which failed to live up to the promises originally made for it? If hustlers from the financial services industry were hauled out from behind the façade of respectability of their fancily titled City firms, identified as conmen and put on trial, the public might find that their savings suddenly experienced a dramatic increase in value.

McManus also exploited the snobbery within the art world, where customers pretend to know more than they do, and might as well walk into a gallery with a flashing light on their head saying "Mug". When they eventually discover they've bought a house-full of fakes, they feel too humiliated to go to the police. Displaying an infallible instinct for human weakness, McManus later diversified into the wine trade. Just before the wedding of Charles and Diana, he bought a job lot of wine - "it was grotesque, you would not have put it on your chips" - then stuck Royal Wedding commemorative labels on it and increased the price tenfold. The stuff sold by the skipload, and the real beauty of the scheme was that hardly anybody opened the bottles for fear of destroying their souvenir value. It was enough to make you contemplate a life of crime, almost.

Interestingly, The Art Of Crime was narrated by Paul McGann, who also supplied the voice-over for The Men Who Changed Football (BBC2). This was a detailed if slightly laborious account of the way a cluster of thrusting entrepreneurs seized control of several key football clubs in the 1980s, and transformed a sport crippled by hooliganism, croneyism and under-investment into the cash landslide it is today. McGann's tone was identical across both programmes, whether he was describing the way Daniel Riordan nicked 13 grand from the safe at Pizza Hut in Scarborough or recounting how Irving Scholar devised the brilliant wheeze of turning Tottenham Hotspur into a high-profile marketing brand. We heard how Ken Bates bought Chealsea for £1 and indeed at the point when the football film featured a walk-on appearance by Robert Maxwell, it became difficult to remember which programme was which.

Just before the wedding of Charles and Diana, he bought a job lot of wine - "it was grotesque, you would not have put it on your chips" - then stuck Royal Wedding commemorative labels on it and increased the price tenfold. The stuff sold by the skipload, and the real beauty of the scheme was that hardly anybody opened the bottles for fear of destroying their souvenir value. It was enough to make you contemplate a life of crime, almost. Interestingly, The Art Of Crime was narrated by Paul McGann, who also supplied the voice-over for The Men Who Changed Football (BBC2). This was a detailed if slightly laborious account of the way a cluster of thrusting entrepreneurs seized control of several key football clubs in the 1980s, and transformed a sport crippled by hooliganism, croneyism and under-investment into the cash landslide it is today. McGann's tone was identical across both programmes, whether he was describing the way Daniel Riordan nicked 13 grand from the safe at Pizza Hut in Scarborough or recounting how Irving Scholar devised the brilliant wheeze of turning Tottenham Hotspur into a high-profile marketing brand. We heard how Ken Bates bought Chealsea for £1 and indeed at the point when the football film featured a walk-on appearance by Robert Maxwell, it became difficult to remember which programme was which.

webTitle: Sketch: Doomed beasts of Toryism await the cull.

fields.headline: Doomed beasts of Toryism await the cull
fields.trailText: I love New Labour jargon. The point is that nobody who uses it actually listens to it.
fields.body:
I love New Labour jargon. The point is that nobody who uses it actually listens to it. So yesterday during health questions Yvette Cooper, a junior minister, solemnly announced: "We are rolling out free fruit in primary schools."

Minutes later, Patrick Nicholls, the Tory MP for Teignbridge, rose superbly from his seat. He was clad in an aggressive chalk stripe suit (the stripe goes all the way through him, or so one of his colleagues assures me.) He wanted to talk about the threat to the British holiday trade caused by the foot and mouth crisis. Sadly, something went wrong.

"In view," he said, "of the massive damage caused to the Toryism industry -"

So that's the problem. That's what's going on! Toryism is in crisis. Every day brings more grim news from round the country. Party membership now lower than at any time since the first world war. William Hague's poll ratings worse than Nero's! There is near panic on the continent, where rightwing leaders are terri fied that the infection will spread across the Channel.

Tory agents are in tears. For decades many of them have built up superb grazing herds of party members. Admittedly these were hardly breeding herds - the average age is about 67 - but they were fine, pure-bred, bull-headed animals, bright-eyed, glossy-skinned, and festooned with blue best of show rosettes.

Now, amid the hopes and dreams which lie shattered in the mud, they are marked for the abattoir and the incinerator. Do these huge but docile beasts realise the fate that is in store? Or will they rattle down country lanes to the polls, perhaps only dimly perceiving what waits for them at the very end?

Possibly the army will be called out. Marksmen will halt the spread of the illness by killing Tories one by one in the fields. They'll have to aim high, since those tweed suits are thought to be bullet-proof.

Some have miraculously survived. Sir Edward Heath, Old Teddy, stomped slowly into the Chamber as if across a sodden meadow. He had a bewildered look, perhaps asking "where am I? What is this place? Shouldn't someone put me out of my misery?" He flumped down on the green bench, like an old bull in his favourite field, and then fell fast asleep.

A few young Tory rams tried to justify their continued existence. John Redwood wanted to know why Keith Vaz had been declared innocent, when the report into his conduct merely records that he had refused to provide information about his conduct. This is like a man on a criminal charge being acquitted simply because he refuses to say where he was at the time. But special rules seem to apply to politicians.

My Tory chum received an urgent message on his bleeper saying that Michael Portillo was about to speak on the Budget, and would MPs be good enough to go to the chamber and listen?

There was but a sprinkling of Tories there to hear their possible next leader. These included some of the party's noisiest barrack room lawyers - Michael Fabricant and John Bercow for two - who were once advised by a party elder, "remember to throw the grenade, and not the pin".

But there were few others. As Mr Portillo rose, just 13 backbenchers out of the 165 Tory MPs were there to listen to him.

After a quarter of an hour, the figure had rocketed to 17 backbenchers. It was a good, scornful speech, and caused Gordon Brown to look extremely grumpy.

But almost nobody was there. Had the cull begun? The unspoken fear is that the entire Tory party may have to be eradicated just to end this dreadful crisis.

webTitle: Nude children on show in MPs' exhibition

fields.headline: Nude children on show in MPs' exhibition
fields.trailText: It is certainly one art exhibition that will not be raided by officers from Scotland Yard's obscene publications unit.
fields.body:
It is certainly one art exhibition that will not be raided by officers from Scotland Yard's obscene publications unit.

The pictures which went on display yesterday might be as explicit as those at the Saatchi gallery, currently under threat of prosecution for indecency, but the chances must be slim that the Metropolitan police will launch a similar raid of the MPs' annual photo exhibition which opened yesterday.

If they did, they would have to start by questioning Lord Healey, the former Labour chancellor and foreign secretary, about his travel photograph, Boy In Peking, which shows a little boy eating an ice cream with his penis hanging out of his trousers. Then they might have to take in for questioning Jon Owen Jones, the Labour MP for Cardiff Central, and a government whip, for his picture of the back of a naked young girl sitting on a plastic tricycle.

Both feature among the 100 photographs on display in the House of Commons upper waiting hall, in an exhibition officially opened yesterday by the Speaker, Michael Martin.

They appear alongside the photographs of Tory MP Gerald Howarth, who, in an attack on Monday on the Saatchi pictures by the American photographer Tierney Gearon of her children, fulminated against "the intellectual elite who think it frightfully clever to masquerade such offerings as art". Mr Howarth's offerings include 10 Para on Exercise, Salisbury Plain.

Austin Mitchell, MP and leader of the parliamentary photographic group, was last night left wondering if they would be raided next: "Should we be expecting a raid any minute?" he asked. "The whole Saatchi thing is ridiculous. There can't be a prohibition against showing natural pic tures of children. It would be barmy if they prosecute the art gallery. If they go down, then we should go down as well.

"I am not going go to Lord Healey and say to him: 'Here boy, you've got to take your pictures down.' As it happens, I have got some pictures of my grandchildren naked on my desk here."

webTitle: Rugby:French outbreak threatens Six Nations and Heineken Cup

fields.headline: French outbreak threatens Six Nations and Heineken Cup
fields.standfirst: Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: The logistical nightmare of the Six Nations championship was no closer to a resolution last night, with the chances of the tournament being completed this season receding fast despite an English suggestion that postponed matches could be played at neutral venues.
fields.body:
The logistical nightmare of the Six Nations championship was no closer to a resolution last night, with the chances of the tournament being completed this season receding fast despite an English suggestion that postponed matches could be played at neutral venues.

With foot and mouth now confirmed in France, Saturday's game in Paris against Wales is still on but doubts are being expressed about the Heineken Cup semi-final between Munster and Stade Français, scheduled for Lille next month.

Most of the Munster team are Ireland squad regulars and, if the Irish government sticks to its 30-day quarantine for countries where the disease has been reported, rearranging Ireland's matches against England and Scotland will have to be done with the Munster men's commitments in mind.

The Six Nations committee, in a telephone conference, has so far rejected English calls to reschedule their Dublin game, postponed from March 24, to late May, sticking to the original provisional date of May 5 which clashes with important domestic English fixtures.

The Rugby Football Union's chief executive Francis Baron described the decision as "stupid", saying there was no realistic chance of foot and mouth being contained swiftly enough, but just about every other contingency plan also now looks fatally flawed.

The RFU, for instance, tried to persuade European Rugby Cup Ltd that moving the Heineken Cup final back a week from May 19 to May 26 might suit all concerned, only for French TV to object to any change. The other hope lies in finding neutral city venues in continental Europe such as Paris or Rome, but again the Irish government would have to weaken its stance significantly to make that idea fly.

Baron and the other home unions, though, are desperate to play the games somehow, if only for commercial reasons. Wales estimate they will lose as much as £6m in ticket, sponsorship and TV revenue if the home game with Ireland fails to go ahead.

"The danger is the championship won't be completed, but we believe it is essential we do so for the health of rugby in the northern hemisphere. That's why we've got to be creative," said Baron, conceding that a doubt hangs over England's home game with France on April 7. "Clearly the news today is not good and we're keeping our fingers crossed."

The RFU has started to rearrange Premiership fixtures for March 24 to fill the void left by the Irish postponement.

Meanwhile English officials have lodged a bid to host the 2007 World Cup and are also advocating the introduction of promotion and relegation to the existing Six Nations, to help boost the game in Europe.

That would involve setting up a second tier of nations including Spain, Romania, Portugal and the Netherlands. "We are anxious to say to the Six Nations committee that we have the best competition in the world," said the RFU's management board chairman Brian Baister. "At the moment it is focused at the top on who will win the championship. Imagine what sort of competition it would be if it were also focused on the bottom in terms of promotion and relegation."

fields.headline: British horses face worldwide ban
fields.standfirst:
Foot and mouth crisis

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: British racehorses face a possible worldwide ban as a result of the foot and mouth crisis.
fields.body:
British racehorses face a possible worldwide ban as a result of the foot and mouth crisis.

Yesterday Australia announced an indefinite halt on the importation of horses from Britain and Ireland. The move could have major implications for Britain and Ireland's multimillion-pound stud industries as it threatens the practice of shuttling stallions between the northern and southern hemispheres.

In a further setback for racing, Germany signalled that this week it would follow Australia's lead. That would stop horses from stables in the British Isles competing in German races.

The Direktorium (German Jockey Club) also announced that it would prefer German horses not to compete in Britain. Although four horses are due to run in the Winter Derby at Lingfield on Saturday, it now seems unlikely that they will travel.

"We cannot forbid them to go, but we can certainly put pressure on them as we understand that, within the next two days, a total ban will be imposed on the importation from Britain to Germany of all animals, including racehorses," said Rudiger Schmanns of the Direktorium.

France is now the only major racing country in Europe allowing its horses to compete in Britain but even this was called into question yesterday after the first confirmed case of foot and mouth across the Channel. However, the French authorities are hopeful that racing can continue there.

"There are two departements where racing is not allowed; one is Mayenne and the other is Orne. Racing is continuing elsewhere for the time being. There are no restrictions on horses travelling between England and France as long as disinfection takes place," said Dr Roland Devolz, France Galop's chief veterinary officer.

Meanwhile, Cheltenham is expected to announce new dates for the Cheltenham Festival today. It will be held on either April 17-19 or 24-26.

Betting-shop punters saw Istabraq win the Champion Hurdle for a fourth successive time yesterday - but only in a computer-generated "virtual race". The novel idea was provided by the Racing Post.

webTitle: Princess Anne in court for speeding

fields.headline: 'Escort' leads 93mph Anne to court
fields.trailText: For most drivers doing 93mph on a 70mph dual carriageway the presence of a police car on one's tail, blue lights flashing, would convey an unambiguous message. But then the Princess Royal is hardly most drivers.
fields.body:
For most drivers doing 93mph on a 70mph dual carriageway the presence of a police car on one's tail, blue lights flashing, would convey an unambiguous message. But then the Princess Royal is hardly most drivers.

When she spotted the police car while driving her Bentley on the A417 outside Gloucester on August 27 last year she assumed that, as on so many occasions in the past, it had come to escort her to an engagement at a nearby agricultural college - and so she accelerated into its view.

But yesterday Cheltenham magistrates fined the princess £400 with £30 costs and gave her five points on her licence after she pleaded guilty by post to the offence.

Graham Sacker, chairman of the court, said the size of the fine reflected the fact that the princess was "a person of high means".

Sheila Bowden, prosecuting, told the court how officers on a bridge overlooking the road saw the princess's car following a line of slow-moving traffic from the Air Balloon pub at Birdlip near Brockworth. "The Bentley then moved into the outside lane of the dual carriageway and sped forward," she said. "The officers formed the opinion that she was speeding, checked her speed, and it registered at 93mph."

Describing the princess's postal testimony, court clerk Kim Edge said she had been "on her way to an official engagement at Hartpury college .. she saw the police car and believed it was waiting to escort her on her journey. She accelerated from behind the traffic in front of her to a clear part of the road so the officers could see her.

"The police car then went on to the A417 and followed her. The car's blue lights flashed briefly, and she believed that was a signal acknowledging they were escorting her."

Had she been under escort, the princess would have been exempt from speeding offences. But in the circumstances, a spokeswoman for Buckingham Palace said yesterday, "the princess accepts that she is subject to the normal rule of law and she will be paying her fine accordingly."

Princess Anne was given a written warning for speeding on the M1 in 1972, and fined £40 for doing 96mph on the same road five years later. In 1990 she was fined £150 and banned from driving for a month after pleading guilty to two speeding offences before magistrates at Stow-on-the-Wold, Gloucestershire.

fields.headline: Deaths scare for arthritis drug
fields.trailText: Thousands of arthritis sufferers are to be issued with new warnings over potential lethal side-effects from a powerful new drug which might be implicated in the deaths of nine people from liver failure.
fields.body:
Thousands of arthritis sufferers are to be issued with new warnings over potential lethal side-effects from a powerful new drug which might be implicated in the deaths of nine people from liver failure.

Officials monitoring the safety of medicines in Europe and Britain have told doctors to strengthen checks on patients treated with Arava, used to combat the most severe forms of rheumatoid arthritis, estimated to affect 600,000 people in Britain.

Only specialist doctors based in hospitals are allowed to prescribe the drug, taken in tablet form and containing a new chemical known as leflunomide. All patients receiving the therapy must be told of the risk of liver injury before startingtreatment.

webTitle: Seven year jail sentence for internet stalker

fields.headline: Seven year jail sentence for internet stalker
fields.trailText: A cyber-stalker who conducted a campaign against a young woman by setting up a website which invited strangers to rape and abuse her was yesterday jailed for seven-and-a-half years.
fields.body:
A cyber-stalker who conducted a campaign against a young woman by setting up a website which invited strangers to rape and abuse her was yesterday jailed for seven-and-a-half years.

Donald Ridley, 37, from Poole, Dorset, pleaded guilty to 25 offences relating to "internet stalking" and child pornography at Bournemouth crown court.

The court heard how Ridley, who had met the woman six years ago, sent her a Valen tine's card when she was 17. At one point his victim was receiving around 30 emails a day from people who had seen the website, and a number even turned up at her home, the court heard.

Detective Constable Rupert Evernden, from Dorset police's vice squad, said: "The victim started getting emails from people trying to contact her - that is how we first became aware of it."

Ridley was finally caught after officers raided his home as part of a separate investigation into child pornography.

webTitle: NHS will pay for nicotine patches

fields.headline: NHS will pay for nicotine patches
fields.trailText: Smokers desperate to kick the habit received a boost last night when the government announced that it would make nicotine replacement therapies available on NHS prescription.
fields.body:
Smokers desperate to kick the habit received a boost last night when the government announced that it would make nicotine replacement therapies available on NHS prescription.

The move, which coincides with No Smoking Day today, was welcomed by anti-smoking campaigners, who said it would help all smokers but especially those who are unemployed or on low incomes.

By the end of next month GPs will be able to prescribe products such as nicotine patches, gum and inhalers which previously had to be bought from pharmacies. Certain therapies - including some patches, lozenges and gums - will also be on general sale in supermarkets and other shops.

The public health minister, Yvette Cooper, said: "We know that 70% of smokers want to give up, and nicotine replacement therapy is an effective treatment that doubles rates for people giving up. Making it available on prescription will ensure the widest possible availability to all smokers."

On making some nicotine replacement therapies available for general sale, she said: "It is absurd that people can buy cigarettes in supermarkets and newsagents but cannot buy patches or gums that they want to help them give up."

The Department of Health has estimated the cost of prescribing the nicotine replacement therapies at between £10m and £40m, depending on how many people take them up. About 13m adults in the UK smoke cigarettes.

But campaigners are sure that the new policy makes sound economic sense. There are 120,000 smoking-related deaths each year and smoking remains the UK's biggest single cause of premature death and ill health. It causes 30% of cancer deaths (and 82% of lung cancer deaths), 25% of heart disease deaths and 83% of deaths from bronchitis and emphysema.

A spokesman for the pressure group Action on Smoking and Health said last night: "We have campaigned for years for this. It is a way of treating 50 diseases associated with smoking before they happen. It has been a stupid anachronism that these therapies, which are so effective, are not available on the NHS."

Campaigners point out that smoking is heavily concentrated in areas of deprivation, among those on a low income and the unemployed, who might not try to give up if they had to pay for treatments.

webTitle: Cable, satellite and digital pick of the day.

fields.headline: Cable, satellite and digital pick of the day
fields.trailText: Lawrence of Arabia | Ravenous | Black Cat, White Cat | The Gingerbread Man | Live Tennis
fields.body:
Films

Lawrence Of Arabia (David Lean, 1962) 10pm, FilmFour
Lean's biopic of the tortured soul that was TE Lawrence is a majestic vision, though in all its three-and-a-half hours it says little about the man who led the Arabs against the Turks in a particularly bloody theatre of the first world war. Peter O'Toole seized the chance to become a star when Albert Finney turned down the role, and while the intensity of his gaze hints at the unstable nature of Lawrence, it's a distant gaze, Robert Bolt's script revealing little of the inner workings. Fine performances from Alec Guinness as the ambivalent Prince Feisal and Omar Sharif; but the real star, as in that later wartime romance The English Patient, is the desert itself, magnificently photographed by Freddie Young, who won an Oscar, along with Lean and composer Maurice Jarre.

Ravenous (Antonia Bird, 1999) 10.15pm, Sky MovieMax
Forget Ridley Scott's toothless Hannibal: for a really unspeakable portrait of murderous cannibalism, this is the genuine article. Director Bird has fashioned a hilarious, bloody, gothic Western in which a small band of soldiers at a remote, snowy army outpost in the high Nevadas, circa 1847, are picked off by Robert Carlyle's demonic Colquhoun. It's a superb portrait of a gleeful maneater, with Guy Pearce as the horrified Captain Boyd, headed for a final showdown.

Black Cat, White Cat (Emir Kusturica, 1998) 1.15am, Sky Premier
Kusturica's exuberant, anarchic celebration of gypsy culture won him a silver lion for best direction at the Venice festival. Set on the banks of the Danube, it's a wild and not wholly comprehensible story encompassing crime, clan rivalry, arranged marriages and, of course, true love. But the plot's not that important: the fun is in the zesty, Felliniesque parade of extraordinary characters and animals: the geese that seem to wander everywhere, and the two cats of the title, the most unlikely wedding witnesses.

The Gingerbread Man (Robert Altman, 1998) 3.25am, Sky Premier
An intriguing if flawed combination of director Altman and writer John Grisham. Adapted from one of the latter's stories, it stars a miscast Kenneth Branagh as Deep South lawyer Rick Magruder, who gets into bed with, and heavily into the case of, Embeth Davidtz's Mallory: a woman with an unstable dad (Robert Duvall) threatening her life. With its primal elements and neurotic characters, Altman's film tries to inject a little chaos theory into the courtroom-orderly Grisham, but the suspense goes missing.
Paul Howlett

Sport

Live Tennis 8pm, British Eurosport
The Tennis Masters Series tournament in Indian Wells is prestigious - and lucrative - enough to attract the world's best players and by now, quarter-final day in the women's event, that's all that should be left. Martina Hingis is looking for her third consecutive singles title and is helped by a draw that kept her apart from both Williams sisters and Lindsay Davenport until the final.
Simon Burnton

webTitle: Exports show regions tied to euro zone

fields.headline: Exports show regions tied to euro zone
fields.standfirst: Special report: economic and monetary union
fields.trailText: The government yesterday published figures showing the heavy dependence of Britain's regional economies on trade with the euro zone.
fields.body:
The government yesterday published figures showing the heavy dependence of Britain's regional economies on trade with the euro zone.

They are seen by Stephen Byers, the trade and industry secretary, as a weapon in the campaign to win over the Labour heartland areas to the euro. A referendum on the single currency is expected within 18 months if Labour wins the general election.

The figures tucked away in the regional competitiveness indicators for 1999 show that 60% of British exports went to EU member states. In the north-east the figure was 79.5%, in the north-west and Merseyside it was 68%, and Yorkshire and Humberside it was 64.8%. In Wales the figure was 72% and in Scotland 72.5%.

For London the figure was 44.9%, reflecting the degree to which the capital is no longer dependent on manufacturing. It was the first time the trade department had published such a regional breakdown.

fields.headline: Papal noise pollution?
fields.standfirst: The Vatican is in the dock over claims that electromagnetic emissions from its radio station transmitters are putting lives at risk. Philip Willan reports on highly charged court case
fields.trailText: The Vatican is in the dock over claims that electromagnetic emissions from its radio station transmitters are putting lives at risk. Philip Willan reports on highly charged court case.
fields.body:
The Vatican is so intent on saving man's immortal soul that it is prepared to turn a blind eye to the destruction of his mortal body. That, in essence, is the argument being put forward by Italian prosecutors, who this week began legal proceedings against three senior Vatican Radio officials accused of putting lives at risk through the powerful electromagnetic emissions generated by their broadcasting masts.

At the centre of the controversy is a Vatican Radio relay station at Santa Maria di Galeria, a few miles north of Rome. A forest of 58 antennae, some as tall as 300 feet, beam religious ceremonies and the spiritual messages of the Pope to the four corners of the globe.

The power required to provide a truly global service for the Jesuit-run radio is generating dangerous levels of electromagnetic pollution, the prosecutors allege.

Residents in the nearby village of Cesano can hear religious programmes coming out of their telephones, their entryphones and even their washing machines. Trains that pass in the vicinity have had to be specially screened to prevent the strong electromagnetic field from interfering with the driver's controls. And a recent health service study found children living within one and a half miles of the transmitters were six times more likely to develop leukaemia than children living in Rome.

The trial, which is the source of acute embarrassment both for the Vatican and the Italian government, opened in Rome on Monday in a highly charged atmosphere. Local residents and environmental groups were present to press their case for the removal of the transmitters or a drastic reduction in the power of the transmissions. The defendants did not attend, however.

The Vatican has argued that Italian courts have no jurisdiction over the radio and declined to pass on the court's summons to the three officials: Father Roberto Tucci, who was made a cardinal last month and who is chairman of the radio's management board; Father Pasquale Borgomeo, its director general; and Costantino Pacifici, the deputy technical director.

The 430 hectare site on which the transmitters stand enjoys extra-territorial status under the terms of a 1951 treaty between the Vatican and the Italian state, and any dispute over its operation should be resolved through bilateral negotiations, church officials insist.

The judge, Andrea Calabria, disagreed. He told the prosecutors that they had erred in issuing a summons to the defendants through diplomatic channels but established the important principle that his court did have jurisdiction, adjourning the trial until the autumn.

The case has caused sharp divisions within the Italian government, with the environment minister signing up as a civil party to the trial and the foreign ministry expressing the opinion that the Holy See was justified in invoking the extra-territorial status of the transmitter site.

Environmental groups have been more aggressive, with some calling on the European Union's environment commissioner to intervene in the dispute and others suggesting that the Vatican officials should be prosecuted for manslaughter.

The Vatican says it already respects internationally recognised safety norms and that there is no reliable scientific evidence to support claims that electromagnetic radiation constitutes a health hazard.

"We have a son with leukaemia and very high levels of electromagnetic pollution in our home," retorted Maria Angelone, a member of a residents' committee in Cesano. "It's not up to us to prove the connection of cause and effect. We want action. With these levels of electro-smog it's as though we were living in a microwave oven."

Even church groups have expressed unease at the Vatican's intransigence. "It's paradoxical that the Pope's radio, which carries his voice to all nations with the message of peace and brotherhood, should become an instrument of suffering and death," a group of Christian theologians from Milan wrote in an open letter to the Holy See.

Italy passed a new law regulating electromagnetic emissions in February, which sets a limit of six volts per square metre for inhabited areas. Residents in Cesano have complained that the eletromagnetic emissions in their homes sometimes exceed 50 volts per metre.

When the investigation began there was no legally established limit for electromagnetic pollution, so prosecutors have charged the three Vatican Radio officials with the crime of "throwing dangerous objects".

In the absence of a diplomatic solution, the trial looks set to become an image-bruising ordeal for the Vatican. Rather than being perceived as the disseminator of a high moral message, it risks being seen instead as an organisation that wantonly casts dangerous objects across international borders.

webTitle: John Bayley is irresistible to younger women ...That's if we believe the tell-all accounts in his latest book.

fields.headline: John Bayley is irresistible to younger women ...
fields.standfirst: That's if we believe the tell-all accounts in his latest book.  John Sutherland  wonders how Iris Murdoch's widower, once one of the country's most respected academic critics, transformed from superdon into superstud
fields.trailText: That's if we believe the tell-all accounts in his latest book. John Sutherland wonders how Iris Murdoch's widower, once one of the country's most respected academic critics, transformed from superdon into superstud.
fields.body:
John Bayley, in the latest of the Daily Telegraph's tell-all instalments of the life of John Bayley, aged 75 and a quarter, records being stalked in the early days of his widowhood, a couple of years ago, by a graduate student he calls Mella (not her real name. Not, for legal reasons, anyone's real name). Guessing, astutely, that the way to a man's heart is through his cork tiles, Mella opened her assault on the widower-Bayley by mopping the kitchen floor. Hardly had the echo of wet slap on tile died away, than the young lady was doing a full-starfish upstairs on the Bayley-Murdoch bed ("our bed!"). She felt "faint", the cunning little minx claimed. Did she hell.

A solicitous Bayley, ever the gentleman, went to see if his young helper was OK. Perhaps a glass of water was required, some wrist chafing, or the smelling salts that he'd left somewhere in the bedroom. He approached Mella's recumbent, supine and suspiciously splayed form "fascinated". Faintness was not, it transpired, the problem. Suddenly, "Mella sprang up, threw her arms round my neck and gave me several kisses at random". She then dragged the old geezer down on to the bed. "At least we were both fully clothed," he piously records. Then, after an ellipsis, the awful admission: "A couple of hours later, we were not." Quite how this and the humpy-rumpy that followed came about, Bayley sighs, "is still uncertain to me". He too has his faint spells, apparently. One thing was clear. He had been, as he wonderingly recalls, "manhandled by a slip of a girl". Old codger rogered, read all about it.

"Mella", as Bayley vaguely tells us, "might be in her early 30s" (although, as he ungallantly records, "her naked body was scrawny"). That means, the lady "might be" some 45 years her victim's junior. Mella, however, was no fluke. Barely had the duvet on "our bed" cooled than another of Bayley's "designing women" was hammering on his door and breezing in with a "hallo Johnny" as if she owned the place and its coy owner. Margot, too, we learn, has jumped the Bayley bones - coming to disturb his slumbers, wholly uninvited, in the middle of the night.

Why, Bayley wonders, are these women throwing themselves at him? Well he might. The photograph of the author, accompanying the extracts in the Telegraph, gives no easy answer to that vexing question. Nor, one guesses, does his shaving mirror when - exhausted by the night's exertions - Johnny drags himself to the privacy of his bathroom (one of the few places in his widower's house uninvaded, apparently, by these sex-maddened Oxonian predators). He is, though dignified and serene-looking, no oil painting. But he should surely think about donating his pheromones to science after death. There's something in them that the rest of us men would really like to get hold of. Essence de Bayley - dab a spot behind your ears and buy a baseball bat to fight the bimbos off.

The reaction of most male readers to Bayley's confessions will be: "Good on you, John"; "There's life in the old dog yet"; or, as Yeats put it (when he, too, was in his 70s), "An aged man is but a paltry thing,/A tattered coat upon a stick, unless/Soul clap its hand and sing." At the very least, Bayley seems to have got through his grieving process in record time. The Casanova therapy should clearly be available (with a lavish supply of Viagra) on the national health for bereaved male spouses. And, as Bayley fondly imagines, from the great beyond Iris (restored to sanity) looked indulgently down on his bed-sport with Mella, "smiling in the same old way". Are there no rolling pins in heaven?

Women readers, I suspect, have more mixed reactions to John's sexual confessions. Imagine the following. A distinguished critic and don develops Alzheimer's disease in his 78th year. His wife, an equally distinguished philosopher (and about the same age), tenderly nurses him during the painful years of his tragic decline. After his death, she writes a moving account of his enfeebled and demented last years, called John. It becomes a bestseller. Film rights are sold. Anthony Hopkins is contracted to play the part of the suffering John. A few months after her husband's death, a young postgraduate, called Fella (in his early, lusty 30s) attaches himself to the 75-year-old Iris. He is evidently love-stricken, and offers to clean the coal-hole. He goes upstairs on some flimsy pretext - to adjust his T-shirt, or whatever. Iris follows, innocently (the stairs, however, are difficult when you are 75). Fella is lying, naked, muscular and proudly erect on the bed. He pulls her down for a spot of the old ellipsis. All goes dark and breathless.

At what point do you stop the above narrative on the grounds of rank improbability? Few, I guess, would let it run as far as the bedroom. It's against nature for a young jock to lust after an old woman. Old women do not pull young guys. Fish do not fly.

This gender inequity is so ingrained in our culture that it seems a fact of nature. In the novel everyone's talking about, David Lodge's Thinks . . . the cocksman hero, Ralph Messenger, is in his mid-50s. His targeted victim, demure novelist Helen Reed, is in her nubile early-40s. Reverse those ages, have Helen bed Roger as easily as one might pluck a ripe plum, and would the novel flow as smoothly as it does? I think not.

So it goes throughout the ranks of literature, TV soap, and film. Hannibal Lecter is, to the eye (and in terms of the actors' real ages) 30 years older than Clarice Starling. Imagine it the other way round. Sixty-year-old agent Starling, that is, and a 30-year-old psychopathic serial killer, the two of them ending up happily ever after. Wrong, wrong, wrong. Higgins is 30 years older than Eliza Doolittle. Can one imagine a 20-year-old professor coaching a 50-year-old flower-girl through The Rain in Spain? My unfair lady? Arthur Clennam is decades older than Little Dorrit. Can you think of a single Dickens (happy) marriage in which the woman is older than the man? Is Romeo older than Juliet? Yes. Can we think it the other way round? No.

John Bayley's obituary file must be, since it began being stocked in the 1960s, the most rewritten in Fleet street. Up to his retirement in 1990 from the Warton Chair in Oxford, he was superdon - one of the most respected academic critics in the country, but little known outside his profession. In retirement - so miscalled - professor emeritus Bayley established himself as one of the country's leading journalists and reviewers. When in the late 1990s his wife's descent into terminal illness began, he was elevated to near sanctity. Best of husbands. On his wife's death, he amazed his friends with two memoirs whose candour Blake Morrison might have envied. Jilly Cooper could have enivied his sales and the film adaptation inspired by Iris. He remarried. And now, John Bayley, sexual athlete. What next? Superdon on Mars?
