webTitle: My life on Mir: Sergei Avdeyev talks to Amelia Gentleman.

fields.headline: My life on Mir
fields.standfirst:
As the Russian space station Mir hurtles towards the end of its 15-year voyage, one man will be especially sad to see it go. Sergei Avdeyev, who spent 748 days on board, talks to Amelia Gentleman

Special report: Space exploration
fields.trailText: As the Russian space station Mir hurtles towards the end of its 15-year voyage, one man will be especially sad to see it go. Sergei Avdeyev, who spent 748 days on board, talks to Amelia Gentleman.
fields.body:
After a few weeks in space a cosmonaut's body begins to rebuild itself. The effect of weightlessness means that the heart no longer needs to pump blood so powerfully upwards. The veins and arteries restructure themselves to acclimatise, the muscles of the heart break down and change shape. Sergei Avdeyev has subjected his heart to more strain than any other cosmonaut in the history of space travel. The 748 days he spent in space - over three separate trips to the Russian space station Mir between 1992 and 1999 - make him the world's most experienced cosmonaut. Sheltered inside the sealed environment of Mir's living quarters, his body has orbited the earth 11,968 times, transported some 321m miles through the cosmos.

His final mission lasted one year and two weeks, double the time he had planned for. On his return, he was brought out from the capsule on a stretcher - too weak to walk, unable to sit up in a chair without slumping forward. It was a year before his heart repaired itself and his body readjusted to gravity.

Over the past few weeks, the memory of Mir has been placing a new, more subtle burden on his heart - emotional rather than physical. As the space station's longest resident, preparations for the imminent destruction of his former home have elicited confused feelings of regret, sadness and a trace of ir ritation.

Avdeyev has been invited as a celebrity guest on a flight chartered to circle Mir's crash zone, joining scientists and rich space enthusiasts to watch fragments of the station crash in a blaze of thousands of incandescent pieces in the middle of the Pacific ocean; the precise date of the last plunge remains unclear, but if Mir keeps falling at its current speed, Russian space engineers expect its smouldering remains to hit the sea at about 120 miles an hour some time next Wednesday.

As fellow passengers gasp at the sight of what organisers promise will be the century's "most spectacular celestial event", Avdeyev will be witnessing the sophisticated technology to which he has dedicated most of his career disintegrate into smouldering wreckage.

At their home in an unusually lavish north Moscow compound built exclusively for cosmonauts, his wife, Maria, remarks that the event will feel like the funeral of an old friend. Avdeyev shies away from such an undisguised admission of sentimentality, giving a more scientific account of his anticipated emotions. "On the surface I will react to it like an engineer. I know every piece of technology has an expiry date, I know there is an end to everything," he says.

"But as a person I will be sad - sorry to lose the place where I spent more than two years of my life. A few of my belongings are still up there - we couldn't bring everything back down with us, so some of my books and work remain. I knew every corner of the vessel by heart, the place where I slept, the window I looked out of. Of course it hurts a bit."

Quietly reserved, and loyal to the space agency which continues to employ him, Avdeyev has not joined the band of fellow Mir veterans who have been campaigning against Mir's death sentence, protesting on Moscow streets that Russia is foolishly abandoning one of its last claims to superpower status.

But he believes that had the Russian government committed itself to securing the station's future several years ago and provided the necessary funds for improvements, Mir could have continued operating safely for several more years - despite having recently marked its 15th birthday, 10 more than it was designed to withstand. Instead there was confusion and bad planning, he says, worsened by money problems. The Russian space agency officials do not agree. Their position is that there was no alternative to destroying Mir because it was an increasingly dangerous liability. "We cannot continue this game of Russian roulette," the agency's head said last year as he pronounced the death sentence.

It is not a subject Avdeyev enjoys discussing. "The decision has been taken and these debates now are useless," he concludes firmly and disappears into the yard for a while to dish out some of his rocket engineer's expertise to one of his cosmonaut neighbours who has a problem with his car.

When he returns, he explains that since Mir cannot be saved he wants at least to convey his delight at having been part of the project. Dismayed at the abysmal press the station has attracted over the accident-ridden last years of its life (which earned it the nickname of Starship Lada in the west) he is keen to highlight the achievements.

In tribute to the station, he has put on the Star Trek-style turquoise space jacket that he wore on board especially for the interview, his name embroidered in Russian and English letters across the chest beneath the Russian tricolour. On his feet he wears a pair of slippers. Mir memorabilia covers the walls of the house he received in reward for his work as on-board engineer - Russian matrioshka dolls painted with the faces of cosmonaut heroes lined up next to photographs of the desert-like plains of Earth viewed from space.

Every minute of the 748 days he spent on board was mapped out according to a timetable drawn up several weeks earlier. The day began at 0800 hours, according to Moscow time, when alarm clocks on the cosmonauts' wrist watches were programmed to go off.

Avdeyev slept in a floating sleeping bag attached to the wall of one of the station's side modules. "Sleeping in a weightless environment is very comfortable once you get used to it because any position - face up or down, on your left side or on your right - feels the same. In your head you tell yourself where is up, so you can pretend to be sleeping lying down, with a pillow under your head. But the concept of what is the ceiling and what is the floor is all in the mind," he says.

The frequent reappearances of dawn and sunset were also confusing to Mir novices. The station passes through night and day 16 times in 24 hours, so in the 20 minutes it took to get up in the morning it often changed from light to dark. Their days were divided between conducting scientific experiments, exercising on a rotation of running and bicycle machines, tending to the station's needs and eating. Cosmonauts prepared their own food, carefully decanting hot water into cellophane packages of dehydrated meals chosen from the rows of plastic drawers in the store room. Even when international cosmonauts started visiting, the diet remained Russian - cabbage broth, beetroot soup, porridge and buckwheat; the meals were not good. To create a feeling of being at home, they sat at a table to eat - the food strapped to the surface, their feet hooked into rings on the floor to ground them.

With each mission more and more human paraphernalia was left on board; cosmonauts built up a library of books (from Pushkin's poetry to rocket manuals). CD collections gathered on board; Avdeyev's team liked to blast Led Zeppelin, Pink Floyd and Russian rock through the modules as they exercised. In the evening they listened to taped recordings of nature - the sea, birds and forest noises - on headphones to block out the constant blast of the engines and ventilators.

Family photographs were taped to the walls; a black and white portrait of Yuri Gagarin was hung in the central chamber alongside an icon. Miniature plastic Christmas trees were unfolded every new year. There was even a growing video collection: cosmonauts could order new films from ground control every time a cargo shipment was due. One French astronaut brought a saxophone; another crew member packed a specially designed folding electric guitar.

The highlight of every week was the two-way video link-up with relatives, but during his last and longest mission the failure of a new satellite meant Avdeyev was often unable to see his family, or they couldn't hear him. The separation from his wife and two daughters gave was the only bitter edge to his experience on board the ship. When staffing and financial problems at Moscow's Star City space headquarters meant that he was obliged to remain an extra six unplanned-for months in space from 1998 to 1999, the distance from their lives saddened him. "The Russian government changed three times while I was out at work. There was a massive financial crisis and the whole way of life at home in Russia changed. That was extremely hard. Of course we could not feel the consequences in space, but I was worried for my family," he says.

Avdeyev is too pragmatic to indulge in mourning for a piece of dead equipment. When he returns from the wake, he will continue processing scientific research from his last mission. His body continues to be scrutinised by doctors researching the consequences of space travel. So far they have detected slight damage to his vision, but his heart has returned to earthly normality.

fields.headline: Palestinians harness media power
fields.standfirst: Special report: Israel and the Middle East
fields.trailText: There was the elegantly turned out Hanan Ashrawi, in silk scarf and tailored jacket, heaving a pitchfork of earth into a three-metre trench dug by the Israeli army.
fields.body:
There was the elegantly turned out Hanan Ashrawi, in silk scarf and tailored jacket, heaving a pitchfork of earth into a three-metre trench dug by the Israeli army.

The image of the Palestinians' most prominent woman - and eloquent defender - at the frontline of the protests against Israel's siege of Bir Zeit university, near the West Bank city of Ramallah, has at last drawn world attention to nearly six months of systematic restriction on civilian movement that has destroyed the economy, and caused widespread suffering.

The trenches and earth barriers that went up around Bir Zeit at the weekend marked the first tangible display of how Ariel Sharon intends to end a Palestinian uprising, and restore a sense of security to his own people.

But as EU and American condemnation of Israel's tightened siege made evident yesterday, such drastic measures are not internationally acceptable. The criticism has so shaken the Israeli army that it has partially relaxed its siege.

The commander of Israeli forces in the West Bank, Brigadier General Benny Gantz, told reporters that the barriers went up because the army had received threats of a car bomb being plotted by two dozen Fatah militia field commanders living inside Ramallah. But a day after stationing an armoured personnel carrier at the southern entrance to an area with a population of more than 200,000, the army claimed it had foiled the attack.

Other towns in the West Bank have been penned in for months. In the old city of Hebron 40,000 Palestinians have been under almost constant curfew so that the army can protect the 200 Jewish settlers living in their midst.

Other towns - such as Nablus - are accessible only by a dirt road through the mountains, and heaps of earth and concrete barriers have blocked all entry points to some West Bank villages.

At least 10 Palestinians have died in the last six months because Israeli soldiers blocked ambulances at military checkpoints or because they were unable to reach hospitals, the director of the Palestinian medical relief committee, Mustafa Barghouti, said.

Israel terms these measures as "internal closure". For the Palestinians, Israeli restrictions are evidence that they remain under military occupation, six years after the arrival of self-rule.

As Monday's demonstration at Bir Zeit university shows, middle class and educated Palestinians who stayed away from the stone-throwing protests at the start of the intifada are beginning to mobilise against Israel's siege.

Mr Sharon knows that it is not physically possible to separate Israel from the Palestinians, and that the economy of the Jewish state does not function without cheap Palestinian labour. But such restrictions are a signal to an anxious domestic audience that the old warrior remains as tough as ever.

Europe turns up heat on Israel

The trenches and earth barriers that went up around Bir Zeit at the weekend marked the first tangible display of how Ariel Sharon intends to end a Palestinian uprising, and restore a sense of security to his own people. But as EU and American condemnation of Israel's tightened siege made evident yesterday, such drastic measures are not internationally acceptable. The criticism has so shaken the Israeli army that it has partially relaxed its siege. The commander of Israeli forces in the West Bank, Brigadier General Benny Gantz, told reporters that the barriers went up because the army had received threats of a car bomb being plotted by two dozen Fatah militia field commanders living inside Ramallah. But a day after stationing an armoured personnel carrier at the southern entrance to an area with a population of more than 200,000, the army claimed it had foiled the attack. Other towns in the West Bank have been penned in for months. In the old city of Hebron 40,000 Palestinians have been under almost constant curfew so that the army can protect the 200 Jewish settlers living in their midst. Other towns - such as Nablus - are accessible only by a dirt road through the mountains, and heaps of earth and concrete barriers have blocked all entry points to some West Bank villages. At least 10 Palestinians have died in the last six months because Israeli soldiers blocked ambulances at military checkpoints or because they were unable to reach hospitals, the director of the Palestinian medical relief committee, Mustafa Barghouti, said. Israel terms these measures as "internal closure". For the Palestinians, Israeli restrictions are evidence that they remain under military occupation, six years after the arrival of self-rule. As Monday's demonstration at Bir Zeit university shows, middle class and educated Palestinians who stayed away from the stone-throwing protests at the start of the intifada are beginning to mobilise against Israel's siege. Mr Sharon knows that it is not physically possible to separate Israel from the Palestinians, and that the economy of the Jewish state does not function without cheap Palestinian labour. But such restrictions are a signal to an anxious domestic audience that the old warrior remains as tough as ever. Europe turns up heat on Israel

webTitle: On the farm: Farming families are in need of counselling as the constant fear and worry take their toll.

fields.headline: On the farm
fields.standfirst:
Farming families are in need of counselling as the constant fear and worry take their toll

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: Farming families are in need of counselling as the constant fear and worry take their toll.
fields.body:
The silence of the land in some corners of the countryside is growing as the number of confirmed cases relentlessly increases and the slaughter goes on. In Cumbria there is a huge wasteland with no farm animals for miles and miles, and there are swathes of empty fields around Heddon-on-the-Wall and in County Durham.

We farmers always said that the countryside underpinned the nation's economy. The evidence for this is now all around us, but surely the individual price paid by farming families and associated businesses is far too high.

Our friends, the Murrays, still wait for a "clean" vet to inspect their animals, and Jane has gone back to work overnight as a nurse. During her enforced isolation from other families, she has had countless phone calls from local people - usually wives - in great distress. The constant worry and fear are causing many sleepless nights, and she believes serious long-term problems are developing: many of those in the front line desperately need counselling.

Jane and Stuart's two small children are to leave the farm under Maff licence to stay with their granny, as they cannot go back to school until the farm is cleared. Granny lives at Berwick-upon-Tweed where the walks are closed and the beach is out of bounds as sheep had been grazing on the dunes.

We continue to prepare for lambing. A large shepherd's pie has gone into the freezer and we are erecting individual pens in the lambing shed. Peter has ordered small bales of straw as our bales for the cattle are 6ft in diameter, and it is wasteful and time-consuming to use them in the small sheep pens.

Peter washed one of the tractors and is catching up on other jobs. There is no excuse at this time of the year for having nothing to do. One of the day's heaviest and more difficult tasks was rescuing the water gate from the nearby reservoir. It lost its moorings in the rapid thaw last week and drifted downstream.

After much pulling, heaving and no doubt swearing, it is back in place to prevent animals from straying along the Dryburn (which is actually very wet).

I have now spoken to Maff and am pleased to say that our occupational movement licence has been issued. We expect it in tomorrow's post. Once the licence is in our hands we can move our animals across the minor road within a strict 500m distance of the farmyard.

But we will not be allowed to drive along the minor road to the hayfield at the bottom. All our other fields situated outside the 500m area must be entered from another field. With the atrociously wet winter we have had it will be amazing if we can still travel after a few journeys, as the mud will be axle-deep by then. Half the hayfield is under water, so we are hoping that by the time we need to use it, in about four weeks, local movement might be relaxed. But that seems unlikely.

A farmer's wife has rung me from Cumbria. I have not met her before but that didn't matter. Her desperation, and that of those all around her, poured down the phone to me. It made me feel totally inadequate - and almost safe, in comparison to those living in the beautiful Eden Valley, which has been hit particularly hard.

She said the spread of misinformation from farm to farm by the modern equivalent of jungle drums - the phone - is causing panic. Some of her friends have lost their life's work. All they can speak of is the silence when the slaughter is over and the stench of the rotting carcasses waiting to be disposed of.

The anger is mounting: anger over the length of time taken to diagnose and then to dispose of the tainted animals. Compared to the outbreaks in the 60s it is taking far too long, and this is where we are all convinced the wider spread of this virus occurs. The farmers want instant action.

Still, one by one, the farms go down around what is suspected to be the original source at Burnside Farm. I was horrified to learn that a subsequently traced outbreak in County Durham ran for almost a week before any decisive action was taken. We know this has resulted in another major spread of foot and mouth, and we want it stopped now.

 The writer and her husband run a livestock farm near Heddon-on-the-Wall, Northumberland. She is writing a daily diary during the foot and mouth crisis.

webTitle: Councils warned to speed up best value measures

fields.headline: Councils warned to speed up best value measures
fields.trailText: Local authorities have been given a stern warning to pick up the pace on best value to deliver modernised town hall services.
fields.body:
Local authorities have been given a stern warning to pick up the pace on "best value" to deliver modernised town hall services.

The best value regime, which forces councils to review all their frontline and back-office services over a five-year period, is almost 12 months old. But in an assessment of progress so far, council inspectors have labelled many authorities unambitious and lacking urgency.

The assessment report, Another Step Forward, published by the audit commission's best value inspection service, makes clear that inspectors will be looking for major improvements in year two.

"Few authorities are ambitious or urgent enough in what they are seeking to achieve through best value," it says. "In many cases, best value reviews are focused on delivering incremental change or gently confirming the need to keep the status quo."

The inspection service also calls for councils to "focus on fewer, better, more strategic reviews" from April. Each council review leads to a visit from the inspectors. And in some reviews, there have been more inspectors involved than the number of staff employed in the service being scrutinised.

While this seems a poor use of inspectors' time, the commission is more concerned that small reviews will simply fail to deliver the fundamental transformation of council services that ministers have promised. Although it has stopped short of dictating which areas councils should package together in large reviews, it now says "review areas need to be a reasonable scale if they are to be capable of finding new ways to plan and deliver services".

For bigger authorities, this could mean 30-40 reviews over a five-year period, rather than 20 a year, which some councils are understood to have identified. Smaller district councils should be aiming for just four reviews a year.

In particular, the commission wants to see more "cross-cutting" reviews being tackled, covering areas such as crime, traffic and jobs. Looking at issues in a more holistic way, not confined by artificial boundaries between council departments, is seen as making much more sense to the public.

The report could force many local authorities into a rapid re-working of their review timetables. Councils are due to publish their second best-value performance plans at the end of the month, in which they will have to details plans for future reviews.

But moving to bigger reviews, and away from the culture of incremental change, will not be straightforward or guarantee improvements.

"Sometimes incremental change can be more effective than big changes," says Michael Hughes, director of research at local government research body Inlogov, based at Birmingham University. "There should still be a place for small, focused reviews, where there are particular problems or where there are clear opportunities for change."

Councils were initially delighted with the introduction of best value. Its forerunner - the compulsory competitive tendering regime, which forced councils to expose key support services to competition with the private sector - had few friends in town halls. But councils have slowly started to recognise the huge and relentless challenge of demonstrating continuous improvement under best value.

The inspection service is not immune from criticism itself. According to Hughes, some authorities that have been through inspections "question whether the inspectors know what they are doing".

Also, the commission promised 700 inspections in the first year of best value. But, to date, just 60 reports have been published.

And with general election purdah likely to be imposed shortly, this figure may not rise much more in coming weeks.

webTitle: United forced to settle for second

fields.headline: United forced to settle for second
fields.standfirst: Butt 5, Sheringham 20, Keane 87
fields.trailText: Manchester United reached the quarter-finals last night without further assistance from David Beckham, who watched from the bench as his colleagues strode past Sturm Graz with the minimum of difficulty. But with Valencia also winning, United go into Friday's draw as runners-up in their second-round group, which means they could face Real Madrid.
fields.body:
Manchester United reached the quarter-finals last night without further assistance from David Beckham, who watched from the bench as his colleagues strode past Sturm Graz with the minimum of difficulty. But with Valencia also winning, United go into Friday's draw as runners-up in their second-round group, which means they could face Real Madrid.

An early goal from Nicky Butt followed by another from Teddy Sheringham enabled United to assume an easy command which they never looked like losing, although a third did not arrive until the 87th minute, when Roy Keane's narrow-angled shot completed a slick passing movement.

In matchplay terms, Sturm began the game like a golfer two holes down and waiting for Tiger Woods to drive off the 16th tee. Any Austrian hopes of United losing their ball lay largely in dreamland.

Yet after United's poor display in Athens, when only a goal in injury-time from Paul Scholes denied Panathinaikos victory, Sir Alex Ferguson's team clearly needed to complete the business of reaching the last eight in a style more appropriate to their Champions League aspirations.

Either United's starting line-up reflected the need for a bit of graft or else Ferguson wanted his disapproval of the previous performance to be reflected in real terms. Probably it was a bit of both.

At all events Beckham, badly below form in recent matches, was left on the bench along with Andy Cole and Dwight Yorke, Ferguson preferring an attacking partnership of Sheringham and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer.

"I took a look at Beckham and thought he needed a rest," Ferguson explained. "There's been a lot of pressure on him so I decided to leave him out so he could regroup and regain his game."

With the return of Ryan Giggs after a hamstring injury delayed by flu almost the sole responsibility for giving United's movements width and guile lay with Luke Chadwick, playing in Beckham's place on the right. Equally Ferguson looked to the collective drive through the middle of Keane, Butt and Scholes to upset any Sturm ideas of frustrating United with a packed defence.

If they did, the plan went awry after a mere five minutes. Kazimierz Sidorczuk had saved superbly from Solskjaer in the opening seconds but when Butt drove a loose ball through a thicket of legs from 20 yards Sturm's Polish goalkeeper had little chance of denying United their early lead.

In attack Sturm were quick, neat and inventive and Mario Haas might have done better than shoot wide after an error by Butt. To a man, however, Ferguson's midfield worked assiduously to deny the Austrian side the space which in United's previous two games had been exploited so well by Valencia and Panathinaikos.

Butt's was the tackle which initiated United's second goal after 20 minutes. The midfielder then produced an astute pass to release Solskjaer in the inside-left position and, with Graz caught square, the Norwegian switched the ball across to Sheringham, who drove it past Sidorczuk.

This, then, was going to be one of Old Trafford's blue-collar occasions; a reminder that hard work lies at the heart of every team's success and never mind the trimmings. It was no coincidence that Butt, with his tenacity in winning possession and keen use of the ball, frequently caught the eye.

Chadwick, too, with a cross from the right, swinging away from the goalkeeper, that Beckham could hardly have bettered. Solskjaer could not quite reach it and when Chadwick sent Scholes clear 10 minutes before half-time Sidorczuk, diving low at his feet, bravely smothered the opportunity.

Another five minutes and sweet passing by Keane and Butt released Chadwick on the right with Sheringham waiting unmarked in front of goal. Chadwick's final ball, however, was poor and by the time Sheringham controlled it defenders were back to cover.

Markus Schopp remained a lively presence on the right for Sturm and once Imre Szabics joined Haas up front for the second half the Austrian team gave United's defenders marginally more work to do. After Gary Neville had fouled Gunther Neukircher a hard, low shot from Ivica Vastic produced an urgent save from Fabien Barthez, his first of the night.

By and large, however, the game remained in the grip of United's midfield, who controlled the tempo and pattern much as they wished. Chadwick's versatility was emphasised when he switched to the left and continued to gnaw at the Graz cover.

 The Group B game between Paris St-Germain and Galatasaray was delayed for 25 minutes after fighting broke out between rival fans and two visiting supporters ran on to the pitch. Five fans were taken to hospital. PSG won 2-0 at home as Galatasaray dropped to second behind Deportivo la Coruna, who drew 1-1 at Milan.

Manchester United (4-4-2): Barthez; Irwin, Stam, G Neville, Silvestre; Chadwick, Keane, Butt, Scholes (Greening, 75min); Sheringham, Solskjaer.

Sturm Graz (4-4-2): Sidorczuk; Neukircher, Ibertsberger, Fleurquin, Korsos; Schopp, Schupp (Martens, 65), Minavand (Szabics, 46), Mahlic (Hlinka, 46); Haas, Vastic.

Referee: V Ivanov (Russia).

webTitle: First Foot and Mouth case identified in France

fields.headline: First case identified in France
fields.standfirst:
New outbreaks expected after herd slaughtered

Special report: Foot and mouth disease
fields.trailText: France yesterday reported its first case of foot and mouth disease, confirming fears that it would prove all but impossible to prevent the virus first detected three weeks ago in Britain from spreading to the continent.
fields.body:
France yesterday reported its first case of foot and mouth disease, confirming fears that it would prove all but impossible to prevent the virus first detected three weeks ago in Britain from spreading to the continent.

The agriculture ministry said six French cows from a farm in the north-western Mayenne region, France's second biggest cattle farming area, had tested positive for the virus, known as la fièvre aphteuse, or blister fever. The 114-strong herd had been slaughtered and would be incinerated during the day.

The farm, outside the small village of La Baroche-Gondouin, is separated only by a narrow road from one that imported 1,750 British sheep last month and had been under strict quarantine since February 27.

The agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, said embattled French farmers - already reeling from a dramatic fall in meat consumption in the wake of a nationwide panic over BSE - should brace themselves for "a clear possibility" of further outbreaks.

"I fear there will be more cases, although at the same time I'm doing everything possible to limit the spread of the disease," he said, adding that tests showed at least half of the 20,000 British sheep imported into France since February were carrying the virus.

"But I sincerely hope that the fact that we took precautions a long way in advance, before the first case of the disease was detected .. will bear fruit and that we will be able to limit the number of cases in France," he said.

Although long seen as almost inevitable, the arrival of foot and mouth in France is nonetheless a bitter blow to the agricultural industry and to the government, which is still trying to negotiate compensation for 40,000 farmers who risk ruin following the BSE scare. Angry livestock traders took to the streets in at least three French towns yesterday to demand additional money.

Along with most other European nations, France had taken urgent measures to avoid contamination of its livestock, including ordering the destruction of all sheep imported from Britain after February 1 and of 30,000 French sheep that had come into contact with them.

The government also banned the export of all animals at risk from the disease, and halted most livestock movements. Some 20 potentially infected farms around the country have been under close veterinary surveillance and effectively in quarantine for the past fortnight. Yesterday French authorities banned all except local traffic within a two-mile radius of the affected farm in Mayenne.

Le Monde quoted a despairing farmer from La Baroche-Gondouin as saying no one now dared leave their homes. Asked who was to blame, he said: "The English, of course. They've already had mad cow disease. I really don't know what they get up to over there. Although after all, maybe they've just been unlucky."

Pending a decision from Brussels on a possible export ban of selected French produce, an agriculture ministry official said no further nationwide preventive measures were planned following the country's first confirmed outbreak of foot and mouth disease in 20 years.

"It was a miracle, given the extent of the epidemic in Britain and the number of sheep we imported from there, that France has not had any cases until now," he said. "The emergency plan put into action last month is working okay. It is at the maximum. We consider it efficient .. we're in a situation that is under control."

Italy

The health ministry yesterday ordered the destruction of 392 sheep suspected of carrying foot and mouth. The animals, imported from France in February, were seized near Pescara, on the Adriatic coast, on Monday after blood tests showed infection. Results are due this morning.

A week ago the health minister, Umberto Veronesi, banned the import of animals subject to foot and mouth. Within Italy, animals can be transported only with health ministry authorisation.

Germany

Measures introduced to prevent the disease entering from Britain, such as an animal import ban and the slaughter of animals imported before the outbreak, are being extended to France. "The situation is very, very serious," said the deputy agriculture minister, Alexander Müller.

Some politicians called for travellers to France to alter their plans. Passengers from France at airports in North Rhein Westfalia, the western state with the most suspect cases (though none confirmed), were ordered to hand over foodstuffs to customs. The state's environment ministry ordered the slaughter of all sheep that had arrived from France in the past three weeks.

Across the country vets remained on call with emergency vaccine. Heinz-Jürgen Thiel, one of the country's leading veterinary experts, stressed the dangers, describing the outbreak in France as the "first breach in the dyke".

Spain

Spain yesterday banned all movement of animals likely to contract the disease, effectively closing frontiers to livestock. The agriculture ministry announced an immediate inspection of all animals imported from France.

New measures were expected at frontier crossings with France, with vehicles and people being disinfected.

Flights from France were expected to be given the same treatment as those from Britain, with passengers barred from bringing foodstuffs and made to walk through pools of disinfectant.

Portugal

The agriculture minister, Capoulas Santos, announced a ban on the import of animals or meat from France.

The government has vigorously denied allegations by the veterinary union that it has covered up a suspected case in southern Alentejo.

The union's chairman, Joao Alvoeiro, said: "The agriculture ministry has already sent material to Italy - as Portugal does not have the means to provide answers to this problem - which will permit confirmation of this case."

The Netherlands

The government has extended the ban on the transport of sheep to cattle, pigs and goats.

"The ban will remain until the national inspection service for livestock and meat has determined how many animals susceptible to foot and mouth have recently been imported from France," a ministry statement said.

A spokeswoman said any potentially infected animals would be destroyed. More than 3,000 imported from Britain have been killed.

Already rocked by an earlier scare, Belgium imposed a blanket ban on all imports of French livestock products. "This frightens us," admitted Belgium's farm minister, Jaak Gabriels. "We have to seek a common reaction together. It affects everybody."

Borders are being closed to imports of farm products from the EU for two weeks.

fields.bodyText: France yesterday reported its first case of foot and mouth disease, confirming fears that it would prove all but impossible to prevent the virus first detected three weeks ago in Britain from spreading to the continent. The agriculture ministry said six French cows from a farm in the north-western Mayenne region, France's second biggest cattle farming area, had tested positive for the virus, known as la fièvre aphteuse, or blister fever. The 114-strong herd had been slaughtered and would be incinerated during the day. The farm, outside the small village of La Baroche-Gondouin, is separated only by a narrow road from one that imported 1,750 British sheep last month and had been under strict quarantine since February 27. The agriculture minister, Jean Glavany, said embattled French farmers - already reeling from a dramatic fall in meat consumption in the wake of a nationwide panic over BSE - should brace themselves for "a clear possibility" of further outbreaks. "I fear there will be more cases, although at the same time I'm doing everything possible to limit the spread of the disease," he said, adding that tests showed at least half of the 20,000 British sheep imported into France since February were carrying the virus. "But I sincerely hope that the fact that we took precautions a long way in advance, before the first case of the disease was detected .. will bear fruit and that we will be able to limit the number of cases in France," he said. Although long seen as almost inevitable, the arrival of foot and mouth in France is nonetheless a bitter blow to the agricultural industry and to the government, which is still trying to negotiate compensation for 40,000 farmers who risk ruin following the BSE scare. Angry livestock traders took to the streets in at least three French towns yesterday to demand additional money. Along with most other European nations, France had taken urgent measures to avoid contamination of its livestock, including ordering the destruction of all sheep imported from Britain after February 1 and of 30,000 French sheep that had come into contact with them. The government also banned the export of all animals at risk from the disease, and halted most livestock movements. Some 20 potentially infected farms around the country have been under close veterinary surveillance and effectively in quarantine for the past fortnight. Yesterday French authorities banned all except local traffic within a two-mile radius of the affected farm in Mayenne. Le Monde quoted a despairing farmer from La Baroche-Gondouin as saying no one now dared leave their homes. Asked who was to blame, he said: "The English, of course. They've already had mad cow disease. I really don't know what they get up to over there. Although after all, maybe they've just been unlucky." "It was a miracle, given the extent of the epidemic in Britain and the number of sheep we imported from there, that France has not had any cases until now," he said. "The emergency plan put into action last month is working okay. It is at the maximum. We consider it efficient .. we're in a situation that is under control." webTitle: Fulham to pay record £4m for Goma

fields.headline: Fulham to pay record £4m for Goma
fields.trailText: Fulham's search for a replacement for their injured central defender Chris Coleman is set to end today with a club- record £4m purchase of Newcastle's Alain Goma.
fields.body:
Fulham's search for a replacement for their injured central defender Chris Coleman is set to end today with a club- record £4m purchase of Newcastle's Alain Goma.

Goma, 28, is to have a medical at Craven Cottage and, provided personal terms are agreed on a 3-year contract, will make his debut for Jean Tigana's First Division leaders on Saturday at Crystal Palace. The signing takes Fulham's outlay on transfers to over £24m since Mohamed Al Fayed bought the club in 1997.

Fulham's managing director Michael Fiddy said: "Alain's signing is indicative of the ambition of the football club to achieve the chairman's vision of both Premiership and European honours in the future."

The former Paris Saint-Germain defender, capped twice by France and recently recovered from a broken hand, was signed by Ruud Gullit in July 1999 for £4.7m. He was put on the transfer list at the beginning of this season, insisting he wanted to return to France or move to London, but then established himself as a consistent performer in Bobby Robson's side.

Coleman, who has had five operations on a broken right leg, shattered ankle and damaged knee ligaments since a car crash in January, hopes to return to first-team action within a year. The 30-year-old will spend two months at a clinic in the south of France.

Referees must apply rules on shirt-pulling more strictly, Fifa insisted yesterday. It follows an increase in such offences since the introduction of a ban on tackles from behind.

Punishments for over-celebrating a goal will be fewer, with Fifa recognising "the natural and emotional joy of scoring". It said celebration would "only be considered a punishable offence if it borders on provocation or leads to time-wasting." Players removing shirts to celebrate a goal will no longer be cautioned.

Celtic's midfielder Neil Lennon, who threatened to quit international football after suffering sectarian abuse in Northern Ireland's friendly with Norway, is in the squad for the games this month with the Czech Republic and Bulgaria.

N Ireland squad (v Czech Republic, Windsor Park, March 24 and Bulgaria, Sofia, March 28): Carroll (Wigan), Taylor (Fulham); Hughes (Newcastle), Taggart (Leicester), Griffin (Dundee Utd), Murdock (Preston), Williams (Wimbledon), Nolan (Bradford), Kennedy (Watford), Elliott (Motherwell), Lennon (Celtic), Magilton (Ipswich), Jeff Whitley (Man City), McCarthy (Birmingham), Johnson (Blackburn), Healy (Preston), Kirk (Hearts), Gray (Oxford), Ferguson (Linfield), Coote (Norwich).

Rep of Ire squad (v Cyprus, Nicosia, March 24 and Andorra, Barcelona, March 28): A Kelly (Blackburn), Given (Newcastle), Kiely (Charlton), G Kelly (Leeds), Staunton (Aston Villa), Harte (Leeds), Breen (Coventry), Dunne (Man City), Cunningham (Wimbledon), Doherty (Tottenham), Roy Keane (Man Utd), Kinsella (Charlton), Carsley (Coventry), McAteer (Blackburn), Holland (Ipswich), Kilbane (Sunderland), Finnan (Fulham), Delap (Derby), Duff (Blackburn), Quinn (Sunderland), Robbie Keane (Leeds), Connolly (Feyenoord).

webTitle: The perfectly proper path to a passport

fields.headline: The perfectly proper path to a passport
fields.trailText: March 14, Francis Wheen: How to get your passport application in the Whitehall fast lane.
fields.body:
An urgent "product recall" announcement appears in the latest issue of Private Eye. "Millions of complaints have been received regarding the constituent parts of Britain - none of which appears to work. Furthermore, some of them are extremely dangerous and can cause serious injury. The manufacturers regret that Britain no longer conforms to acceptable safety standards and have therefore decided to withdraw the product from the market."

At a time when half the British population is swabbing down its gumboots with disinfectant and the other half is trapped in trains that go nowhere, it might indeed seem the slogan of UK plc should be Disasters R Us. All the more reason, then, to celebrate the one component of the British state that continues to operate smoothly amid the chaos.

In Sir Anthony Hammond 's report on the Hinduja affair, there are only two moments when the reader fears that Whitehall's famous Rolls-Royce engine may need some fine-tuning. The first occurs when Peter Mandelson explains why he was unlikely to have rung Mike O'Brien, the immigration minister at the Home Office. "Mr Mandelson . . . told me that he did not have a ministerial telephone directory in his office, so would not have known how to contact Mr O'Brien." Fear not, however: there's a back-up system. As Sir Anthony notes: "Mr Mandelson could have used the No 10 Downing Street switchboard which would have connected him to Mr O'Brien's office."

The other tiny malfunction is the failure of Andrew Walmsley, head of the immigration and nationality directorate, to write a formal report on his decision to speed up and then grant SP Hinduja's application for citizenship. Though this was contrary to "good practice", managers in the directorate said "Mr Walmsley was an expert on nationality policy and tended to keep a lot of the reasons for his decision-making in his head. As such, they suggested, the lack of minuting did not suggest that Mr Walmsley was being evasive or trying to hide the reasons for his decisions."

Although requests for citizenship would normally be handled by more junior officials, Walmsley chose to deal with the "high-profile" case of SP Hinduja himself. Hammond finds this a plausible reason for the astonishing speed with which Hinduja was waved through. As a senior civil servant, "Mr Walmsley did not have the same volume of casework to deal with and Mr SP Hinduja's application did not need to join the queue of cases waiting to be processed . . . In line with his general philosophy, Mr Walmsley had wanted to be helpful."

Hinduja didn't even have to bother with fresh paperwork: he merely dug out an old application form he had first submitted (unsuccessfully) under the Tory government. When Hammond queried this departure from normal procedure, Walmsley replied that it "should be seen in the context of the nationality directorate wanting to offer applicants a swift and helpful service, saving them the effort of having to fill in a new form."

Less exalted immigrants who have had dealings with the Home Office may be surprised to learn it, but "helpfulness" is the department's motto. And the home secretary leads by example, as he proved last May when Peter Mandelson forwarded a letter from GP Hinduja asking if yet another brother, Prakash, could have a British passport, even though he lived in Switzerland. Jack Straw scribbled a note to his private secretary: "Mara - Mr Mandelson raised this matter with me. Please have a word first then get some advice. ? Zola Budd." Straw told Hammond he "could not recall" why he mentioned the South African athlete. Suspicious observers might guess he was trying to be very helpful indeed by citing a previous case in which someone who did not meet the residency requirements had been given British citizenship. Fortunately, Sir Anthony is not a suspicious observer: "I do not regard this as significant."

What of the letter Straw's private secretary then sent to Andrew Walmsley, asking him to look at Prakash Hinduja's request "as soon as possible", and the subsequent phone call in which she revealed that "the Home Secretary would like the case to be dealt with 'helpfully' "? Straw informed Hammond that "in his view, the word 'helpfully' meant he wanted the matter dealt with properly, as was his approach to all cases". Sir Anthony agrees: "I am satisfied that the use of the word 'helpfully' did not have any suspicious connotations, nor did it suggest that the home secretary wished to give Mr Prakash Hinduja any preferential treatment."

From which we can only conclude that all applicants receive the same Rolls-Royce service, complete with a uniformed chauffeur. The former immigration minister Mike O'Brien confirmed as much, telling Hammond that in 1999, when SP Hinduja's naturalisation was approved, he was encouraging immigration officials to take "a more positive attitude" to citizenship applications. Can this be the Mike O'Brien who pushed through the draconian immigration and asylum bill that year? The minister who cocked up the introduction of a new computer system in the immigration and nationality department, creating a backlog of 80,000 cases and misery galore?

Presumably not, since Sir Anthony neglects to mention it. The phrase "I am satisfied" is repeated no fewer than 18 times in his report: he believes that everyone has behaved "perfectly properly". Who could fail to be inspired by such excellence? If we all try a little bit harder to imitate the Whitehall elite, poor old Britain may yet be saved from the scrapheap.

fields.headline: BBCNOW/ Hickox
fields.standfirst: Barbican, London/Radio 3  ***
fields.trailText: Barbican, London/Radio 3 ***
fields.body:
The BBC National Orchestra of Wales and the City of London Sinfonia share Richard Hickox as principal conductor, and the two orchestras are also sharing a short Britten and Shostakovich series at the Barbican over the next two months. For the Welsh orchestra it is a rare opportunity for London exposure outside of its annual tour of duty at the Proms. In its opening programme on Tuesday there was far more Britten than Shostakovich - a group of pieces from the 1930s and early 1940s, most of them composed while Britten was living in the US, combined with the Russian's suite from Katerina Ismailova, the politically corrected version of his opera Lady Macbeth of Mtsensk.

Early Britten is fascinating stuff, full of influences and models being examined and either assimilated or rejected, as he gradually brought together the elements of his personal language. In the Piano Concerto, the flavours come from Prokofiev (his piano concertos and ballets) and Ravel (the Concerto for Left Hand and La Valse); in the wracked Sinfonia da Requiem it is the Austro-German tradition of Mahler and, especially, of Berg. Those are well-known, if somewhat underplayed pieces, but Hickox also conducted two rarities.

The curious brass processional Russian Funeral, combining a Mahlerian-style death march with a Soviet revolutionary song, pre-dates Britten's American sojourn; it was written for a concert by the London Labour Choral Union in 1936. The American Overture was composed in New York in 1941, then lost; when it was rediscovered (in New York Public Library) Britten claimed to have no memory of it, perhaps because he had recycled some of the procedures (the work briskly puts each section of the orchestra through its paces) and even some of the material for the Young Person's Guide to the Orchestra five years later.

Hickox and the BBCNOW delivered all these pieces and the Shostakovich suite of entr'actes with gutsy directness; what the performances occasionally lacked in finesse they more than made up for in rhythmic vigour and punch. Barry Douglas was the first-rate soloist in the concerto; though he was occasionally overwhelmed by the orchestra (it is a rather clamorous piece), he handled all the bravura and tricky gear changes with cool, unfussy efficiency.

webTitle: New FSA rules to benefit endowment holders

fields.headline: New FSA rules to benefit endowment holders
fields.standfirst: Guardian Unlimited Money
fields.trailText: New guidelines aimed at giving a better deal to the thousands of people who cash in their endowment policies early every year are being drawn up by the financial services authority, it was revealed yesterday.
fields.body:
New guidelines aimed at giving a better deal to the thousands of people who cash in their endowment policies early every year are being drawn up by the financial services authority, it was revealed yesterday.

The guidance, which will be issued to life insurers within weeks, could lead to some policyholders receiving thousands of pounds more. It will ensure they are told about the alternatives to surrendering their endowments - which include selling them on to other investors, an option many people are not aware of.

Each year about 60,000 people surrender their endowment back to the life insurer when they could have sold it for an average of 10%-15% more. Among them, these people are missing out on almost £80m a year, or around £1,250 on a typical £10,000 policy, said the Association of Policy Market Makers, the trade body representing firms dealing in second-hand endowments.

Campaigners, who have been calling for changes to the rules for more than two years, welcomed the news that the FSA would urge life insurers to inform policyholders of the alternatives to surrendering a policy.

Several companies including Norwich Union and Friends Provident already notify people about other options such as selling to a second-hand endowment policy specialist, which then resells policies. But some insurers make no mention of this when customers say they are going to cash in their endowment.

The guidance, which will be issued to life insurers within weeks, could lead to some policyholders receiving thousands of pounds more. It will ensure they are told about the alternatives to surrendering their endowments - which include selling them on to other investors, an option many people are not aware of. Each year about 60,000 people surrender their endowment back to the life insurer when they could have sold it for an average of 10%-15% more. Among them, these people are missing out on almost £80m a year, or around £1,250 on a typical £10,000 policy, said the Association of Policy Market Makers, the trade body representing firms dealing in second-hand endowments. Campaigners, who have been calling for changes to the rules for more than two years, welcomed the news that the FSA would urge life insurers to inform policyholders of the alternatives to surrendering a policy. Several companies including Norwich Union and Friends Provident already notify people about other options such as selling to a second-hand endowment policy specialist, which then resells policies. But some insurers make no mention of this when customers say they are going to cash in their endowment.

fields.headline: Deliverance
fields.standfirst:
Leeds Metropolitan Studio Gallery
Rating: **
fields.trailText:
Leeds Metropolitan Studio Gallery
Rating: **
fields.body:
More a group hug than a group show, this mawkish male-bonding exercise takes its cue from the early 1970s Burt Reynolds vehicle of the same name, where a quartet of butch Atlanta businessmen achieve a testosterone high by canoeing through the most godforsaken backwaters of the Appalachian mountains.

John Boorman's film is a bitter cocktail of machismo, mutilation and revolting backwoods encounters with the products of a steadily diminishing gene pool. As a starting point for four male artists primarily interested in their own masculinity, this has plenty of potential. Who will fulfil the role of the sensitive, guitar-strumming Drew (Ronny Cox in the film) for example? And, more to the point, who wants to be Burt?

Sadly, the movie seems to have done no more than divert the show up Concept Creek without a paddle. Most of the darker undercurrents of the film are avoided, and its impressive ecological message is entirely ignored. Though there are witty and worthwhile individual contributions, there seems little to link the artists besides their all being men; this turns out to be no more illuminating than suggesting that none of them are zebras.

Andrew McDonald takes top honours with his intimidating animation, The Return of John. Confronted with the provocations of an alarmingly headless aggressor, you begin to understand Sir Gawain's predicament with the Green Knight. If you wouldn't hit a man wearing glasses, what are you going to do about a man with nowhere to put them?

Paul Stone's piece, Stay, is reminiscent of Kander and Ebb's image of transparent male insecurity from the musical Chicago, Mister Cellophane; only in this case it's Mister Polythene Bag. At this time of year a disquieting mannequin roughly manufactured from high street carriers can pass as thought-provoking art. Any closer to November 5 and you'd toss it a coin to let the irritating kids who made it buy fireworks.

Pat Flynn's sculptural conceit of bringing the pixilated approximations of computer games to life proves that what we accept as an asteroid on a VDU screen could equally well signify the deposits of a huge cyber-elephant. Yuen Fong Ling's installation indicative of men at work - a pair of seminar flip-charts disgorging reams of unfilled paper - eloquently illustrates the arguments linking the movie and artistic responses together. A nice idea on paper, but ultimately Deliverance fails to deliver.

Until March 31. Details: 0113-283 3130.

fields.headline: Rimsky-Korsakov's striking Snowmaiden
fields.standfirst:
The Snowmaiden
Guildhall School, London
Rating: *****
fields.trailText:
The Snowmaiden
Guildhall School, London
Rating: *****
fields.body:
The centenary of Rimsky- Korsakov's death falls in 2008, so there is still time for British companies to plan some kind of celebration, finally recognising his stature as one of the great opera composers. What British companies and their audiences are missing is now being triumphantly demonstrated by the Guildhall School, whose enterprise continues to put its professional counterparts to shame. Its production of The Snowmaiden is an unqualified delight and makes an unarguable case for the viability of Rimsky's works on stage.

Rimsky completed The Snowmaiden, or Snegurochka to give it its original Russian title, in 1882, taking his libretto from a play by Ostrovsky. He always thought it his best opera. Snegurochka is the child of Beautiful Spring and Father Frost, a teenage girl who yearns to escape from the dark forest and live among humans; when she does so she meets two men, one rich one poor, who vie for her affections, but because her heart is made of ice she cannot fall in love. Eventually she persuades her mother to teach her how to love, but when she agrees to marry one of her suitors, a ray of sunlight melts her heart.

It doesn't take a great deal of Freudian insight to see the work as an adolescent rite of passage, but typically for Rimsky it is a rite of spring too - Snegurochka's death appeases the sun god, so that warmth and prosperity can return to the land at the end of the opera, celebrated in an extraordinary final chorus.

That is just one of the striking features in the score, whose treasure trove of melodies quarried from folk music seems inexhaustible, and which acts as a conduit for the whole of Russian musical history from Glinka, Borodin and Mussorgsky, and anticipating Stravinsky too. Stephen Medcalf's production perfectly teases out all the strands in this canvas of Russian life, managing the great chorus and dance scenes in the limited space of the Guildhall stage with great ingenuity.

The singing is never less than very decent, and often a good deal more. Natasha Jouhl was Snegurochka at Monday's performance, with Andrew Rees a sturdy toned Tsar Berendei (both roles are double cast); Estelle Kaique is a sumptuous sounding Spring, and Alenka Ponjavic very impressive in the trousers role of the shepherd Lyel. All get every word of Clive Timms's English translation across, and in the pit Timms also encourages the Guildhall orchestra to bring every colour of Rimsky's glittering score to life.

Further performances tonight and Friday. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

fields.headline: Midori
fields.standfirst:
Barbican, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Barbican, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Midori is a tiny violinist with a big sound to get across. This programme of familiar and lesser-known sonatas found her playing to be typically physical and generous in its intent. Yet in some ways her physicality can limit her - the more energy she devotes to projecting her sound, the less effect her exertions have.

The programme opened with the first movement of Bach's Sonata No 4, which was played with a quiet intensity by Midori, whose long phrases, artfully ornamented, hung suspended as Robert McDonald's seamless accompaniment unfurled around them. It was the first and third movements, both of them slow, restrained and aria-like, that showed her playing at its best, while McDonald came into his own in the complex imitative exchanges of the second. For the final allegro movement the familiar Midori returned, swaying forward and backward, braced against her violin, hair flying. Yet for all her efforts her lines failed to sing out as before, and her playing sounded tense and constrained.

Beethoven's Sonata No 10 in G opened in an atmosphere of warm serenity. In the second movement in particular we had another chance to admire the control with which Midori can play quietly - it takes nerve for a string player to sustain such soft, smooth notes for so long without allowing a ripple of disturbance. However, louder passages of the scherzo and finale found her tone treading the fine line between fullness and harshness - all too often coming down on the wrong side.

Midori's and McDonald's aptitude for seamless, expansive phrasing came to the fore in the rarity of the evening, the Sonata in B minor by Respighi, a composer remembered largely for a handful of orchestral works. The first two movements had a rhapsodic quality to them; although the first peaked too soon, the second showed Respighi's lyricism burgeoning. The third, an involved set of variations, though taxing on both players, was persuasively performed.

Preceding the Respighi, an arrangement of Schubert's Valse-Caprice No 6 showed Midori bringing her technical precision to a lighter piece. Her performance was certainly adept, yet sober and well-behaved. The seriousness and energy with which she throws herself into her playing sometimes leaves the impression that she is fighting against her instrument. She really doesn't need to try quite so hard.

fields.headline: Children of working mothers 'at risk'
fields.standfirst:
Guardian Unlimited Education
Guardian Unlimited Work
fields.trailText: Children of mothers who worked full time during most of the pre-school years do less well at A-level and are more at risk of unemployment and psychological stress, according to controversial research published today by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.
fields.body:
Children of mothers who worked full time during most of the pre-school years do less well at A-level and are more at risk of unemployment and psychological stress, according to controversial research published today by the Joseph Rowntree Foundation.

Academics at Essex University followed the fortunes of 1,263 young people born in the 1970s to investigate links between the parents' patterns of work and the children's subsequent wellbeing.

They found there was a trade-off for mothers spending less time with children under five because of full-time work commitments. The advantages of raising family income were offset by the risks of reducing their children's long-term attainment at school.

The study, by John Ermisch and Marco Francesconi of the university's institute for social and economic research, did not identify such clear disadvantages if fathers worked full time or mothers worked part time.

Professor Ermisch, an academic whose previous work included explosion of the myth that young women became pregnant to jump the housing queue, said the findings supported the need for progressive employment policies. "Entitling parents to more time with young children can be justified as a potential investment in the labour force of tomorrow," he said.

Unlike previous research, the Essex project looked at pairs of brothers and sisters whose only detectable difference was the amount of time spent by their parents at work.

Children of mothers who worked full time for about 18 months during the pre-school years had a 64% chance of passing an A-level. The odds fell to 52% if the mother worked full time for an additional year.

Longer periods of full-time working increased the probability of unemployment when the child reached adulthood from 7% to 9%. The chances of psychological stress also rose from 23% to 28%. But the probability of daughters giving birth before their 21st birthday reduced from 3% to 1%.

If mothers worked part time for long periods, their children were 6% less likely to get an A-level but they were 2% less likely to suffer mental problems later in life.

Since most fathers of children born in the 1970s were in full-time work during most of their children's upbringing, it was harder to measure the consequences. But if fathers spent longer at work when their children were very young, it was likely to lead to a 6% reduction in the A-level pass rate. The children of those fathers were less likely to be unemployed or suffer psychological stress.

Prof Ermisch said: "The young people in our study were pre-schoolers more than 20 years ago when working parents may have had fewer options in terms of alternative childcare.

"Even so, the implication of our findings is that if parents have less time to spend with young children before they start school, there may be long term consequences.

Mary MacLeod, chief executive of the National Family and Parenting Institute, said: "This is a comprehensive study that reinforces the need for parents of young children to have as much choice and flexibility as possible in balancing work and parenthood."

The government should build on last week's budget announcement of two weeks' paid paternity leave for fathers and increased maternity pay.

"We need to be cautious about making cast iron judgments on working mothers from one study ... For many mothers full-time work is a necessity, not a lifestyle choice. I hope this research won't be used as another stick to beat them," said Ms MacLeod.

Sue Monk, chief executive of the campaigning group Parents at Work, said the Essex study did not look at the quality of childcare provided when parents were at work. American research showed that good childcare improved children's later academic performance.

David Willetts, the shadow social security secretary, said the study showed the government was wrong to bias the tax and benefits system in favour of two-earner couples and institutionalised childcare. "Parents with young children should be free to choose whether and when they return to work," he said.

Research yields conflicting advice

Today's report from Essex University may perplex mothers who were reassured by previous studies:

 In 1999 Elizabeth Harvey of the University of Connecticut found no long-term difference between children whose mothers worked full time in their first three years and those whose mothers did not. Early differences in obedience and academic achievement did not persist.

 A Canadian study in 1998 found the money earned by working mothers was good for children because it improved living standards.

 Last year Heather Joshi and Georgia Verropoulou of London University's institute of education found a slight risk children read less well if mothers worked while they were under five - and were 10% less likely to do A-levels. But poverty, family history and mother's education were bigger influences.

 Research last year by Bristol University found half of mothers returning full time switched to part time within two years, and 19% gave up work completely.

 Preliminary findings from Kent University show only 60% of mothers intending to return full time did so by the time babies were six months; the trend was to do less work than intended.

webTitle: MPs say tardy banks should be fined

fields.headline: MPs say tardy banks should be fined
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday lambasted retail banks for being "disappointingly slow" in moving customers' accounts and recommended fines for particularly tardy cases.
fields.body:
MPs yesterday lambasted retail banks for being "disappointingly slow" in moving customers' accounts and recommended fines for particularly tardy cases.

The report by the Treasury select committee also called for tougher action on banks that leave customers in old savings accounts that pay lower rates than newer ones. They said charges for withdrawals from cash machines, abandoned this year, should not be reintroduced.

As the committee's report was released it emerged that the banks would be pitched against consumers in unprecedented public hearings when the compe tition commission holds hearings on March 30 about Lloyds TSB's £19bn takeover of Abbey National.

The committee report was critical of attempts by the government to set up banking facilities in post offices.

The MPs said the banking code, currently voluntary, should require banks to swap information about customers' direct debits faster than the current deadline of 10 days.

fields.headline: Dub'l-inTROODer
fields.standfirst:
Transmission Gallery, Glasgow
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Transmission Gallery, Glasgow
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Teamwork disrupts all our expectations of the artist. They shatter the concept of the lone genius, starving in a garret. Yet in visual art some affecting and dramatic work has been produced by the likes of Christo and Jeanne-Claude, and Scottish artists Dalziel and Scullion.

In Transmission Gallery's manic tribute to duality and plurality, John Beagles and Graham Ramsay's miniature industrial unit dominates the proceedings. Orderly from the outside, inside it is a deviant house of fun, crammed full of demented wind-up toys, newspaper cuttings, two dummies of drone workers and a severed hand with a fried egg.

This chaos is nothing compared to the Ecole de Burrows et Bob Smith, a dysfunctional educational institution sprawling across the gallery floor and walls, where the teachers' registers feature memory prompts such as "quite handsome" and "no talent whatsoever". A mattress, rivalling Emin's bed in its messiness, is where the opening night Lennon/Ono Bed-In featuring Joseph Beuys and his Coyote took place. It didn't, of course, but the notion is another wry dig at institutional practice and history, especially where art is concerned, from David Burrows, and Bob and Roberta Smith.

Bank have been working collaboratively for almost a decade; here they show apocalyptic paintings - think Soviet propaganda posters meets Berlin wall graffiti. Lighter and slicker is the work of Austrian duo Markus Muntean and Adi Rosenblum, photographs of young people in a mocked up fast-food outlet.

Where the light hits their faces, they have smudges of grease. They somehow still look cool. There is nothing cool about Heidi, Paul McCarthy and Mike Kelley's hilariously dark take on family values. Excessive, almost unwatchable, the film makes Mike Leigh's work look sunny. Sequences focus on family members such as Tim. A dummy is used to represent him on the toilet: the whole family are helping him pass larger and larger items into a bowl. A sausage, and then a salami, accompanied by a thin, brown dribble, are enthusiastically greeted by a team of helpers.

Helping Tim is the less glamorous end of collaborative work, maybe, but like everyone in this show, his family seem to be enjoying themselves mightily.

Until March 31. Details: 0141-552 4813.

fields.headline: Agnes Martin
fields.standfirst:
Anthony d'Offay Gallery, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText:
Anthony d'Offay Gallery, London
Rating: ****
fields.body:
Agnes Martin is a pilgrim, with her eyes wide open to the desert vistas, to the sky, to the sun. Since 1967, this Canadian-born 89-year-old painter has lived in seclusion in New Mexico. Like Georgia O'Keeffe before her, she has found calm and some deep sense of beauty there. It radiates from her paintings in a way that is at first hard to assimilate amid the noise and rain of London's Oxford Street.

Here are paintings that disdain pomp and theatre. Square canvases, mapped out in horizontal bands of pale colour: salmon pink, lemon yellow, eggshell blue, pretty colours alternating with strips of white, for all the world like designs on a beach umbrella in a turn-of-the-century coastal resort. Rather than the desert, these paintings made me think at first of Monet, or the Gilded Age charm of an Edith Wharton novel.

Then you move in close, and the power of Agnes Martin hits you. Martin is an artist not of colour, but of texture. She made her name in New York in the early 1960s with paintings whose muted monochrome appearance was enriched by a passionate graphite labour as she pencilled straight-ruled, but haphazardly and humanly executed, grids across the surface. The same happens here. Seen close to, the bands of colour are bounded by pencilled lines that wobble, jerk, but finally reach their goal on the other side of the canvas. There's something vulnerable about it, and this is true of the paint too, as you realise it is anything but a smooth expanse of colour. It is uneven, at one point opaque, at another like cotton wool, and the canvas's grain ruffles the plane of colour.

This is Martin's originality, to look into the same grand empty space as the American abstract expressionist painters before her, those macho prophets, but to record her vision in an altogether more practical way. Her paintings insist on the material fact of painting - the paint caught in the weft of the canvas divided by those carefully pencilled lines. Martin's art seems to go to the heart of American history. She is both the pilgrim and the frontierswoman, and her attraction to the big empty spaces is paid for with a religious sense of responsibility to craft. Martin's paintings have the simplicity of a Shaker chair, and their discipline and calm make you envy the artist, out there in the light and space of the west, as you emerge again onto Oxford Street.

Until April 6. Details: 020-7499 4100.

fields.headline: The Servant
fields.standfirst:
Lyric Hammersmith, London
Rating: ***
fields.trailText:
Lyric Hammersmith, London
Rating: ***
fields.body:
Why revive The Servant? Because, I suppose, it appeals to our fascination with power, possession and destruction. But watching Neil Bartlett's svelte adaptation of Robin Maugham's play and novella, I can't help feeling that much of the juice has been drained from the myth and that the famous 1963 Pinter-Losey film remains the definitive version.

Like Pinter, Bartlett sets the action in the early 1960s and the transposition proves crucial. Maugham's original 1948 novella shows a rich toff destroyed by a diabolical prole and is, among other things, a fable about the dangers of postwar socialism. Set it in the 1960s, however, and the focus shifts towards the moral collapse of an effete upper class. The master, Tony, rejects his fiancee, Sally, in favour of his servant, Barrett, precisely because the latter insulates him from the outside world and provides "warmth, comfort and food". As this new version makes crystal clear, Barrett also supplies the juvenile rough trade that his master desperately craves: first in the shape of the under-age Vera and then in the form of a male tart called Mabel.

I wouldn't deny the story has a lurid interest, but the myth is now beginning to look a shade threadbare. For a start, Tony himself doesn't fall from a very great height. Faust has his appetites and Dorian Gray his beauty, but Tony is simply a pampered wimp who allows himself to drift into Barrett's clutches through moral inertia. And, although Bartlett's version highlights Tony's sexual ambivalence, it neither lends the action a plausible economic context (is Tony's private income inexhaustible?) nor rids it entirely of melodrama.

The image of Barrett gloating on the stairs is uncomfortably close to Maugham's Grand Guignol vision of the servant as a slimy reptile whose body "was green and horrible in the moonlight".

What one can still enjoy is the acting and Bartlett's own directorial grace notes. Jack Davenport makes a virtue of Tony's absence of character, suggesting an emotionally arrested public schoolboy who will let the world go hang as long as he gets his daily supply of muffins and tarts.

Despite the melodramatic overtones, Michael Feast also turns Barrett into a slippery chameleon and shrewd analyst of upper- class weakness. There's a key moment, in his second coming, when he fractionally pauses before handing Tony a whisky tumbler as if he knows his master is once more his plaything. And Emma Amos as Tony's spurned fiancee and Zoe Telford as Barrett's piece of jailbait both suggest a deep class antagonism. It's a briskly entertaining production well designed by Rae Smith. But where Bartlett's earlier revivals of Rattigan and Somerset Maugham have yielded rare riches, here you feel a familiar tale of old Chelsea is simply being retold with added sexual spice.

Until April 21. Box office: 020-8741 2311.
